The letters in this volume cover the twelve-month span from July 1866 to June 1867 and include 138 of Thomas Carlyle’s letters, plus his notes, 26 February 1867, to photographs of Menton, and his bequest of Craigenputtoch to Edinburgh University (both draft and final forms). In April 1866 TC began an elegiac memoir of Jane Welsh Carlyle in the hope that this process of reconstructing his past might somehow redeem his sorrowful present. Having completed this work at the end of July, he then wrote memoirs of Edward Irving, Francis Jeffrey, Robert Southey, and William Wordsworth, finishing the last one in Menton 8 March 1867. What distinguished the Reminiscences (1881) from the outset was TC’s unflinching honesty, which defied conventional expectations and as Kenneth J. Fielding and Ian Campbell argued, “broke through much more forcibly into authenticity in experience and style” (Carlyle, Reminiscences xiii). Throughout this period TC was torn between doubt and anger, and his correspondence reflected this deep inward conflict. On the one hand he was nagged by the fear that he was cloistering himself in the sanctum of his pain and indulging in what Matthew Arnold called “the dialogue of the mind with itself.”1. “Preface to Poems 1853,” Matthew Arnold, Complete Prose Works, ed. R. H. Super (1960) 1:1. On the other, he was driven by a desire to justify himself and JWC as writers who had bravely refused to be courted by the “Plebs of Literature” or to be swayed by the temptations of popularity and fame. Wavering between reclusiveness and social engagement, TC struggled to resist being consumed by his grief. Reluctantly, he strove to vacate his “religious city of refuge” and to heed the exhortation that JWC conveyed through his dreams to “work a little longer, if thou still canst” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 395, 198, 150).

This acute tension in TC’s outlook was evident in the concluding remarks that he appended to his memorial of JWC on 28 July 1866. Noting the coincidence of completing the draft on the same day that arrangements for her gravestone in Haddington church had been finalized, he upbraided himself for his idle and pointless recollections: “In these very minutes … the Tomb is now complete, and as it should be. Once I hope to see it again; and then (possibly) my native Scotland never more.— Everything admonishes me to end here my poor scrawlings and weak reminiscences of days that are no more. I still mainly mean to burn this Book before my own departure; but feel that I
shall always have a kind of grudge to do it, and an indolent excuse, ‘Not yet; wait, any day that can be done!’—and that it is possible the thing may be left behind me, legible to interested survivors,—friends only, I will hope.” “Poor” as these “scrawlings” were, they served as a symbol of the emotional and intellectual solidarity between him and JWC. No one else, not even close “friends,” could ever fathom the depth of their bond. In a defiant mood, he expressly forbade “each and all, to publish this Bit of Writing as it stands here; and warn … that without fit editing no part of it should be printed … and that the ‘fit editing’ of perhaps nine-tenths of it will, after I am gone, have become impossible” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 198–99). Trapped between the need to communicate and the desire to protect his sacred shrine, TC delayed the destruction of the manuscript.

He accepted that this act of “devotion” to JWC was benefiting him emotionally. On 8 August he told Lady Louisa Ashburton that it “[h]as done me a great deal of good in searching thro’ the Affairs of the Past. I have been at that, day after day, all summer; at all hours, in a sacred, sad quasi-religious kind of company with Her who has left me forever: this has been the far best solace I have had; and with it, in genl , I have preferred to be left alone when permitted.” He questioned whether “any work yet remains to me,” and surmised that “the ansr is still evidtly a goodish way off.” On 27 October, he informed Thomas Erskine, “I have been and am very sad, sad as death I may well say; but not miserable either; nothing of the mean wretchedness which has defaced other long portions of my life. This is all noble, tender, solemn to me. I might define it as a time of divine worship rather, perhaps the only period of real worship I have known for a great while past.” In other moments, he felt devastated by his irrevocable separation from JWC. To his brother Alexander living in Canada, he confessed that “her loss has been the loss of all that made life valuable; and I do not seem to gather much insensibility to it; but at all hours of the day, and every turn of my procedures in the world, am painfully reminded that she, my bright fellow-pilgrim, has gone from me beyond the stars, and that the rest of my journey must be done wearily alone” (TC to AC, 20 Oct. 1866 ).

Yet in “natural supernatural” ways, TC was emotionally and intellectually closer to JWC than he had been for the last two decades of her life. The moral “beggary” (TC to Lady A, 8 Aug. 1866 ) of England in 1866 reminded him vividly of 1848 and the “time preceding [Latter-Day Pamphlets],” when “my heart was long overloaded with the meanings at length uttered there, and no way of getting them set forth would answer.” Then it was JWC who had helped him to get “delivered of my black electricities and consuming fires.” She “went along with me in everything … and minded no whit any results that might follow this evident speaking of the truth” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 149). It was JWC’s lambent spiritual presence that encouraged TC to “fix his
thoughts” on the present “Condition of England.” He was engaging in his own version of Irving’s “speaking with tongues,” listening for the sound of her distinctive voice while silently contemplating the details of her former existence. In TC’s mind she had resumed her role as his “complete Approver” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 149). From the grave, he could hear her exhorting him to attack the vices of the age with reckless “veracity.”

JWC’s influence was especially evident in TC’s continued involvement in the Governor Eyre controversy. While he was in Edinburgh in April 1866, TC had savored her report of a heated exchange that she had conducted with Abraham Hayward, the translator and author, who had condemned Eyre’s use of excessive force in an article in Fraser’s. To Hayward’s declaration that “no man living could stand up for Eyre now,” she retorted, “I hope Mr Carlyle does. … I haven’t had an opportunity of asking him, but I should be surprised and grieved if I found him sentimentalizing over a pack of black brutes” ( 10 April 1866;see 43:176-77JWC to TC, [10 April 1866]). D. A. Wilson speculated that the episode “may have been prophetic, or may have inspired Carlyle to take … the line he adopted” (Wilson, Carlyle 6:62). In the aftermath of JWC’s death, TC took to defending Eyre in a romantic idiom that would have appealed deeply to the self-proclaimed descendant of William Wallace and John Knox. He informed Lady Ashburton on 7 September, “You never heard such a shriekery and psalmody of curses as is going on round the humane modest heroic Eyre (all this I have construed him to be, tho’ I never saw him nor wish to see): he is economically ruined withal; has served the Govt 25 years, … is now thrown into the street by both Govvts has nothing of income. That is a reward for quelling Nigger insurrectns isn’t it?” (TC to Lady A, 7 Sept. 1866 ).

Over the summer months he labored diligently to organize the Eyre Defence Committee and to enlist the aid of Charles Dickens, Charles Kingsley, Alfred Tennyson, and John Ruskin. But the more embroiled TC became in the affair, the less tolerant he became of its complexities and repercussions. He persisted with the campaign largely because, as he explained in his journal later in the year, “[t]hat is something … she wd have liked” (30 Dec. 1867). On 27 September Ruskin forwarded him a dossier of material detailing Eyre’s incompetence as governor of Jamaica that had been compiled and sent to him by George Price, a liberal plantation owner and a prominent member of the Jamaican Legislative Assembly. Among the documents were detailed newspaper accounts of Eyre’s culpability in the “Tramway Scandal,” which had provoked a public inquiry and a demand for his resignation in 1865. TC replied indignantly: “I have agn read all these Letters; but do not, from Mr Price … get the least glimmer of new light abt ‘the Tramway swindle’ or any of the other miracles alleged,—whh I can only conceive as more or less natural misbirths of that nearly inconceivable little chaos in a coalbox … whh they call ‘House of Assembly’; all intent upon talk of various kinds, while their
Governor was pushing towards work and result. A mere heap of flaming soot; abstrusely equal to zero for us! Mr Price, I have no reason to doubt, was and is perfectly honest and bon√¢-fide; but need not concern us farther” (TC to JR
JRU, 27 Sept. 1866
).

Ruskin was probably not personally convinced, but he wrote back immediately to assure TC that “your kind note being … quite enough for me” (29 Sept. 1866; Cate 121). Beneath the surface of the relationship between the “Sage” and his disciple, there was considerable uncertainty and distrust on both sides. Suffering dizzy spells and blurred vision, and agonizing about his love for Rose La Touche, Ruskin felt incapable of playing the role that TC had assigned to him as an activist and proselytizer. The violent outcry and the mass protests against Eyre had unsettled Ruskin and obliged him to consider the case against the governor more calmly than TC, who relished playing the part of the provocateur. He sympathized with Ruskin’s frustrations, but his loyalty to the “cause” he and JWC shared seems to have overridden feelings that might have rendered him less hostile to any criticism of the Jamaican governor. In his speech to the Eyre Defence and Aid Fund on 5 September 1866, Ruskin prefaced his justification of Eyre’s actions with a carefully measured assessment of his own motives. He had joined the committee “in the simple desire of obtaining justice, not for black men only, nor for white, but for men of every race and colour. He detested all cruelty, and all injustice by whomsoever inflicted, or suffered” (Eyre Defence 21). TC agreed in principle with these sentiments. In the petition that he composed early 1868, he expressed his contempt for “seditious Incendiaries, of black-savage type or of white-savage” (Workman 99). Still, TC would have liked Ruskin to argue in a more intemperate and aggressive fashion. His summary of the speech to Caroline Davenport Bromley—“a right gallant thrust. … While all the world stands tremulous, shilly-shallying from the gutter, impetuous Ruskin plunges his rapier up to the very hilt in the abominable belly of the vast blockheadism” (15 Sept. 1866)—succinctly revealed his own rhetorical preferences.

In reality, this description of Ruskin the agitator was more relevant to TC. His essay “Shooting Niagara: And After?” was not published until August 1867, but a crossed-out date at the conclusion of a manuscript fragment held at the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Duke University indicates that he was working on it at least twelve months prior to its appearance.2. See David R. Sorensen, “‘Amid the Thickest Welter’: Manuscript Fragments from Thomas Carlyle’s Shooting Niagara: And After?”CSA 29 (2013): 7–24. Many of the portentous “achievements” (Carlyle, Works 30:2) to which TC alluded in “Shooting Niagara” occurred between May and December 1866, including the financial panic caused by the discount house Overend and Gurney on 10 May; the outbreak of mass rioting
at Hyde Park on 23 July, followed by a meeting organized by Edmond Beales and the Reform League in favor of universal suffrage; the surrender of Austria by Prussia on 26 July at Nikolsburg, which resulted in the unification of the North German states with Prussia under the leadership of Bismarck; and the first meeting of the Eyre Testimonial and Defence Fund held on 29 August. Between July 1866 and June 1867, TC’s letters bristled with indignation at the manifold signs of Britain’s social and political decadence, in language that anticipated “Shooting Niagara.” The metaphor of the country paddling obliviously to its watery doom dominated his imagination. In his journal he wrote, “Is not Natl Death … perhaps preferable to such utter Rottenness of Natl Life? … [A]ll England … embarking on the Niagara rapids, called ‘Reform Bill,’ is strangely indifft to whatever may follow it” (26 May 1867).

TC’s pessimism was somewhat mitigated by the emergence of Germany as a leading European power. He was delighted to receive a letter from his friend and former researcher Joseph Neuberg on 23 August 1866—the same day that the Treaty of Prague ratified the terms of Prussia’s victory over Austria—and described it as the “pleasantest” he “had for a long time.” Neuberg announced: “Bismarck is the hero of the day; his portraits are on all the shop windows. I send you one, if you care to have it. It is not a lovely face; but he has brought about great things. … And you have been the only one, that I know, who recognised him as ‘distinguished,’ when all the world cursed him” (JN to TC, 21 Aug. 1866). Neuberg was not exaggerating. Previously vilified by the British press, Bismarck was now being hailed as a Carlylean hero. In an editorial a week earlier, the Times declared: “There is now no longer any check upon the great career of Count Bismark [sic]. … His progress has hitherto been marked by great, rapid, decisive strides. He has broken whatever he could not bend. He has taken fortune, the world’s opinion, his countrymen’s suffrage, by storm. He has made the blunders of his foes, no less than the exploits of his armies, subservient to his purpose. Austria is at his feet, not only crushed, but discredited” (16 Aug. 1866).

TC was astonished and delighted by this change of attitude and by the new balance of power on the continent. He replied to Neuberg: “That Germany is to stand on her feet henceforth … with clear steel in her hand, and an honest purpose in her heart—this seems to me the best news we or Europe have heard for the last forty years or more” (TC to JN, 23 Aug. 1866 ). Prussia’s ascendance not only revived his belief in the possibility that British “laissez-faire” democracy might be challenged by a superior “Teutonic” model, but also that his arduous labors in writing The History of Frederick the Great had not been entirely wasted. Once more, the public and private spheres of his life intersected. In the reminiscences of JWC, he recalled the thirteen-year period of the book’s composition, “much the worst we ever had.” While he had immersed himself in the “dead-lift” effort of making order out of his
“Prussian Blockheadisms,” she had lapsed into illness, depression, and withdrawal. He was haunted by the image of her “reclining on the sofa” in the evenings, “weak, but I knew little how weak,” while he complained of his travails in writing “of the Battle of Mollwitz.” Compared to the memory of her “courage, patience, [and] silent heroism,” Frederick was as insignificant as “the dung of a thousand centuries ago.” The book had deserved its fate, to “wander into the belly of oblivion for ever” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 155–56). Yet with dramatic suddenness, events had breathed fresh relevance into TC’s Prussian epic, lending it topicality and thrusting its author toward the center of a crucial debate about Britain’s future relations with Germany. Any temptation that he had to gloat was checked by his nagging realization of what had been sacrificed for the sake of his vindication as the “Sage of Chelsea.”

Nonetheless, Prussia’s triumph in 1866 sharpened TC’s desire to antagonize the liberal establishment in England. Writing to Eyre, 1 November 1866, he ridiculed John Stuart Mill’s Jamaica Committee, which had originally announced that it had “imperatively needed £10,000” for its prosecution of the governor for murder, but as of yet had only received “£475 some shillings some pence.” The committee had denounced Eyre for flouting the rule of law, yet the only laws that were respected and obeyed at home were those dictated by the “Respectable Professors of the Dismal Science” (Latter-Day Pamphlets, Carlyle, Works 20:44). The Jamaica Committee had effectively endorsed public disorder: “Very contemptible and very lamentable to me, their noises and they; intrinsically little better … than angry and hungry dogs barking in the gutter, and making night hideous,—whh they do contrive to accomplish: hideous, and even alarming, in this sad night of the Anarchies, and of the ‘Governments’ whose principle appears to be, ‘Shudder at contradiction!’ and ‘How sit the winds and the Newspapers Articles?’ … I ask, with surprise and apprehension, What are we arriving at? Is the thing I have long prophesied as inevitable, so near upon fulfilmt, then?” (TC to E. J. Eyre, 1 Nov. 1866 ). These were the questions that he needed to ask in order to prepare himself to unmask the “universal rottenness, and quagmire of mendacities, in which poor England is drowning” (“Shooting Niagara,” Carlyle, Works 30:9).

On 28 November 1866 TC announced to his brother John that he had finally decided, after months of procrastination, to accept Lady Ashburton’s invitation to stay with her at her rented villa in Menton, a French resort on the Mediterranean. The catalyst in persuading TC to go was his friend and disciple John Tyndall, who “was here last night, one of the most determined of mankind; insists on setting off with me, depositing me scathless;—and will then, ‘after 6 hours or so,’ return! I was shocked to hear of such a thing undertaken for my sake; but it was vain to remonstrate. … He is a strange, lean ardent kind of soul.” By 1 a.m., 24 December1866, they had reached their destination after two and a half days of travel from London. TC’s senses were
invigorated by the change of climate and scenery, notwithstanding the long and exhausting journey by rail and carriage. From Menton he wrote to his sister Jean Carlyle Aitken, recapturing their journey in rich and precise detail: “We left Paris … and abt 6 on Sunday morning, saw that the dirty raw-frosty vapours, wh had continued witht a moment’s interruptn from London onward, had fled quite away; and that a beautiful summer sunrise was colouring the western horizon, and that we were close upon Marseilles and the Mediterranean. Beautiful strange the difference of climate” (24 Dec.1866).

TC was overwhelmed by the natural beauty of his surroundings. To John Forster, 24 January 1867, he wrote: “I am doing tolerably in this new locatn; and sometimes almost begin to think there is a faint perceptibility of real improvet in health since I left Chelsea. … Our Town itself is curiously exotic; built like a little Sussex-Coast Town, along the shore, or miscellaneously sprawling up the steep cliffs … towering up, visibly, for 6 miles behind us, invisibly for 60 or more … into the airiest beautifullest ragged peaks and steeples I ever saw; the strange beauty of whh … is still new to me every morning when I first sally out.” He reveled in the simplicity of the locals and compared them unfavorably with the English residents of the town, distinguished by “plenty of money, no great share of any better endowt: a populatn … rather to be avoided than sought for.” A visit from the Chancellor of the Exchequer, William Gladstone, only intensified his disgust with British politics and politicians. After enduring “several hours of [Gladstone] in this house,” TC was relieved to be rid of his “talk ponderous copious, but to me of no use or emolument” (TC to JF, 24 Jan. 1867 ). Issues of deeper import took precedence in his mind.

In Menton, TC was engrossed by the spiritual dimension of the past, as he completed his reminiscences of Irving and Jeffrey, and forged ahead with Southey and Wordsworth. His very surroundings were saturated in piety and pathos. Lady Ashburton’s Villa Madonna had once been part of a convent with its adjacent chapel; they stood on the grounds of the ex-summer palace of the prince of Monaco. In a letter to his brother John A. Carlyle, 25 January 1867, he recounted that “the Chapel, still free for use, accessible from a Country road that passes close, is directly under Villa drawing-room, and the big old Bell is still visibly attached to an outside corner of the same: Bell whh I almost rub upon daily is tied up into perfect dumbness; Chapel without even a bambino or candle-end in it … seems to have seen its finis as ‘Chapel.’” He was still prone to scourge himself for his solipsistic literary excursions, explaining to Ruskin, 15 February 1867, that the “worst of my existence here is that I am thoroughly idle,—for the ‘work’ I try at intervals is a mockery of work.” Yet he persisted with the endeavor because it seemed to validate his existence as a writer, and JWC’s as his critical “Approver.” To Emerson he repeated his intention “to burn [these things] out of the way before I myself
die.” Still, the reminiscences constituted “‘the work’ of my day [because] to me, if to no other, it is useful; to reduce matters to writing means that you shall know them, see them in their origins sequences, in their essential lineaments, considerably better than you ever did before” (27 Jan. 1867).

Having decided to return to Chelsea toward the end of February, TC declined Lady Ashburton’s proposal to accompany her on a tour of Italy, including Rome, Bologna, and Florence. Writing from Chelsea, 18 March 1867, he gave details of the homeward journey and recorded his pleasure in taking “an hour’s promenade on the old-known streets of Paris (for I went strolling to various old places I had seen 43 years ago with a silent thot that I was now seeing them for the final time) amid the novel populatns, and their brisk French features, and my memories of them for the last 100 years and prophecies of them for the next 100 … fully equal … to what the best oil canvas ‘gallery,’ in Rome or elsewhere, cd have yielded. … For this … was ‘painted’ by Almighty God, who far excels Raphael or Titian.” The return to Cheyne Row inevitably left him downcast, especially with the impending anniversary of JWC’s death filling him with a renewed sense of desolation and loneliness. He wrote to Lady Ashburton, 20 April 1867: “These days are the anniversary of my Edinr ones last year. By the day of the week, this saturday; by the day of the month, tomorrow (Easter Sunday), abt 3 p.m., there happened—I need not tell you what; nor how the memory of it must forever dwell with me; with me for all manner of reasons, best speakable to my own heart alone.”

His personal anguish was compounded by the news of Joseph Neuberg’s death on 22 March 1867. In a remarkably frank and detailed biographical tribute that he wrote in his journal, TC acknowledged his profound indebtedness to his loyal friend and assistant. He had no doubts about Neuberg’s importance to him: “For the last 20 or 25 years, he had been my most attached adherent, ever-loyal, ever patient, ardent, ever-willing to do me service in every kind … in regard to the Book Friedrich … his help was truly … valuable (or invaluable …) he did all kinds of excerpting and abstracting … as if I myself had done it;—and, in brief, was an alter-ego in all the deeper parts of that horrible immensity of drudgery. … [H]e stood all my spurts of ill temper, c witht once wincing; working like a patient hero for me, as if he had been nothing, I something, and as if it ennobled his poor existence so to do!” (3 April 1867). In his journal TC tried to reciprocate by re-creating Neuberg’s life separately from himself.

Adopting an approach similar to the one that he had used in the reminiscences, TC retold the story of Neuberg’s life so that he could see it “in a difft aspect now, and it surely ought to continue.” He sifted through the information that he had at hand, trying to catch a glimpse of Neuberg as an individual. TC admitted that “I never questioned him abt his history; partly out of delicacy, tho’ I saw he wd have told me.” But as he recited what he did know, a
composite picture of Neuberg’s personality began to emerge. Not quite able to transcend his own anti-Semitism, which had been inflamed by the behavior of the “Hebrew Conjurer” (“Shooting Niagara,” Carlyle, Works 30:11). Disraeli in securing passage of the Reform Bill, TC classified Neuberg as a “Jew of the better type or almost of the best: a man of perfect integrity, of serious reflective temper, of fine and strong faculties (able to understand anything presented to him), of many high aspiratns.” Implicitly at least, TC seemed to appreciate that Neuberg, through his relentless exertions, had contradicted ubiquitous Victorian stereotypes about his ethnicity being acquisitive and devious by selflessly devoting himself to his cherished “ideal”—“the toiling at Frh.” His final project was a translation of Frederick the Great, “1½ voll. of it … still to do:—a task he infinitely liked, and took far too much pains abt; as I often told him.” “Poor good Neuberg,” TC lamented, “far better to me than I ever owned him as being!” In a startling admission, he confided to Lady Ashburton that Neuberg’s death caused him almost as much heartache as JWC’s: “[It] came upon me like a dull heavy weight; as a kind of corollary to that other, but with nothing of its poignancy; a dull broad blow following a stab into the heart; so remains with me” (20 April 1867).

Amidst the gloom, TC could draw some solace in honoring JWC by generously arranging to have the title deeds of the Craigenputtoch estate, which she had bequeathed to him in her will, given to the University of Edinburgh after his death. His purpose was to found bursaries for poor and deserving students, funded from the rents of the property. The gesture was at one with the goal of his memoir of JWC. He wished to locate her unique character and identity in the context of her Scottish ancestry, including its mythical dimension. In the bequest he noted that “Craigenputtock was, for many generations, the patrimony of a family named Welsh … in series going back, think some, to the famous ‘John Welsh,’ son-in-law of the Reformer, Knox.” Because she shared his name, TC decided to dedicate them to JWC’s father, John Welsh, “the last such male heir in his family … a highly honoured, widely regretted man.” Remembering his own course of study at Edinburgh, TC stipulated that five of the bursaries were to be given in mathematics, “above all in pure geometry,” and five for “the most excellent proficiency in matters classical.” He hoped that the plan, once implemented, would lend help “to the young heroic soul struggling for what is highest.” For him personally, the bequest was a “thread of pure water from the Scottish rocks, tinkling into its little basin by the thirsty wayside, for those whom it veritably belongs to” (TC’s final bequest, 20 June 1867). Symbolically, it was a living link to the vanished past of Haddington, Craigenputtoch, and Edinburgh.

Despite frequent bouts of melancholy, TC was eager to re-enter the public arena in order to address the prevalent “Signs of the Times.” Mass unemployment in the north of England and Scotland, railway failures and bank collapses,
and the deterioration of domestic manufacture convinced him that the country was entering another and darker phase of “boom and bust.” Without success, he had urged Froude and Ruskin, July 1866, to launch a “Latter-Day Periodical” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 178; see also TC to Lady A, 21 July 1866 ) in order to assail the twin shibboleths of democracy and “political economy.” On 8 May 1867 he complained to Lady Ashburton: “Our ‘trade’ is said to be all tumbled flat, this good while past; our ‘railways threatened with bankruptcy,’ nearly every one of them visibly in spasm to weather that fatal cape; ‘house-building’ stopped, many people thrown out of work … in short, Mammon pulling the nose of his worshippers … and great suffering and mutual accusatn in consequence. A good many people beginning to think it ‘ominous,’ and that probably we are in a bad way! Courage, this is not the end, my long-eared friends; tho’ that end will be here. Après nous le deluge!”

Ironically, TC’s earlier exhortations to Ruskin to “bite very ardently” (TC to JAF, 2 Aug. 1866 ) came back to “bite” him in May. In one of his Time and Tide letters published in the Manchester Examiner and Times, Ruskin reported the details of a conversation that he had with TC on 25 April 1867. According to Ruskin, TC had told him that he “now cannot walk [in the streets of Chelsea, and of the whole district of London around it] without being insulted, chiefly because he is a grey, old man; and also because he is cleanly dressed—these two conditions of him being wholly hostile, as the mob of the street feel, to their own instincts” (Ruskin’s Works 27:480–81). When an unidentified Rochdale man wrote to TC asking him whether he had indeed uttered these opinions, the response was terse and direct: “Sir—the thing now ‘going the rounds’ is untrue; diverges from the fact throughout … an ‘incredible … thing’” (22 May 1867). Six days later TC reiterated his position in a letter to the Pall Mall Gazette, dismissing Ruskin’s paragraph as “erroneous, misfounded, superfluous, and even absurd.” Hurt and bewildered, Ruskin demanded that TC “either justify the terms of that letter in the Pallmall Gazette, or retract them, and that publicly” (1 June 1867). The affair escalated, with the Times making the dispute the subject of an editorial on 3 June. TC replied to the paper on 8 June with a letter of semiretraction, explaining that he “substantially” agreed with Ruskin’s opinion of the “the Populace or Canaille of London,” but distinguished this “non-human, or half-human” population from his own “harmless” London neighbors.

The quarrel was eventually defused, thanks mainly to Ruskin’s magnanimity. The context of the original conversation tends to reinforce Charles Eliot Norton’s statement in 1869 that Ruskin had transmitted TC’s words accurately: “He did say, so I heard from a person who was present when he said it, what Ruskin reported.” Memories of the humble population of Menton, which TC had described in his letter of 24 January to Forster as the “fine hardy honest-looking excellt brown people, the frugallest, civillest, and …
best poor people in the world,” were fresh in his mind. In such circumstances, it is highly probable that he did erupt in a diatribe against London’s “canaille” in Ruskin’s company. But like Froude, Ruskin was frequently misled by TC’s mordant Scottish humor, and by his inveterate habit of engaging in cynical self-mockery. He invariably burst into hearty laughter after such outbursts, and as Norton added, he “likely forgot his words as soon as uttered, and … had no intention that they should be taken au pied de la lettre” (letter of 22 July 1869; cited Cate 29). The poet and novelist Mary Boyle, who was staying at Menton during TC’s visit and accompanied him “on walks and drives,” remembered how he “would launch forth into the most unwarrantable philippics, but then he would break off suddenly, and all the venom and bitterness be drowned in a burst of ringing laughter, and his handsome, though naturally grim, face would ripple all over with good-humoured smiles” (Mary Boyle, Her Book, ed. Sir Courtney Boyle [1901] 268).

Offended by Ruskin’s tin-eared indiscretion, TC was slow to forgive him. In his journal he invoked JWC’s judgment in support of his own: “A curious specimen, Ruskin, with really high and pretty talents in him, who has fluttered abt me (abt us especially, while it was ‘us’!) with an exuberant, constant, and plainly excessive amiability of ways … and was so taken by both of us,—with clear insight that in regard to ‘affectn’ for us it amounted to nothing. … We always remarked, too, that his talk had no solidity, hugely lacked sincerity, trustfulness, ease; and was always flying off, on the deepest topics, into idle ‘affectn’ of scepticism, pococurantism c c, as if eager to hide agn, and ashamed to be seen. Pretty notions, pretty talents, sharp, arrowy utterances, and perceptns and aspirattns, but all of a restless not of a quiet: of a weakish not a strong character;— as central element, an immense pruriency of ambitn, what might have been called by us … a merely great and transcendt vanity, if nothing else was ‘great’!” But perhaps recalling JWC’s own droll humor, TC conceded that “I really can’t be seriously angry at him, either” (12 June 1867). Like all of TC’s friends and associates in this period, Ruskin discovered that friendship with “the man of genius” remained conditional on the approving voice of his dead wife.

div1.p: July 1866date>–June 1867

1866 July. TC asks William Dods to supervise the installation of JWC’s tombstone in Haddington (2). He acknowledges Friedrich Althaus’s essay on his life (12), and sees Maria Price in Chelsea, giving her a London Library life ticket to commemorate JWC’s birthday (14). He is glad to hear from Lady Ashburton, he tells her, and is thinking of accepting Miss Bromley’s invitation to sea bathing on the south coast, as a preparation for “some ‘kind of work’ (if any real work be possible)” (21). Ruskin, having returned from mainland Europe, visits. TC completes his reminiscences of JWC (28). TC reports to Forster that the Haddington arrangements for the tombstone for JWC are now complete, and he wishes to pay all the costs as quickly as possible (29). He asks for more copies of family photographs from Robert S. Tait (30). Though his brother James invites him to Scotsbrig, he would prefer no Scottish holiday this year (30).

August. TC begins an intermittent journal (1). David Laing visits Chelsea, and TC talks to Froude and to Ruskin. Despite a cold, TC goes to Ripple Court to stay with Miss Bromley for sea bathing (13–27); two days later, Maggie Welsh leaves Chelsea for her brother’s in Liverpool (15). Lady Ashburton visits Britain briefly. TC’s health recovers slowly. He welcomes Joseph Neuberg’s letter, having not heard from him for a long time (23). TC returns to a newly painted 5 Cheyne Row, and Neuberg visits in the evening (27). TC begins his support for Edward J. Eyre by presiding at the first Governor Eyre Defence Committee meeting (29).

September. TC tells Charles Kingsley of his vehement support for Eyre (3) and presides at the second Governor Eyre Defence Committee meeting (5). He cannot decide whether to accept Lady Ashburton’s invitation to join her in Menton (7). A U.S. admirer, John Reuben Thompson, offers to send a gift of tobacco from Virginia (12). TC invites his nephew James Aitken Jr. to visit in Chelsea. He declines an invitation from the Kingsleys to visit (17) and one from Lady Lothian to dine (25). He remains active on the Governor Eyre question.

October. TC decides against traveling to Menton for the present since cholera is reported there; Froude (9) and Ruskin (10) visit. He is, he tells Forster, “edging gradually to-wards some kind of light work” (15). After a long silence, he writes cordially to his brother Alexander in Canada (20). He again asks Lady
Ashburton for a postponement for his visit to Menton (24), since his “writing” (his reminiscences of Edward Irving) is still a month from completion.

November. TC writes encouragingly to Eyre, disparaging the work of the Jamaica Committee, which attacks his actions (1). He thanks his brother John for taking care of Craigenputtoch business (2, 5). He declines an invitation to lecture at Harrow School (6). He sends copies of Tait’s photographs of the “Chelsea Interior” to relatives in Scotland. “I am really thinking of Mentone!” (11). He invites Anthony Sterling to ride with him one afternoon (21). He invites his sister Jean Aitken to visit in Chelsea, since he expects to finish his writing in early December (26). John Tyndall finally persuades him to go to Menton by promising to accompany him on the journey (27).

December. The new lease for Craigenputtoch arrives in Chelsea (3). TC writes to Thomas Erskine, whose sister Christian Stirling has died (5). TC’s sister Jean Aitken arrives from Scotland (5). TC tells Lady Ashburton he is prepared to set off for Menton on 18 December with Tyndall. TC writes to his brother James about amendments that he wants made to the Craigenputtoch lease (7) and returns the lease itself to John A. Carlyle (8); he returns a manuscript to Emilie Venturi with the suggestion she send it to Froude for a reading (13). Finally TC settles on 21 December for the journey with Tyndall, writes his farewell to Forster (20) and, helped by Tyndall and Jean, is ready for the road and rail. He leaves Jean in Chelsea to enjoy a London holiday; he writes to her from Menton (24) to say he has safely arrived and to James Aitken Jr. in London asking for a book and a waistcoat to be sent to Menton (30).

1867 January. TC’s nephew James Aitken Jr., sorting mail while TC is in Menton, forwards some letters and summarizes others; he reports a visit from Gerald Blunt and relays household news. He passes on a gift from TC of £5 to James Baillie, a relative of JWC’s now living impoverished in Dover. London suffers from heavy snowfall. Tyndall, who escorted TC to Menton, returns to London; TC now takes walks, enjoying the scenery, the mild weather, and the company of Lady Ashburton and Frances and Emilia von Bunsen. Often gloomy in his journal entries, TC is writing the reminiscences of Jeffrey, Southey, and Wordsworth, “reawakening the sleep of the Past.” He asks his housekeeper, Sarah Warren, to bake and send some oatcakes; he admits to her “I might return back to you a little stronger than I went” (21). Gladstone calls (21), en route to London from Italy. TC drives to Ventimiglia (22). Menton itself, he writes, is “curiously exotic” (24). TC catches up with his correspondence (25), sleeps better, and takes long walks in and around Menton. He writes to Maggie Welsh asking for Welsh family news (26), to Geraldine Jewsbury ([ca. 26]), and to Emerson (27). He is finding Menton as “beautiful as a very picture” (27) but describes himself as “dismally sad” (journal entry, 28).

February. Thomas Woolner reports seeing TC while passing through Menton, finding “the dear fellow in good spirits” (9); writing his brother John on the same day, TC explains his occasional low spirits are due to a troublesome corn on his little toe, now dealt with, allowing him a daily walk of two hours. He spends his evenings quietly with Lady Ashburton, reading and occasionally visiting English acquaintances, especially Lady Alford. James Aitken Jr. sends news from London, including of Neuberg’s illness (25). TC writes to Neuberg, suggesting he, too, would benefit from the mild winter in Menton, and describing his pleasure in the scenery and his walks there (10). He enjoys the company and conversation of Baron von Sulzer, “serious, intelligt young man.” He still is working on the reminiscences; he finishes Southey’s, though it is only a “small (imaginary) Task” (11). Charlotte Sterling dies. TC writes to Ruskin of the pleasures of Menton’s scenery and climate (15). Grace Welsh dies in Edinburgh (15). Pipes finally arrive from Chelsea, and Ruskin writes (17). TC receives letters from his brother John and sister Jean, and they pass on a letter from Alick in Canada; TC tells them of his sightseeing and begins to discuss his plans to return to Chelsea. Lady Ashburton wants him to accompany her to Italy, but TC declines (18). James Aitken Jr. continues to deal with TC’s correspondence in Chelsea and send summaries to Menton (20). Lord Brownlow dies in Menton (20), and his mother, Lady Alford (“Lady A.’s chief friend and resource in this place”), and brother leave for England to bury him. The weather breaks, and TC sends reports to Jean Aitken of his “dirty cold” (24).

March. Lord Northbrook writes TC (2) suggesting he would enjoy seeing Genoa if he accompanied Lady Ashburton there, but in his journal (3) TC writes of falling “into a sad abeyance” with his cold and general restlessness. He has been reading Shakespeare. Disliking the windy weather, he now plans to return to London around the middle of the month, accompanied by the Brownlows’ butler, Mr. Tweedie; he considers a break of journey in Vichy but rejects the idea. He hopes his brother John will come to Chelsea for a month’s visit, “a kind of light amid the gloom of my arrival” (4), and John replies, “I will cheerfully meet you in London” (8). Caroline Fox visits TC in Menton; Lady Ashburton, with little warning, leaves for Florence and Rome (leaving her daughter behind in Menton) which settles TC’s mind on departure. Sulzer helps him with train timetables, which TC always finds very hard to understand (10). John Forster writes from London where he has been hand¬≠ling TC’s publishing affairs (9). Neuberg, who has been very ill, thanks TC for his letter, which “came to me like a blessed voice from Upper World” (11). TC leaves Menton with Mr. Tweedie by train with an overnight stop in Avignon (14); he then stops at Lyon and Paris (15), and Amiens and Boulogne, crossing the English Channel and arriving in Chelsea just after midnight (16). The
Household Suffrage Bill begins (18) its long progress through the House of Commons (passed 15 July). TC writes to Mary Boyle and asks her to thank the Brownlows for the services of Mr. Tweedie, “worth ten Couriers to me” (20). Neuberg dies (22), his translation of Frederick the Great unfinished. Robert S. Tait visits Chelsea with this news (26) and accompanies TC and John A. Carlyle to the funeral (27). “Poor good Neuberg; far better to me than I ever owned him as being!” Lady Amberley visits (27).

April. TC writes to Erskine on the death of his sister David Paterson (23), remembering his visit to Erskine in Edinburgh in April 1866 (1). Lady Ashburton writes from Italy to say she will be in Addiscombe by June at the latest (6); in fact she does not arrive until October. In Chelsea TC keeps very quiet, visiting only Froude and Forster. Ruskin visits (10). TC commissions a bust of Neuberg for his sister Rosetta Frankau ([11]); Lady Ashburton writes from Menton to sympathize (17), and TC replies despondently as the anniversary of JWC’s death approaches (20). Ruskin is publishing his letters to a working man on the laws of work; TC writes that once the Reform Bill is passed, “thank Heaven, we shall have done with it then!” (20). Lady Ashburton invites TC to Vichy to join her (26). TC calls on Rosetta Frankau (29). John A. Carlyle leaves for Edinburgh (29).

May. TC declines an invitation to dine with Lady Amberley, though he says she would be welcome in Chelsea anytime (3). Bankruptcies and bank failures are widely reported. TC declines Lady Ashburton’s invitation to Vichy (8). He visits Tyndall, but generally avoids “calls.” Reform agitation continues. TC complains of the heat, which affects both his sleep and his digestion. Brother James and his son James Carlyle Jr. arrange to manage the repairs of Craigenputtoch on TC’s behalf, in preparation for taking on the lease (11); with John A. Carlyle’s and David Masson’s help, TC prepares the bequest of Craigenputtoch to Edinburgh University to fund student bursaries (12). He declines a dinner at the Spring Rices’ (23). TC contradicts Ruskin’s published comment that he faces insults in the streets of London by writing to the Pall Mall Gazette (28) where the story had been reprinted; Ruskin, upset, asks TC for clarification (30). TC rides for his health in Hyde Park (30).

June. TC complains to his brother John that his health is very poor. A “Library Edition” of TC’s work is being considered by Chapman Hall. TC escorts Lady Stanley to the National Portrait Exhibition in the South Kensington Museum (1). Maggie Welsh returns to keep house for TC. TC begins sittings for George Frederic Watts; Julia Margaret Cameron photographs TC twice (early June), and TC responds with comments on her two photographs (9). TC writes to the Times (7) and to Ruskin (8) in an effort to draw a line under their quarrel; and then writes a long friendly letter to Ruskin explaining his side of
the question (13). David Masson calls and together they finalize the Craigenputtoch bequest (11). It is signed and witnessed by Forster and Froude (20). TC asks his nephew James Carlyle Jr. to look into the cost of renovating the tomb of JWC’s paternal grandfather, John Welsh, in Dunscore churchyard (20). A dinner with Lady Augusta Stanley is declined (22). John Rutter Chorley is very ill (19), and dies (29). Frederick Foxton stays a few nights with TC, probably leaving Mon. 24.

div3.sourceNote: TC-FC, 2 July. Addressed for delivery by hand: “For Frc Chapman Esq / by Miss Welsh.” MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. JWC’s cousin Maggie Welsh was staying at Cheyne Row to help TC in the aftermath of JWC’s death, 21 April; TC wrote (around 19 July) in his reminiscences of JWC: “Maggie … was waiting here (partly by accident, and much to my surprise), night of Monday April twenty-third, 1866 , when John and I arrived from Dumfries, ‘dismallest night of my existence,’ I may call it,—and is still here (good, honourable, and assiduously polite soul); the question still not settled, whether she is helpful to me, on the whole, or hindersome? We must see soon.— Ah me, one Cousin is not another, by such an immensity of way!” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 175).
div3.head: TC TO FREDERIC CHAPMAN

docBody.p: “W. Maccall Esqr,William Maccall had asked TC for help in selling two of his translations; see 43:43–44TC to FC, 22 Nov. 1865. / Bexley Heath, Kent”:—his Two Mss, since you rejected them, I understood to have been returned, to the above Address, many months ago!TC had sent the MSS to Frederic Chapman, his publisher, Nov. 1865. This morng he writes to me, that he has not heard a whisper of them. How, in the name of wonder, is this! Pray do at last despatch to him (with, or even without, the smallest Note), and let me, and all of us, be free of the affair.

postscript.p: (Chelsea, july 2d, 1866)TC noted: “(Sunday july 1; copious rains with thunder etc.,—for the present clearly gone)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 153).

div3.sourceNote: TC-WM, 2 July. Addr: Bexley Heath / Kent. PM: London, 2 July 1866. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM MACCALL

docBody.p: There was instant diligence used in regard to yr Two Mss. Within a week, Miss Jewsbury, I recollect, had reported as to both,—unfavourably, indeed almost hopelessly; whh, from so experienced a Taster, was to be taken as an ill symptom.

Carefully ignoring that, we directly thereupon sent yr Mss to Fredc Chapman (193 Piccadilly), instructing him to have them examined qu√†m prim√πm [as soon as possible], and then to communicate with you (address, “Bexley Heath”); whh he promised punctually to do. Since that, inquiries (to my knowledge) have been twice made; and the genl result was, I understood, many months ago, that the Mss. were agn safe in yr hands. The unpunctuality of Frc and his people discloses itself here,—not by any means for the first
time in my experience.For earlier complaints about Frederic Chapman’s slowness in business matters, see 42:79TC to RWE, 14 June 1865 . I write to him anew this day to send you yr Mss. finally, according to his word given.See TC to FC, 2 July . Most likely he now will; at any rate, you can have them personally, I conclude, any day, by applying at 193. Piccadilly.

I am grieved to hear of yr continued difficulties and ever-recurring disappointts. Froude told me lately he had at last been able to accept a Paper of yrs: but this has not yet appeared.James Anthony Froude, editor of Fraser’s Magazine 1860–74, published Maccall’s “The Theory of Compensation” in Fraser’s (Dec. 1866): 794–815. Francis Espinasse later noted that Maccall’s contributions to Fraser’s “were chiefly in the sphere of foreign literature and biography” (Espinasse, Literary Recollections and Sketches [1893] 251).

If, at any time, hard come actually to hard, in matter of domestic finance, I ask you to let me know, that I may at least have the chance of helping if in my power.For TC’s previous help for Maccall, both with money and recommendations to magazine editors, see 41:174–75JWC to GLC, [22 Feb. 1865]. Believe me always sympathetic with yr struggles, if that cd avail anything.

div3.sourceNote: TC-WD [WDO], 2 July. MS: Strouse. Pbd: Glasgow Herald, 13 July 1901.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p: I am thankful to have yr news of this morning; and feel greatly obliged for the punctuality and perfect accuracy (as indeed I had expected from yr hand) with whh this service has been got done.William Dods, old friend of JWC, was overseeing the installation of JWC’s memorial tablet in St. Mary’s Church, Haddington; see 43:234–36JAC to WDO, 19 June , and TC to WDO, 21 June . TC wrote about Dods’s news in his reminiscences of JWC, 3 July: “Yesterday Note from Haddington, Tablet fixed since Saturday [30 June], and nothing wrong (thanks!); old tombstone to be painted now. I wish Dods had done; no speech, only silence, is rightly sacred” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 158).

By all means, please to have the Tombstone painted, in the most effectual manner (“one coat,” 3 coats, or whichever way is surest best),—and have the Letters (of the old part)That portion of the tombstone dedicated to JWC’s father, John Welsh; see 43:240TC to JCA, 23 June 1866. For its position in the then roofless choir of St. Mary’s, see 43:241TC to JCA, 23 June 1866. accurately painted black,—by the best hand Haddington can afford you; all under yr own supervision, if you will still be so kind.

This done,—and you may understand, it cannot be done too soon, if done
rightly,—have the goodness to pay everybody’s acct, and send me the summary.TC wrote in his reminiscences of JWC, 10 July: “Tablet safe and rightly fixed at Haddington (says Dods above a week ago: but they are painting, black-lettering the other Stone (original Tombstone), and that ‘takes time’). Time is, to my feelings, an indisputable outlay; but to no other body’s. Wish I had the accounts, and could compose the matter into silence! But even Gaffin (Regent’s Quadrant) doesn’t send his” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 162). Edward Gaffin (1819–69), sculptor and marble mason, Regent Quadrant and 17 Kensington Place. The accounts were not presented until late July; see TC to JF, 29 July, and TC to WDWDO, 30 July.
With many sad but kind thanks

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: John A. Carlyle wrote to their brother Alexander in Canada, 4 July: “Last week … [when] I got back to Chelsea I found Tom looking much better than when I had left him. He has now got over all the painful details and arrangements consequent on his wife’s death. You would find the inscription, which he has put on the grave-stone at Haddington, in the newspaper I sent you. … The loss of her of course was a very heavy calamity to him (though none of the rest of us except Mary [Carlyle Austin] ever got on well with her); for they were much attached to each other, and she always kept every thing in order most dexterously and faithfully for him, and with all her vehemenius [vehemence] of temper was really a most true-hearted and excellent woman” (Marrs 754). John A. Carlyle, mainly staying with TC since JWC’s death, returned from a trip to Jersey, 30 June.

div3.sourceNote: MW-BB, [5 July]. MS: NLS 3278.139. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by similarity of content to MW-[EMS], [6 July]. Letters by Margaret (Maggie) Welsh written at TC’s request, implicitly or explicitly, are included in this vol.
div3.head: MW TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p:
I did quite mean to write to you at the time that I sent the parcel away for you. I knew that the Miss WelshesJWC’s aunts Ann, Elizabeth, and Grace Welsh in Edinburgh. would kindly forward it to you, I hope ere this it may have perhaps reached you. You were the first person poor Mr Carlyle spoke of when the melancholy proposal was first mentioned of sending some small remembrances to one another who one knew would prize some little thing that had belonged to her. The dress I thought would be useful to you; I knew you would almost doubly prize the flannel dressing gown, knowing that it was made by her MotherGrace Welsh. for her once when she was ill at Craigenputtock.JWC and TC lived most of the time at Craigenputtoch, Dumfriesshire, from May 1828 until May 1834. When dear Cousin was so ill herself two years ago she made
me go bring it down for her to wear, out of a box in which she kept things that she valued for the sake of old times!JWC was ill Oct. 1863–July 1864; Maggie Welsh helped care for her Dec. 1863–May 1864; the dressing gown was perhaps in the leather box JWC referred to at the time as containing “all of valuable and precious that I have in the world!” (40:137JWC to MCR, [16 July 1864]). I know well my dear Betty what a sad grief to you the loss of one whom you loved so dearly for so long must be. I am sure there was no one that poor dear Cousin loved better than she did you. It seemed always as if she thought of you as she did of her Mother; I know well how you will mourn for her.For letters to Betty Braid about JWC’s feelings for Betty and about JWC’s death, see 43:223TC to BB, 2 May 1866; 43:259GEJ to BB, 22 [21] April 1866; and 260GEJ to BB, 23 April 1866. Poor Mr Carlyle is pretty well in health, he tries to bear up under his sorrow, but one can see how sad he is at heart, how he misses her each hour of the day.Lord and Lady Amberley visited TC, early evening, 4 July; Lady Amberley, previously JWC’s friend Kate Stanley, wrote in her journal that it was “the first time I had seen him since his wife’s death. He seemed very low and plunged at once into war and politics, of course praising the Prussians, and Bismarck particularly, very much. He asked Amberley to come soon and walk with him and said we might have come sooner to see him” (Amberley Papers 1:520–21). Otto von Bismarck, prime minister of Prussia since; Prussian troops invaded Holstein, 9 June; Austria and its allies, including Hanover, were defeated by the Prussians at the battle of Königgrätz or Sudowa, 3 July, leading to the success of Bismarck’s policy for uniting Germany under Prussia and excluding Austria from influence, recognized by the treaty of Prague, 23 Aug. It is a sad lonely house without her who was the very light life of it, it always looks as if she must surely be coming to it! Still when one thinks of the sore sickness she went through in that long illness two years ago, it would appear almost cruel to wish her back to such a life again, when one hopes believes that now all weary pain of body of mind are for ever ended for her. It is only for those who are left to grieve for the loss of her who was so bright loving, that one can feel it right to pity. I used to hear her always speaking so much of “dear Betty” that you must forgive my using it in writing.
With kindest regards, a hope that you are pretty well in health

closer.name: Yours very sincerely Margaret Welsh
closer.note: TC spent some of Thurs., 5 July, making a list of dates from his journal, 1854–65, commenting: “Her Letters must be got sorted up and (approximately) dated and put in order” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 158).

div3.sourceNote: MW-ES [ESN], [6 July]. Addr: 2 Park Crescent / Church Street / Stoke Newington. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. Delivered by hand, the envelope contains TC’s card, on which he wrote “For Mrs Snowden.” Dated by TC to Eliza Snowden, 30 June, where he wrote that Maggie Welsh would be sending her “some poor little memorial token” ( TC to ESN, 30 June). Eliza Jane Snowden, b. Miles (1808–71?), with whose family the Carlyles lodged in Ampton St., London, 1831–32; see TC to MAC, 10 Nov. 1831, and 43:biographical notes.
div3.head: MW TO ELIZA SNOWDEN

docBody.p: Mr Carlyle has asked me to write a few lines to you to say that he begs you will accept of this very small remembrance of Mrs Carlyle. It is but a very trifling offering, but Mr Carlyle says he feels sure you will value it for the sake of one who was for so many years a loving friend. My dear Cousin’s death was a very great shock to us all, for in spite of great feebleness weakness for some time past, she was so cheerful bright that those around her had fain hoped she might be spared to her poor husband, to others who loved her dearly, for some years to come. It is indeed a terrible blow to him; for after nearly forty years of this life’s pilgrimage together, it must indeed seem a dreary life now without the one constant companion. As you will see the boa little cuffs have been often worn by her,Possibly the boa and fur cuffs that JWC bought in 1846; see 21:86JWC to HW, [7 Nov. 1846]. but I feel sure that that will only perhaps make them of more value in your eyes.
Believe me / Dear Madam

div3.sourceNote: TC-Mrs. S [MRSSU], 10 July. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. Possibly Louisa Ann Suckling, b. Chambers (b. ca. 1825), m., 1849, Rev. Henry Edward Suckling (1827–1907); otherwise unidentified.
div3.head: TC TO MRS. SUCKLING

docBody.p: I have made some attempts to inquire into yr case;Rev. Henry Suckling divorced his wife on grounds of adultery, 1861, and remarried 1862. It is likely that their two children, Charles (b. 1850) and Alfred Edward (b. 1851), lived with him and that Mrs. Suckling was indigent. He had been curate of Shrivenham, Berkshire, 1858–62, and moved to the curacy of Reepham, Norfolk, 1862–72. but hitherto with no result whatever;—and indeed I am myself, at prest, so involved in sorrowful employments and consideratns, I have in effect no power to investigate things extraneous.

On reflexion, and by guessing from yr style, manner c, I conclude to send
you a small but well-meant remittance (whh is here inclosed),TC recorded in his checkbook: “10 july 1866 / to Mrs Suckling (Curate’s Wife—Charity) £5 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). The money came from the bequest left him by Lady Harriet Ashburton (see 34:82–83TC to LOA, 29 July 1858); TC noted in his memoranda book of charitable giving: “10 july (t’other written first), to / Mrs Suckling (Norfolk Curate’s / Wife, in dire distress) / £5 .. 0 .. 0” (MS: Bodleian Lib.); TC wrote his check of 14 July to Maria Price (see MW to MP, 10 July) before this check to Mrs. Suckling, 10 July.—with regret that there can come nothing more from this poor source, and that the help it may give must be so temporary.
Please post the inclosed Letter-cover, save yrself the trouble of farther writing.
Yrs, with much pity for the case you describe,

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: Between 7 and 10 July TC was both writing his reminiscences of JWC (“Maggie Welsh, now here with me, has helped in adjusting into clearness the recollection of all this”) and finding and sorting some of JWC’s letters: “(Sunday, july 8; began writing again, at the second line of this page; the intermediate time has been spent in a strenuous search for, and collection of all her Letters now discoverable (by Maggie Welsh and me). … They are exceedingly difficult to arrange; not having in general any date; so that place often enough, and day and even year throughout, are mainly to be got by the Post Office Stamp, supported by inference and inquiry such as is still possible, at least to me.) / The whole of yesterday I spent in reading and arranging the Letters of 1857; such a day’s reading as I perhaps never had in my life before. What a piercing radiancy of meaning to me in those dear records, hastily thrown off, full of misery, yet of bright eternal love; all as if on wings of lightning, tingling through one’s very heart of hearts! Oh, I was blind not to see how brittle was that thread of noble celestial (almost more than terrestrial) life; how much it was all in all to me, and how impossible it should long be left with me. Her sufferings seem little short of those in an hospital fever-ward, as she painfully drags herself about; and yet constantly there is such an electric shower of all-illuminating brilliancy, penetration, recognition, wise discernment, just enthusiasm, humour, grace, patience, courage, love,—and in fine of spontaneous nobleness of mind and intellect,—as I know not where to parallel! I have asked myself, Ought all this to be lost, or kept to myself, and the brief time that now belongs to me? Can nothing of it be saved, then, for the worthy that still remain among these roaring myriads of profane unworthy?— I really must consider it further; and already I feel it to have become uncertain to me whether at least this poor Notebook ought to be burnt ere my decease or left to its chances among my survivors?—— As to ‘talent,’ epistolary and other, these Letters, I perceive, equal and surpass whatever of best I know to exist in that kind; for ‘talent,’ ‘genius,’ or whatever we may call it, what an evidence, if my little woman needed that to me! … Ah me, ah me!— — At least, I have tied up that Bundle (the two letters touching on Friedrich have a paper round them; the first written in Edinburgh, it appears now!) (Enter Froude; almost the only man I care to speak with, in these weeks. Out with him to Battersea Park; day gray, temperate and windy)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 160–62).

postscript.p:
Mrs Suckling
Stratton-Strawless, Norfolk.Stratton Strawless is a village in Norfolk, 7 mi. (11 km.) N of Norwich.

div3.sourceNote: MW-MP, 10 July. Pbd: Maria Price, “Recollections of Thomas Carlyle,” Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine 159 (1896): 36. Maria Ann Price (1839–1910), protégée of JWC’s from Oct. 1865, lived with her father, Joseph Price (ca. 1800–1872), widower, master tailor, and her three sisters in Camberwell; see JWC to KST, 7 Nov. [1865]; see also 43:biographical notes.
div3.head: MW TO MARIA PRICE

docBody.p: My Dear Miss——,—Mr Carlyle has asked me to write a few lines to you to say that he would be very glad to see you, if you could come up to Chelsea on Saturday next,JWC’s birthday, 14 July. Maria Prince wrote later: “Beyond a short letter of condolence, I could not intrude myself on Mr Carlyle’s notice, and all seemed ended; and so it would have been but for his own great goodness” (Price 35–36). TC wrote in his reminiscences of JWC, 3 July: “Miss Price to have a London-Library Life Ticket;—I consider, yes: and on or before ‘july 14.’— Cease here today” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 158). any time before 2 o’clock. I hope it may be convenient for you to come that day, as I think Mr Carlyle would prefer Saturday, if you could possibly come.Maria Prince wrote: “I went to Chelsea, and was shown straight in to Mr Carlyle as he sat in the back-part of the dining-room. He had aged very much, and I was greatly impressed by the solemn sadness of his manner, the great dignity (if I may say so) of his grief. He at once began to talk of his wife (‘My Jane who has just left us’), and told me a great deal. … He told me of her brilliant youth, of their early married days, of her constant and bright helpfulness. … [I]t was his wish to give me something in remembrance of ‘his Jane,’ and thought he would make me a life member of ‘The London Library,’ so that I could always have reading enough. Then he handed me a small envelope containing a ticket of life membership— / ‘For Miss— —, / 14th July 1866. / T. Carlyle.’ / —saying, ‘I give it you, in her name, and for her sake’. … [T]his was her birthday, and that was why he so wished to see me on this particular day” (Price 36). TC noted in his checkbook: “14 july 1866 / to Harrison, London Library,—for Miss Price’s Ticket) / £27 .. 0 .. 6”; he noted at the top of the counterfoil, pointing to the date, “(written 9th: ah me!)” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Robert Harrison (1820–97; see 36:28136:biographical notes), librarian of London Lib. In his memoranda book of charitable giving, TC noted: “july 14, Library Life-Ticket / to Meira [sic] Price (the deserving [illegible]) / £26 .. 10 .. 6” (MS: Bodleian); see also David Southern, “Jane Welsh Carlyle’s Last Protégée,” Carlyle Studies Annual 23 (2007): 191–92. Robert Harrison wrote, 2 July: “Miss Price can be admitted a member of the Library whenever you please. She will be formally elected at the meeting of Monday next the 9th instant and I will send the printed notice … to you. I hope you are feeling better again after your heavy trial. I have opportunities of hearing of you from many of your friends and therefore do not trouble you with calls, which are not always consoling ceremonies.” I know you will if you can. I was very glad to hear that you arrived safely at home that evening from kind Miss Jewsbury’s.During the winter and spring, 1865–66, JWC had taken Geraldine Jewsbury to call on Maria Price (Price 34). Price noted later: “Margaret Welsh … Miss Jewsbury, and the Misses R[eichenbach] were most kind to me; still, the sun of my little world had gone. … Both Miss Welsh and Miss Jewsbury, and the kind German ladies [the Reichenbach das.], often invited me over; and when Miss Welsh returned to Scotland, Miss [Mary] Aitken, bright, clever, and friendly, came to live with her uncle, and from time to time I saw him for a few minutes talk” (Price 35–36).—

p.closer: With kind regards, believe me, yours very sincerely, Margaret Welsh.TC continued going through JWC material and thinking about what to do with her letters, 9 and 10 July: “(july 9: day again all spent in searching and sorting: A Box of hers, full of strange and sad memorials of her Mother, with a few of Father and infant Self (put up in 1842)—full of poignant meanings to her then and to me now. Her own Christening Cap is there (for example) … two or three Christmas notes of mine; which I could not read without almost sheer weeping.— (I know not well how to advance here, henceforth. Examine all the Letters? That is such a consuming of time?— It is late today: go out and see or consider).) / july 10. Maggie Welsh engaged in sorting (so far as postmark will go) all the Letters.—correctly into years; I then to try where doubt is. Reading of 1857 etc., has been so vividly mnemonic to me; so strangely interesting,—I think of examining farther. Cannot continue here till that;—though the feeling of being stopt, is confusing, unpleasant, even regretful” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 162).

div3.sourceNote: TC-FA [FAL], 12 July. MS: NLS 23167. Quot: Rosemary Ashton, Little Germany (2013) 186. Friedrich Althaus (1829–97), German writer and historian; he moved to London in 1852, where he wrote for German periodicals, and taught German at the Woolwich Military Academy; in 1874 he was appointed prof. of German at Univ. Coll., London. He lived at 4 Winchester Rd., St. John’s Wood, London.
div3.head: TC TO FRIEDRICH ALTHAUS

docBody.p: Mr Carlyle sends his compliments to Mr F. Althaus; has recd Mr A.’s Essay; recognises well enough the careful study, the ingenuity loyalty, the altogether friendly feelings everywhere manifest there; returns Mr A. his thanks for the same.In early July, Althaus sent TC a draft copy of his article, “Thomas Carlyle: Eine biographisch-literarische Charakteristik,” which was published in Unsere Zeit 2 (July 1866): 1–41. For a trans. of the essay, together with TC’s marginal annotations and notes, see “Thomas Carlyle: A Biographical Literary Portrait by Friedrich Althaus, with Thomas Carlyle’s Notes,” Two Reminiscences of Thomas Carlyle, ed. John Clubbe (Durham, NC, 1974) 1–122. Althaus noted later that on receipt of the article, “even Carlyle himself wrote me a friendly letter of acknowledgment” (Two Reminiscences 5). Althaus had prepared the article with the assistance of Joseph Neuberg and recalled: “There was no lack of biographical notices and scattered facts, yet all in all these were extremely unsatisfactory; especially for the beginnings of his career were the dates full of gaps. Finally I had to turn to Carlyle himself with a series of questions, but in this received no reply.” He was then introduced to Neuberg; “Neuberg could enlighten me immediately on many doubtful points; on others he too was uncertain, but kindly and readily promised to make enquiries of Carlyle himself” (Two Reminiscences 4).

Errors not a few are unavoidable in such an Enterprise; but none of Mr A.’s are of much importance,—nor require the least notice farther from either of the Parties principally interested.TC was to correct and annotate the article, late Aug.; he wrote: “The following German Sketch of me was received here, and read with little interest, tho’ with recognition of the Author’s kind intentions, some two months ago. I had heard of Althaus his project, a good while before, thro’ Neuberg; who put many questions on his behalf,—to little purpose, as would seem. … Of incorrectible, or not easily correctible there will be very much; but this, on the whole, is considerably the best Sketch I have yet seen on the subject. … T.C. (Chelsea, 29 August 1866)” (Two Reminiscences 23).

5. Grt Cheyne Row, Chelsea, 12 july 1866TC noted: “(july 13. Two days of miscellaneous detention (sorting of Letters; interruptions; bits of reading,—generally a ‘waiting’ as if for something, no part of which comes, not even the Accounts from Dods or Gaffin!)—on the whole two days of absence from my little ‘shrine of pious memory’ here where alone it is best for me to be, at present!. … Hand sadly shaky, weather extremely hot)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 162–63).

div3.sourceNote: MW-WD [WDO], 14 July. MS: NLS 1797.136. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: MW TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p:
Mr Carlyle has asked me to write a few lines to you for him. He bids me give you his very kind regards say to you that he would take it very kind of you if, when you can conveniently, when all the arrangements as to the tombstone are completed, you would send him the account of all the expenses connected with this matter.See TC to WDO, 30 July
. As it does not need me to tell you Mr Carlyle seems to feel very much all your kindness throughout this sad business. I know that you Mrs DoddsWilliam Dods’s wife, Jane. will be pleased to hear that he is on the whole pretty well, though he does indeed look sad lonely enough. Dr Carlyle is away at present on a visit to some friends in JerseyJohn A. Carlyle was attending the marriage of his stepson William Watt, 18 July, in Jersey; see 43:241–42 TC to JCA, 23 June. does not speak yet of returning. Mr Carlyle has promised, if all be well, to go pay his visits to old friends in the south of EnglandTC was considering visiting Caroline Davenport Bromley at Ripple Court, nr. Ringwould, Kent, in Aug. (see 43:238–39TC to LLA, 21 June), and was also hoping to visit Lady Ashburton at Melchet Court, Hampshire, in Sept., if she were home by then; see TC to LLA, 21 July . during August September. The Change would I am sure be good for him—

I trust Mrs Dodds is pretty well; will you please to give my kind regards to her. When you see Mrs DavidsonJanet Davidson (1782–1869), living at Craighope House, Court St., Haddington: see 39:42JWC to JAD, [29 Jan. 1863] . will you be so good as to give my kind regards to her, say that her most kind letter to me reached me quite safely. I fear this extreme heat must be very trying for an invalid as she is.
docBody.closer: Believe me, Dear Sir / Yours very truly / Margaret Welsh

div3.head: TC TO DINAH MULOCK CRAIK

docBody.p: The PetitionA petition for a government pension for the late George Lillie Craik’s das., Mary Craik (1827–1909), who had helped to nurse JWC May—July 1864, and Georgiana Craik (1831–95), novelist. seems quite right; and I am perfectly ready to put down my name as the first signature,—provided this be, by those that understand such matters, considered the fit course. But Mr Forster, who alone of my circle cd give a judgement abt it, is not here,—still absent in Yorkshire for a few days.John Forster’s work as a Lunacy Commissioner took him traveling around the country. Add to whh, that there is not the least hurry necessary; as nothing whatever can be done in the affair at present,—the Pensions for this year being completely settled, and the time of settlement for those of next year being certainly still a good way off. For the rest, no friend can be more heartily zealous, nor more prudently skilful than Mr Forster;—nor intrinsically do I consider that there is any likelihood of ultimate failure in this case.The Civil Pensions list, pbd. Athenaeum, 17 Nov., included the entry: “Miss Mary Craik and Miss Georgiana Craik, 30l. a year each, in consideration of the services of their father, the late Dr. Craik, as Professor of History and English Literature in the Queen’s College, Belfast.” For George Lillie Craik’s recent death, see 43:244TC to MCR, 29 [28] June.
The clear method, therefore, it appears to me is, that nobody do anything whatever but sit quiet till Mr Forster return,—and then take his advice as to what the fit steps are.

“Palace-Gate House, Kensington,” is usually Mr F’s Address; but Mrs F. he, in the present months, reside at Hampstead, Mrs F. there at present, and the Address, “Castle Hôtel Hampstead”See TC to JF, 29 July. A Note to Mrs F. wd at once bring you informatn on what day Mr F. cd receive yrself or yr messenger with Petitn c;—after whh everybody’s road wd be clear.

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: TC noted: “(july 14; twelfth Saturday since)”; “(Interruption; from Ruskin, july 16; must stop again for this day)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 164, 168).

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 21 July. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Your Letter came with beautiful promptitude, directly on yr receiving mine;TC’s letter untraced; Lady Ashburton wrote, 18 June, when she had not heard from him; apparently letters to and from the Continent often went astray. and was a great satisfactn to me. How fortunate that Vichy was so beneficent to the little Mary and you, after all those painful roamings!Lady Ashburton had been traveling in Europe since July 1865, and was currently in Vichy, spa town, central France; Lady Ashburton wrote of Vichy, 18 June: “Here we have now been a month— … I am better than I have been for many a long day, owing to these wonderful waters— little Mary too, is perfectly well.” Mary Florence Baring was Lady Ashburton’s da. That is something achieved. To be free of bodily misery is always a mighty blessing;—tho’ there remain plenty of other kinds, these are always more handsomely manageable: one is never fairly or degradingly wretched till one’s miserable clay house too begins to smoke and take-in wet! I have since seen yr Dr Frank,Dr. Philip Frank; Lady Ashburton wrote, 18 June: “Dr Frank is a Man, who I think you would like— He was brought up in Germany— is full of original, good thought—if you care to hear last tidings of us, he will call, at your door.” who seemed to me a very intelligent young man: he confirmed all you said of Self Mary; talked of writing to you in the course of a day,Dr. Frank wrote to Lady Ashburton, [17 July 1866]: “I went on Friday to see Carlyle— Thanks to your kind words on my behalf and the news of which I was the bearer, the great thinker actually received me. He was really in a genial mood; gentle—calm, but energetic withal in all his statements full of vigor. He spoke with great affection of you … the fine temper of your heart and the warm impulsiveness of your nature; how he wished you to roam no more but to take root with Mary in a home of your own, ceasing to be a rolling stone in foreign lands— And then he talked very wisely about dear little Mary, how desirable it was for her too to be settled; thinking that the too varied numerous impressions inseparable from continual change might tend to tax the young growing brain of the child beyond its strength—before its time. … [O]f course I did not stay long went away with many messages for you in case I should be writing before he himself might be able to do so” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388).—whh has encouraged, or partly induced, this delay, on my part, of doing so. In fact there was no change in my affairs; my life altogether silent, as quiet as was possible; and I had, and have, next to nothing to say. Except indeed to tell you how far my movements, or no-movements, for the autumn are in any way settled;—and this it is now full time for me to do.

For the rest, I hope you are still true to yr purpose of “1 Septr”: for if so, I am ready to engage to meet you at Melchet abt that time; take a view of things there,—for a few days; not many; for I must get to work, or at least to permanent adjustt, with as little loss of time as is most favourable. And it depends on yr Ladyship, you perceive, whether Ripple-Court and the Fortnight of Sea-bathing is to be my one “movet,” or whether, in case of yr holding out, there is to be a second.— This is practically all I had to say: George BunsenGeorg Friedrich von Bunsen, fourth son of Christian Karl Josias von Bunsen and Frances von Bunsen; the Bunsen family were friends of both TC and Lady Ashburton; see 43:1–2 TC to LLA, 4 Oct. 1865
. c c have been here, since I began; and have set my hand shaking (by the talk we got into), and stolen all my time. Alas, alas, that it is not the kind of way I like to spend my days in just now; nor that of talking “company” is the companionship I usually have!—
Adieu dear Lady—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 29 July. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster.—I was at Jack Straw’s one day (made somebody drive me up), but found you were all gone:—indeed Jack’s Castle did seem to be rather in a moulting state since I had seen it last.Jack Straw’s Castle, or the Castle Hotel (see 14), Hampstead, where John and Eliza Ann Forster had been staying; see TC to DMC, 16 July. It was named after Jack Straw, supposedly one of the leaders of the peasants’ revolt of 1381, who allegedly addressed a crowd of rebels from a hay wagon on Hampstead Heath; the name may have been an alias for Wat (Walter) Tyler (d. 1381; ODNB), leader of the peasants’ revolt.

figure.p:
Jack Straw’s Castle, Hampstead Heath
Illustrated London News, 23 September 1871

docBody.p: This is only to say that I know yr goings comings (“Hans PlaceHans Pl., Chelsea; possibly the Forsters’ house at Palace Gate, Kensington, was unavailable and the Forsters meanwhile were staying in Hans Pl.; they were still there in Nov.; see TC to WBE, 9 Nov. tomorrow,” perhaps early); that I have, at last, got Dods’s final report from Haddington, of everything completely settled there;—and that if you wd now qu√†m prim√πm [as soon as possible] bid Chaffin send you his (you; that was the arrangt). I wd at once pay him;Edward Gaffin. TC noted in his checkbook: “1 Augt 1866 / to Jn Forster / (for Chaffin [Gaffin]) / £23 .. 15 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). so have that mournful and also sacred little matter ended, and consigned to the Eternities where it belongs. Ah me, ah me!— — Do it, as you have done all hitherto.
I also want to see you, abt CraikSee TC to DMC, 16 July. abt many other things—I am at home every evg after 8; and every day till 3.
In haste, and

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: TC, drawing to the end of his reminiscences of JWC, wrote, 25 July: “(occupied yesterday in the Geraldine pieces here appended; have to go into my writing-case, and sort and reposit her last Letters, and the rings a[nd] buckle;—could not yesterday)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 185).
