postscript.p: Chelsea, 29 july 1866TC completed his reminiscences of JWC the previous day, 28 July: “The paper of this poor Notebook of hers is done; all I had to say, too (though there lie such volumes yet unsaid), seems to be almost done: and I must sorrowfully end it, and seek for something else. Very sorrowfully still; for it has ‚Ä† (interruption for days [TC’s insertion above line]) been my sacred shrine, and religious city of refuge from the bitterness of these sorrows, during all the doleful weeks that are past since I took it up: a kind of devotional thing (as I once already said), which softens all grief into tenderness and infinite pity and repentant love; one’s whole sad Life drowned as if in tears for one, and all the wrath and scorn [TC alters from “scornful indignant humour”] and other grim elements silently melted away. And now, am I to leave it; to take farewell of Her a second time? Right silent and serene is She, my lost Darling yonder, as I often think in my gloom; no sorrow more for Her,—nor will there long be for me. Since the mark ‘‚Ä†’ above, there have been interruptions of extraneous sort,—and days have been spent in final sortings (the rings and belt-buckle of April 21 [day of JWC’s death], still in my writing-case till day before yesterday), adjustment of last Letters, etc. etc. … Everything admonishes me to end here my poor scrawlings and weak reminiscences of days that are no more. / I still mainly mean to burn this Book before my own departure; but feel that I shall always have a kind of grudge to do it, and an indolent excuse, ‘Not yet; wait, any day that can be done!’—and that it is possible the thing may be left behind me, legible to interested survivors,—friends only, I will hope. … / In which event, I solemnly forbid them, each and all, to publish this Bit of Writing as it stands here; and warn him that without fit editing no part of it should be printed (nor so far as I can order, shall ever be);— that the ‘fit editing’ of perhaps nine-tenths of it will, after I am gone, have become impossible / TC (Saturday 28 july 1866)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 198–99). TC had begun his reminiscences of JWC in Jewsbury’s notebook at the end of her memories of JWC; see 43:232–33 TC to GEJ, (22 May) . He filled the rest of that notebook, ending with “(as he did, I believe, with success en-”; he continued, beginning “-enough),” on the empty pages of the JWC notebook that contained her journal, 15 April–5 July 1856 (see 30:243–62 30:biographical notes ) (MS: NLS 533; Carlyle, Reminiscences 75). His reminiscences of JWC were completed in this notebook; TC noted on a slip of paper inserted on its flyleaf: “vol II (Notes c on the mythic jottings, contend / (ended, and tied up (28 july 1866)).” TC had referred to Jewsbury’s notebook of memories of JWC as “this little Book of Myths” (25 May; MS: NLS 533; Carlyle, Reminiscences 66).

div3.sourceNote: TC-RST, 30 July. Addr: Queen Anne Street / Cavendish Square. PM: London, 30 July 1866. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ROBERT S. TAIT

docBody.p: Dear Tait,—I am very sensible of yr kindness, and sorry to trouble you farther abt Photographs at prest: but these six of my MotherPresumably photographs of the portrait of Margaret Carlyle; see 28:56TC to MAC, 28 Feb. 1853; for the portrait, see 13: frontis. seem all to have “come” very indifftly, in comparison with the others; and one of them (whh I inclose) is quite thrown out, by something wrong abt the right eye,—is it not?

I wd therefore thank you much (if there is still time before yr departure) to try for six others of a more distinct and complete sort,—not so pale colourless as these. Do, if you can. And in any case, be punctual to keep count: 7 + 6 + (whatevr more I shall get) till settlet with yr Lady-Printer.The 1866 PO directory listed 19 women printers, including Emily Faithfull (1835–95; ODNB; see 35:33JWC to DD, 14 Feb. 1859), publisher and women’s activist. But possibly TC refers to Sarah and Elizabeth Wootton, photographic publishers, whose firm was to enamel two photographs of JWC for TC; see TC to TWO, 16 Nov., and TC to AWO, 28 March 1867.
With many thanks

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: TC was also at this time looking for pictures of JWC; he wrote, 10 July: “Parsons the Painter ‘is to come Friday next’: has already thrice broken his word (about that poor Picture he is to bring me of her)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 162). He then noted, 28 July: “No ‘Picture’ procurable; Painter Parsons, after fretting vexing me for two months, as good as gives it up; his Photograph, and one of Tait’s (perhaps eighteen years younger), with Macleay’s Miniature,—that is, too probably, all I shall every [sic] realise of Portrait. Well, well!——” (MS: NLS 533; Carlyle, Reminiscences 199). These were TC’s last words in his reminiscences of JWC, written below his signature (“T.C.”) and date (“Saty 28 july 1866”). John Robert Parsons (ca. 1825–1909), painter, art dealer, and photographer, at 26 Edward St., Portman Sq.; originally from Ireland, Parsons had been in London since the 1840s, and had worked with his cousin William Haylett Royston, who owned a family firm of stationers and booksellers; at some time he lodged with Royston’s family at 1 Cheyne Row (Colin Ford, “A Pre-Raphaelite Partnership: Dante Gabriel Rossetti and John Robert Parsons,” The Burlington Magazine May 2004: 310). WilliamKenneth Macleay (1802–78; ODNB), painter; for Parsons’s photograph of Macleay’s 1826 miniature of JWC, see above; for the miniature, see 32:16–17JWC to MR, [24 Oct. 1856]. The copy of Parsons’s photograph of Macleay’s miniature in Carlyle’s House has Parsons’s stamp printed on the reverse; see 17above; Carlyle’s House Catalogue lists two carte de visite photographs by Parsons, one of TC aged 52, and one of JWC (90); and two photographs of JWC by Tait and Parsons (109). See also TC to TWO, [24 Oct.].

figure.p:
Kenneth Macleay’s 1826 miniature of Jane Welsh Carlyle
Photograph by J. R. Parsons
Courtesy of Carlyle’s House, National Trust

J. R. Parsons’s photographer’s stamp
Courtesy of Carlyle’s House, National Trust

div3.sourceNote: TC-WD [WDO], 30 July. MS: Strouse. Pbd: R. A. Dakers, “The Jane Welsh Carlyle Centenary. Interesting Carlyle letters,” Glasgow Herald 13 July 1901.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p: It was a great satisfactn to me to receive yr Letter, on Saty Evg,TC wrote: “In these very minutes (july 28), Dods after a month’s dreary delay, which to him has been nothing, but to me much, sends me the finale of those fixings, paintings etc.; and the Tomb is now complete, and as it should be. Once I hope to see it again; and then (possibly) my native Scotland never more” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 198). According to R. A. Dakers, TC “paid annual pilgrimages as long as he was able to the grave in the Parish Church. … As long as Provost Dods lived he stayed in his house [on Court St.] during his brief visit, but after the Provost’s death [1873] he departed from this course and went to the George Hotel” (Glasgow Herald). Only one visit to Haddington has been traced, summer 1870, mentioned in TC’s letter to his brother Alexander (Marrs 269). when I was agn despairing of it for the week; and to know that all was at length settled and completed to yr mind, in that mournful little province of my affairs,—mournful, and yet sacred; in whh it was so importt to me to know that everything was right and complete!

Inclosed is the little Bill of Charges.TC recorded in his checkbook: “30 July 1866 / to Wm Dodds Esq / (alas, the last!) / £2 .. 6 .. 3” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). I need not say how much I am obliged for the trouble and care you have had,—right willingly undergone by you, as I well know;—nor that, to the end of my life, it shall be memorable to me, and indeed of its own accord will. By this post, I send you a poor little volume of my writing, Life of Sterling (1851), according to R. A. Dakers. whh I will beg you to keep as a memorial of these things.

With many grateful regards to Mrs Dods, to her Son who was so good to me that evg,William Dods’s second wife, Jane Dods, and Charles S. Dods (b. 1840), William Dods’s sixth son from his first marriage; it seems that the night before JWC’s funeral, TC could not sleep, and was walking in the garden: “here Mr C. S. Dods met him, and talked with him for a considerable time”; Charles S. Dods after William Dods’s death lived (or continued living) in the Dods’s house; he gave the letters and information to R. A. Dakers for the article in the Glasgow Herald. I remain always

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 30 July. MS: NLS Acc. 7988. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: I got James’s LetterPresumably from James Carlyle Jr. last week; and was much obliged and gratified by yr kind invitatn. Scotsbrig is still as it were a kind of home of mine; and I always assure myself of a brotherly welcome there, while I continue in this world whh grows more and more foreign and solitary to me. For the prest year, I have felt that I must avoid Scotland; and even that I ought to [stay] as strictly as possible at home, and there sit quiet, and bethink me still farther what it is that has befallen. Except one fortnight of sea-bathing, whh is to be in the latter half of Augt coming, in a kind and most quiet friend’s house (not far from Dover) abt 60 miles off,Caroline Davenport Bromley’s house, Ripple Court, Kent, was about 5 mi. (8 km.) NNE of Dover, which was about 78 mi. (125 km.) by rail from London.—I do not contemplate any travelling this year.

We were, the Doctor I, disagreeably struck with what James’s says abt a lingering cold you have got. That is a very bad, wearisome and even dangerous neighbour; of whh you ought to be more cautious than you are. Quite unsafe and improper to heat yrself with work, and then to sit carelessly cooling! Nobody can stand that without risk of damage; and you shd absolutely never do it (whh is a rule I myself observe, quite strictly,—soon punished, if I don’t!) You must have got mischief, too, out of the unroofing of the house, c,—whh I am glad to hear is now nearly over.

The Doctor came back to us from Jersey,John A. Carlyle had been attending the marriage of his stepson William Watt; see MW to WDO, 14 July
. end of last week; and yesternight (9½ p.m.) set off for Dumfries; calculating to arrive at 7.35 this morning, as I hope he has safely done.John A. Carlyle wrote, 30 July: “the long journey was accomplished throughout with perfect punctuality, ending here at 7.34 a.m.” Jean is ailing there, for a week past; and perhaps one of his reasons for such speed, was the wish to see her, and see you (as he contemplated doing directly after). It is possible he may be with you the very day you read this,—tho’ probably the next day (Wednesday, with some warning to you) may be what he fixes. I expect to hear a precise acct of Jean’s health yours witht loss of a post on his part.

My own bodily health is not worse than it used to be; perhaps almost, in some points, a slight degree better.John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle, 30 July: “I left Tom looking quiet tolerably well, he had told me I could do him no good by staying longer” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). My mood of mind is not miserable; but I have to define it as very wae nearly always; sad altogether serious altogether,—as well behoves in these New circumstances that have come.

I remember a certn old Photograph, much worn out, whh I used to see every day; having got some New of the same, I take it into my head to send you one. Whether there was a wornout one of myself, I can’t recollect; but will, on second thots, send you one of these as well. They are, I think, the best likenesses, these, of all: She abt 46 or so; I perhaps 52 or ’3.TC had been getting prints of Tait’s photographs of JWC (see TC to RST, 30 July), but these were of JWC aged 53 and 54; for one taken in 1855, see frontis. There is no record of a photograph of her at “46 or so.” Presumably TC asked Tait for copies of other photographs than his own. Anthony Sterling had taken many photographs in 1853 of portraits of JWC (see 28:22JWC to KS, [28 Jan. 1853], and 53JWC to MR, 24 Feb. [1853]), particularly the crayon sketch by Samuel Laurence (1812–84; ODNB), when JWC was 47 (see 9:frontispiece, where wrongly dated) and perhaps also the portrait by Laurence (see A. Carlyle, NLM 1:258) and the portrait by C. Hartmann (see A. Carlyle, NLM 1: frontis.), both 1849 when she was 48; he gave her copies to send to friends. Sterling also took photographs of pictures of TC (see 28:99–100TC to AC, 8 April 1853). TC was sitting for portraits by Laurence, autumn 1848, when TC was 53 (see 23:98TC to JAC, (26 Aug) 1848, and 113–14TC to TSS, 19 Sept. 1848), and Thomas Carrick, June 1849 (see 24:61TC to JAC, 8 [9] June 1849).— — Good be with you all. Yr affectionate Brother T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 1 Aug. MS: NLS 7197.83. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES A. WARD

docBody.p:
All things considered, I vote that you are right in yr determinatn. Having got harnessed to yr Enterprise, in that gradual, intricate and at length complete manner, you cannot, with any propriety (even if you cd at all, whh is doubtful), cut yrself loose from it,—especially now when it is at the starting, and all things, yr own mind included, are elaborately ready.Charles A. Ward had written, 9 July: “Another week and I have not been able to get to you. Sometimes so thoroughly spent towards night that I have turned into bed at 8 o’clock for though I sell stimulants I do not use them. I hold there is no genuine restorer but sleep no fluid harmless but water— the nearer to content a man can rest in that the more nearly shall his pulse beat in gay unison to the music of health. … Not a night have I not thought of you the considerate gentle kindness of Mrs Carlyle in coming in to bid a pleasant welcome when last I came to sturdy well built no 5. I am terribly tested.” He then wrote again, 29 July, about the conflict he felt between continuing in his business as a wine merchant in order to make money or in pursuing his writing with little hope of monetary reward; TC had apparently been in touch with him recently: “One whole week has now gone by since you were good enough to put in a protest against what appears to you in me to be a too great Mammon worship. … First it is my mother’s life wish next it is and has been ever my own most sorrowful detestation. … Nay, even an old word of your own has helped it, ‘I do not advise you to put your blessedness in literature.’” Ward had several times sent TC copies of his articles (see 36:262–64TC to CAW, 24 Sept. 1860), and TC had suggested magazines where he might send them (see 40:15MW to LLA, [18 Feb. 1864]); he now appeared to have committed himself to moneymaking, in the hope that when he had enough he might then have time for writing: “I do not value the money, God knows full well, but I see that I can do nothing without it. / The question of questions is what time will there be when the money’s gotten? … I have thought long about it have chosen the long dark road. … If life is too short for a resolute prudence I did not make life am ready to yield it up and all its plans. go on, therefore,
Fausto pede [with lucky feet]; with all your skill and energy, and patient vigilance and courage, and whatever virtues are in you. Especially with nobleness, spotless integrity; the full possessn of yr moral self, to be striven for as the height of the prize!—

In any lawful Enterprise, prosecuted on these principles, a man “cultivates” himself daily and hourly, in all manner of ways, and may hope to come out educated so as, except in the School of Experience, he cd nowhere be. And far beyond all Colleges, and readings and tutorings, that irrefragable old Gentn, Experience, is capable of teaching the wise soul that will listen to him. At the close of the adventure, therefore, you may hope to have read, if not so many Books as some have done, yet a great many other things, whh are much more didactic. Upon many or all of whh, the world may still benefit by yr opinn;—and this is a fact, I think, whh, whatever course and issue yr adventure take, you ought at no time to leave out of view. Keep that sacredly with you all along, I shd say; as the Israelites did with their Ark, in that terrible Pilgrimage they had thro’ the thirsty wildernesses of this world.See Exod.

On the whole, I have long since discerned for myself, and held to the convicn as firmly as I cd, that, in all undertakings whatsoever, a man, at the last strict balance of accounts, will find he has got, out of the undertaking, just what amount of good he himself managed to put it into it. Just so much, I always think,—if he can count “good” in contradistinctn to nuggets, celebratns c c;—no more, but also no less. This is all I had to say at prest.Ward replied, 1 Aug.: “very doubtful would the issue be of anything else than that which your most wise well considered letter now advises That I take to determinates. / It is to me a horrid detestable determination that is clenched to night for hope formularised for the first time. … They say you must love to succeed in a thing. I believe as much good profit may be got out of hating provided it be intense enough, mine has been somewhat vigorous towards this particular thing in its time, though now flowing drubbed and silent. / As for the enterprise I am upon I do not look to find any solid pleasure in it, even with the best good speed attending. For a long time I have felt as one who has bidden farewell to pleasure, the truer that feeling proves the happier in a certain sense am I, the less my own will tempts the easier tis to walk by the lantern of the ‘ought to be.’”

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: TC began to keep a journal again, 1 Aug.: “Augt 1st, 1866.— Spent the day in sorting (some fine things of hers still discovered; put by in Box): settled with Forster (last of Haddington duties, and solacts, then?) Wrote to C. A. Ward, ingens, serious yg man, bent on spreading himself out into trade-success (under very peculiar circs), well, then?—walked, in the tepid but airy streets, rain having blown quite away” (TC’s journal; privately owned).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAF, 2 Aug. Pbd: Waldo H. Dunn, “Carlyle’s Last Letters to Froude,” The Twentieth Century 159 (Jan. 1956): 47–49. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:325.
div3.head: TC TO J. A. FROUDE

docBody.p:
David LaingDavid Laing, Edinburgh antiquary, old friend of TC and his assessor during his rectorship of Edinburgh University; see 43:38–39TC to DL, 16 [15] Nov. 1865
. For the 1862 portrait of David Laing by William Fettes Douglas (1822–91; ODNB), see above. of Edinburgh was here the other evening, indeed two different evenings; and regretted considerably that he could not see you. I find the good man has actually a kind of interest in that Spanish Letter about James IV,In his supplement to his edition of The Poems of William Dunbar, Laing quoted a letter from Don Pedro de Ayala (d. 1513), a Spanish diplomat at the court of James IV (1473–1513; ODNB), king of Scotland, dated 25 July 1498, containing a full description of the king (Poems of William Dunbar [Edinburgh, 1834, supp. 1865] 1:266–71); see 43:136TC to DL, 15 March. more than I was aware of. The first night, he said he was for the Record Office, at any rate, and could then see it, did see it accordingly, but had to report, on the second evening, that parts of it were in cipher, unknown to him, and that he could get no good of it whatever. The thing he wanted was some translated notice about King James’s beard,—notice which your friend Bergenroth (?)TC’s question mark; Gustav Adolph Bergenroth (1813–69; ODNB), historian. can alone furnish him, in the circumstances. As Laing himself experienced no difficulty whatever in getting at the Berganroth Copy, and
Bergenroth no doubt knows the cipher—it really might be useful, and worth all the trouble, if Bergenroth could be induced to go [to]Inserted in printed text. the Record Office some day, and make a complete completely legible copy, for benefit of Laing, of me, of you too perhaps and of all the world.The encrypted letter, located in the Simancas archive in Spain, had been decoded and translated by Bergenroth in Calendar of Spanish Letters, Despatches, and State Papers, relating to the Negotiations between England and Spain; preserved in the archives at Simancas and Elsewhere, 2 vols. (1862), from where Laing took his quotations. In the letter Ayala noted that James “never cuts his hair or his beard. It becomes him very well” (Bergenroth 1:169); perhaps Laing found further material in the Public Records Office which he thought might corroborate this information, and which required Bergenroth’s expertise in decoding. If Bergenroth is a man to whom money can be offered for such a service, I will gladly pay him for whatever pains he takes.

figure.p:
David Laing, by William Fettes Douglas, 1862
Courtesy of the National Portrait Gallery of Scotland

docBody.p: Laing’s question about the beard is not so insignificant as it seems. I shewed him what I reckoned a very curious Medal (Picture of one, with excellent Dissertation, in my always excellent Köhler,Johann David Köhler, Wöchentlich herausgegebener historischer M√ºnz-Belustigung (N√ºrnberg, 1729–50) 17:393; TC’s copy: HCC. For Köhler’s illustration of the medal, see above. by far the first of German Historians, tho’ now forgotten); Medal struck just before the Battle of Flodden,The Battle of Flodden, 9 Sept. 1513, where James IV was defeated by an English army led by Thomas Howard (1443–1524; ODNB), earl of Surrey. while Henry VIII was conquering in the Netherlands,Henry VIII (1491–1547; ODNB), king of England, and Maximilian I (1459–1519), Holy Roman Emperor, were fighting the French, mostly in NE France, May—Oct. 1513; one of the most significant engagements was the siege of Tournai, in the Netherlands, from early Sept. to 23 Sept. 1513, when it fell to the forces of Henry VIII.—intended seeming[ly]Inserted in printed text. as a kind of Leading (properly Mis-Leading Article in the Newspaper, by James):James’s profile is on one side of the medal, on the other side James’s two-faced head, facing Janus-like both England and France, is on a column that was placed on a rock in the sea. James wanted to honor his existing treaties and obligations with both France and England, which were at war with each other, and the medal was a public statement projecting himself as a statesman able to deal with both. The medal may not have been contemporary.—and in this medal (what appeared to be Laing’s one interest in it), James is pictured as a handsome enough fellow clean-shaven.James did have a beard until the day after his marriage, 8 Aug. 1503, to Margaret Tudor (1489–1541; ODNB), sister of Henry VIII, when two of her retinue, Agnes, b. Tilney (d. ca. 1545), countess of Surrey, and her step-da. Muriel, Lady Gray, shaved his beard off, for which they were rewarded with £180 worth of cloth of gold (Accounts of the Lord High Treasurer of Scotland, ed. Sir James Balfour Paul [Edinburgh, 1900] 2:314). The countess was the 2d wife of Thomas Howard, earl of Surrey, who later defeated James at Flodden. “Totally wrong,” answers Laing; can half-prove it by some hint he has got elsewhere, and would fain whole-prove it from the Bergenroth letter.

figure.p:
Medal of James IV of Scotland
Johann David Köhler, Wöchentlich herausgegebener historischer Münz-Belustigung (Nurnberg. 1729–50)
Courtesy of Edinburgh University Library, Special Collections Department

docBody.p:
Perhaps, too (which would be welcome to me) he may be able to prove the unauthenticity of that shocking tale of dead body wrapt in lead, which old StoweJohn Stow (1525?—1605; ODNB), A Survey of London (1598); describing St. Michael’s Church, Cripplegate, Stow wrote: “There is also (but without any outward monument) the head of James, the fift [sic] king of Scots of that name, slaine at Flodden field, and buried here by this occasion. After the battaile the bodie of the said king being founde, was closed in lead, and conveyed from thence to London, and so to the Monasterie of Sheyne in Surrey, where it remained for a time, in what order I am not certaine: but since the dissolution of that house, in the raigne of Edward the sixt, Henry Gray, Duke of Suffolke, being lodged, and keeping house there: I have beene sheined the same bodie so lapped in lead, close to the head and bodie, throwne into a waste roome amongst the old timber, leade, and other rubble” (Stow, Survey of London 238). saw in the Ex-Monastery of East Sheen.A priory for Carthusian monks was founded, 1414, in Sheen, Richmond; it was dissolved, 1539, during the reign of Henry VIII.And beard was sticking thro’ the lead there;—and in the Picture at Taymouth, I think the beard is black.In two letters to David Laing, 1854, in which TC discussed the possible setting up of an exhibition of Scottish Historical Portraits, he recommended the inclusion of the portrait of James IV then to be found at Taymouth Castle, Perth; see 29:81TC to DL, 2 May 1854, and 87TC to DL, 3 May 1854. However most of the contents of Taymouth Castle were sold in the early 20th century, and the portrait is untraced. There is one portrait of James in the Scottish National Portrait Gallery, Edinburgh, and several in the National Portrait Gallery, London, but in all of them James is clean shaven. Laing has little belief in that or any of the Pictures, thinks them all copies c, c. But it is possible Bergenroth’s Spaniard may give us the beard’s colour as well; and thereby might chance to contradict the too shocking story in Stowe.Stow continued: “Since the which time workemen there for their foolish pleasure, hewed off his head: and Launcelot Young at this present mayster Glazier to her Majestie, feeling a sweet savour to come from thence, and seeing the same dryed from all moisture, and yet the forme remayning, with the hayre of the heade, and beard red, brought it to London to his house in Woodstreet, where for a time he kept it for the sweetnesse, but in the end caused the Sexton of that church to burie it amongst other bones, taken out of their charnell, c.” (Stow, Survey of London 238). Presumably the hair of both head and beard had continued to grow for a while after death. For, it seems (as my Köhler reminds me), there were no fewer than 12 or 11 other persons all dressed out like the King before the Battle opened; and the last thing that was testified to of James was that his Page saw him ride across the Tweed at nightfall, and vanish in the darkness over there.There were many stories as to what became of James IV after the battle, including that there were several men dressed like the king, both to confuse the enemy and to prevent the soldiers despairing if they saw the king slain; that the king was seen crossing the river Tweed, the border between Scotland and England; and that he was seen on the evening after the battle in Kelso, and then went on pilgrimage; see Norman MacDougall, James IV (Edinburgh, 1989) 298–300. So that
it must have been one of the false Eleven that the English go[t], and carried home in a sack (proh pudor [for shame]!)— It also appears the English made no chase at Flodden; and didn’t know till next morning that the victory (talis qualis [of such kind]) was theirs.

On the whole, I think you had better take up James yourself, and let us see clearly both about him and his famed lamentable Flodden,—concerning which latter, I am told, a capital Book, fruit of long study inspection, by the now Parson of that Parish in Northumberland—BookRobert Jones, The Battle of Flodden Field, Fought September 9, 1513 (Edinburgh, 1864); Rev. Dr. Jones was vicar of Branxton, Northumberland, near the site of the battle. that is to be sent me shortly.— A very pretty Historical Essay, if you care to take it up. I think, at all events, the Spanish Letter (literally translated, Spanish words occasionally given) ought to be printed in Fraser.— Enough, enough!

The same day I directed Ruskin where to get your address;—has he not written to you on that “Periodical” we (or at least I) were once talking of?For the speculation about a journal during July, see TC to LLA, 21 July
. Froude recalled later: “Politics, philosophy, literature, were rushing on faster than ever in the direction which [Carlyle] most disliked. He sketched a scheme for a journal in which there was to be a running fire of opposition to all that. I and Ruskin were to contribute, and it might have come to something if all three of us had been willing, which it appears we were not” (Froude, Carlyle 4:325).
I did not find him bite very ardently, on my first or on this second mention of the Project; nor do I know what you can well answer him. Nor am I to be much or perhaps at all considered in it,—I, alas, alas!— But the thing will have to be done, one day, I am well of opinion; tho’ by whom, or how, which of us can say.

I send many kind regards to Mrs Froude;Henrietta Elizabeth Froude. hope you are all getting good of your sea-breezes,The Froudes were probably in Devon, where they often went in the summer. and thankfully enjoying the good that is for you. Since you left, I am perhaps a trifle more silent; but possibly that is no real derangement, possibly that too may be good for me.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2 Aug. MS: NLS 526.41. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I got yr two Letters; and was glad to hear you had arrived safe, and especially that Jean Jamie were in a better way than you had feared.John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 30 July, reporting his safe arrival at Dumfries; he continued: “I found Jean still in bed with the remains of her tic, but she seems to be almost quite well now requires only a dose of medicine wh I have prescribed for her which she is to take without delay. Young James of Scotsbrig was here … said his father was better.” Jean certainly has had an ugly tussle, of some kind, for the 10 days past;— if it be “wet feet,” she certainly ought to take a great deal more of care! I shall not be satisfied till her bit of Sunday Letter come to me as before.— Jamie of Scotsbrig doesn’t write, perhaps, because in my Note to him I spoke of yr being there perhaps in a day’s time after the arrival of that. I shd like to hear more punctually that Jamie is in a better way, too.

I didn’t forget the Robt Welsh Letter;Either JWC’s deceased paternal uncle Robert Welsh, solicitor, or his son Robert, also now deceased; see 43:230TC to JCA, 14 May; precise contents of letter unknown.—here at any rate it is, for yr keeping or Adamson’s.Samuel Adamson, British Linen Co. Bank. Dumfries, where TC had an account. Perhaps there is no need of going into “Clare Constat”“Clare Constat”: term in Scots law regarding the requirement of a feudal superior to confirm the inheritance of land, by this time usually a mere formality. Craigenputtoch came to JWC when her father d. intestate, 1819; in 1824 she settled it upon her mother for life, at the same time making a will bequeathing the property to TC, if he survived her (see 3:352 JBW to GW, [19 July 1825], and 354 JBW to TC, 19 July [1825]). TC noted the finding of the will at Dumfries, 31 May; see 43:233–34TC to WDO, 19 June. In his Reminiscences TC wrote, 7 June: “Will found … after some difficulty, since her own departure, and the death of any Welsh to whom she could have wished me to bequeath it. To my kindred it has no relation, nor shall it go to them. … ‘Bursaries’ had come into my own head, when we heard that poor final young Welsh was in consumption; but to her I never mentioned it … and how I have only hypothesis and guess” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 102). The “final young Welsh” was JWC’s cousin Robert Welsh, who d. shortly after JWC; TC wrote, 25 May: “A notable kindred to our own time,—the last—the last male of whom has died since her (was to have been the heir of Craigenputtock:—tho’ now, How shall it be according to her probable wish?)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 74). See also 2:305JBW to EA, 8 March [1823]. at
all just now, or till they speak?Apparently after JWC’s death, an unidentified relative made a claim to Craigenputtoch: “[T]he man who believed himself to be the ‘heir-at-law’ of Mrs. Carlyle, a nameless distant relative, wanted to grab the estate at Craigenputtock, and set an Edinburgh lawyer to work to ‘assert his title.’ … In virtue of [JWC’s will] the title to Craigenputtock was Carlyle’s. The lawyer of the ‘heir-at-law’ expressed satisfaction, and did nothing further” (Wilson, Carlyle 6:94). At any rate that is the rule of settling with them: I think their demand was (to whh Mr Donaldson,Alexander “Sandy” Donaldson (ca. 1787–1840) was the Welsh family lawyer in Haddington; see 12:159TC to JAC, 3 June 1840 ; perhaps his practice was being continued by a relative, unidentified further. seemed passive, resourceless), “£200”! Divide by 10 for the ansr to it.— A valuable little Doct.

Since the “Valuer”Possibly David Paterson (ca. 1825–85), listed in 1861 Dumfriesshire Census as “Cattle dealer”; otherwise unidentified. John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 8 Aug.: “The letter of Mr. R. Welsh was at once handed over to Adamson’s care, I called today to enquire if the valuation had been made. Mr. Paterson was to have gone yesterday to make it, but the morning was very wet stormy so that he could not start. It will be made, he says, the very first favourable day that occurs.” is at it, I wish he cd get done! Waste of time is, to me, a very serious and importunate expenditure in these months. if after the Valuer has done, Jamie cared to go up and have his sayTC’s intention was to lease Craigenputtoch to his brother James; see 43:18TC to JC, 18 Oct. 1865 ; this was finally achieved in Dec.; see TC to JC, 7 Dec. (in fact he will have to do so, for his own sake, soon),—it might be well; and the sooner, the better, not the worse.TC wrote “not the worse.” above “the better.” But let him take completely his own mind in the matter.—— I whispered nothing abt the “Bridge” at Scotsbrig;Meaning unclear; possibly John A. Carlyle was offering a bridge loan to Jamie to enable him to acquire the lease of Craigenputtoch; or possibly he was offering to repair the bridge at Scotsbrig, which he had been instrumental in getting built 1846; see 20:124TC to JAC, 18 Feb. 1846, and 21:7TC to JWC, 8 Aug. 1846. but you know what I think abt it,—that it is pity yr geners offer abt it shd go to the winds.

Laing came monday Evg, and regretted much not to find you. Was off, next day, by Oxford, Cambridge c, home.— — We have had cold wet, and have now warm do in quantity;—in blinks, very fine tepidly windy, grayish-sunshiny weather.
Excuse this paper; it is withal the kind I can write best on,—and is of the size of my hurry. With kindest regards to everybody c,

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady SM [LASM], 6 Aug. MS: Glasgow City Archives (Maxwell of Pollock). Lady Anna Maria Stirling Maxwell, b. Leslie-Melville (ca. 1825–74).
div3.head: TC TO LADY ANNA STIRLING MAXWELL

docBody.p: I return many thanks for the Photograph;Apparently a photograph of a portrait that Lady Stirling Maxwell believed to be of her ancestor, Alexander Leslie (see n.2). and really feel much obliged by yr great kindness in calling here the other day to leave it for me,—when I was so unfortunate as not to see you.

In the first place, this figure is that of a fattish stout and rather big man. Secondly, he is not in armour, as a distinguished soldier in that time shd have been. Thirdly his ruff seems rather Elizabethan, or at least Jacobian than of the mode of Charles I, when a band, or Vandyke tippet,—band most commonly, whh is nothing but a large shirt-collar folded back,—was the usual wear. Fourthly, he has not, to my memory, the least resemblance to the contemporaneous Prints I have seen of “Alexandr Leslie” the then famous “Feldmarshall.” One, a very coarse woodcut, I have in this house, in a Book called Rycraft’s Champions;Josiah Ricraft, A Survey of Englands Champions, and Truths faithfull Patriots (1647) 6–12; TC’s copy: HCC. For the portrait of Leslie, see above. but I cd not dig it up that night or since; nor indeed is it worth much. These are sad consideratns on the per contra side;—and, on the whole, as matters stand, I dare not believe!

figure.p:
General Alexander Leslie, 1st earl of Leven
© National Portrait Gallery, London

docBody.p: Pardon all this discussn; whh I by no means meant to enter into, but was seduced by old memories. Let me wish you, both my old friend yr Ladyship, a happy Autumn at Keir,—and that all may go well with you there or elsewhere.

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: Ruskin drove to Chelsea, 5 Aug., and walked over Clapham Common with TC and then had him to dinner, along with “T. Richmond” (Ruskin’s Diaries 2:596). T. Richmond was presumably Thomas Richmond Jr. (1820–74), portrait painter, brother of Ruskin’s friend George Richmond (1809–96; ODNB).

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 8 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Yr second letter came, a week ago,—Letter in ansr to the ZermattZermatt, village in Valais, central Switzerland. one;—so that I have now Two to acknowledge;Lady Ashburton wrote 23 July and 29 July. and must testify that I am much obliged by yr great kindness and punctuality.

There has nothing New occurred here,—a paltry little cold, caught ten days ago, and refusing to go for good during the damp windy times of “Lammas Flood,”Lammas Day, 1 Aug., often heralding several days of rain; see 3:368TC to JBW, 10 Aug. 1825, or 34:121TC to [RMA?], 12 Aug. 1858. is not worth noting as news; the rather, as I persist for Ripple and my fortnight of sea-bathing,Caroline Davenport Bromley had invited TC for a fortnight’s sea-bathing at her house near Dover; see TC to JC, 30 July. on Monday next (13th–27th), and all other parts of my treaty with you remain unaltered, and confirmed by yr acceptance.Lady Ashburton wrote, 29 July, from Rigi Kaltbad, a resort in the canton of Lucerne, the Swiss Alps: “I fully hope to be at Melchet the end of August—for some little time— if I thought there was any hope of your spending a good part of the winter with me at Seaton, I shd be tempted to remain in England.” At
the beginning of Septr, if all go well, you will find me either here, or still at Ripple, if that suit you better. I intend a day or two of Melchet, and to learn definitely what are yr arrangts; then to settle for my Winter existence the best I can. Miss Welsh leaves this a day or two after me; but will come agn if I like: she is really a well-bred, correct, attentive honourable creature; sits whole evgs silent if I wish it, and is always cheerful, punctual helpful. Has done me a great deal of good in searching thro’ the Affairs of the Past. I have been at that, day after day, all summer; at all hours, in a sacred, sad quasi-religious kind of company with Her who has left me forever: this has been the far best solace I have had;TC had been collecting, reading, and annotating JWC’s letters; see vol. 43 and July letters. and with it, in genl , I have preferred to be left alone when permitted. I still look out into the future, asking if any work yet remains to
me? This is the grand questn; and if this fall out negative— But I sometimes hope it will not quite; tho’ the Ansr is still evidtly a goodish way off.

I am much grieved to hear of yr manifold vexatns, impediments embarrassts, and this, too, on a field where they might so easily have been spared! It strikes me and all yr friends, however, that there is but one cure: To plant yrself down at Melchet so soon as possible, then begin conquering the problem,—whh, in all likelihood, will prove ten times more conquerable than yr haunted imaginatn now represents it to be! For example, cd not you at once, or after a month or two, decide to live at Melchet with whatever degree of “economy” you liked to fix,—more economically, one wd think, than anywhere else in the world;Lady Ashburton wrote, 29 July: “for since I wrote last—I have heard more of the state of my affairs, which shows me how desirable for another 12 months is Economy on my part— abroad I live for less than half what I spend in England— The American trustees refuse to acknowledge Bingham’s will as valid in America, therefore refuse to send me one penny— Melchet will be cheaper in the end I am told, if it is not allowed to lawyer any longer—but the material part of the work be done by Christmas—to accomplish this, I must produce a large sum of money which I must borrow. … All this as you can imagine, is very harassing— only the hope of being of use to you, having the blessing delight of your companionship, would make me undertake English life English housekeeping”; for the terms of Lord Ashburton’s will, see 40:113–14TC to LLA, 5 June 1864. and with many over-and-aboves still more precious for the dear little Bairn and her Mamma? I always think so; but will say no more till we are prest on the spot.

Seaton I dare not think of; the scene there wd be full of sadness to me,—all gone preternatural since the Spring gone a year.Lady Ashburton’s house, Seaforth Lodge, Seaton, in Devon, where TC and JWC stayed 8 March–3 April 1865; see vol. 41. Besides it is too far away. Melchet and its possibilities I will examine into carefully, gratefully; and surely shall not, willingly, forego altogether the benefict bounties that lie funded for me there beyond most other places now left!— — I have even, in some moments, been thinking of MentoneMenton, French resort on the Mediterranean, near the border with Italy, where Lady Ashburton intended to rent a villa for the winter. The Italian form of its name, Mentone, was generally used by TC, Lady Ashburton, and the English people TC was to meet there. Menton is the French form; a plebiscite voted for the annexation of Menton from Monaco to France, 1860. J. Henry Bennet wrote in 1861 (and kept in all the subsequent extended editions): “Mentone has become Menton, a French town, but I have retained the Italian denomination, because it was the one by which I first knew this smiling spot, and because I prefer the word” (Bennet, Mentone and the Riviera as a Winter Climate [1861] vi). for a couple of the dark months this winter, in case all else go awry. But the awful expense of railway, with its inevitable torment and injury to nerves; then the idle foreign element, do food, do noises, do c c: prudence resolutely shuts down the lid agn, whispering hoarsely, “You fool, you fool!”——

This is too long a Letter; I will write no more till you get to Engld;—¬≠London will be quiet for you, almost as the Rigi itself; Beales, Bright, Gladstone, Russell co all sunk silent,Edmond Beales, John Bright, William Gladstone, and Earl Russell, Liberal prime minister 1865–66; all vociferously in favor of the Liberal government’s Reform Bill. The bill was defeated, 18 June, and the government resigned 26 June; see 43:239TC to LLA, 21 June. and Hyde-Park all new-fenced with a cost of plank.The defeat of the Reform Bill led to several large public demonstrations in Trafalgar Square; when the new Conservative government tried to suppress the meetings, an even larger event was held in Hyde Park, 23 July, resulting in the iron railings being broken down; see 32. Presumably temporary fencing was then put up. The History of Engld appears to me to get baser and baser every day. And whether we have yet got to the lowest may still be questionable;—tho’, in good moments, I do see symptoms, or fancy I do, of people here there beginning to look round with some wonder.

figure.p:
“The Mob Pulling Down the Railings in Park-Lane”
Illustrated London News, 4 August 1866

docBody.p: The Prussn contrast with all this beggary, how bright! No public news for 40 years has pleased me so much as this of Germany in the last two months.The Austro-Prussian War, or the Seven Weeks’ War, June—July, resulted in the annexation by Prussia of many states previously under Austrian control and the establishment of a federation of North German States under Prussian leadership. Most unexpected astonishing to everybody here; not to me, in itself at all, for I have been prophesying it half a life-time; but did not expect we shd yet see it perhaps 50 years. BismarckOtto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck, influential adviser to Wilhelm I (1797–1888), king of Prussia; his aim was to unite all Germany under Prussian leadership. has had my clear vote (so far as I had light for voting), this long while; and now he is getting everybody’s, here too,—strange to see the faces obliged to be made, the coats obliged to turn themselves. Bk, I take it, is probably the one Statesman now alive in Europe; and if so, I bless Heaven for him.— If you shd fall in with any Book elucidation of him his past course— But doubtless there is none? Bring us his best Photograph at any rate.— — with with blessings on the bonny little Bairn youWord repeated at turn of page with a line over it.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, [ca. 10 Aug.]. MS: NLS 518.35. Hitherto unpbd. Dated approximately by TC’s departure for Dover, 13 Aug.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Sister,—I go off on Monday, by the 12 o’clock train (Victoria statn; am to arrive at Dover, 4.30, and be driven for an hour thereafter;—“home,” therefore, a while before six). The place is called Ripple-Court; my good Hostess’s
name (good gracious, and even polite and elderly-handsome, but very dull to me) is Miss Davenport, Bromley: But the suffict Address will be “Ripple-Court, Dover”: and I hope some of you, John or you, or both, will send me a bit of Letter on Sunday, to give me welcome there.

The weather is grown cold for sea-bathing (whh nevertheless I must attempt), “good sea abt 2 miles off;”—and I own I rather scunner at my outlook for that inane fortnight; but will try to do my wisest in the circs, can reflect always that 14 days do not last forever. Perhaps the worst is, I have caught in the late blustery damp time, a perceptible snatch of cold (whh however seems to be abating); and I am slightly below par in point of health, tho’ not so bad as you often enough saw me last summer. But I can ill afford any deficit in that respect, other things being as they are.

Miss Welsh is to go for Liverpool c 2 days after my departure;Maggie Welsh left 15 Aug.; she was going to Liverpool to visit her brother Alexander’s family before returning home to Auchtertool, Fife. Jessie the servant, for Thornhill (to be married shortly),Jessie Hiddleston (1835–1904; see 43:271–72 43:biographical notes), the Carlyles’ maid 1865–66; she m. 7 Dec., Robert Broadfoot in Edinburgh. Jessie later described her last meeting with TC to D. A. Wilson: “I went upstairs to his room to say good-bye. … He had not needed to give me any written character as I was not going into service again. He was in bed, resting on an elbow. We talked about everything, and I realised it was for ever, and was sorry I had thought of going away, and cried and said I would like to stay. He smoothed back my hair and kissed me on the forehead and made me feel very proud of myself, saying,—‘I don’t know your intended husband, Jessie, but you’ll get a good husband if he’s as clever a man as the wife he’s getting is a woman. You have been very kind to me and I shall miss you much.’ / My crying affected him too—we were thinking of everything. At last he said, ‘I’m just going away on some visits, and in strangers’ houses I’ll not miss you so much as if I were staying at home.’ / So I was comforted and went downstairs and departed, though sorry to go” (Wilson, Carlyle 6:94–95). perhaps a day earlier; and Painters,Oliver Pitts, plumber and glazier, 15 Lombard St., Chelsea; TC recorded in his checkbook: “8 Septr 1866 / to Oliver Pitts (the Painter) / £11 .. 8 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). under Mrs Warren’s eye,Mrs. Sarah Warren, TC’s cook and housekeeper. are to occupy the first week of my absence. I shall have to expect Lady Ashburton abt the time of my return hither, and have promised her “a day or two at Melchet” (her place in the country); after whh I shall be free agn, and must know what I mean to do thro’ the winter. Ah me, ah me!—— Yrs ever affecte

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 13 Aug. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N. B. PM: Dover, 13 Aug. 1866. MS: NLS 526.42. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:95. TC wrote on Ripple Court headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.dateline: Ripple Court / Ringwould / Dover Monday, 13 Augt / 1866
docBody.p: My dear Brother,—I got yr kind Note this morning, whh was very kind indeed, as well as Jean’s; and much obliged to both of you.

I arrived here, safe and less unhappy much than I might have been, about an hour ago (4 p.m. was the time; Dover was at 3 p.m. as you said,John A. Carlyle wrote, 12 Aug.: “I am sorry that I don’t happen to be at hand to go with you to Victoria Station. … You have only to bid your cabman drive straight to the place where the Dover train starts then be sure that you get into a carriage which goes the whole way to Dover. No later train would suit you so well as the 12 o’clock one, I think you ought to arrive at Dover about 3 p.m.” as I had bethot me soon after the note to Jean): nothing went wrong with me at all; the day was of the very best, the country, once one got rid of the chaotic horrors of London, was old England all out, whh to me is the highest known form of rural desirability, and peaceable modest beauty: hop-gardens, woods, clean verdant meadows, people all in the heart of their harvesting,—it was positively a kind of medicine to my sick, depressed and sorrowful heart. The Carriage c was punctually waiting; in five minutes I was safe across Dover, climbing the Castle Hill, by a route new to me, and a country whh I cd not recognise one yard of, after an abeyance of 42 years. In autumn 1824 or ’5, with Mrs Strachey, Edwd IrvingTC visited Dover, Oct. 1824, with Edward Irving, his wife, Isabella, b. Martin (1797–1854), and their infant son; Julia Strachey, b. Kirkpatrick (1791–1847), and her husband, Edward Strachey (1774–1832; ODNB ); and Julia’s cousin Catherine Aurora “Kitty” Kirkpatrick (1802–89); see 3:165–67 TC to JCE, 4 Oct. 1824
, and 171 TC to JBW, 5 Oct. 1824
. c—ah me, how much has come and gone since that! But the scene, as yet entirely rural, seemed to have lost nothing of it[s] beauty: the solitary drive was superlative; I do not think the Queen had such a one today,Queen Victoria was staying at Osborne House, Isle of Wight; the Times, 14 Aug., reported: “The Queen … embarked yesterday afternoon on board the Royal yacht Alberta … and steamed through Spithead.”—as, most certainly, she had nothing like such a cigar (one of those Ruskin gave me)!Ruskin’s father, John James Ruskin, had often sent TC boxes of cigars, and apparently John Ruskin continued doing so; see 41:175TC to JRU, 22 Feb. 1865.—I am also very much improved by a bit of excellt bread butter with a do glass of sherry, whh will enable me to await dinner at 7 with composure of stomach at least!—

Miss Bromley is the hospitablest of women (in intentn hitherto in actn); her place is quiet as Hades;—and she has (miracle to speak of!) actually bot some kind of pony-cob; I really believe, chiefly or altogether for my use here.
I have little doubt I shall do better than I expected here.—— Better add RingwouldRingwould, one of the villages close to Ripple Court. (whh is Post Office) to the address I gave. With my blessings brotherly regards to Jean you

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 16 Aug. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N. B. PM: Dover, 16 Aug. 1866. MS: NLS 526.43. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote on Ripple Court headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I think you wd get my former Note on Tuesday evg, and will probably get this on Friday, still in time for southern post.— — I wish you to write at once to “Mr Quiller, Chemist, Sloane Square,” a recipe for a dozen of those pills whh I labelled “Hop,”Charles Rowett Quiller (1829–71), pharmacist, 15 Sloane Sq.; TC often used hop pills to treat sleeplessness; see 41:71 TC to JAC, [ca. 12 Oct. 1864] . and urge him to be punctual in despatching them hither by the Post of saturday evg; whh will land them at Ringwold for me next morning.

I have had two beautiful rides,—one of them this day before the rain began,—I also after some industry and inquiry, found, yesterday, a nice place for bathing, had there an unexceptionable bathe;—but, alas, alas, what availeth all that, my sleep c being as it is! I must not give up, if I can at all help it (no, I wont!)—but the look of things, this day especially, is towards bankruptcy, wd I allow it. Sadder I have never been than in these environments, with not even no society, but with e.g. DasentGeorge Webbe Dasent (1817–96; ODNB ), Scandinavian scholar and translator; see 42:85 TC to JCA, 15 June 1865
; he also worked on the Times, 1845–70, and was knighted, 1876; his wife, m. 1846, was Fanny Louisa, b. Delane, and they had two sons and one da. Caroline Bromley reported to Lady Louisa Ashburton, 29 Aug.: “Today the whole Dasent family are come to stay a week or so with me. It will indeed be living among the Pigmies after Carlyle, but nearly everybody would appear small insignificant after living with him” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). The Dasents also came for dinner, 16 Aug.; see below. other plainly minus quantities for such. But in effect the root of the matter is dyspepsia and consequt want of sleep:TC wrote in his journal: “Wednesday 15 Aug t, Ripple Court (near Walmer, Dover, Miss Davenport Bromley’s temporary rural House).— Arrived here day before yesterday, beautiful sunny day in the midst of wet windy ones,—solitude and green country, spotted with autumn colours and labours, mournfully welcome to me, after the dreary sadness and unwelcome interruptions to my poor labours at Chelsea, whh, alas, were nothing more or better than the sorting, labelling, tying up in bundles all that is now left me of Her that is gone. I had taken cold too; and was abundantly dispirited and sad of heart.— Was in this country once, now forty-two years ago, remember a Sunday of wandering between Dover and here with Edwd Irving Mr. Strachey:—what a flight of Time!— My project here was 14 days of solitude and sea-bathing. Hitherto, except a very long sleep (not of the healthiest) last night, almost all has gone rather awry with me;—heart sadder than ever. ‘Horse is at the door!’—stop!— / 16 Augt. Had a beautiful ride yesterday, a tolerable bathe, plenty of walking, driving, c, and imagined I was considerably improving myself: but, alas, in the evng came the Dasents, and a dinner; amounting to total wreck of sleep to me,—got up at 3 a.m., sat reading till 6, c;—and except a ride (good enough in it itself, but far from ‘pleasant’ in my state of nerves and heart) have had a day of desolate misery, the harder to bear as it is useless too, and results from a ‘visit,’ whh I cd have avoided, had I been skilful. Past 5 p.m. now; and no method clear to me, of escaping a fate like that of last night. Oh my lost one, oh, my lost one—irrecoverable to my lonely heart forever! Silence at any rate” (text: TC’s journal; pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:327 inc.).—be prompt therefore in giving Quiller his orders.
With best regards to everybody

div3.sourceNote: TC-BWP, 17 Aug. Typescript copy: The Free Library of Philadelphia. Quot: John Clubbe, Froude’s Life of Carlyle (1979) 667; Kaplan 481. Bryan Waller Procter (“Barry Cornwall”) (1787–1874; ODNB ; see 33:biographical notes), poet and lawyer; known to TC since; see TC to JBW, 23 June 1824 ; see also Carlyle, Reminiscences 290–91. Alexander Ireland (1810–94; ODNB ) wrote on the typescript: “Mrs Procter showed me on 17 Jan y 1882, the original of letter.— It is dated 17th August 1866. / (?) Riffle [Ripple] Court / Ringwould, Dover.”
div3.head: TC TO B. W. PROCTER

docBody.p: I have been reading your book on Charles Lamb,B. W. Procter, Charles Lamb: A Memoir (1866); the Examiner, 11 Aug., described it as “one of the good books of our time, a charming addition to the province of biography in English literature.” in the solitary silent regions whither I had fled for a few days of dialogue with Mother Earth and her elements, and I have found in your work something so touching, brave, serene, and pious, that I cannot but write you one brief word of recognition,—which I know you will receive with welcome; all the more as I especially forbid you to bother yourself with answering it.
No answer to this; I already forbade you. Take it as an interjection; written merely for solace of my own poor heart. And so, good be with you, dear old friend.—
With many kind remembrances to Mrs. Procter.Procter’s wife, m. 1824, was Anne Benson, b. Skepper (1799–1888).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 22 Aug. MS: NLS 526.44. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:96; Surtees, Ludovisi 124. TC wrote on Ripple Court headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I got yr Letter with the salutary inclosure,TC asked John A. Carlyle for a prescription for hop pills to be sent direct to Charles Quiller, the pharmacist in Chelsea; see TC to JAC, 16 Aug.; perhaps Quiller sent the pills to John for forwarding. on Sunday morning (we have only one Mail here); and could not but thank you for such industry and promptitude on my behalf. Yr readiness and eagerness at all times to be of help to me,—this, you may depend on it, is a thing I am always well aware of, at the bottom of all my impatiences and discontents. Jean’s Note came yesterday morning, whh was also a kindness to me, and was welcome reading in the silence of the early fields.

I am now better than when I wrote last; and calculate on finishing my term here, on supportable terms; but look forward to Monday night my own bed agn as still the desirable haven. Miss Bromley’s hospitable kindness and politeness towards me are beyond all bounds: yesterday, for instance, in spite of all I cd say, she overset her whole household arrangt for me,—insisting she wd herself dine with me “at 3 p.m.” (whh was highly unnecessary), and did so, and will continue to do it most likely while I remain; dining on Monday, for the first time agn, at 8!— I did sleep last night better than I have ever done hitherto, tho’ still not quite eminently well. The place is beautifully silent, but
also vacant to me; and has a character of Hades, whh is the complexn my own thots generally have.

Lady Ashburton has come from Switzerland, and has also gone;—back at L√ºzernLucerne; see TC to LLA, 8 Aug. this morng, if the program have held! She had some sudden call hither; and is a sudden creature: monday night last abt 11 p.m. Miss Bromley I saw her into the Calais Steamer, embarking in a tempest of discordant hurries. I had seen her for an hour in London; she shot across hither and staid over sunday monday, very communicative especially to me.

One of her grand projects was that I shd come to Mentone, and stay with her thro’ the winter, till May next, when finally she is coming home. Excellt quiet place, do house,—rooms methods, times all to oneself; beautiful “Society” too; in short it was all beautiful, and the poor Lady’s heart seemed to be set on it; so that I cd see it wd give her much pleasure that I shd consent. She even engaged volunteered to ask Maggy Welsh too, who shd screen me and pad everything into softness for me in the new scene, “Oh it wd be so beautiful,”—nay I had even to forbid her from writing at once to Maggy by way of shoving me! At first, while she was talking, the thing had some plausibility; and I did not say absolutely no, but wd consider: now, however, my thots left to themselves seem to go quite the other way; and I scunner not at the horrible 30 hours of steam jangle, but at all the other novelties incongruities. I must give it a serious consideratn, however; and ansr No (as I imagine it must be No) not unwisely but after real deliberatn. Think you of it, endeavour to compute everything; and tell me seriously. On Monday night, if you hear nothing to the contrary consider Chelsea my Address agn.— What a touching little bit of fly-leaf from Haddington ChurchyardPossibly the title page of James Miller, The Lamp of Lothian; or, the History of Haddington (Edinburgh, 1844) with its drawing of St. Mary’s Church from the river; see above; more probably an unidentified, more recent, pamphlet or leaflet. that was that you sent! Ah me, the whole world’s history has shrunk to me now into that!

figure.p:
Title page of James Miller, The Lamp of Lothian; or, the History of Haddington (1844)
Courtesy of Edinburgh University Library

docBody.p: Adieu dear Brother; I have been hurried and bothered latterly; and finish in a confusedly galloping state. Such a day for strenuous inanity, for perpetual rigid “engaget” abt nothing at all!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 23 Aug. Pbd: Sadler 295 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:96–97. TC presumably wrote on Ripple Court headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Your letter of this morning is one of the pleasantest I have had for a long time: I am very glad to know you at hand again, for I have not so much as known your address all this while,—and this is itself a pleasure which I had even from the outside of your letter. But inside, all is weird, graphic, sunny, c.; except your own horrible state of health,Neuberg wrote from Hampstead, 21 Aug.: “I came home last week, in a very feeble poorish condition, but beginning to rally now again.” which I trust is mending, nothing can be welcomer than the picture you yield. That Germany is to stand on her feet henceforth, and not be dismembered on the highway; but face all manner of Napoleons and hungry, sponging dogs, with clear steel in her hand, and an honest purpose in her heart—this seems to me the best news we or Europe have heard for the last forty years or more.Neuberg wrote: “I found Germany in a wonderful state of transformation: like on the day after a successful revolution. … [E]very town, and most railway stations I passed, were occupied by armed Prussians; with here and there parties of disarmed Austrian prisoners … a medley of Czechs, Slovaks, Croats, Hungarians c. who often did not understand each other; and physically as well as intellectually greatly inferior to their conquerors.” May the Heavens prosper it! Many thanks also for Bismarck’s photograph: he has a royal enough physiognomy, and I more and more believe him to be a highly considerable man;Neuberg wrote: “Bismarck is the hero of the day; his portraits are on all the shop windows. I send you one, if you care to have it. It is not a lovely face; but he has brought about great things. … And you have been the only one, that I know, who recognised him as ‘distinguished,’ when all the world cursed him.” This was possibly the photograph listed by Helen Allingham, 1881, as being in the back dining-room at Cheyne Row (Carlyle’s House 104). perhaps the nearest approach to a CromwellOliver Cromwell (1599–1658; ODNB), lord protector of England, Scotland, and Ireland 1653–58. that is well possible in these poor times.End of pbd. text.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 23 Aug.: MS: NLS 526.45. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—Here is a pleast Letter from Neuberg, whh perhaps you will like to read. It has come this morning;—the Bismarck Photograph you can keep till you are tired of it then send back. Nay if it were in high request with Jean or any of you, I cd agn send it for good after a little while.

My sleep is still baddish or at best so-so; and the imprisonment in thrums is by no means gratifying to me: but I have the finest horse imaginable, get a beautiful solitary ride every day:—and shall be all the gladder to get back to my own nest agn, and be out of these cobweb intricacies. Monday evg at Chelsea agn, if all go well.
Adieu, dear Brother; kind love to all.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HH, 23 Aug. Pbd: Times, 12 Sept. 1866; Eyre Defence and Aid Fund 24; Hamilton Hume, The Life of Edward John Eyre, Late Governor of Jamaica (1867) 289–90; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:239–41; John Nichol, Thomas Carlyle (1892) 203–5 inc; Workman 91–92. Quot: Wylie 297; Wilson, Carlyle 6:103; Kaplan 491.
div3.head: TC TO HAMILTON HUME

docBody.p:
The clamour raised against Governor EyreEdward John Eyre, colonial governor of Jamaica 1864–66, had put down an insurrection by the Jamaicans in Oct. 1865 with what was deemed unnecessary savagery; see 43:61TC to LLO, 2 Dec. 1865. Following the publication in June 1866 of the Royal Commission’s report on the Morant Bay rebellion (see 43:176JWC to TC, [10 April]), which commended Eyre for restoring order but criticized him for using excessive force, the British government ordered that he be removed from his post without compensation; his successor, Sir John Peter Grant (1807–93; ODNB), was appointed, 16 July, and Eyre arrived in Southampton, 12 Aug. The Jamaica Committee had been formed by a group of MPs., Dec. 1865, to explore the possibility of prosecuting Eyre for criminal action; on 9 July, after a heated debate, the chairman, Charles Buxton (1822–71; ODNB), resigned; a reconstituted Jamaica Committee was set up, 27 July, determined to prosecute Eyre for murder, with John Stuart Mill as chairman, and Thomas Huxley (1825–95; ODNB), Thomas Hughes (1822–96; ODNB), and Herbert Spencer (1820–1903; ODNB) in support. For a portrait of Eyre in the Illustrated London News, 6 April 1867, see opp.above. appears to me to be disgraceful to the good sense of England; and if it rested on any depth of conviction, and
were not rather (as I always flatter myself it is) a thing of rumour and hearsay, of repetition and reverberation, mostly from the teeth outward, I should consider it of evil omen to the country, and to its highest interests, in these times. For my own share, all the light that has yet reached me on Mr. Eyre and his history in the world goes steadily to establish the conclusion that he is a just, humane, and valiant man, faithful to his trusts everywhere, and with no ordinary faculty of executing them; that his late services in Jamaica were of great, perhaps of incalculable value, as certainly they were of perilous and appalling difficulty—something like the case of ‘fire,’ suddenly reported, ‘in the ship’s powder room,’ in mid-ocean, where the moments mean the ages, and life and death hang on your use or misuse of the moments; and, in short, that penalty and clamour are not the thing this Governor merits from any of us, but honour and thanks, and wise imitation (I will farther say), should similar emergencies rise, on the great scale or on the small, in whatever we are governing!

figure.p: Illustrated London News, 6 April 1867

docBody.p: The English nation never loved anarchy, nor was wont to spend its sympathy on miserable mad seditions, especially of this inhuman and half-brutish type; but always loved order, and the prompt suppression of seditions, and reserved its tears for something worthier than promoters of such delirious and fatal enterprises who had got their wages for their sad industry. Has the English nation changed, then, altogether? I flatter myself it has not, not yet quite; but only that certain loose, superficial portions of it have become a great deal louder, and not any wiser than they formerly used to be.

At any rate, though much averse at any time, and at this time in particular, to figure on committees, or run into public noises without call, I do at once, and feel that as a British citizen I should and must make you welcome to my name for your committee,The news of Eyre’s dismissal and the threat of his prosecution prompted widespread support for his cause, and the Eyre Testimonial and Defence Fund was formed. and to whatever good it can do you. With the hope only that many other British men, of far more significance in such a matter, will at once or gradually do the like; and that, in fine, by wise effort and persistence, a blind and disgraceful act of public injustice may be prevented, and
an egregious folly as well—not to say, for none can say or compute, what a vital detriment throughout the British Empire, in such an example set to all the colonies and governors the British Empire has.

Farther service, I fear, I am not in a state to promise; but the whole weight of my conviction and good wishes is with you, and if other service possible to me do present itself, I shall not want for willingness in case of need. Enclosed is my mite of contribution to your fund.TC’s check was incorrectly made out; Hume wrote to TC, 3 Sept.: “Will you oblige me by placing your name at the back of the enclosed cheque as you will observe that it is made payable to your order.” TC recorded in his checkbook: “6 Septr 1866 / To Hn Hume Esq. / (Eyre Defence Fund) / £5 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).
docBody.closer: I have the honour to be yours truly, / T. Carlyle.

postscript.p:
To Hamilton Hume, Esq.,
Hon. Sec. ‘Eyre Defence Fund.’

div3.sourceNote: TC-GWS, 28 Aug. Typescript copy: Houghton. Pbd: “Thomas Carlyle. Personal Reminiscences,” New York Tribune, 23 Feb. 1881; G. W. Smalley, London Letters and Some Others (1890) 291. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:97. George Washburn Smalley, American journalist who had recently arrived in London.
div3.head: TC TO GEORGE W. SMALLEY

docBody.p: If you will be so kind as come down to me tomorrow (Wedy), at 8 p.m., we will have a cup of tea together.Smalley wrote, 8 Feb. 1881: “To Mr. Emerson, to whom I owe many other things, I owe my introduction to Mr. Carlyle. On my first visit to London, fourteen years ago, I left Mr. Emerson’s letter at the door of the house in Cheyne Row, and the same evening brought me this note” (New York Tribune, 23 Feb.). The New York Tribune article (signed G. W. S.) was prompted by TC’s death, 5 Feb. 1881.

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: Smalley described his visit: “The street was, and still is, a very modest street. There is a chandler’s shop on the corner, and a laundry next door but one to Mr. Carlyle’s. So humble are the surroundings and the house itself that years afterward, when I took a … friend to call on Mr. Carlyle he looked about him in wonder as we stopped at the door, and asked half incredulously, ‘Does so great a man live in so little a house?’ A maid-servant answered the bell, and I was shown into a room on the left of the narrow passage on the ground-floor. The room was dimly lighted. A lady came forward, whom I afterward knew as Mr. Carlyle’s niece, Miss Aitken, and said in a whisper that her uncle was asleep but that he expected me and I was to wait. On the left of the door, against the wall, was a sofa, and on the sofa was Mr. Carlyle. He soon woke and I introduced myself, Miss Aitken having vanished. Now I had heard before coming to England an awkward story or two of the great writer’s odd way of receiving strangers. Americans, it was said, were less welcome than others; and though I knew very well that Mr. Emerson’s introduction was the best I could have, I was not over-confident of a cordial greeting.” The “lady” was not Mary Aitken but is unidentified: perhaps Smalley had confused his first visit, Aug. 1866, with the later one as Mary Aitken did not come to live with TC until after his visit to Dumfries, summer 1868. Emerson apparently told Smalley: “You must not be surprised if you find him inhospitable to American ideas, and perhaps to Americans” (Slater 49).“But I found that in this, as in some other points, the Carlyle of common report and the actual Carlyle were two different persons. His hearty way of saying, ‘Eh! and so you are a friend of Mr. Emerson,’ and his outstretched hand, were quite enough to put a shy man at his ease. Not even in America had I ever seen anybody to whom ordinary social usages were more obviously indifferent. It was the hour when London dines, and in order to dine arrays itself in swallow-tail and white tie. Mr. Carlyle had dined early, and the tall figure that rose from the sofa was clad in a dressing-gown of a red pattern reaching below his knees. He questioned me eagerly about Mr. Emerson. … His manner as he spoke of his American friend was gentle and affectionate. … [H]e said he usually took a walk at this hour, and would I go with him? I remembered the pouring rain and wondered if he would go out in it, but the weather was a thing to which, as I found later, he gave no thought. By the time he had put on a coat and hat and seized his big stick, it rained no longer. It was quite dark, and it had long been his habit to walk after the sun had gone down. He did not seem to care for the river and the fresh currents of air which blew freely from its banks. His steps were bent toward the quieter corners of quiet old Chelsea. … His pace was such as few men of past seventy would have cared to set; and he maintained it to the end. The stream of talk ran not less swiftly. … It was past nine when we returned. The candles had been lighted. The fire—for though it was August a fire had been kindled—blazed cheerfully. The table was spread: the tea was made and keeping hot under its Scotch cosey. … There was no detail of a life strange to him which had not some interest for him. He put all sorts of questions as he sat behind his teapot and took huge sips from his cup and munched his bread and butter and plum-cake. … Tea and questions over … [h]e sat himself down by the fireside, on the floor, his back against the jamb of the chimneypiece, took a comb out of his pocket and combed down his tangled bushy hair till it hid is forehead altogether, and you could no longer see where the hair ended and the eyebrows began. This done, he filled and lighted his pipe; a long clay pipe … known, I think, as a churchwarden; quite two feet from bowl to mouthpiece. As the perfume of the tobacco filled the room and the clouds of smoke rolled about him, he began to talk again. It was no longer talk in the common sense of the word; there were no more questions, no pauses. It was a monologue, and no small part of it sounded strangely familiar. … He had, in fact, by that time fallen into the habit of repeating orally what in days long gone he had written,—not consciously or purposely, but as if the same trains of thought came back to him; and he was content to have a listener while he thought over the old problems that had vexed him, and once more offered his solution of them. … I never had a stranger sensation than in thus hearing from the mouth of the philosopher the oral repetition of his written and printed wisdom. … When it seemed to have to come to an end I rose to take leave, and upon my telling him I was going to Berlin he asked me to come again on my return and bring him all the news of the Prussian capital” (New York Tribune, 23 Feb.; G. W. Smalley, London Letters and Some Others [1890] 292–99).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 28 Aug. MS: NLS 526.46. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:99.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I got home yesterday betn 5 6 p.m., witht any accidt,—a day not much sadder than it wd otherwise have been, by the jumbling discords of my metallic vehicle, and the tedious phenoma it provided for me. There had been, after 3 days of extreme heat, an extensive Thunderstorm (whh I did not hear) abt 4 a.m., and copious rain whh at least laid all the dust; and the Country, harvest just ending in it, was fresh and beautiful throughout, till the last 7 or 8 miles of it, whh might have challenged the created and almost the chaotic universe to produce its fellow in disgusting the sane mind not concerned in the “unexampled prosperity” now afoot. The Painters, busy outside during my absence, had all got away, their work seemingly well enough done, and their smells also gone. Mrs Warren was here assiduous, in the gaunt solitude; and was, and is, extremely attentive; but the loss of JessieSee TC to JCA, [ca. 10] Aug.
is for the prest a considerable increase of bother to me. A potential successor to her is coming, suggested by Mrs Forster who has the Sister of her these some years;Eliza Forster; the potential maid was possibly a sister of Susannah Cooper (b. ca. 1812), the Forsters’ maid listed in the 1871 census; and possibly the “Servant Helen in Chelsea” that TC mentioned in his Sept. journal; see TC to JRT, 10 Sept.
; not further identified. we shall see in a week or two (not due yet till “Septr 7”) how this new figure acts or promises.Jessie Hiddleston was apparently eventually replaced by a niece (later Mrs. Wye of Slough) of Sarah Warren; see Wilson, Carlyle 6:95. Neuberg came in the evg; and was perhaps a little less boring than usual: I have yet spoken to nobody else; but shall perhaps try ChorleyJohn Rutter Chorley. when I go out. I slept well; and upon the whole cannot but be thankful to get back to my own den, on such terms as are left me. The Town is clean airy, utterly vacant of acquaintance; and no company at all is a treasure compared with much that is offered one. Among a heap of vile post rubbish, I was glad enough to find yr Letter Jean’s. I sent you all a Manchestr Newspr, by way of sign; but doubt I was too late with it, and that this and it will come together.

Yr ideas abt Mentone are clearly stated;John A. Carlyle wrote, 24 Aug.: “I have thought a good deal about Lady Ashburton’s project of having you at Mentone during the winter, will write again more fully on the subject when I have had a little more time to consider it maturely. In the meantime I can see clearly that a winter in so clear bright a climate might be the means of doing you great good, if it could be tried on rational steady terms. In particular it might put you into such health as to enable you, when you get back, to avoid the late walks, late hours generally, into which you have been driven by circumstances which are very unnatural for a man in weak health.” Caroline Davenport Bromley wrote to Lady Ashburton, 29 Aug.: “I wonder if Carlyle will ever make up his mind to go to you. He had a letter fm his brother Dr Carlyle strongly urging him to go but he seemed very uncertain” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). and I agree with them in nearly
every point. That of a man-servant who understands me his work, and wd loyally try to do it, wd be indeed a prize;John A. Carlyle continued: “Another thing I will suggest. Would it not be far better to take some solid sturdy man-servant of your own with you than Miss Maggie. He would be a great comfort to you both in the journey at Mentone after you return home if you find him suitable.” but “Forster” cannot get one to himself; in truth I despair of such an article. By far the best valet I ever had is the Jessie just gone; and now I am waiting to commence my instructn of the next, who, before or soon after completn, will also walk away: it is the universal nomadism that has disgusted me for long years back. Never mind,—or mind as little as one can! At prest my notion is, Mentone practically won’t do: but I will study it a bit before answering. Laing (thro a London Bookseller)J. D. A. Darling, Booksellers, 126 Bishopsgate St. had 2 Books waiting for me yesternight: one on Flodden Field you shall see by by; among the worst Books ever written,—and dear of 5 half-pence instd of “5/.”TC recorded in his checkbook: “28 Augt
1866 / to Darling (Bookseller; Welsh, Flodden (worst of Books!) / £0 .. 9 .. 8” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). It is unclear whether TC referred to the book he previously spoke of so highly, Rev. Dr. Robert Jones, The Battle of Flodden Field, Fought September 9, 1513 (Edinburgh, 1864) (see TC to JAF, 2 Aug.) or some other book about Flodden.
