The Welsh book is unidentified further.— A Yankee from Emerson is to come, Wedy evg;George Washburn Smalley. Wedy afternoon, the “Eyre Committee” is to have its first meeting,—whh perhaps I may attendSee TC to CDB, 30 Aug.
Adieu, dear Brother; with love to Jean all the rest.

div3.sourceNote: TC-CDB, 30 Aug. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:329 inc.
div3.head: TC TO CAROLINE DAVENPORT BROMLEY

docBody.p:
Yesterday, in spite of the rain, I got up to the Eyre Committee, and even let myself be voted into the chair,The meeting took place at 9 Waterloo Pl., Pall Mall; TC took the chair at this meeting. such being the post of danger on the occasion, and truly something of a forlorn hope, and place for enfans perdue [lost children]. We seemed, so far as I can measure, to be a most feeble committee; a military captain, a naval ditto, a young city merchant, Henry Kingsley, Charles still hanging back afraid, old S. C. Hall of the Art Union, a well-meaning man; only these, with a secretary who had bright swift eyes, but
showed little knowledge of his element.Captain John Walrond Clarke (1820–1903), of the 10th hussars; Captain Wray Gledstanes Palliser, R.N. (d. 1891); Alan Lambert (b. ca. 1837), of Messrs. Cottam Morton, West India merchants, 47 Lime St.; Henry Kingsley; his brother Charles Kingsley; Samuel Carter Hall (1800–89; ODNB ), author, ed. of the Art Journal 1839–80; and Hamilton Hume. … In short, contrary to all hope, I had to set my own shoulders to the wheel, and if it made any progress at all, which I hope it did, especially in that of trying for an infinitely better committee,According to the report of the first meeting, TC, “on taking the chair,” explained that he “considered that the committee should be presided over by some nobleman of power and influence. As he … however, considered it to be a solemn public duty on the part of every man who believed that Governor Eyre had quelled the insurrection in Jamaica, and saved that island, to come forward and boldly proclaim such to be his opinion, he would gladly consent to take the chair at the present meeting.” Several people expressed by letter “disapprobation at the word ‘Testimonial’ being used,” being of the opinion that “a Fund being raised for the defence of Mr. Eyre was in itself a Testimonial.” TC “considered that it would be advisable to meet the wishes of all well affected parties, and he therefore proposed that the title of the fund be altered from ‘The Eyre Testimonial and Defence Fund’ to ‘The Eyre Defence and Aid Fund.’ In his opinion the amount of money subscribed, though an important, was by no means the most important point. The main object of the committee ought to be to attack resolutely, by all fair methods, the fallacy (for such he could not but believe it to be) that these noisy denunciations of Mr. Eyre were the deliberate voice of the people of England, or did at all express England’s opinion about Mr. Eyre. / It was ultimately agreed that the fund should henceforth be entitled ‘The Eyre Defence and Aid Fund’” (Eyre Defence and Aid Fund 21). the probable chief cause was that my old coat is not afraid of a little mud on the sleeve of it, as superfiner ones might be. Poor Eyre! I am heartily sorry for him, and for the English nation, which makes such a dismal fool of itself. Eyre, it seems, has fallen suddenly from 6,000l. a year into almost zero, and has a large family and needy kindred dependent on him.By 1866 Eyre supported a wife and six children; he also had at least one unmarried sister, Mary Ann Eyre (ca. 1810–88). Dismissed before completion of his term of office as governor, he was not entitled to a full pension; if found guilty, he would get no pension at all. Such his reward for saving the West Indies, and hanging one incendiary mulatto, well worth the gallows,George William Gordon (ca. 1820–65; ODNB ); his father, Joseph Gordon, had been a wealthy white sugar planter, and his mother, name unknown, a slave. He m. a white widow, Mary Jane Perkins. A political opponent of Eyre, Gordon was accused of complicity in the Morant Bay rebellion; although no evidence was brought, he was found guilty by court martial and hanged; see also 43:61 TC to LLO, 2 Dec. 1865
. if I can judge.

div3.sourceNote: TC-CK, 3 Sept. MS: NLS 1796.107. Pbd: Workman 92–94.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES KINGSLEY

docBody.p: From the first time I got acct of Govr Eyre’s proceedings in the Jamaica outbreak, my clear feeling was, That his conduct had been that of a faithful, valiant, wise and manful Representative of the English Govt,—in an affair whh, had he not been such, wd have excelled in horror and sanguinary misery most things one can well conceive as happening above ground in this Earth;—and in fact, from all I had learned of Eyre then or before, my notion wd have been, had my post been that of English King, to appoint Eyre Dictator over Jamaica for the next 25 years, as pretty much the one chance there was for saving the West Indies or it. And nothing I have happened to hear since has in the least altered my opinn, or thrown any new light whatr on the Jamaica matter to me,—tho’ it has on the English a little, and of a very baleful and ominous complexn, so far as it goes! In truth, few things in my time have more disgusted me than this receptn, by my Writing Countrymen, of a Hero who had, with such promptitude, sagacity intrepidity, trampled out fire in the powder-room, and saved the whole W. Indies ship from flying aloft amid the deep seas,—not with human thanks and recognitn deep and universal, but with blatant clamours, rising to the height of execratns as I here there find. The blame, first of all, I take it, was that of the Govt; whh shd have permitted no questioning answering by the many-headed; but have declared with brevity that it was satisfied with its servant,—“Bring you a fault home upon him, in the proved form; then will we speak, not till then!” Hence these lamentatns, shriekeries, and insanities; at once frightful, doleful, and abominable, as if Phlegethon and HoundsditchPhlegethon was a river of hell-fire in Greek mythology, and Houndsditch was an area of East London inhabited by Jewish secondhand clothes dealers. had run into one, and both good sense and common honesty had forsaken poor Engld for the time! However, I do believe these to be blatancies, mass bleatings by innumerable sheep (rabid as wolves in some cases), but with the sense merely of one sheep’s head in them,—if you have noticed the ways of sheep, one head correctly equal in insight to 1,000 or to 1,000,000,—and perhaps even that one applying itself only half or tenth-part to form a real judgt: alas, alas!—

All yr misgivings abt Engld and her interests of every kind, have long long been my own in still dismaller forms;—and if these blatancies are not to be put down by a voice of the Natn emphatic enough for the purpose, I shall regard even them as of very ill omen at prest.

Meanwhile, is not the practical English of all this: “I will join the Eyre
Comee; personally appear among them, Wedny next,The next meeting was Wed., 5 Sept.
3 p.m., if Heaven permit”?— We are a poor Comee, and do need help. Froude has been written to, is much wanted;Hamilton Hume wrote, 3 Sept.: “Mr Froude has written to say that in consequence of his relations with the proprietor of Frasers Magazine he cannot join our Committee.” Froude himself wrote later: “I was myself one of the cowards. I pleaded that I did not understand the matter, that I was editor of ‘Fraser,’ and should disturb the proprietors; mere paltry excuses to escape doing what I knew to be right” (Froude, Carlyle 4:329). but personally I feel bound to be silent to you both: men in official or quasi-officl positns cannot be careless of the enfuriated sheep of the world as I can.Kingsley was currently chaplain to Queen Victoria, as well as professor of modern history at Cambridge University. He was criticized by several of his more radical friends for his support of Eyre; he wrote to Thomas Dixon, 27 Oct.: “I have followed the sage of Chelsea’s teaching, about my noble friend, ex-Governor Eyre of Jamaica. I have been cursed for it, as if I had been a dog, who had never stood up for the working man … and imperilled my own prospects in life in behalf of freedom and justice. Now, men insult me because I stand up for a man whom I believe ill-used, calumniated, and hunted to death by fanatics. … [A] brave and good man, doing his best under terrible difficulties” (Charles Kingsley: His Letters and Memories of His Life, ed. Frances Eliza Grenfell Kingsley, 2 vols. [1878] 2:235). Kingsley continued to support Eyre privately but did not join the committee. Ruskin is coming; full of holy zeal.Ruskin wrote, 5 Sept.: “Doing my duty as well as I can for Governor Eyre” (Ruskin’s Diaries 598).
Yrs ever
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 7 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Two days ago came yr Letter;—and immediately I wrote off to Maggie (who is in Liverpool, capable of being got at sooner than yr message by AuchtertoolMaggie Welsh was currently staying with her brother Alick in Liverpool; see TC to JCA, [ca. 10] Aug.
Her home was in Auchtertool, with their brother Walter Welsh and sister Mary Welsh. wd reach her), warning beforehand that my going to Mentone was not absolutely yet decided, but seemed fast tending towards “Practically won’t do,”— must be decided so at once, if a decisn at once were insisted on. That is the fact, dear Lady, and I cannot help it hitherto: for the rest, things are not essentially concluded, nor Mentone quite dismissed (if you will let it hang yet a little);Lady Ashburton’s letter, 17 Sept., was probably a reply to a later missing letter from TC, rather than to this one, as TC wrote on the corner of the letter: “No 2 (written after my Letter.” Lady Ashburton wrote from Davos Platz: “Your letter my very dear friend, has indeed made me happy— I gave you any length of time to remain uncertain—so that the decision at last is the more sweet for being about your comfort well being I hope that may be Mentone— My domicile there is now fixed— DV [deo Volente: God willing] and I hope to find myself in it about 2nd or 3rd Nov. … I shall be more than happy to see Prof Tyndall—he is one of my beloved husband’s friends I have always most wished to know— Tell him I shall have room for him anytime he finds he can come.” and Maggie’s Ansr, whh probably is on the way, need give
you no uneasiness,—for it has been already so far decided as that she is not to accompany, if I even do go; that a moderately good servant (who cd go into yr kitchen, get me coffee (e.g.) as at home, c c wd be far usefuller;—and, just now, I am experimenting here, whether absolute solitude be not the real state for me,—in vast preference to any “company” I can fall in with, 9 times out of 10!— — On the whole, tho’ it is so signal a proof of yr friendliness, I almost wish you hadn’t written to Maggie, on this subject:—but indeed it cannot essential do any ill to her or to me; nor alter the final resolutn, whatever that may be. Give me to the end of next week; I will then write positively Yes or No:—and you may depend on at least one thing, that I can have no doubt left of yr exceeding friendship and loyal wish to do what is likely to be best for me,—and that I will endeavr to ascertn that, for my own behoof, as faithfully as I can. At prest I am overwhelmed with paltry “busss” (only a small part of it my own in any sense); and must first get that off my neck, shall not till then do much good upon my own.

One thing, more definite, I have to report for the little Lady’s sake Yrs.Lady Ashburton was seeking a governess for Mary Florence. Miss ReichenbachEither Elisabeth or Hedwig, das. of Count Oskar von Reichenbach. evidtly cannot speak, nor even correctly write French;—whh indeed is of no interest, for a second fact is, Her Father (probably with some gloomy reminiscence of his former dignities,Reichenbach had been a wealthy landowner in Silesia before being exiled in 1850, but the Reichenbachs were now in reduced circumstances; see 42:184JWC to TC, [11 Aug. 1865], and 236–3742:biographical notes. or for what reason I don’t know) has long since settled that “neither of the Daughters can accept a Governessship” or permanent engaget of that kind. Whh is probably not very reasonable on his part; but wh at any rate completely settles the questn for us. So you must look out elsewhere; and, witht doubt, will find some eligible or tolerable Swiss yg Lady. Happily you feel deeply that it is yourself who must be the real Governess! I shd consider a little Playmate Compann of her own age, cd such be found, as very desirable too. But if the Mother is wise enough, the Mother is worth all other equipts arrangets, for a towardly Daughter!

I (only see what Paper!) I am, unexpectedly much sunk in “Eyre-Comittee” work; but intend to cut it all away within a few days, and retire into my nook agn. I am not “Chairman of the Eyre Comittee” as the Newsprs call me (tho’ I did one day take the chair); and I shall have, for behoof of the Newsprs, to 
state my opinn openly in some way,Hamilton Hume wrote, 2 Sept.: “I now come to the subject of your first letter to me.— It appears to be the opinion of every member of the Committee to whom I have spoken that if you would kindly allow it to be published in the papers it would aid us immensely.— The battle we have to fight will be a most severe one, and the greater the vigour and determination we show now the greater the chance of our ultimate success.” TC agreed, and his letter (see 
TC to HH, 23 Aug.

) was pbd. in the Times, 12 Sept. Hume prefaced TC’s letter: “Mr. Carlyle, who is not Chairman of the Eyre Defence Committee, but merely a member of it (the chairman not being yet selected, and the committee being only in course of formation), has received, and is daily in the habit of receiving from entire strangers, a quantity of letters, newspaper excerpts,  c., on the subject of “The Eyre Defence Fund,’ not one of which can he afford to read, much less answer. In consequence he has permitted me to publish the following,—his prompt and emphatic answer to myself on my first applying to him to join the committee,—as his one answer to all such volunteer correspondence from without.”—tho’ I had rather pay £50 than take that ugly trouble. That done, howr, I mean to have done. You never heard such a shriekery and psalmody of curses as is going on round the humane modest   heroic Eyre (all this I have construed him to be, tho’ I never saw him nor wish to see): he is economically ruined withal; has served the Govt 25 years, was within 2½ years of Pension; had, when the Mutiny occurred, £6,000 a year;—is now thrown into the street by both Govts   has nothing of income. That is a reward for quelling Nigger insurrectns, isn’t it! Had he only failed to quell it, and allowed it to blow up the whole W. Indies, he wd have had his £6,000, his complete  c  c witht any but a passing criticism on him from any man or body of men. We are the wonderfullest people, or growing to be.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JRT, 10 Sept. Addr: Washington Hotel (till called for) / Liverpool. PM: London, 10 Sept. 1866. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. John Reuben Thompson (1823–73), from Virginia, U.S.; poet and journalist, in Britain, 1864–66, to promote the Confederate cause.
div3.head: TC TO J. R. THOMPSON

docBody.p: Dear Sir,——You are very kind, to think of a Virginn memorial to me,Presumably a gift of Virginia tobacco. among so many other cares as you must have. “Alexr WelshAlexander Welsh, JWC’s cousin in Liverpool. Esqr, Sandown Park, Wavertree, Liverpool”: that is the address of a friend and connexion of mine; who I have no doubt will punctually take charge of the little narcotic treasure, land it safe here.

I will cordially wish you a good voyage,Thompson was returning home, sailing from Liverpool, 15 Sept.
and happy arrival and settlet,—happier than cd have been expected after all these stormful adventures;—and shall often think of you and of the brave Southern friends you sometimes brot to us,Thompson had visited TC several times during the past two years, both alone and with other Confederate friends; see 41:75 JWC to MR, [17 Oct. 1864] , and 83 TC to JRT, 31 Oct. 1864
, and 43:29 JWC to KST, 7 Nov. [1865]
; his last recorded visit was 4 Sept., about which he wrote in his diary: “Spent the evening with Carlyle. He talked delightfully of many matters. Speaking of literature, he said it had so degenerated that we might hope an end was coming to books, and that after a while we might relapse into the taciturnity of our ancestors” (Elizabeth C. Stoddard, “Extracts from the Diary of John R. Thompson,” Lippincott’s Monthly Magazine 24 [Nov. 1888] 707). when the evgs were (as has turned out) brighter to me than they can ever be again.
With many kind regards and good wishes, I remain always

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: TC wrote in his journal, 10 Sept.: “Engaged in hiring servants … a most dreary employt,—aggravated to me by the gloomy painful background it has in my prest feelings: ‘Once I was not thus pestered; ah no!’ [Previously JWC always hired the servants.] Very melancholy, sickly and miserable, these 3 or 4 days. Almost the one good hour I have (tender at least, if sad as death) is the silent one, abt midnight, when walking by the deserted pavets, and thinking of her who has gone ‘to the land that is very far off,’ and can hear me or help me no more.— I must awaken to this beggarly thing, and get it widely despatched if I can.— Some talk is of my going to Italy thro’ winter (Mentone Lady Ashburton’s), whh fluctuates alternates, and is not yet settled; as it too must be” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Menton was in France, not Italy; see TC to LLA, 8 Aug. TC apparently employed Alice Clark at this time; he inserted a note at this point: “Mrs Warren’s wages are £15 a year, and 30/— for beer. Paid half-yearly. / Small girl, Alice Clark (began 23 Sep 1866), paid £6 a year.” He also noted: “Sep 6–10 Servant Helen in Chelsea” (TC’s journal; privately owned). “Servant Helen” unidentified, although possibly a sister of the Forsters’ maid; see TC to JAC, 28 Aug.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JA [JAJR], 14 Sept. MS: NLS 1763.289. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES AITKEN JR.

docBody.p: Dear James,—The tobacco came, day before yesterday; all quite safe, and nothing to pay; quality of the wad sensibly superior to Milo’s,Presumably Thomas Milo, tobacconist, Strand, London. whh howr is of the same kind.

I expect you SundaySunday, 16 Sept.
abt 3:—but farther than that, I have been thinking you might as well come and pay me a visit, one fortnight counting from that date; and bring yr things either then, or send them on in some little box or portmanteau before. A fortnight of Chelsea will be to you a variety;James Aitken Jr. drafted a reply at the end of TC’s letter: “I sincerely thank you for yr kind invitation to stay at Chelsea for a fortnight I assure you it will be much more agreeable to me. I shall enjoy it very much more than any other kind of holiday that cd have been suggested for me in my present [circumstances]— I shall bring my Carpet bag with me on Sunday aftn.” This invitation to James Aitken Jr. was possibly what TC referred to in his journal, 10 Sept.: “Write to Jim Aitken abt another thing I am sometimes thinking of? Walk warily; but you can’t stop” (TC’s journal; privately owned); perhaps TC was considering inviting James to stay with him on a more permanent basis. and me too it will do some good (so canny, quiet discreet did I find you, in the House, last time)James Aitken Jr. was staying at Cheyne Row when TC arrived home after JWC’s death; see 43:258SDI to CCUES, 22 April. to see by me, night morning, a loving young face in this great solitude.TC noted, 26 Sept.: “Jas Aitken with me; very good, kindly and quiet;—rather in my way, too, now then. Was invited ‘for a fortnight’” (TC’s journal; privately owned).

I have just heard both from yr Mother and the Doctor;John A. Carlyle wrote, 19 Sept.: “I was glad to hear that you had invited Jem to take his holiday with you in Chelsea, that he is now there. A little letter to his mother came from him today, in which he mentions that he had had diarrhea on Saturday also apparently to some extent on Sunday. Please tell him to take care of it if it happens to return, as it is not without danger at present.” all is well at Dumfries, nothing going farther wrong in the rest of the circle.

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: John Mitchel (1815–75; ODNB; see 20:105TC to CGD, 19 Jan. 1846, and 21:25–26JWC to TC, [23–24 Aug. 1846]), Irish nationalist, wrote from Paris, 12 Sept., acknowledging TC’s letter of May 1848 when Mitchel had been about to be transported for 14 years from Dublin to Bermuda for his advocacy of rebellion in Ireland; he was subsequently moved to Van Diemen’s Land (now Tasmania), 1850, where his family joined him, and from where he escaped, 1853; for the start of the letter, see 23:35–37TC to LC, 26 May 1848; Mitchel continued: “Often since, I have wondered at myself for not giving you some sign that I am alive, remember you. Thought of writing several times, on receiving perhaps a new volume of Friedrich, to criticize you perhaps—or on hearing how Edinburgh University had done itself the honour to make you Lord-Rector, to congratulate you. Now at last I write, not to criticize or congratulate, but to say one friendly word to you in your loneliness—for I have just heard that your good kind Wife is dead— Whom I well remember to have met in that room at Chelsea, on an evening twenty years ago. Certain days hours of my life, very far behind me now, are vividly present to me always, when I wish to call them up— And that evening is one of them— Words of consolation I have none, but you will take this bit of a letter as at least a token of human sympathy, from one who also hath had losses. / And I hear you are still at Chelsea—still, I suppose in that very room, with those very books, others—for books gather. They also get scattered— I have had in my life four quite considerable collections of books, all scattered from time to time, by various sudden changes, now existing somewhere in infinite space, over the breadth of two hemispheres, or of four, if it takes four hemispheres to make a globe: a point which few have had more ample means of determining than I have had.” Mitchel had supported the Confederacy in the U.S. Civil War: “I fear you will never forgive us poor Confederates, for being beaten. We did all we could— But the Yankee calculation—giving five of their men for one of ours, brought us to an end at last. For they had all the universe behind them as a recruiting depot, could replace their five—we had nothing behind us but the guarded sea, could not replace our one. It was in vain that our good Confederates cut so deep, and so often, into that Yankee army, so big though so flabby—they could not, on that calculation, get to the end of it. It was a wild sad struggle. My eldest son, an artillery officer, Commandant of Fort Sumter, was torn to pieces by a shell on the ramparts, dying at his post. He, poor fellow, always remembered you, whom when a little boy, he saw in Dublin. My third son fell on the fields of Gettysburg: the second still lives, but with four wounds. He served in the Virginia army from the first day of the war to the last. / I was here in France when the war broke out— Could not for a long while get to the Confederate States, owing to the blockade, for I had my family (the female part of it) with me, could not venture to run them through the blockade. At last I went over by myself in the third year of the war—was followed the next year by my wife daughter, who undertook to penetrate the blockade in one of the small swift steamers built for that purpose. Their ship was chased, they were driven ashore on a desert beach at midnight— the ship with everything it contained (including their all) burnt before their eyes— Well this is a small part of our story, but the rest is to match. I am now here, simply because there is no law for me in America—not much of it for anybody, but for me decidedly, avowedly none” (pbd: K. J. Fielding, “Ireland, John Mitchel, and his ‘sarcastic friend’ Thomas Carlyle,” Literatur im Kontext—Literature in Context, ed. J. Schwend et al. [Frankfurt, 1992] 140–42). Mitchel’s wife was Jane Mitchel, b. Verner (1819/20–99; ODNB), m. 1837; for TC’s meeting with her in Dublin, 1846, see 21:25JWC to TC, [23–24 Aug. 1846]; she joined Mitchel in Van Diemen’s Land with their five children; a da., Isabel, was b. there. The two sons who d. in the Civil War were John and William, and James was badly wounded. The da. who ran the blockade with Jane Mitchel might have been Isabel or Henrietta, b. before Mitchel’s transportation to Van Diemen’s Land.

div3.sourceNote: TC-CDB, 15 Sept. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:330 inc.
div3.head: TC TO CAROLINE DAVENPORT BROMLEY

docBody.p: The Eyre Committee is going on better, indeed is now getting fairly on its feet.The second meeting of the Eyre Defence Committee took place, 5 Sept., with TC again in the chair; TC began with: “he was glad to find that no less than twenty-five new names had been added” and “that subscriptions were flowing in from all quarters” (Eyre Defence and Aid Fund 21). Ruskin’s speech—now don’t frown upon it, but read it again till you understand it—is a right gallant thrust I can assure you. While all the world stands tremulous, shilly-shallying from the gutter, impetuous Ruskin plunges his rapier up to the very hilt in the abominable belly of the vast blockheadism, and leaves it staring very considerably.Ruskin spoke at length about his motives for supporting the governor’s cause: “He had joined the committee … in the simple desire of obtaining justice, not for black men only, nor for white, but for men of every race and colour. He detested all cruelty, and all injustice by whomsoever inflicted, or suffered; he would sternly reprobate the crime which dragged a black family from their home, to dig your fields; and more sternly the crime which turned a white family out of their home, that you might drive by a shorter road over their hearth. But, whatever might be the motive or the temper of the accusations brought against Mr. Eyre, the ground of them was, under any circumstances, untenable. His accusers were under the radical mistake of confusing the office of a governor with that of a judge. … The question put at issue by the adverse prosecution was in fact this … whether Mr. Eyre, under circumstances of instant public danger, did, or did not, do to the best of his power and ability, what he believed to be his duty? … Had he, after all efforts bravely made, failed of his purpose—had he lost Jamaica, instead of saving it—if then … he might justly and advisedly have been superseded; but not even then brought to trial, on such grounds. But as the matter stands, the official removal of him from his place was an act of national imbecility. … It was the act—as this threat of prosecution was the cry—of a nation blinded by its avarice to all true valour and virtue … it was the suicidal act of a people which, for the sake of filling its pockets, would pour mortal venom into all its airs and all its streams; would shorten the lives of its labourers by thirty years a life, that it might get its needle-packets twopence each cheaper; would communicate its liberty to foreign nations by forcing them to buy poison at the cannon’s mouth, and prove its chivalry to them by shrinking in panic from the side of a people being slaughtered, though a people who had given them their daughter for their future queen;—and then would howl in the frantic collapse of their decayed consciences, that they might be permitted righteously to reward with ruin the man who had dared to strike down one seditious leader, and rescue the lives of a population” (Eyre Defence and Aid Fund 21–22).

div3.sourceNote: TC-CK, 17 Sept. MS: offered for auction, eBay, May 2015, with a death notice and two cartes de visite, all in a single frame with winnow on reverse to allow the second page of the letter to be read. Pbd: R. Atkinson, bookseller, London, catalog (n.d.) inc.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES KINGSLEY

docBody.p: I am very sensible to yr and Mrs Kingsley’s kindness; but, alas, I must not leave my gloomy solitude for any sunnier place at prest.Frances Kingsley; presumably Kingsley had invited TC to visit their home at Eversley Rectory, Hampshire, about 40 mi. (64 km.) from Chelsea. I am trying to get into something like employt of my days again, with very poor success hitherto, but with constantly renewed efforts,Ruskin wrote suggesting an idea for a final work by TC, 1 Oct.: “It seems to me that a magnificent closing work for you to do would be to set your finger on the turning points and barriers in European history—to gather them into train of light—to give, without troubling yourself about detail or proof, your own final impression of the crises and causes of things—and your thoughts of the leading men, who they were and what they were. If you like to do this—I’ll come and write for you a piece of every day, if after beginning it, you still found the mere handwork troublesome. I have a notion it would be very wholesome work for me, it would be very proud dear for me. But that’s by the way.— Only think of the thing itself.” at lowest, I am inuring myself to the New conditns under whh the poor remnants of life must be spent or wasted henceforth. Any smallest alteratn of my silent daily habits produces an anarchy to me whh you cd not believe unless you saw it!— —
That you want to talk with me, is good news. Come see me, I pray you, when you are in Town agn, and you shall have plenty of that.

div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH HOWE

docBody.p: I have read yr Pamphlet on the “Canadn Union” questn;Joseph Howe, Confederation Considered in Relation to the Interests of the Empire (1866). and got a great deal of light upon it whh was all new to me.

Many years have passed since you were here;Howe had visited TC several times on previous visits to Britain; see 38:30TC to HP, 31 Dec. 1861. and in the last of them a calamity and loss to me whh can never be repaired. But if you will come down,—let us say Sunday evg next, 8 p.m., to tea,—I shall be well pleased to have an hours talk with you agn. if on Sunday evg you can’t,—please to name any other, and it is most likely I can.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady L [LLO], 25 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11439. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY LOTHIAN

docBody.p:
I “would” right gladly, if I only cd:Lady Lothian wrote, 22 Sept.: “Would you could dine with us on Tuesday. … There wd be nobody but Mr Gladstone.” Lord and Lady Lothian were staying with Lady Lothian’s parents at 36 Belgrave Sq.; see 43:82 TC to JAC, 21 Dec. 1865
. On the reverse of the letter, TC wrote: “The Lady Lothian / (dine with Gladstone?— No!) / Septr 1866.” but, alas, since April last, I have never dined out; and am still too dreary and sad of soul, not to say, at prest too shaky of body withal (liver, sleep c c), to venture on such an enterprise, even on your kind and simple terms.

I will call, one of these days, perhaps this very day, on my solitary promenade up to Town or to the Park (3–5 p.m. is daily the obligato time for me), in hopes to see Lord Lothian or you in passing up or down;—and I please myself with the prospect of many a little colloquy of that kind in the weeks that are coming.

If you cd persuade the Ex-Chancellor to part company once and forever with Bright, Beales, and the Suffrage Question;William Gladstone had been chancellor of the exchequer in Lord Russell’s government, which had promoted the Reform Bill for extending the electorate, also supported by John Bright and Edmond Beales; see TC to LLA, 8 Aug.
and to revise a little, in the real depths of his mind, what he means by “Unexampled Prosperity”For TC’s earlier critical use of the phrase “unexampled prosperity,” see 28:298 TC to JCA, 26 Oct. 1853
, and 29:18 TC to KAVE, 15 Jan. 1854
(“fools call it”; 1854). A use by Gladstone is untraced, but it was a phrase in common usage, mid-1860s, to refer to the state of the country under Gladstonian policies of laissez-faire economics. such as we now have,—you might do an incalculable advantage to him to us and to the whole world!— And you might then also, when yr hand is in, try if you couldn’t persuade the prest vile weather to become fine, and let us see the blue sky agn?——

closer.salute: Believe me, Dear Lady, Yrs sincerely /
closer.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WDC, 27 Sept. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM DOUGAL CHRISTIE

docBody.p: I go wholly with yr Letter; and have to approve of yr practical determinatn too, tho’ sorry for it.

The SecretaryHamilton Hume, sec. of the Eyre Defence Committee. shall have yr hintsChristie’s views on Eyre are unrecorded, but he was envoy-extraordinary and minister-plenipotentiary to Brazil, 1859–63, and retired after various misunderstandings with the Brazilian government, particularly relating to the slave trade. He wrote of his experiences in Notes on Brazilian Questions (1865). witht delay; and ought to be very much obliged to you, if he is of my view.

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: TC wrote, 26 Sept.: “Writing, languidly, something whh I call ‘Reminiscences of Edwd Irving’;—whh turns out hitherto to be more abt myself than him. Perhaps not easy to help its being so, especially thus far? Continue it, at any rate; tho’ good for little.” TC was to complete his reminiscences of Irving while in Menton, 2 Jan. 1867. He also noted, 26 Sept.: “Servant concern done: see ‘Alice Clark’” (TC’s journal; privately owned); Alice Clark began work 23 Sept.; for her appointment, see TC to JRT, 10 Sept.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 27 Sept. MS: Yale. Pbd: Ruskin’s Works 36:517; Cate 119–20.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: I have agn read all these Letters; but do not, from Mr PriceRuskin had forwarded to TC letters sent him by George Price (1812–90) (Bernard Semmel, The Governor Eyre Controversy [1962] 112). Price managed his family’s Jamaican sugar plantation, Worthy Park, 1844–63, and established a reputation as a good employer who respected his Negro workers, paid them fair wages, eliminated irregular patterns of employment, and gave them better security. In 1854 he was elected to the Legislative Assembly, and became Custos (chief magistrate) of the precinct of St. Catherine; he resigned, 1864, in protest against Governor Eyre; returning to England, 1865, he continued to campaign against Eyre, and pbd. Jamaica and the Colonial Office: Who Caused the Crisis? (July 1866), a scathing analysis of Eyre’s misgovernment. The book contained copies of various letters from Price and others concerning the Jamaican crisis, and Price apparently included some of these in his letter to Ruskin; see TC to JRU, 11 Oct. or his Jamaica Standard,Probably the Colonial Standard and Jamaica Despatch. get the least glimmer of new light abt “the Tramway swindle”The tramway scandal, 1862–65, concerned a scheme for the construction of a tramway, projected before Eyre’s term of office but sanctioned by Eyre, which Prince opposed on the grounds that the scheme was fraudulent and Edmund Leahy (ca. 1813–88), Colonial engineer and architect 1858–63, dishonest. In a public inquiry into Eyre’s mishandling of the case, Eyre was accused of flouting local laws and procedures, and of failing to investigate Leahy’s fraudulent estimates. Price led a movement in the Assembly to suspend any further money bills until Eyre’s executive committee resigned; Eyre responded by dissolving the Assembly and informing the Colonial Office in London that he had done so because of the Assembly’s refusal to pass the money bill, though making no reference to the tramway scandal. Price persisted in his criticism, and under extreme pressure Eyre examined Leahy’s figures, agreed that fraud had been intended, and eventually but still extremely reluctantly agreed to prosecute Leahy, who was found guilty and dismissed. Price believed that the tramway scandal was a major cause of the Morant Bay disturbance in 1865. or any of the other miracles alledged,—whh I can only conceive as more or less natural misbirths of that nearly inconceivable little chaos in a coalbox (probably very violent, and sure to be fuliginous) whh they call “House of Assembly”; all intent upon talk of various kinds, while their Governor was pushing towards work and result. A mere heap of flaming soot; abstrusely equal to zero for us! Mr Price, I have no reason to doubt, was and is perfectly honest and bon√¢-fide; but need not concern us farther.Ruskin replied, 29 Sept.: “The reason I attached overdue weight to Price’s letter you might partly guess from his niece’s, which I left with you, not inadvertently.” George Price’s niece was Maria La Touche, b. Price (d. 1906), da. of George Price’s eldest brother; Ruskin had been friendly with Maria, and particularly with her da. Rose (1848–75), for several years.

The best thing you can now do is to consult seriously that practical Mr Harris;Ruskin wrote: “I asked [Hamilton Hume] … whether he might not be helped in his present work by the lawyer’s precision of my friend Mr. Pattison—(I heedlessly called him Harrison to you the other night—having another lawyer and politico-economist friend of that name).” Pattison and Harrison are unidentified; Mark Pattison (1813–84; ODNB), rector of Lincoln College, Oxford, later a friend of Ruskin’s, was not a lawyer, and Frederic Harrison (1831–1923; ODNB), although a lawyer, was anti-politicial economy and anti-Eyre.
and if, unfortunately, he won’t be of the Committee, get him to undertake that Lucid Digest, or conclusive little Summary of facts and of principles, whh must be set forth, and addressed to the British People for their answer. Such a thing wd have immense results, if rightly done; and, to all appearance, he is the one man for it. Be diligt, I bid you!—

The Letter from Christie (Ex-Brasilian Excellency, and a very shrewd fellow) came this morng: I leave a memorandum of it with Hume; to whom, if you chance to look in, you may give it in corpore [in bodily form];Christie’s letter (see TC to WDC, 27 Sept. ) is untraced, and the contents unknown; Ruskin wrote: “I went to Waterloo Place and gave Mr. Hume that letter about Lord Russell, yesterday.”—otherwise, keep or return hither.—— —— I expect you agn abt Wedny; and hope to be alone, get more good of you.Ruskin wrote: “I am so glad you like to have me alone.” Ay de mi [Alas]!—
Yrs ever / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 6 Oct. MS: NLS 518.28. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Sister,—Here is the shortest of words to you; written just while I am running out. I have written to [no]ne of you lately; supposing JamesTC omitted the “no” in “none.” James Aitken Jr. had been staying with TC for two weeks; see TC to JAC, 14 Sept.
wd be occasionally writing; and indeed, of importt, there being nothing to say. James went off on Thursday morng (some Liverpool friendUnidentified further. being due for him by appointt of a ten days): he was very good while here, the quietest and kindliest of human creatures; our only difficulty was my uncertainty of rising,—if above 8½ o’clock, it was too late for Rood-LaneJames Aitken Jr. had established himself as a shipbroker (“ship and ins. broker,” 1867 PO directory); see 43:149 JWC to TC, [30 March] ; his office was at 9 Rood Lane, City of London. and him; he always seemed to grudge missing his little run with me, and breakfast witht my company. His stay, as a break of the solitude, has done me good: solitude is not unwholesome to me (nor is it so miserable as most of the “conversatn” I can
get); but at times, when nerves are jarred and dyspepsia there, my sadness gets too sombre. With fair health of body,—but what chance have I of that?— I cd stand out well enough; and contrive work for myself, not quite useless, and yet fit for my strength. You perceive my hand is steadier, at any rate.TC had been suffering from a shaky right hand for some time; see 43:195 JWC to TC, [15 April] .

We were very sorry indeed to hear of Scotsbrig Jamie’s ugly accidt,Both Jean Aitken and John A. Carlyle wrote to TC about their brother Jamie’s accident; John A. Carlyle wrote, 28 Sept.: “Jamie of Scotsbrig had got himself rather badly [hurt] in returning from the marriage on the Tuesday night before. In the darkest part of the Hoddam road young James Austin he were letting their horse walk cautiously, when a drunk man [Roddick of Trailtrow] … came driving furiously in the opposite direction upset their conveyance, his own of which he broke one wheel both the shafts. Of course Jamie young James were thrown down violently both hurt. … So far as I can judge Jamie is out of all danger, suffering only from the pains in his shoulders. … We did not hear at all of his accident till the 24th—six days after it had happened— it seemed unnecessary to grieve you with the news of it till we had heard how Jamie had got out of it.” Jean wrote, 30 Sept.: “John [Jamie’s son] wrote to the Dr on Thursday that his Father was ‘getting better had been able to go out a little this day week Sunday. The three cuts on his face were healing nicely.’ … I hope he may be nearly better by this time, but the Dr is not in communictn with young Jas just now John is less ready in writing, so we do not hear so often as cd be wished.” in additn to his other disgusts and sorrows from those that shd have been helping him! The Dr’s Note mentioning ‘Jamie Austin junr’ as his Gig compann was quite enigmatic till Yrs explained it.The cousins, James Carlyle Jr. and Catherine Austin, m. 18 Sept., apparently in a hurry and to some disapproval. Jean Aitken wrote, 23 Sept.: “nothing at all new to tell you except the wedding at the Gill on Tuesday [18 Sept.]—wch we heard nothing of till we read it in The Drs Standard last night. / I have just got my orders as usual [from John A. Carlyle]. ‘You had better not say anything about this at all I shall cut it out and inclose it myself’ I told him I had no wish to say much on such a subject but if I had anything to say I cd see nothing to prevent me. He thinks I suppose I am a little severe on James for his vapouring high-flying ways; defends him at all times, as if he were his own. / I am glad they have got their shoot-together-wedding over, poor souls hope they may do well from the bottom of my heart. The Dr laments as if James had thrown himself away in taking Catherine. She is quite uncultivated poor lassie except the experience that hard work has given her; but I think in reality she is the best of the two. She is well stocked in some of the qualities that is wanting is Jas. She is a patient, considerate lass Catherine with plenty of common sense. It is the only mends they could make I am glad it is done.” For Jean’s earlier annoyance with John, see 43:123–24 TC to JCA, 21 Feb.
John A. Carlyle enclosed a note, 23 Sept., to TC with Jean’s letter: “By one of the enclosed cuttings you will see that Catherine was married last week we only heard of it by the papers yesterday.” The implication was that they got married because of pregnancy; there was perhaps a miscarriage as, in the event, no child was born until 14 Aug. 1867; that child, James, d. after only three hours. I shd be very glad to hear that some good arranget had been fallen upon at Scotsbrig,—probably they are taking time, whh is well;Catherine had been housekeeper at Scotsbrig; see 42:78 TC to JWC, 13 June 1865
. the only other thing I cd wish hinted to Jamie senr is, By
no means to “pull off his clothes till he is going to bed”: little doubt he knows that wholesome proverb; whh no old man, with the best of sons, shd forget!Both Jamie’s sons continued to live at Scotsbrig for some months, until James and Catherine moved to Craigenputtoch.—

Froude has come in,Froude was a regular caller; TC wrote in his journal, 12 Oct.: “Froude came (my best talker round here, even he does me little good).” and I must run. “Mentone,” owing to Italn cholera c,Lady Ashburton wrote, 17 Sept.: “I will let you know as soon as I possibly can—whether it is safe to go to Mentone.” is somewhat out at sea for the prest; but I will send the Dr a Note soon, and the Lady A. Letters that have come. Here is a Yankee Letter for you; burn it, read or unread. Blessings on all of you

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 10 Oct. MS: NLS 518.29. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I got both yr Letters. It was very stupid of me, to send you those two useless Letters of the Lady A. twice; and to bungle my post-affairs in the way I did! Here is another Lady A. Letter, quite useless too (and a bit of it illegible), whh has just come, an hour ago, and is my first since those two. Send it back in a cover tomorrow (witht more than a word, if you have too little time).Lady A wrote from Glion, Switzerland, 7 Oct.: “I have delayed writing till I heard about the cholera at Mentone—as it has not yet appeared there, We must hope it will not—so DV. I purpose settling myself in my house about the end of Octr—the said house is, I fear, not as comfortable as I had hoped—but there was no choice.” John A. Carlyle returned the letter: “Here is Lady A’s letter which I seem to have made out completely as you will see by the pencil marks.” Yr acct of Thornhill is sad to me, yet soft and with a touch of blessing in it.John A. Carlyle was researching local history, apparently with the help of his nephew John Aitken; over the next few days he sent TC various old documents, so perhaps he sent information about the graves in Thornhill churchyard. Blessed are the Dead, that die well, having finished their work with honour.Cf. Rev. 14:13. Yea, yea!——

My special errand today is abt that Book (of Irish Knox’s?) on Iona   St Colm.Vita Sancti Columbae: Auctore Adamnano Monasterii Hiensis Abbate [The Life of St. Columba Founder of Hy; Written by Adamnan], ed. William Reeves (Dublin, 1857; Edinburgh, 1857). Adomn√°n (627/8?–704; ODNB), abbot of Iona; William Reeves (1815–92; ODNB), antiquary, author, and cleric in the church of Ireland. “Irish Knox” is unidentified, but John A. Carlyle replied, [11 Oct.]: “The author’s name is Reeves” and TC wrote in his journal, 12 Oct.: “am looking out for a certn Reeves on Iona   St. Colm, to see if anything will come of old notions I had on that matter” (TC’s journal; privately owned). 
The Duke of ArgyllThe dukes of Argyll had owned Iona since the 1690s; TC and George Douglas Campbell (1823–1900; ODNB), 8th duke of Argyll, were guests together at The Grange, Jan. 1862 (see 38:43–44TC to JWC, 29 Jan. 1862); TC then dined with him April 1862 (see 38:79TC to JAC, 7 April 1862); possibly he asked the duke about the book at that time. long since volunteered to lend it me, but has never done so; and it now strikes me that, if you happen to know the Title   immediate London Bookseller, the best method will be that you at once Order it for me,   let me have it of my own.John A. Carlyle replied, [ca. 11 Oct.]: “The book on Iona   St Colm was published by the Irish Archeological Society   the Bannatyne Club,   it is not on sale. I will write tonight to David Laing   ask him to lend you his copy. It is a long-winded book, but is thought to contain all that can be known on its subject. I almost lost patience in reading it.” He then wrote, 15 Oct.: “Today I have a note from Laing in which he tells me he sent off Reeve’s Columba   dissertation on the Culdees by some parcel conveyance … on Saturday.” Laing sent the edn. pbd. by the Bannatyne Club, Edinburgh, of which he was secretary, and Reeves’ The Culdees of the British Islands (Dublin, priv. printing, 1864). Culdees were ascetic Christian monks in the Middle Ages. John A. Carlyle wrote, 18 Oct.: “The Irish copy of Reeves is less unwieldly, being printed on thinner paper, than Laing’s Bannatyne one;   I once had some notion of getting a copy but it cost two Guineas, if still attainable,   one has to go through the form of becoming a member for the year in which it was published.” Pbd. by the Irish Archaeological and Celtic Society and circulated by the Edinburgh Bannatyne Club as one of its publications, Vita Sancti Columbae was in Latin with the notes in English. Tonight probably I shall end Froude’s two new 
volumes (very good reading; can be sent you if you wish);Froude’s History of England, vols. 9 and 10 (1866). TC wrote in his journal, 12 Oct.: “[Froude’s] two new voll (9   10) have been my reading for the evgs; good really, but now done” (TC’s journal; privately owned). John A. Carlyle wrote, 15 Oct.: “I should like to see Froude’s last two volumes, if they can be sent easily”; he wrote, 18 Oct.: “I like Froude’s vols very much. They are the best I have seen of his; but I have only got half through the 9th vol.” and I shall be ready for the Iona job (hope there is a good map, there or procurable!)—so soon as it pleases to come to hand. I have French Ana“Ana” refers to collections of essays, aphorisms, anecdotes, etc., sometimes of single authors, as in Voltairiana (Paris, 1748) (see 39:123TC to HG, 7 May 1863
), sometimes in wider collections, such as Table-Talk; or, Selections from the Ana, Containing Extracts from the Different Collections of Ana, French, English, Italian, and German. With bibliographical notices (Edinburgh, 1827).
  c to occupy my silent evgs till then; and can wait a little if needful, tho’ had rather not.— Yesterday there was a long walk with Froude in Battersea Park, east wind very brisk; tonight Ruskin is to be expected for a couple of hours: suffict for the day is the good thereof!Cf. Matt. 6:34.

I also wish you to give these two Photographs (both of 1865, one of them the best there was or can be)Both TC and JWC had photographs taken of themselves in April and May 1865; see 41:215TC to JOWA, 21 April 1865 (where JWC refers to one of the photographs of her being TC’s favorite) and 42:8, 48–49, 64, 66, and 162–63. John A. Carlyle replied, [ca. 11 Oct.]: “I have given Jean the two photographs. If you have two others of the same sort, can spare them, they wd be very welcome to me.” to Jean,—her copies, if I mistake not, being considerably worn out. Maggie Welsh got me, for some 3/6 or so, a double little frame, or gilt space that holds two Photos, almost side by side, very neatly;—that and its two, one of them a younger than the precious one here, is now close by me in my dressing-closet the first thing daily.TC possibly referred to the green leather frame containing the cartes-de-visite of a younger TC (pre-1854) and younger JWC (ca. 1854–57; see also 36:61JWC to RST, [ca. 6 Feb. 1860]) that is in Carlyle House; see oppabove. If you can, at Dumfries (or if Jean can, you pay for it), get such a frame, send me the small bill, I shall be well-pleased.John A. Carlyle wrote, 15 Oct.: “The frame for Jean’s two photographs can be got here, is already ordered price 4 shillings.” He then wrote, 18 Oct.: “I have given Jean her 4 Dozen Stamps,” presumably sent by TC in payment for the frame. Pray examine at the Gill, if you are there agn, how Mary is off in that way.

figure.p:
Thomas Carlyle and Jane Welsh Carlyle
Courtesy of Carlyle’s House, National Trust

docBody.p:
Ex-Excellency Dugald Christie called yesterday; rather in grave humour; feels deserted by the pusillans late Ministry; disappointed of getting his teeth in them thro’ Parlt;—and has decided on going into Newspaper Literature, to
“supplement his diminished income.”Christie retired from the diplomatic service, 1863; he failed to win a parliamentary seat at Cambridge, 1865. He then devoted his time to publishing books and essays on the history and literature of the seventeenth century. Wishes me to recommend him; whh I undertook if applied to. Silence abt this,—whh indeed is, to you, a superfluous precept, I well suppose!—

Go back agn to Cowhill occaslly; it will be a resource. I used to hear long ago of “Johnstons of Cowhill”;The Cowhill estate, 4½ mi. (7 km.) NW of Dumfries, had been bought by George Johnston (ca. 1738–1826) in the late 1760s. His descendants still lived there, the current owner being William Johnston (1831–1901), J. P. It was probable that the house contained documents and records that John A. Carlyle would find useful in his research. but thot always it was the Hill of Kye, and never suspected broom and “couws.”“Cow” or “cowe” is an old Scottish word for the plant broom.

Jamie Aitken, I hope, may be here on Saty Sunday. His Letter to you I did with as you bade. Yr support of him, poor fellow, is very generous proper.John A. Carlyle wrote to Janet Hanning, 25 Oct.: “Young James Aitken is now settled as a Shipbroker in London, generally spends the Sundays at Chelsea. He has not got much business yet, but thinks his prospects of employment are good; in such a large place as London no one can step all at once into employment” (MS: Yale).
Adieu dear Brother; I have scribbled far beyond what I meant. Now out for my silent walk.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 11 Oct. MS: NLS 7197.85. Pbd: Cate 122–23; Workman 94–95.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p:
I chanced to be a little out of sorts last night,—the cause inconceivably small, that of first drinking two mouthfuls of bad tea in a house where I called, and then of eating cauliflower instead of potatoe at dinner here; inconceivably small, but suffict to keep me prettily awake the greater part of last night! It was therefore probably as well that the second misfortune came,—tho’ possibly, too, yr talkRuskin visited TC most weeks at this time, usually on a Wed.; presumably he had canceled his visit on Wed. 10 Oct.
might have warmed the poor nerves into genial heat, and saved me from the Monsters of the Night; nobody can say for certn. Certain only that thus we now are:—and that, so far as I can now judge, Wednesday Evg next will be the favourable time. Unless you prefer Monday or any other day of next week, and will take the trouble of announcing it to me? Otherwise silence (as to Wedny) shall mean assent.

Last night I drew Price from his doomed Limbo down in kitchen (happy to find him still unburnt), sent him to you.Presumably the letters George Price sent to Ruskin; see TC to JRU, 27 Sept.
Don’t send him back, please!—

((Interruptn of many hours, at this point, by a mass of printed Slips from Hamn Hume; part of his Pamphlt on Eyre.Hamilton Hume, ed., Eyre Defence and Aid Fund. Facts diligtly chosen; but presented as if wrapt in bales of wool,—or by the broadest end, or even by the side, instead of the point! Ah me, I feel as if I had been douched for hours in dirty water,—yr own feeling, probably, in reading Price. For Hume’s Pamphlet, yes; but for Eyre’s Comittee, they will never do!— You will ultimately have to call in yr Mr Harrison?,TC’s “?” above “on” of “Harrison”; for the confusion over the name, see TC to JRU, 27 Sept. or man of real logic and law. Meanwhile, go to poor Hume, help him a little,—take you his Printed Slips read them: can you? I must absolutely shut up in that directn, to save my sanity!))TC applied double parentheses to his last paragraph.— —
Enough today; /

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 15 Oct. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Receive this little salutatn as you hastily pass on yr way. Whose office soever may be a sinecure, Yrs is evidently none! I was sorry not to see you when you called and when I called: but a time will come, let us hope, before long. Mrs F.’s absence is a sad item too,—especially the cause of it, whh, alas, seems to grow sadder sadder! Poor Miss Forster, I remember her very well; and am sad at heart to think of the sore misery that has come!Elizabeth Forster (1818–68), John Forster’s sister, who lived in Newcastle. She had been a governess, but was now an invalid; Eliza Anne Forster was visiting her; two years later Eliza Ann went to Newcastle to bring Elizabeth to London, where she was to die; see Davies, John Forster 121. TC’s meeting with her is not recorded.—

Except that exact “14 days in Kent,”—whh itself consisted of absolutely still life, riding by Walmer Castle and under the the silent Chalk-Cliffs c c (and was not an improvet on my Chelsea life), I have been entirely silent and alone here; very sad of mood, but also very calm for most part; and on the whole, better perhaps, and more supportable to my-self, in communing with my own sombre piously regretful thots, than with almost any company I was like to have. I am not growing worse in bodily health; sometimes I almost think, slowly a degree better. Sometimes too, as if edging gradually to-wards
some kind of light work, whh I might still do while the days still are. God grant me that, as the one real solace that is left me while I continue here!—
Take care of yrself, dear F,—especially of that bad cough I heard of yr having.

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: TC had been approached by William Froude (1810–79; ODNB), engineer and naval architect, brother of James Anthony Froude, with a request for help for a young woman who had fallen into debt; William Froude wrote, 17 Oct.: “Your approval of my wifes discretion in reference to what she had already done said and the quasi discretional direction you give as to the application of the money seemed to us to justify her in taking the precautionary method of applying the assistance which I think I told my brother she was inclined to advise. … I only wanted to say that we feel you have kindly generously given an impulse from without in a good direction to one who was in real danger: that your way of dealing with the case has been more likely to make a permanent impression for good than almost anything else which she could have fallen in with.” TC noted: “15 Octr1866 / to W. Froude Esqr / for Exeter ‘Distracted Child’:—Charity). / £6 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753), and in the memoranda book of charitable donations (see TC to MRSSU, 10 July): “Octr 15–18, To a starving ‘Author’ (poor Reporter c), and to an unlucky yg creature at Exeter (‘Tartarus in a Teapot,’ as I called her case,—well dealt with, I hope), £6 .. 2 .. 6” (MS: Bodleian Lib.). William Froude’s wife, m.. 1839, was Catherine, b. Holdsworth (d. 1878).

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 16 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Yr Note came yesterday morning; a few hours after my last had set out for you. I proceeded, in the afternoon walk, to discover “Carlisle Terrace, Kensington,” the Reichenbach place of abode; found, contrary to expectatn, the Count just returned from Germany; and so could at least reckon on a prompt answer. Answer once got, I proceeded with it to the Telegraph Office;—and, in all likelihood, you already have it; and are wondering at the perverse obstinacy of the man.Lady Ashburton wrote, 11 Oct.: “I have been in vain endeavouring to find a person … for my darling little Mary, but the only Governess who at all answers my idea cannot come till Spring. … [D]o you think the Baron von R would allow his Daughter to come till then? she spending the winter at Mentone—I paying her travelling expenses, giving her £40–for the 5 months— I shd be so glad if he cd consent to this temporary arrangement— I really think the change of climate c might be an advantage to the young lady. … See what you can manage in this transaction. … Let me know by Telegram—yes or no.” TC wrote at the end of the letter: “Reichenbach’s daughter won’t (so her Father decides): I telegraphed accordly, Monday aftern last [15 Oct.].” See also TC to LLA, 7 Sept.
But it was not quite that, I found on examining; nor was there the least want of polite respect, gratitude, and lively sense of yr kindness
and munificence on the occasion: but the truth is, the poor Count’s Household-Finance depends altogether (or nearly so) on his Children, two Daughters with music c and a sonOskar von Reichenbach. with some railway-engineer appointt; and the eldest, Miss Elizabeth now in questn, had some 8 or 10 Music-lesson weekly (at 7/6 per), and wd, if she went away at this season, completely break that fine “Connexion”: so that c c,—with real regret, I cd perceive, especially on the poor Mother’s part.—— For yr sake too, I regret at little; but on the whole not much, computing that with a day or two’s vigorous investigatn, and trial of candidates, you will be able to fill the place satisfactorily enough from the ground where you are, and probably with less trouble, not more, than Miss R. her journeyings and adjustings from the distance might have caused.— Courage! The dear little Child is well; that is an immense item: with her Mother’s eye over her, she is not likely to be ill off in the matter of governesses.

You are likely to have company enough, by by, if you have too little at prest. I had forgotten the LowesLady Ashburton wrote: “I wish I had you on this glorious mountain top—its only drawback is I have not a creature to speak to. Oh! how pleasant it will be having you, Lowe, Venables.” Robert Lowe (1811–92; ODNB; see 33:275–7633:biographical notes), politician, and his wife, m. 1836, Georgiana, b. Orred (d. 1884); George Stovin Venables (1810–88; ODNB), lawyer and journalist; all known to TC since at least the 1850s and all members of the Ashburton circle. till you mentioned them agn. Lowe is a sound stalwart man,—rather of gritty compositn, I have usually felt; true and rational, but not of wide field or finest sympathies. He called here not very long ago, the first time for years; and got a hearty bit of praise from me, for his Reform-Bill eloquences heroisms, and took it well.Lowe was a Liberal M.P., 1859–68, but opposed to electoral reform; his recent visit is not traced further. Engld, as you say, is “in very bad health;”—in fact, not unlike plunging “into the hollow pot” before long. A most sad end; but I doubt, and have long doubted, an inevitable! The sight thot of all these roaring blockheadisms, and cowardly lying phantasms in high places, is disgusting miserable to me.— Adieu, dear Friend Yrs everT. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-C H [CAH], 18 Oct. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO CHAPMAN HALL

docBody.p: Received from Messrs Chapman and Hall, by bill of four months, due 10 feby next, Four Hundred and Sixty-one Pounds, thirteen shgs sixpence,TC wrote “sixpence” in error for “4d”; Chapman Hall’s check was for £461 .. 13 .. 4 and was payable Feb. 1867; the check with his signed endorsement was sent, 18 Oct., to Samuel Adamson for payment into TC’s account at the British Linen Company Bank, Dumfries; this check was advertised for sale by Thomas F. Madigan Booksellers, catalog Jan. 1939, p. 4. Samuel Adamson replied from the bank, 19 Oct.: “I have received your favor of 18th inst. enclosing Chapman and Hall’s bill to you of £431 .. 13 .. 4 due 18th February which I shall collect and place to your credit as requested when due.” TC wrote above the “3”: “6 (n.b.)”; later, on the reverse of the letter, he wrote: “did write abt £461=431! (April 1867).” being their debt to me for “Carlyle’s Works” up to midsummer last.

div3.sourceNote: TC-AC, 20 Oct. MS: MUL. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:237–40 inc.; Marrs 757–59. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:107.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER CARLYLE

docBody.p:
It is a long time since I wrote directly to you; and you know what irreparable sorrow and loss has befallen me since then,—whh has naturally indisposed me to writing or corresponding, except where altogether indispensable; and has thrown me into silence, and sad and solemn meditations of many kinds, instead. My loss was sudden, as if by lightning: but her death was very beautiful, and such as she had always wished; her noble life, at that point of time (what with those poor Edinr celebrations, and her love to me the object of them), wd be felt by her, I know well, to be crowned by perfect victory; and indeed everybody testifies, what was most of all evidt to myself, that her last eighteen months, and especially her last two weeks and her last day, were the happiest she had had for many years.For JWC’s last months, Oct. 1865 to April 1866, see vol. 43. Beautiful she was in her utter feebleness and genl misery of health; had such an unconquerable radiancy of cheerfulness, and tranquil clearness, and warmth of affection and generosity to those about her, as are now forever memorable to those that looked on them. To me her loss has been the loss of all that made life valuable; and I do not seem to gather much insensibility to it; but at all hours of the day, and every turn of my procedures in the world, am painfully reminded that she, my
bright fellow-pilgrim, has gone from me beyond the stars, and that the rest of my journey must be done wearily alone. It is the will of God, it is the everlasting Order of Nature; and I must not repine,—nor do I; but strive always to readjust my astonished thoughts, and try more and more to set myself and “my house in order,” and to find still something not quite useless whh I may do for the days that remain, till I follow not unworthily those that have honourably gone. Enough on this subject, dear Brother of my young years now far away; more than enough,—for you know already, in yr own sympathetic heart, all that I cd say upon it.

My busss at present is with two small things I had to send you as memorial: the first is a Photograph done the year before her death, and incomparably the best there ever was of her; April 1865; see 41:215 TC to JOWA, 21 April 1865
, and TC to JAC, 10 Oct.
it will recal many remembrances, and be a softly pious kind of company to yr thots now and then. The other is the bit of green Paper here inclosed, whh I have been intending for some time and whh is now come to hand in the ready state.TC sent £100 to John A. Carlyle to be changed into a money order to send to Canada: “17 Octr 1866 / to Brr John (for Alick in Canada) / £100 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753); John A. Carlyle replied, 18 Oct.: “I … enclose the £100 order for Alick which I have got from the Bank of Scotland. … The Bank Order costs nothing. Today is the Canada post, but there is also one on Saturday.” The small Gift is to me, in no conceivable sense, any loss at all; and you it may be of some use,—to help some of yr children, to do this or that: no doubt there are “holes that need stopping up,” and you will find uses for it. Consider it as her Gift; she is in part the cause of it,—the guiding cause at this time. I told you once, I was grown rich; that is not so true as I then thot it (for my revenues, coming out Book sales their fluctuations, soon fell off agn; but it is still true enough; and of money there is indisputably abundance and super-abundance far beyond what I shall ever (to all allWord repeated with a line over it at turn of page. appearance) have the least chance to need;—so that, if at any time you are in a strait, I charge you strictly to let me know; it will be a real charity to me. Alas, it is, at all times, so little we can do for one another:—and the time is fast striding on, when it will be nothing, forever!— My blessing be with you, dear Brother, with all that are yours, far over the sea yonder.

I am myself in average bodily health; not worse that way, since April last; perhaps even some slight shade better, so quiet and mostly passive have I been: but indeed the 12 years deadly wrestle with my last Book had quite broken me of itself, not to speak of the 58 foregoing years,TC was 70. and New calamities that have followed! I am living quite alone for the last two months and more; and tho’ it is occasionally not a little dreary, and at all times sad and sombre more or less, I find it more supportable than most kinds of company I might
have. The Dr, as you know, was with me most of the summer; so was “Maggie Welsh” (one of the Liverpool Cousins, used to the house here): John talked of being back perhaps in Novr; Maggie too will consent to come if I ask it;—and it is not yet certn how I shall finally arrange. There was left me here an excellt elderly servant,Sarah Warren. of highly respectable, skilful rational ways; with her, and a small gleg little girlAlice Clark, employed 23 Sept.
under her, the house goes on quite reasonably well hitherto, and I have no disturbance on that side.

From John I heard the other day;—indeed it was he that got ready for me that green Paper inclosed:—our Dumfriesshire friends are all in their usual health; and nothing very bad happening to any of them. Bad harvest (the worst I can remember, for weather, since 1816 at Mainhill) they have indeed had; but cattle is now more more their dependance, and the prices of that are still good. Jamie, I think, is not much stronger than one of us (tho 8 years younger than even you); and has had some domestic “pluisters”Presumably the hasty marriage of James’s son James Jr. to his cousin Catherine Austin, who was the housekeeper at Scotsbrig, and James’s accident on the way home from the wedding; see TC to JCA, 6 Oct.
(no Wife and no Daughter there for him now!), but, I hear, is getting well clear agn.

Nothing of yr harvest, whh is more importt than the Annandale one, has come to our knowledge here; nor of what the elders and the younger branches of you are at;—nothing since TomAlexander’s eldest son, Thomas. wrote to us; who always sends distinct accounts. We latterly sometimes bother ourselves on yr account about the mad Fenian rumours whh the Newsprs bring: never was anything madder, tho’ doubtless it more or less disturbs those that are in close neighbourhood to it.The Fenian Brotherhood was an Irish Republican organization in the U.S., which supported Irish independence through political, financial, and military means. In the first half of 1866, several Fenian raids were made on British installations in Canada. Because of supply shortages and a lack of coordination and manpower, the Fenians were soon defeated and many were arrested and imprisoned; many Fenians wrote letters of protest to Andrew Johnson (1808–75), president of the U.S., 1865–69, complaining of a lack of assistance from the U.S. consul, and requesting his assistance to obtain their release. In Oct. a group of Fenians assembled in Vermont, apparently with the intention of again raiding into Canada, but were deterred by U.S. troops. I believe nothing whatever of actual will come of it more; and that, when once the Yankee Elections are over (whh will be next month), it will die out altogether; no Yankee Politicn, never so blackguard, having the temptatn to pretend flattering it farther.Facing mid-term Congressional elections, the Democratic President Johnson, although anxious not to alienate the large Irish-American population that usually voted Democrat, was also concerned not to violate existing neutrality laws with Canada. The Times reported, 16 Oct.: “In view of the engrossing importance of the autumn elections now pending in America the Fenians are just now the object of most tender considerations from both parties. … [T]he President is doing everything in his power to keep the Fenians in the Democratic ranks.”— — Tell us how you all are, dear Brother; none
of us can ever forget you here, least of all I. We have some Photographs, shd not object to more. Jenny youFor the photograph of Alick and his wife, Janet, see 42:221–22 TC to JAC, 14 Sept. 1865
. are framed in my little dressing-room, every morng noon;—you quite the old face, every lineament of it known to me. Adieu, dear Brother, with my warmest blessing. Yrs ever /
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-J[UC] [JUC], 21 Oct. Pbd: New York Times, 22 April 1883; Wilson, Carlyle 6:109–10 inc. According to the New York Times, the recipient was “a lady of this City”; TC called her Juliette; unidentified further.
div3.head: TC TO JULIETTE [UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT]

docBody.p: You pretty, but unreasonable, child! I never translated “Goethe’s Works,” nor any part of them but the “Wilhelm Meister,” and some short fractions scattered up and down among my own writings. The “Wilhelm Meister,” (both parts) I would willingly send you, but the Publisher here informs me that the conveyance, c., to New-York will outweigh any advantage to you, and that the direct and easiest plan is that you apply to “Johnston Co.” (address inclosed) who are close at hand,TC’s publisher was Chapman Hall; Johnston Co. was presumably a New York bookseller. in case you actually want a “Wilhelm Meister” which is itself uncertain to me.

Don’t calculate on seeing me when you next come to London. I am grown very old; have no desire—but the contrary—for being “seen”—and find my little remnant of time all occupied with infinitely more important things. Read me, read Goethe, and if you will be a good girl, and feel a call to do so, read all the good books you can come at; and carefully avoid (like poison) all the Bad, so far as you can discriminate them, which will be more and more, the more faithfully you try. Happy is he (still more is she) who has got to know a Bad Book by the very flavor; and to fly from it, (and from the base, vain and unprofitable soul that wrote it) as from a thing requiring to be left at once to leeward! And let me tell you further, pretty little Juliette, reading, even of the best, is but one of the sources of wisdom, and by no manner of means, the most important. The most important, all-including is, that you love wisdom loyally in your heart of hearts; and that wherever you learn from a Book, or elsewhere, a thing credibly wise, you don’t lose time in calling or thinking it “wise,” but proceed at once to see how, with your best discernment, energy, and caution, you can manage to do it! That is the rule of rules; that latter.
May your years be many, and bright with modest nobleness; “happy” enough they will be, in such case—and so adieu, my pretty child.

div3.head: TC TO FRANCES WEDGWOOD

docBody.p: I was sorry to have missed you agn, when you were so good as [to] call. It is very long since we met; and much has befallen us since then!As well as JWC’s death, TC probably also refers to the death of the Wedgwoods’ eldest son, James Macintosh Wedgwood (1834–64); see 40:82TC to JWC, 28 April 1864.

I wd. right willingly come on Saty. Evg.; but alas I must not, I cannot! I have not been out, to dinner or the like, since April last; and feel mostly as if I cd. never go agn.; at least I shudder from it as time yet is. Tell Darwin how faithfully I always remember him, and his unwearied goodness to me, among many sufferings of his own.Erasmus Darwin (1804–81) had been a close friend of the Carlyles (particularly JWC) since; see 9:148TC to JAC, 17 Feb. 1837, and 41:29TC to JWC, 16 Sept.1864; for his condolence letter to TC on JWC’s death, see 43:223TC to TE, 1 May; he was often unwell.
I constantly hope to call at Cumberland Place;The Wedgwood family lived at 1 Cumberland Place, Regent’s Park. and will some day in spite of distance.

div3.sourceNote: TC-[CAW?], 22 Oct. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. Recipient conjecturally identified as Charles Augustus Ward, who had previously sent gifts of vegetables and fruit to the Carlyles at this time of year; see TC to CAW, 11 Sept. 1864 , and TC to CAW, 21 Oct. 1865 . Otherwise unidentified; pheasants were previously sent or given by the Airlies ( JWC to LAI, [28 Nov. or 5 Dec. 1859]), Charlotte Williams Wynn (1807–69; ODNB ) ( JWC to TC, [14 Jan. 1848]), and from The Grange ( JWC to TC, [18 Jan. 1858], and JWC to IEB, [14 Jan. 1860]).
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES A. WARD

docBody.p: On Saty evg, you sent me a brace of beautiful Birds; many thanks to you for such munificence and friendly remembrance.

The Birds were not a feather of them lost; tho’ to me Pheasants are a forbidden
dainty;For TC’s negative reaction to eating pheasant, see 36:47JWC to MCA, [16 Jan. 1860].—you may remember that another time, when such a golden Cock of the woods comes to hand.

It is a long while since I saw you here:Ward had apparently called late Oct. 1865; see 43:19TC to CAW, 21 Oct. 1865. I am commonly alone in the evg (Wednesday sometimes excepted); doing, from 8 o’clock to 1, nothing more importt than read.

div3.sourceNote: TC-TW [TWO], [24 Oct.]. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote on J. R. Parsons’s letter to Robert Scott Tait, 23 Oct., presumably forwarded by Tait to TC.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p: Dear Woolner,—I need not bid you pay good heed to this,—whh Tait has just sent me from ParsonsParsons wrote to Tait, 23 Oct.: “there are some pencil marks on the small negative of Mrs Carlyle—on the face—which I think had better be wiped off before any printing is done from it, or else—the prints will require after touching” (MS: Hilles). See also TC to RST, 30 July. (author of the Negative that leans cheek on hand, and has no bonnet.Presumably the negative was made by Parsons from Tait’s April 1855 photograph of JWC (see frontis.) or Tait’s 28 July 1854 photograph of JWC (see above). For the enameling of JWC’s photographs, see TC to TWO, 16 Nov. No delay! Yrs ever

figure.p:
Jane Welsh Carlyle, by Robert Scott Tait, 28 July 1854
Courtesy of Carlyle’s House, National Trust

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 24 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Yr kindness to me is at all times great and genuine; I never can forget that, nor to be grateful for it:—but the sudden message of last night has thrown me quite into a tumult;Lady Ashburton wrote, 21 Oct.: “the thing that my mind is full of, is your visit to me—there is no use putting it off till the latter end of Decr—if you can muster courage to come, it ought to be before the cold of winter has come on— It seems to me that the best plan, is for Baily to go to England, accompany you back … he has many things to do there—so that you need [not] be uncomfortable at thinking he is returning only for you.” James Bailey, Lady Ashburton’s butler. and makes me, for the moment, almost despair of Mentone altogether!

I do devoutly hope Bailey has not set out for England “in a day or two”Lady Ashburton wrote: “I shall send Bailey probably in a day or 2 … he will remain in England till you start— Do make up your mind for this.” The letter was presumably forwarded to John A. Carlyle, as TC wrote at the foot of the letter: “Goes like a ‘High Wind’! I have written in brief absolute prohibitn of ‘Bailey’ (the Butler); promising to fix ‘yes or no’ at the end of Novr, if left free,—if not, no at once. Rather unpleast to be out in high winds!” He then wrote on the reverse of the letter: “Lady An: ‘Baily just coming for you’! (Octr 24 or so)—was forbidden at once.” (whh, strictly counting, wd be this morning, wednesday); but that he is still quietly following his affairs beside you at Glion, when this ansr arrives,—whh I send off witht loss of a moment.
