By no means let Baily now, or at any time, come to escort or accompany me;Lady Ashburton replied, [28 Oct.]: “Bailey is still here—as I thought it possible you might not care to have him—now I shall not send him— Take your own time—you will always be welcome.” TC wrote on the back of the letter: “Lady Ashbn last (abt 29 octr 1866.” believe me I shall manage the journey very well, or at any rate, best, on my own resources, and at my own time,—if, on serious practical consideratn (whh has not yet been suffictly given), the kind haven of hospitality and friendly shelter you offer me on that bright shore, do seem to promise real improvet, and not the contrary (in whh latter case you yrself be the first not to wish it, but to forbid it absolutely), in my poor shattered affairs. At the prest time, it is flatly impossible: nothing, not one item round me or in me, is ready for such an enterprise; I have even something of writing (what I fondly call ‘work’) whh goes on daily, and whh will last me still a month,TC was writing his reminiscences of Edward Irving; he noted, 12 Oct.: “Going on with ‘Irving’; worth little” (TC’s journal; privately owned).—were there even nothing else, I cd not afford to quit that till I had tied it up, locked it away, complete. In the rear of whh or alongside of whh, there are, of greater and of smaller or smallest, such mists and multiplicities of “things,”—not to be left in a coil, but in a sorted state, before lifting anchor.— In short, abt the end of next month, if you will please to be so patient with me, and to let the matter hang loose so long, I will say positively whether I am to come or not: and in the former event (whh I still hope), Tyndall, I consider, who is worth ten couriers to me, will be my real resource for the travelling part.John Tyndall had accompanied TC to Edinburgh for his rectorial address (see 43:146JWC to TC, [28 March], 150–52TC to JWC, 30 March, and Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 12–14) and had offered to accompany TC to Menton; see TC to LLA, 7 Sept. So let it stand, dear Lady; and don’t fret yrself abt such an affair any further.

Miss Bromley seemed to calculate on catching you for a few days, on yr road to Mentone: is that quite gone aback?— It is not from me that the “Thro’-ithers” shall get any furtherance: trust me there!— — And now to my “Work”
so-called, in this still almost solemn Hermitage, -tageEnd of word repeated with a line over it at top of following page.; where I have not spoken to any body (nor much wished to speak) since Sunday last.

div3.sourceNote: TC-TE, 27 Oct. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:318–19.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS ERSKINE

docBody.p: Dear Mr. Erskine,—Your word of remembrance was very welcome to me, and has gone ringing through my solitude here with a gentle, pleasant, and friendly sound ever since. I have had many thoughts since I last saw you,This was presumably at the end of TC’s stay with Thomas Erskine, 11 Gt. Stuart St., Edinburgh, during the rectorial visit, 31 March to 7 April; see 43:153–54TC to JWC, (1 April), 158–59TC to JWC, 3 April. Erskine was unable to attend JWC’s funeral; see 43:222TC to TE, 1 May. silent nearly all, and mostly beyond the domain of words. A calamity which was most sudden, which was infinite to me, and for which there is no remedy conceivable, my poor little home in this world, as if struck by lightning, when I least expected it, and shattered all into ruin!— I have had enough to think of, to mourn over, and earnestly consider; taking counsel of the Eternities mainly, and of such still voices as dwell there. I have been and am very sad, sad as death I may well say; but not miserable either; nothing of the mean wretchedness which has defaced other long portions of my life. This is all noble, tender, solemn to me. I might define it as a time of divine worship rather, perhaps the only period of real worship I have known for a great while past. I have tried considerably to be busy, too, and am still trying. Much has to be set in order, and rest is not permitted till I follow whither she has gone before me. May my death, which stands calmly consolatory in my sight at all moments, be beautiful as hers, and God’s will be done now and for ever.

For several weeks there was absolutely no speech or company. Now there is occasionally an hour of rational discourse, which is worth something. Vain, idle talk, which is always rife enough, I find much sadder than any form of silence. My bodily health is not worse, perhaps ever a shade better than what you last saw of it. My arrangements for the winter are not yet fixed; but I try to keep myself in what I fondly call work, of a weak kind, fitted to my weakness. That is my anchor, if it will hold. Adieu, dear Mr. Erskine! Here has F.J. A. Froude lived nearby at 5 Onslow Gdns., Fulham Rd., and was one of TC’s most regular callers. come in upon me, who is my nearest neighbour and a good man. I must say farewell.

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: Helen Jemina Chalmers (1826–87), 5th da. of the Scottish theologian and the Carlyles’ old friend Thomas Chalmers (1780–1847; ODNB), wrote, 26 Oct.: “I remember how much pleased my father was by your kindly helping him with his West Port church— when it was suggested that there should be an authors stall at the Bazaar to be held in December in aid of the Workmen’s Club … I thought that you wd kindly pardon me asking you to send a volume of yours to it—even tho’ you might not be able to grant my request. / I remember how thoroughly my father enjoyed your Cromwell— I still have the copy he read all covered with his marks.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-BA [BAT], 29 Oct. Pbd: Blanche Atkinson, “My Four Letters from Carlyle,” Good Words 33 (1892): 460.
div3.head: TC TO BLANCHE ATKINSON

docBody.p: In my great darkness as to the fair young Blanche’s affairs, how can I advise? I will say only: A young lady’s chief duty and outlook is not to write novelsAtkinson wrote later: “It seems to me, looking back across all these years, almost incredible that the idea of writing to Mr. Carlyle (of all people in the world!) to consult him as to the wisdom of continuing to write a novel upon which I was then engaged, should ever have entered my head. And to write to him then, only six months after his wife’s death, and to hope, however dimly, that he would really give the weighty matter his attention, was surely as wild a piece of presumption as even a conceited girl was ever guilty of! But the thought of the tremendous seriousness of life, and the fear that writing a novel was a foolish way of spending time, had laid hold upon me and could not be thrown off. On the other hand, I was ambitious. … Already my heroine had gone through a course of ‘Modern Painters’ and Ruskinism. My hero was in the very act of becoming acquainted with a clergyman of the type of Frederick Maurice, who was intended to bring him from the condition of the ‘Everlasting No’ to the ‘Everlasting Yes,’ and to the gospel of ‘Sartor Resartus.’ / ‘Write and ask Carlyle’—was the only thing I could think of to settle the question; and I wrote. I believe that my real hope was that he would answer, ‘By all means go on. You write so beautifully, and your intentions are so good, that it would be a serious loss to the world to be without your novel’” (Good Words 460). (especially not while she is ‘ignorant of the world,’ and not even perhaps when she knows it too well!)—but, by-and-by, to be queen of a household, and to manage it queenlike and womanlike. Let her turn her whole faculty and industry in that direction; shove her own novel well aside for a good while, or forever; and be shy even of reading novels. If she do read, let it be good and wise books (more and more exclusively those) which not one in ten thousand of the kind called ‘novels’ now is.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JA Jr. [JAJR], 31 Oct. MS: NLS 518.30. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES AITKEN JR.

docBody.p: Come to me, Saturday for dinner stay till Monday morng,—if it is convent and you like: and be sure you let me know on Saty morning at latest whether it is or not.

div3.sourceNote: TC-EJE, 1 Nov. MS: Mitchell Lib., Sydney, Australia. Pbd: Workman 96–98. Quot: Kaplan 492.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD JOHN EYRE

docBody.p:
Your LetterE. J. Eyre wrote, 29 Oct.: “For some time past I have been wishing to write to you to thank you for the prompt and generous manner in which you came forward to promote the formation of a Committee to aid me in my defence against the prosecutions or rather I should say the persecutions threatened by the self styled ‘Jamaica committee.’ / I can no longer refrain from acting on my wish now that the proceedings of that Body have assumed a reality and that the Committee of which you are Vice Chairman has thought it necessary to engage Counsel for my Defence.” is very welcome to me and very gratifying, tho’ it was not necessary. Believe me, it is not you that are in my debt; it is rather I that am in Yrs. The insane uproar rising round such a man, as recompense for such service done, was a summons to all sane citizens to stand forth as yr vindicators.Eyre wrote: “I cheerfully accepted the responsibility which my position [as governor of Jamaica] entailed upon me and I should have deemed myself unworthy of the name of Englishman and undeserving of the high trust reposed in me by my Sovereign, had I hesitated or wavered at such a time. / That many of my fellow countrymen should have misjudged me is naturally a source of pain and regret but it is not so much on my own account as that I feel ashamed that persons calling themselves English gentleman should allow traditional prejudices and biases or political and partisan considerations to warp their judgment and lead them to acts as ungenerous as they are unjust.” Many have already done so; and innumerable more (as I happen to have some evidence) will do so, and shake away their present bits of cautions
cowardices, shd the pinch, or real attempt, ever come. In a word, if I in my poor sphere can have done you any good, it was a clear gain to myself first of all; and with no trouble whh was not (for good reasons) a satisfactn as well.

For yourself, dear Sir, and yr good cause, I will say only, Courage, courage! Have not you been in worse than this before now (also witht blame of yr own), and yet have come out of it triumpht?Possibly a reference to an occurrence during one of Eyre’s journeys in Australia described in his Journals of Expedition of Discovery into Central Australia, and Overland, from Adelaide to King George’s Sound in the Years 1840–41 (1845); his friend and overseer John Baxter (ca. 1799–1841) was killed by two aborigines who had been serving as guides; they ran away, taking firearms and some of the provisions, leaving Eyre and one aborigine to travel alone for a month through the bush. Often in the blackest coil of tempests and distresses, there is found ultimately, for the brave man, new victory and brightness to have lain hidden.— —

It will give me real pleasure to make your acquaintance with you when you come to Town.Eyre wrote: “Hoping ere long I have the pleasure of making your acquaintance and of thanking you in person for all your kindness.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-HH, [ca. 1 Nov.]. Pbd: Shepherd, Carlyle 2:242.
div3.head: TC TO HAMILTON HUME

docBody.p: To Hamilton Hume, Esq., c. c.

Please write to this Salford (Manchester) man;TC’s letter to Hume was written on the back of a letter to TC from Thomas Gibbons, asking for information on the Eyre situation; Gibbons unidentified further.—and set him upon getting up a subscription there?

Your Committee ‘pamphlet’Hume, ed., The Eyre Defence and Aid Fund. is much approved of; and a wider and wider circulation of it recommended. So says a brother of mine from Dumfries,—for whom I have a £5 to pay you (on Monday, I hope).TC noted: “5 Novr 1866 / Hamn Hume (Eyre Defence Fund,—for Brr John, who will pay at Dumfries / £5 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). The newspaper slips in re GordonPresumably reports from either Jamaican or British newspapers concerning George William Gordon; see TC to CDB, 30 Aug. were both good: thanks for sending them. I have written to Mr. Eyre, in reply to his interesting letter. Professor TyndallTyndall wrote to the Jamaica Committee, 7 Nov., saying that having carefully examined all the facts, he had decided to join the Eyre Defence Committee (Hamilton Hume, Life of Edward John Eyre [1867] 268–76). The letter was pbd., Morning Post, 8 Nov., with a covering letter from Hume: “Professor Tyndall having forwarded to me the following letter addressed to the Jamaica Committee, and believing as I do that it is likely to interest the public, I shall esteem it a favour if you will permit it to appear in your columns.” seemed to be
contemplating something of public utterance on our affair: has he been with you? As above said, I hope to call on Monday.TC’s signature has been cut away.

div3.sourceNote: TC-BA [BAT], 1 Nov. Pbd: Blanche Atkinson, “My Four Letters from Carlyle,” Good Words 33 (1892): 460–61.
div3.head: TC TO BLANCHE ATKINSON

docBody.p: I like this second letter better than the former;See TC to BAT, 29 Oct. After receiving TC’s letter of discouragement, Atkinson wrote: “I shed a few mortified tears over this complete extinguishing of my hopes; but I wrote my thanks for the advice, and promised to obey it, as far as concerned the shoving aside of my novel. I protested, however, against the idea that a girl’s only outlook was to be towards marriage; and affirmed that to be ‘queen of a household’ was not and could never be my chief desire in life. I was then visiting a widowed aunt, in whose school I liked to give a good deal of time to the pleasant work of teaching; and I told Mr. Carlyle that fact, and assured him that I loved ‘good and wise books,’ and studied them as I had the opportunity. I wish I had kept a copy of my letter. I know it was written in warm earnestness; evidently something in it pleased him, for he wrote once more—this lovely letter, and enclosed his photograph” (460). better news for me that you are faithfully teaching your good aunt’s schoolAtkinson’s aunt (unidentified further) had a school at Farnworth, near Warrington. than writing novels. And, furthermore, I see in you a spurt of proper maidenly pride, which is much to my mind; ‘Quit the noble pride of thy heart never!’ (says Richter, to one who had grown nobly old un-married). Not necessary to be married; but it is necessary to live wisely and with dignity, to be true and useful, and to work well while it is called to-day!

In sum, therefore: Be a good, diligent, and prudent girl; summon up your own best judgement; vigilantly exercise it, ‘eyes well open, lips oftenest well shut;’ it is your own judgement alone, and no other person’s, that can wisely guide your steps, wisely select your objects, and your methods towards them. I say, exercise it, with pious fidelity; and loyally do, in a courageous yet modest manner, without loitering, what it audibly bids you; it will, on such terms (not on others) really and daily improve upon you, and become more luminous and trustworthy.

Married or not married, surely it is always fit and comely that a woman do know domesticities to the bottom? One expects to find it of her, when need comes; as of a man, that he can resist when insulted.

Nor do I forbid you literature, if there absolutely be no better aim. But in that case, first prepare for it: read, study, reflect; inquire far and near (perhaps in various ages, in various countries or languages); become acquainted
with the great souls that have been—see if you have anything to add which is distinctly in their spirit; and if yes, do so.Atkinson later published several novels and stories for children.

And now let us be silent, dear Blanche—for that is best, on both sides;—and never doubt but I do wish you well, and feel obliged by your regard of me. In token of which fact, here is the shadow of my old face, come as if to assure you of it. Farewell; and may a good genius guide you.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2 Nov. MS: NLS 526.47. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Yr news of yesterday were all good; and I am very well pleased and much satisfied indeed,—especially that Jamie can fairly have Craigenputtock,TC’s plan to lease Craigenputtoch to his brother Jamie; see TC to JAC, 2 Aug. all my notions abt it being fulfilled; he shall have the specified quantity of limePulverized limestone used to correct acidity in the soil. c; nor shall CommonJohn Common (ca. 1827–89), tenant at Craigenputtoch since; he was at first thought to be a good and active tenant; see 33:128TC to JAC, [7] Dec. 1857, and 34:99–100 , but had apparently become less so in recent years. be bothered into haggles;—I wish only, the sum necessary for “repairs” (house, offices, fences) cd be equitably fixed, to whh also I wd at once agree; but perhaps that cannot be settled just yet.— If Jamie get Craigenvey,Craigenvey, farm about 1 mi. (1.5 km.) NW of Craigenputtoch. he seems to suit it better than another, and I trust it too may be profitable to him. It will be a real pleasure to me for the rest of my life, to think of him John living prosperously diligt contented and in peace up yonder!— — Inclosed is the “Valuatn”; of whh I never read one word (except yr abstract of it): get a Lease drawn out (any “time” Jamie likes, not exceeding 21 years;—or is 19 the old legal custom?)According to the entry for Dunscore parish, written 1835, in The New Statistical Account of Scotland (Edinburgh, 1845) 344–45: “The duration of leases is generally fifteen years, and sometimes nineteen.” The previous lease of Craigenputtoch had been for 15 years; see 27:9TC to JAC, 10 Jan. 1852. in such form as you judge to be best safest: then WhitsundayWhitsunday was one of the Scottish quarter days, the traditional times for leasing of farms; in 1867 it fell on 9 June. may come; I hope all will be right there.

Not less satisfactory seems yr acct of the Entry; since the FactorMr. Maxwell, unidentified further; John A. Carlyle wrote, 26 Nov.: “Poor Maxwell (Factor) lost a son last week by fever … so did not come in … nothing was got done about Entry money.” is an
equitable reasonable man gentn, I leave to judge there will be no difficulty farther with him, when he has studied the ground he stands on.

And this being all of busss today, I will stop short; my fire being out, and a long walk rather recommendable. Were it not for those sad “bowels” (all ruined and relaxed) I cd still walk a long way: but we must not be unthankful either!— “Jem”James Aitken Jr. is coming to me Saty-Monday. Blessings on you all

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, [ca. 5 Nov.]. MS: NLS 526.48. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by James Aitken Jr.’s visit 3–5 Nov.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—I have hardly a minute left; but will write to you today rather than tomorrow, in ansr to yr Letter of this morning.

I did not understand that Jamie’s Offer of rent rested at all on the WalkerMr. Walker not further identified. valuatn, but on his own deliberate estimate (formed during many years) of what the place might be worth to him,—whh latter estimate I consider fairly likelier than Walker’s to be true. If you think the utmost study of Walker can throw any New or difft light on Jamie’s practical conclusn, by all means let him see it, study it till he is satisfied, and then revoke his Offer, to what extent he likes,—he shall not be bound by this Offer at all, if he wishes to change! But on my own side, I confess I have no notion to propose a revocatn of it; any little knowledge I have of the matter (or of Jamie’s former estimatings abt it) goes rather the reverse way. But he shall have, and has by these presents, perfect liberty to do so,—you, of course, forbearing to write to Common that the farm is let, till we see farther.

As to the Lease, if that be the course you decide upon for Wedny,—I wished a Clause added abt the Tenant’s actually keeping up the fences (once they are set up for him), and protecting the woods: I believe there was such an engaget undertaken by Common (tacitly I will suppose, for he never tried to keep it); but on Jamie’s part I wish it to be expressly promised, in whh case, knowing my man, I will take it for equivalent to performed.

No more today: I am not in good case, have to run out. Yesterday Jim I pilgrimed to Neuberg (found him c all right enough);—and today it proves to have been too far rather, or at least too hurried.— Froude had already found he was wrong abt Kirkaldy’s death.Sir William Kirkcaldy of Grange (ca. 1520–73; ODNB), Scottish politician and soldier; a Protestant reformer, he nevertheless supported Mary Queen of Scots (1542–87; ODNB) in the civil war against James Douglas (ca. 1516–81; ODNB), 4th earl of Morton, regent of Scotland 1572–78; defeated while trying to hold Edinburgh Castle for her, he was executed for treason on the afternoon of 3 Aug. 1573. On his deathbed, 1572, John Knox (ca. 1514–72; ODNB), Scottish religious reformer, had prophesied that Kirkcaldy would die with the sun on his face, asking a friend to go to Kirkcaldy, “whom, yee know, I have loved so deerelie,” and bid him “leave that evill cause, and give over that castell. If not, he sall be brought doun over the walls of it with shame, and hang against the sunne” (David Calderwood, History of the Kirk of Scotland [Edinburgh, 1842–49] 3:284–85). Froude wrote: “He was hung with his face looking up the street towards the Castle”; when the cart carrying him drove off, his body swung round so that the afternoon sun was on his face (Froude, History of England from the Fall of Wolsey to the Death of Elizabeth [1866] 10:475); however the castle lies W from the gallows in the High Street, so that when Kirkcaldy’s body swung round he would have been facing east, away from the afternoon sun. In the next edn. of his work Froude rewrote the sentence: “He was hung with his face looking down the street towards Holyrood” (Froude, History of England from the Fall of Wolsey to the Death of Elizabeth [1870] 10:475).

div3.head: TC TO FREDERIC W. FARRAR

docBody.p: I am very sensible of the honourFarrar recalled later: “When I was at Harrow I founded one of those Scientific and Natural History Societies among the boys. … I … strongly felt that to see and hear great men was, in itself, a sort of liberal education for young boys. I therefore invited several men of great eminence to come and give us lectures. … I was anxious that the boys should see and hear Carlyle, and I wrote to invite him to deliver a lecture. … Carlyle was interested in my request, for he afterwards spoke about it to Professor Tyndall, who told me that when he informed the Sage of Chelsea of his intended lecture to the school, Carlyle answered in his deep voice, ‘Mind you don’t tell them anything which is not true!’” (Farrar 272–73). Farrar gave a lecture, “On Some defects in Public School Education,” at the Royal Institution, 8 Feb. 1867; he dedicated the printed pamphlet of it to Tyndall. you do me; and surely shd be well pleased, cd I do yr young people any good at all:—but regret to ansr that, especially in present circumstances, such an enterprise is not practicable to me.
With thanks and regards,

div3.sourceNote: TC-[BWP], [8 Nov.]. Quot: Catalogue No. 287, Carnegie Book Shop (New York, 1960) 5. Presumably a reply to an invitation from Bryan Waller Procter.
div3.head: TC TO [B. W. PROCTER]

docBody.p:
I see almost no society at prest, and have little aptitude or tendency that way,Procter wrote, [6 Nov. 1866]: “Once in the year—on the 21st November—I have always a little social party, of old friends. … We shall dine at 7 o’clock precisely, there will be some roast mutton (good I hope) wine. I should like to see you amongst them, if you would like (or rather if you would not dislike to come. / If I live to that day (the 21st of the month) I shall be 77 years old: I am old enough to have discovered that life has little—if anything that is beyond old friends books. Make one of the former if you can.” For Procter’s confusion about his age, see TC to BWP, 17 Aug.
finding silence, and the steady application to what of work is possible.TC wrote on the envelope: “refused (handsomely) may return.” John A. Carlyle wrote, 26 Nov.: “I return Procter’s letter which is interesting tho’ of course his dinner wd not have suited you.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-MH [MHU], 9 Nov. Addr: 1. Tor Villas, Campden Hill / Kensington. PM: London, 9 Nov. 1866. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd. The envelope was addressed to “Miss Margt Hunt” but TC’s salutation at the beginning and end of the letter was “Madam”; Margaret Hunt, b. Raine (1831–1912; ODNB), novelist; she and her husband, Alfred William Hunt (1830–96; ODNB), artist, rented 1 Tor Villas from their friend William Holman Hunt (1827–1910; ODNB), Pre-Raphaelite artist, from 1865.
div3.head: TC TO MARGARET HUNT

docBody.p:
Thanks for yr pleast little Gift;Apparently a letter written by Jean Paul Richter (1763–1825), German novelist and humorist, about whom TC had written and some of whose works he had translated; see Carlyle, Works 22:117–332 and 27:96–159. For a previous gift of a Richter autograph, see 43:64TC to MEW, 4 Dec. 1865. whh has interested me more than cd have been expected. The catching of old Gleim’s Letter (Septimus Fixlein)Johann Wilhelm Ludwig Gleim (1719–1803), poet and canon of Halberstadt; see Carlyle, Works 19:303. Gleim sent Richter 50 Prussian dollars as a token of gratitude for his writings, May 1796; he signed the letter “Septimus Fixlein,” a pun on Richter’s Leben des Quintus Fixlein (1795); see Life of Jean Paul F. Richter, compiled from various sources, together with his Autobiography (1845) 196 and Carlyle, Works 27:135–36. just in the act of arrival is curious; also the mention of Otto,Christian Otto (1763–1828); friend of Richter from 1785 (Life of Richter 146); after Richter’s death, Otto ed. and pbd. Richter’s Warheit aus Jean Paul’s Leben, 3 vols. (Breslau, 1826–28), reviewed by TC in “Jean Paul Friedrich Richter Again”; see Carlyle, Works 27:96–159. who has since become
Richter’s Biographer. Your reading seems all to be correct; all except almost the last word, “Kornen,”Possibly Herr Korner, Richter’s landlord in Leipzig, 1782; see Life of Richter 128–30 and Carlyle, Works 27:125; otherwise unidentified.—whh, had it even been “Können,” and a real German word, points towards no sense. The signature, I conclude, is gone; the style, the handwriting, and the substance of facts are, no doubt, verificatn enough.

Kahla (written “Kahle”) is a Town not many miles from Hof in Voigtland.Kahla, town in Thuringia, about 34 mi. (55 km.) N of Hof, Richter’s hometown in Bavaria. Voigtland was an old name for the region now comprising parts of Bavaria, Saxony, Thuringia, and the Czech Republic. Jean Paul had lately published his Hesperus;Richter’s Hesperus was pbd. 1796. and been touring abt, now grown a famous man. He lived habitually at Hof, till his Mother’s DeathRichter’s mother was Sophia Kosina, b. Kuhn (d. 1797). there in 1797. It is possible enough the Letter may have been addressed to Fräulein Mayer, who became his wife in 1798.Richter m., 1801, Caroline, b. Meyer (1770–1860). She was of Berlin, truly, daughter of a Physician there; but may have been on visit to WeimarWeimar, town in Thuringia about 19 mi. (30 km.) NW of Kahla. when the acquaintance was first made: it is certn they directly went to settle in Weimar after wedding; and continued there for some years. Pity that the Letter is not complete!—
With many thanks, I remain,
docBody.closer: Dear Madam, / Yrs sincerely T. Carlyle

div3.head: TC TO WILHELMINA BEHRENS

docBody.p: Oh, you foolish Child, what good will you ever get from the “Autographs” of Authors!Wilhelmina Behrens wrote, 8 Nov.: “It has long been my most ardent wish to add the name of the world-renowned author of ‘Sartor Resartus’ to my collection of autographs of great men.” She signed herself Mina Behrens. To avoid the multitude of bad and foolish Authors, as if they were poison (whh they are), and to study well the few wise and good, try with all yr skill if they couldn’t help you a little towards wisdom of yr own,—might not that be a likelier employment?

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: Maggie Welsh wrote, 9 Nov., from her sister Jeannie Chrystal’s home, 14 Queen’s Cres., Glasgow: “Your last welcome letter Mary [Welsh] forwarded to me from the Manse [Auchtertool] a few days after I came here from Liverpool. When I first came I purposed only being a few days with Jeanie, however I was nothing loth to remain a little longer when I found that Walter [Welsh] Mary were both to be from home for a fortnight, over above all there was a regular Chimney-sweeping having to be gone through while they were away. … I had a very kind letter from Mrs Forster ten days ago, she has had a busy time of it since they were in Hans Place, latterly a most anxious time with poor Miss Forster, but I trust from what Mrs F. told me the worst was over with her. I think since then she has continued to recover. I suppose they will all now be at the sea-side somewhere. / One would fancy it rather bleak there just now, at least unless there is a little more sun-shine than we have been rejoicing in of late. This is truly the first day we have had a sight of the sun’s face since I came here, a pleasant sight it is! There was a great storm of wind yesterday with heavy rain (that is, heavier than usual!) thunder, it has really cleared the clouds fogs away in the meantime. / All the household here were ill with influenza last week; I escaped with only two days in bed, so I thought myself very lucky. I am glad to say that now all are almost well again. … I fear from what you say that in health you are not feeling very well (even as well as usual which never says much). / Is Mr Froude come home yet? It is not, one knows too well, that anyone can do much for you dear Mr Carlyle still it may help now then to cheer you for an hour or two, to see talk to a friend that you like that has such a great love for yourself. … Please forgive the troublesome small paper, but the house is this morning entirely destitute of writing paper, we forgot yesterday to get any. … With kind love for yourself from Jeanie myself / Ever yours affectly / Maggie Welsh.” Eliza Ann Forster had been in Newcastle visiting Elizabeth Forster who was an invalid; see TC to JF, 15 Oct.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], [10 Nov.]. Addr: Glion / Vevey / La Suisse, redirected in another hand to Menton. Envelope only: MS: NLS Acc. 11388.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: [Letter untraced]Apparently TC wrote more positively than previously in this letter about visiting Menton as Lady Ashburton replied, 17 Nov.: “Your letter of 10th arrived yesterday—to my great satisfaction—it would be difficult to tell you, how happy that letter made me, as giving me a clearer hope of seeing you here.” See also TC to JCA, 11 Nov.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 11 Nov. MS: NLS 518.31 inc. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Jean,——Thanks for yr usual Letter, tho’ only in one hasty word. Had I guessed that the Dr had the least wish for one of those poor “Chelsea Interiors,”Presumably photographs of Tait’s painting A Chelsea Interior; see TC to RST, 30 July. I shd have needed no hint to send him one!— I accordingly sot out the Two; packed them (began directly after reading yr Note), till I found that
the little girlAlice Clark, the maid. had actually got them off (“above two feet long,” I was afraid!)—wd begin nothing else. Let the Dr deliberately take his choice; there are no others at prest to be had; but Tait talks of making Parsons take a Negative,See TC to TWO, [23 Oct.]. whh will perhaps come better.

James brot me the Archy-Little DouglasPresumably some historical document discovered by John Aitken in his researches; see TC to JAC, 10 Oct. Possibly referring to Archibald Little 1803–88), son of Dr. William Little (1758–1847) of Cressfield House, Ecclefechan, friend of TC’s father; Archy Little studied medicine at Edinburgh Univ. with John A. Carlyle; see 2:454TC to JAC, 20 Oct. 1823; he emigrated to Australia 1825, but returned to Britain for a long visit ca. 1839–42; see 14:41TC to AC, [10 Feb. 1842]; any connection with the Douglas family, the major landowner in Dumfriesshire, is untraced. record last night; and we read it together; a process interestg to me, yet dreary sad. James is doing his best, I believe; and tho’ times are low, little or no busss has yet come his way, he keeps hoping.—— Tell the Dr (what I have twice forgot) that I paid the £5 for him to the Eyre Fund, abt week ago. Tyndall’s PaperProbably Tyndall’s letter pbd. in the Morning Post, 8 Nov.; see TC to HH, [ca. 1 Nov.]; otherwise unidentified. I wd have sent; but James informs me you have it.— I am really thinking of Mentone! Does the Dr recollect sending me a pair of hand-spun, wool-lined huge “Inverness mittens” with muffettees adjoined?TC thanked Jean for sending him muffettees (wristwarmers), Dec. 1861; see 38:23TC to JCA, 7 Dec. 1861 . The warmest things I ever had. Above 3 years ago. I am actually wearingPage ends here; the letter is incomplete.

div3.sourceNote: TC-AW, 13 Nov. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. The first and last pages of the letter are badly faded, and some words are indecipherable.
div3.head: TC TO ANN WELSH

docBody.p:
I heard two days [ago], without least hint [before], that Grace had fallen ill of liver; was confined to bed [. …] long hitherto, and that, as natural, you were all in anxiety, and she in much suffering.Maggie Welsh wrote to TC, 9 Nov.: “[Mary, Maggie’s sister] went out one day to see the Miss Welsh’s I am grieved, as I am sure you will be too, to hear that poor Miss Grace has been very unwell indeed for some little time back. She was entirely confined to her bed when Mary was there; it seems to be some very bad attack from the liver, which they fear is very much out of order.” Maggie then reported, 13 Nov.: “[Grace] has been entirely confined to bed for five weeks. If she tries to stand even for a moment she gets quite faint breathless suffers much from pain in the side chest. … [The doctors] seem quite certain that there is nothing wrong with the heart or the lungs, but that the liver is terribly out of order; truly nothing need to be worse than that. … Poor Miss Grace has had many severe illnesses one would fain hope she may yet rally from this. Miss Ann says they have a most kindly obliging servant, which must be an unspeakable comfort at such a time, that she herself is even in better health than usual. Elizabeth, she says, is just as usual, very frail. I thought you would wish to hear about poor Grace so have troubled you with this.” Grace Welsh d. 15 Feb. 1867. All this is abundantly distressing; and to me the more so, as I have, all this while, been often think[ing] of
Grace, and intending a Letter to her (if I ever wrote Letters) of [. …] thanks for a kindness she had done me,—in that clear Summary of Dates belonging to a Kindred that will be ever precious and honourable to me; and abt whh my thots have continually turned, since that Document arrived and before.Grace Welsh had written, 12 June: “I send you as correct a list as I can make, of the dates of the births deaths of our poor short lived family. The births I easily got for they are all entered in our family Bible. But for the other sad events, I had to look for through a great many letters, papers” (MS: NLS 1768.150). TC noted the next day: “june 13. This morning the adjoined Paper has come from Miss Grace Welsh, youngest of the Three Aunts, in answer to our requests; which ratifies some of the above dates, and chronological sequences. It is extracted ‘from the Old Family Bible’ and other sure sources”; TC copied the list into his reminiscences (Carlyle, Reminiscences 113–15). See also 43:238TC to LLA, 21 June. Alas, and I cannot now thank her, but am reduced to bid you thank her, for the service it has yielded me in what I was doing;—and to beg you, most especially of all, to let me know at once authentically How she is. Do this, like a good “Aunt Anne”; and don’t delay, I beseech you! That is the one errand I had today.

I have been very silent, all summer, and find it generally best to be so; solitary altogether rather than in company that wd what it calls “distract” me from my sad thots. Infinitely sad they often are; but they are also, in a sense, blessed; very tender, beautiful and high, as they may well be. But I will say no more of this.

Here are two Photographs, taken by difft people the year before her death:Presumably the photographs taken by John Watkins (1823–74) and Elliott Fry in April and May 1865; see 41:215 and 217TC to JOWA, 21 April 1865; 42:8JWC to MR, 4 May [1865]; and 48–49TC to JWC, 29 May 1865. I know not whether you can care for them at prest; but they were intended always for the House, “to go when I wrote to Grace,”—and I may send them now.
Say all that is kind to Elizabeth, especially to poor Grace in her bed of [. … … … .] as I request;—and believe me

div3.sourceNote: TC-TW [TWO], 16 Nov. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p: Dear Woolner,—When you go abt those Enamels wd you instruct the peopleWoolner was arranging enameling of a picture of Cromwell and two photographs of JWC through Sarah and Elizabeth Wootten, wholesale and retail stationers, importers of foreign goods, and photographic publishers, 152 Regent St.; the Wootton sisters’ firm apparently organized the enameling of photographs as part of their photographic publishing; it was a development, mid-19th century, of the fusing of photographs permanently onto porcelain enamel; see also TC to [AWO], 28 March 1867. to put on the back of Cromwell, the Inscriptn here adjoined,Inscription untraced; the piece of paper on which the letter is written has had the side torn off. Sotheby’s noted: “Enamel Portrait of Cromwell, in oval frame, autograph note by Carlyle at the back” (Catalolgue of Printed Books … Drawings and Engravings … c [June 1932] 42, item 217).—in what kind of letters they like best. Nay on the opposite blank part of the patch of paper,—why not write in yr own fair distinct hand, a copy of the Inscriptn, that at least they may be sure of reading it correctly? Do this, in yr usual obliging way; and keep the people awake to their engaget.—

postscript.p: (Friday 16 Novr , Chelsea)John Stanley wrote, 16 Nov., hoping to call on TC either Sat. 17 or Mon. 19 Nov.; TC wrote on the envelope: “(Coll Stanley ‘Johnny’) Novr 1866.” For TC’s tour of London slums, 7 Nov. 1865, with Johnny Stanley, see 43:29JWC to KST, 7 Nov. [1865].

div3.sourceNote: TC-GEJ, 20 Nov. Addr: 43 Markham Sq. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO GERALDINE JEWSBURY

docBody.p: Dear Miss Jewsbury,—This morng I hear from Lady A., date, Mentone 17th (Saty last). She “thanks Miss Jewsbury much”Lady Ashburton wrote, 17 Nov.: “pray thank Miss Jewsbury for recollecting her [Mary’s] wants.” c;—but, unluckily for us, is provided with a six-months Governess (daughter of the Parson of Neufch√¢tel), who is at work, altogether suits.Lady Ashburton had been looking for a governess for Mary (see TC to LLA, 16 Oct.); she continued: “I have found a most excellent … person for these six months—the daughter of the Clergyman at Neuchatel— Mary and she appear perfectly pleased with one another.” The governess was Mlle. PetitPierre (not further identified). Possibly Jewsbury had had someone specific in mind. So that is ended; at least so far as we yet see.
Her Ladyship complains of the heat at Mentone!Lady Ashburton reported: “it is too hot for you here, as yet— both Mary I are knocked down by it.”—

div3.sourceNote: TC-AS, 21 Nov. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ANTHONY STERLING

docBody.p: I am sorry to have missed sight of you agn; the chance occurs so seldom!TC and Anthony Sterling’s last recorded meeting was 31 Dec. 1865; see 43:101TC to JAC, 1 Jan.—
I have not been out to any dinner or guest-party since April last; and am still too weak of body and sad of mind to venture on such an enterprise, even on these favourable terms.

Do you still ride? If so, and you wd give me warning, I cd have a horse,TC was able to borrow a horse from Miss Bromley; Neuberg wrote to John A. Carlyle, 1 Dec.: “I rode with [TC] on [Tues.], for the first time again after a long pause. He rode a horse belonging to Miss Bromley; a very powerful fiery creature (I mean the horse, not the Miss whom I have not the honour to know), and I had occasion to admire the great bodily vigour your brother still possesses. His horse … was very unruly and troublesome, and I thought the exertion of riding him was too fatiguing for your brother, I proposed to change horses with him, he to ride my horse; when he answered: ‘Oh, you could never manage him; he would have you off in a minute!’” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). and be ready for you here any day at 3 p.m.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 26 Nov. MS: NLS 518.32. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
I know not that you can much help me to get fettled for Mentone,—nor have I yet said that I am going, tho’ it seems to grow likelier;—but you will certainly be cheering to me, in my great solitude here; and therefore I say at once, Come! I meant the Dr you shd perhaps ripen into staying here thro’ winter,—whh you might have done in such perfect freedom, with all the implemts appurtenances ready,—but I find by his Note of this morning he cd never have relished that arranget:John A. Carlyle’s letter untraced. so that the best, and clearly the one good thing is, Come yourself. On or abt the 5 of decr, I shd say,—by that time I shall have got the poor bits of Papers I am languidly working over brot to a close,TC was still writing his reminiscences of Edward Irving; they were not completed by Jean’s visit; she arrived 5 Dec. and TC wrote in his journal, 13 Dec.: “Have been writing (under such perpetual interruptns) ‘Reminiscences of Edwd Irving’ (turns out to be rather, of myself and Ed Irving!)—many pages; not yet finished; hardly once in the 3 days can I get to it, of late.—Ought probably to be burnt when done (and possibly enough shall); but in the meanwhile, the writing of it clears my own insight into these past days; has branches and sections still dearer to me than Irving;—and calms and soothes me to go on. No more today (wet, wet, and warm; as the Gulf Stream can make us!)—” (TC’s journal; privately owned). and there will be a natural vacatn for some few days. If any earlier or
later day suit you better,—well: but if not, let 5 Decr be the time. It will probably be near 3 weeks after before TyndallTyndall had offered to travel to Menton with TC. I get upon the road (if we get at all);—and yr own Jim will still be left you; and you can stay here till you have “seen London” to the full extent of yr appetite.

I cannot think of anything I specially want from Dumfries,—if it be not a pair of good black or nearly black winter-trousers,—whh BoydWilliam Boyd (1811–90), master tailor at Cummertrees; see 43:84 JWC to DRJR, [22 Dec. 1865] . cd make (better and with less fash than anybody here), if you cd find the cloth, whh I greatly doubt. My prest pair, got in imitatn of yr Johnnie’s, (black, coarse, with a particle of white here and there) have done well enough; excellt fit, but cloth vilish, not made of wool alone:—try slightly (not much) what you can do. I shall need a New dress-coat; whh must be made here: but the SnipJohn George Sampson, tailors and drapers, 2 Princes St., Leicester Sq.; see 43:84 TC to JCA, Xmas day 1865
. TC noted: “20 decr 1866 / Sampson Tailor / £4 .. 4 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). bothers me excessively in making anything whatr.
I will write to the Dr shortly; have no moment more today.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 28 Nov. MS: NLS 526.49. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:240–41 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:110.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—Unless you have some dubiety of yr own on some point of the Lease, there seems no use in the fash of sending it hither.John A. Carlyle wrote, 26 Nov.: “Do you wish to see the Draft of Lease beforehand, or can you trust Adamson me to take care that it fulfils all conditions on both sides.” If you have, send it; but I suppose there is nothing that will be dubious to Jamie or you. Jamie, I cd guess, is quite as well witht Craigenvey at that money!Their brother Jamie had contemplated leasing the farm Craigenvey; see TC to JAC, 2 Nov.
John A. Carlyle wrote: “Jamie was here last week again about Craigenvey 14 offers were given for it, Jamie’s being £250, Yorkstone has let the place to someone else at a higher rent.” It was always reckoned a place decidedly inferior to Craigenputtock.James Carlyle Jr. sent TC the annual accounts for Craigenputtoch, 16 Nov.; debits included a meeting with a road surveyor, stones for road, inspecting roads and woods; credits were for sale of wood (£285) and interest on deposit; the final balance was £300 .. 17 .. 17.

I inclose £4; the 3 are for my poor old women, any time betn this and
Newsyearsday: Babby Moffat, Lizzy Carruthers, Jenny Ker (Tom Halliday’s Widow), these are the three.Barbara Irving, b. Moffat (ca. 1791–1873), Elizabeth Carruthers (1785–1868), and Janet Halliday, b. Ker (ca. 1787–1867), winow of Tom Halliday (d. 1832). TC noted: “28 Nov r 1866 / to Dr Carlyle (Ecclefn ‘Brass-Band,’ and 3 poor people / £4 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). The money for the brass band was perhaps a contribution towards their new uniforms; the Dumfries and Galloway Standard, 8 Dec., reported a concert in Ecclefechan on 30 Nov.: “The Ecclefechan Brass Band turned out for the first time in their new band dress, which consists of white trousers with a red stripe and blue jackets trimmed with yellow braid, and which gave them a very pleasing appearance.” In his letter John A. Carlyle said he would “be guided by what Jamie says in regard to … the Brass Band.”

It appears I am actually to go to Mentone! Tyndall was here last night, one of the most determined of mankind; insists on setting off with me, depositing me scathless,—and will then, “after 6 hours or so,” return! I was shocked to hear of such a thing undertaken for my sake; but it was vain to remonstrate,—as well remonstrate with the wind. He is a strange lean, ardent kind of soul. I have not yet written to Lady A., but suppose I must, one of these days.

I finished Reeve’s two Books,See TC to JAC, 10 Oct.
after a sore haggle and tussle, several nights ago. I have nowhere found such an Irish Scholar, of any epoch; seldom or never, in late generatns, any man so thoroughly well read prepared in what he was writing abt: but alas for the arranget, the method c c it beats Banagher!“That beats Banagher”: phrase meaning either pretty bad or rather extraordinary, from the town of Banagher, Ireland, seen as a classic example of a “rotten borough.” No German is more stupid in regard to all that. To read him is a real task and weariness: it was only his more and more evidt solidity and insight that led me on.— — I was grieved, the other day to hear that he was now dead!Rev. William Reeves did not die until 1892. One Lecky, a dangling feeble kind of Irish Dandy and Dilettante (of some reputatn for the moment),William Edward Hartpole Lecky (1838–1903; ODNB), historian; his recent work, The History of the Rise and Influence of the Spirit of Rationalism in Europe (1865), was “an important contribution to history writing” (ODNB); he saw historical change as a result of impersonal and economic causes rather than of the actions of great men. whom Froude brot to me, languidly gave assurance that Reeve was dead 2 years ago! I fear there is no doubt of it.— — Yesterday I had a most brisk gallop agn, this time it has done me good. Jean will write.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 28 Nov. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. TC has written “(No 2)” upside down at the top of the letter.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Probably no correct estimate can be formed just now; but certain I shd like some Schedule of items, with guess of their several amounts,—by way of satisfactn to my ignorance;—and under the head of fences, I cd like there were included a proper Entrance Gate (from the Highway); stone posts (with bit of masonry perhaps), set straight across the road, c; this ought to be an item!

As to what is to be put into the Lease on this score, I will take Jamie himself for ultimate judge;In his first letter of 26 Nov., John A. Carlyle wrote: “Jamie told me when I saw him, that he wished to have the name of young James inserted subordinately in the lease for Craigepk, John’s name being in the leases of Scotsbrig Scalewood already, as that it wd not do to have him in Craigenpk too. Jamie will be Tenant there himself, just as he is of the other two farms—subject to no control of either of his sons— it is a matter of course to put second names in leases.” Scalewood, farm about 2 mi. (3 km.) SW of Scotsbrig; for TC’s earlier references, see 19:231TC to AC, 30 Sept. 1845, and 25:205 TC to JWC, 9 Sept. 1850. and you he, whose fidelity and justice to me cannot be
questioned, must settle it with yr own best skill and fairness what is the maximum to be fixed on there,— “Schedule of guesses” c need not be introduced there at all, but merely sent to me at any time. No more, nothing more; but Get well thro’ it!—— Yrs ever T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JA Jr. [JAJR], 3 Dec. MS: Stanger Album, Dove Cottage Museum Lib., Grasmere. Text from typed copy. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES AITKEN JR.

docBody.p: Dear James,—The inclosed has just arrived; and I am informed you directed to come here tonight assist in “signing Leases.”The lease for Craigenputtoch; John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., [1 Dec.]: “I have just got the Lease I think it is quite accurate now. I told your uncle he would probably get [it] on monday [3 Dec.] morning when J. C. Aitken will be with him for one witness, therefore I think it better to send it across for your Father’s signature yours. So please send it back with Mary I will post it here” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). or I know not what, as if the matter were catching fire, and not a moment to be lost!
I wish at once to say Don’t come tonight nor tomorrow night; but let everything stand as we settled yesternight! That is the real course, let that be settled.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 3 Dec. MS: NLS 526.50. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—The Lease came this morning perfectly safe;See TC to JAJR, 3 Dec. and I at once locked it into the drawer till I shd have time to read it and study it, there being hitherto in the purport of it some things (especially that of the £700 and odd to be paid down, as it were, before starting!) whh are not a little dark to me at prest. I am far from designing to object to anything that has been seemingly settled; but I naturally wish to have my ignorance illuminated if I can. Another thing perfectly dark to me is, Why Common, if covenanting by his Lease to “keep up those fences” (the main gaps in whh he appeared to have himself expressly torn down), is not bound to keep them up, but hands the task to me?John A. Carlyle itemized the main points of the draft lease in his letter to James Carlyle Jr., 27 Nov.; for these points and TC’s disagreements with some of them, see TC to JC, 7 Dec. In short, I wish a little time;—and I suppose there is no hurry.
You, who have brother-like taken so much trouble on yr shoulders already, must not write another word abt all that;—if you know any farther explanatn, give it to Jean, who will bring it faithfully in her head.Jean Aitken was coming to visit TC; she arrived 5 Dec.

I at once shot off yr Note to Jas; and warned him not to come this night and witness.See TC to JAJR, 3 Dec. He was here last night, on small errand,—and got a wet walk home; having declined a bed here. We settled everything; and by tomorrow, since not today, will predict to me at what hour he is to arrive with his Mother; to sleep here himself, c c.

The light (close by a westn window here) is quite done. Day latterly has been a mere puddle of rain mud and wind;—excellt for those “400,000” regenerators of their country,The reform demonstration held by the Friendly, Temperance, and Trades’ Societies took place 3 Dec.; it assembled in St. James’s Park and marched to Beaufort House, Fulham, near Chelsea; the organizers expected 200,000, but according to most reports “the highest estimate of the number of those in the procession yesterday does not exceed 25,000” (Morning Post, 4 Dec.). For an earlier reform demonstration at Hyde Park, see TC to LLA, 8 Aug. For TC’s inclusion of Beaufort House (once the residence of Sir Thomas More [1478–1535; ODNB], lord chancellor), in his description of the environs of their new home to JWC, 1834, see 7:173TC to JWC, 21 May 1834. promenading the streets,—of whom I have not heard the faintest whisper all day.—— Embark poor Jean with yr best skill, and bid her keep up her heart: a warm welcome, and do fire await her here!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-TE, 5 Dec. Pbd: William Hanna, ed., Letters of Thomas Erskine of Linlathen (Edinburgh, 1877) 2:298.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS ERSKINE

docBody.p: Oh my dear Mr. Erskine, what a boundless disaster has befallen you;Christian Stirling, Thomas Erskine’s sister, d. 1 Dec., 16 Charlotte Sq., Edinburgh; see also TC to LLA, 6 Dec.— I know it too well! The one that was your own in this world is lost. The gentle, wise, and beautiful soul, who had lovingly attended you, and been your fellow-pilgrim and guardian spirit for so many years,Christian Stirling, widowed 1830, lived with her brother at Linlathen from 1847. For Tait’s photograph of her, taken May 1855, see 31:186TC to JWC, 21 Aug. 1856; it is to be found, with Tait’s other photographs of the Carlyles and their friends, in vol. 1 of JWC’s photograph albums (Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, Columbia, and EUL). is gone to her rest, and, in this world, can be with you no more.

I know well enough how vain are human words of comfort, nor will importune
you with any such: you will go for some solacement where you know it is to be found; and time and meditation will abate the poignancy of what is at first so harsh and so strange. God is above us; she is with God, even as we are: what more can we say? If in the bitterness of your grief you sometimes reflect, “I am suffering this in her stead; had I gone first, it must have been she,” you may find that a momentary encouragement, if only a momentary.
I write no more, dear Mr. Erskine; but I understand well how sad is your heart, and my sympathy with you, could it do the least good, is painfully true. God be with you, dear friend.—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JA Jr. [JAJR], 5 Dec. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES AITKEN JR.

docBody.p: It is an absurd neglect not to have sent you word! I had a Letter from the Dr this morning,—all going right and according to program:—but I cannot just now find the document (tho’ happily I perfectly recollect it) amid the heap of litter lying round me. “Birthday gifts,”TC’s birthday was 4 Dec.; for some of the gifts, see TC to TDI, 5 Dec., and TC to GMO, 5 Dec. blockhead messages c c—bad luck to them!

Yr Mother is to arrive at Euston Square Station this night (Wedny) at 9.50 (not said in what class), you expressly to be there with all yr eyes abt you, and bring her off, gently, safely! We expect you here some time betn 10 and 11,—near 11, one may guess. Both yr rooms are getting warmed c this day or yestdy. All will be right if you bring yr Mother self right, on this side of 11, or shortly after.

div3.sourceNote: TC-TD [TDI], 5 Dec. MS: Harry Ransom Center, Univ. of Texas. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS DIXON

docBody.p:
I recd yr obliging Letter yesterday afternoon; and, in the course of the evg, what you had announced as coming, an excellt Portrait of Bewick,Dixon wrote, 3 Dec.: “I have the great pleasure to inform you that I have sent off by Rail today a gift for your acceptance as our gift to you on your seventy first Birthday. … It being a Portrait of Thomas Bewick Wood Engraver, Artist of the British Birds sent to you last year. We knowing how highly you valued Portraits thought we could not send you anything better as a gift. … With our sincere wishes for your health and strength long to be spared to us all and to fight our Battles in thought for us with your pen, is the earnest prayer of the senders of this gift.” Thomas Bewick (1753–1828; ODNB ), wood engraver. Dixon and his friends had sent TC Bewick’s Birds, 2 vols. (Newcastle, 1797 and 1804) for his 70th birthday; see 43:64–65 TC to [TDI], 4 Dec. 1865
. frame, glass, engraving all perfectly right.
With many thanks, good wishes regards to you and the other friends,

div3.sourceNote: TC-GM [GMO], 5 Dec. Pbd: H. C. Harwood, “Victorian Glimpses,” London Mercury 8 (June 1923): 167–74. George Morrall (1828–99), iron worker from Wolverhampton; “Mr. George Morrall would have been classed as an intelligent artisan. To be precise, he was in his prime a sheet iron roller, and good wages enabled him to acquire a solid library, ravaged again and again in times of unemployment or sickness, again and again recruited as trade improved” (Harwood, 167). Morrall had previously written asking for a photograph of TC; see JWC to GMO, 28 Jan. [1865].
div3.head: TC TO GEORGE MORRALL

docBody.p: I had yr giftGift unidentified further. last night, in hon of my poor “Birthday”; yr letter announcing it had come in the morning.

I am honestly sensible of yr great regard for me; and return you many thanks for it also for this Expression of it;—begging you, with regard to the former, to retain it on my behalf as long as possible, and with regard to the latter, not in future (shd I live to have future birthdays) to take any such trouble.
With many good wishes, thanks and regards,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 5 Dec. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,—I have just seen Macmillan, who is a very respectable and rational man;Alexander Macmillan (1818–96; ODNB), bookseller and publisher; JWC was particularly friendly with the Macmillan family in 1865; she stayed overnight with them, June, and visited them during July and Aug. 1865; see 42:58JWC to TC, [3 June 1865]; 163JCW to TC, [30 July 1865]; and 171JWC to TC, [4 Aug. 1865]. Macmillan attended TC’s rectorial address; see 43:160JWC to TC, [4 April]. and I have ventured to put his name on a Card of mine along with yr address,—in the faith that you wd give him 5 minutes of yr time, and yr ansr by word of mouth to what he proposesMacmillan wrote, 5 Dec.: “I want to ask Mr John Forster to do me a great favour and write a brief biographical critical Essay to an edition of Oliver Goldsmith’s works which I am going to publish in a cheap form in the same size as our Globe edition of Shakespeare. I do not know Mr Forster and want to go armed with your kind introduction if you will be so good as give it to me.” TC’s note to Forster was on Macmillan’s letter; he wrote at the top: “read this—T.C.” Forster had written a biography of Goldsmith, The Life and Adventures of Oliver Goldsmith (1848), but he declined Macmillan’s request; the introduction to the Globe edition of The Miscellaneous Works of Oliver Goldsmith (1869) was written by David Masson. Be as merciful as you can.
You were too good to me last night: I am not fit for such scenes; indeed I am not!Presumably Forster gave TC a birthday dinner, as he had the previous year; see 43:66TC to JAC, 5 Dec. 1865. Dear F.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 6 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Dear Lady A.——Yr last Note settling the Governess questn arrived duly;See TC to GEJ, 20 Nov. and did its work: but I have latterly (perhaps witht reason) been partly expecting another to tell me how you “were getting on at Mentone,” and whether Tyndall and I (since “the end of Novr”) seemed real or in part imaginary quantities!—

My ultimate “Yes” has not yet been said, but I have pretty much ceased to say No;—and Tyndall is emphatic and steady on the affirmative side. “Ready to fly off with you on decr 18; and will!” says he always. I still shudder aghast at the journey; but will now decide Yes or No, according to what you write, of the capabilities, the sleep-likelihoods, the c c.— “But how long do you mean to stay at Lady A.’s?” I asked Tyndall latterly, “Six hours!” ansd he;—
paid no regard to my protests that I cd not be couriered on such terms. “I will take her bright image into my head; that will be reward enough!” insists he. And indeed he can’t get staying:—and I don’t think wd (practically) stay above one day or thereby.—— —— So stand matters here: a word from Mentone, telling us how there, will bring the decisn.

Poor Thomas Erskine has lost his invaluable good Mrs Stirling; and is naturally plunged in sorrow,—poor old man, she was, as it were, his one possessn,His other sister, David Paterson, had previously lived with them in Linlathen after she was widowed, 1856 (see 31:189JWC to TC, [23 Aug. 1856], and 221TC to IC, 10 Sept. 1856), but now lived in Edinburgh, where she was to d. 23 March 1867; see TC to TE, 1 April 1867. and has been his guide guardian spirit for the last 30 years. Sunday morning last she died, in Charlotte Square Edinr (whither they had lately come over); was ill (mostly witht serious fear from the Doctors) only one week.Christian Stirling’s death certificate recorded her death as from “Bronchial pneumonia, nine days.” Poor old Erskine, I am heartily sorry for him; understand too well what his grief is!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 7 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I read over that half-signed Lease the day before yesterday; and have had it disagreeably in my head ever since;—not that there need be anything particularly disagreeable or painful, when one hopes all is easily rectifiable: only, I found at once, and find more and more clearly ever since, that I cannot, and must not, sign the Lease in its prest form; and also what the fault of it is to me. The one fault is, The introductn of anything belonging to Paterson the “valuator”For Mr. Paterson, see TC to JAC, 2 Aug.
or to his suggestions; the whole of whh were unknown to me, and insignificant to me; the one point I cared about being that the sum he fixed upon as rent was also yr sum.John A. Carlyle had written to James Carlyle, 2 Nov., advising him to agree to Paterson’s valuation of the annual rent. Once hearing that, I had no vestige more of curiosity, and have never to this hour opened his Paper, nor probably shall. I understood and understand him to be a man of judgt on those matters, but not probably of better judgt than (for example) yourself; and certainly of no judgt abt Craigenputtock (whh he had seen only for a few hours) worth the tenth part of Yrs who have known it in all practical phases and forms for
many years! I therefore ignored all his advices abt bringing Craigenpk into proper heart and fettle agn; and greatly preferred, and shall prefer, to take yours. The whole of Paterson, accordingly, I find, will have to come out;—for the notion of clubbing both sets of advices together wd seem to me still more unwise; and indeed those of Paterson, were they even sound and true (whh I will take yr judgt upon, and not his) are not at all in the form fit for being put in a Lease, and cd give rise to nothing but trouble and danger. Paterson to come out altogether, that is the remedy;—Paterson once completely out, root and branch, I have no objectn to anything else: and, as there may be some delay now, I will put in writing for you at once what Bargain I believe myself to have made with you; that so there may be record of it till a new Lease is drawn up whh I can sign.John A. Carlyle itemized the draft lease in a letter to James Carlyle Jr., 27 Nov.: “1. Lease 19 years Rent including Game £250. / 2. All Houses Fences to be thoroughly repaired, Tenant carting materials. / 3. Landlord to spend £200 in draining fencing with stone dykes. Tenant carting materials for the Drains Dykes. / 4. Woods cut or may be cut, with the exception of two portions specified in valuation to be replanted for shelter, a new Plantation of about 6 acres to be made on low moor, instead of those two portions as recommended in valuation. / 5. Landlord to pay for any quantity of Lime the Tenant may be able to cart up to 4,000 bushels, Tenant to have power—if after trial it be found more advantageous—to substitute half-inch bones of equal price for any portion of the above quantity. / 6. Tenant to keep all Houses, Fences Gates in good repair throughout the Lease” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).
1°. Lease of Craigenk for 19 years; rent £250.

2°. To put the Farm into the old vigour, out of its now exhausted state, I am to pay for, and you are to cart, 4,000 bushels of good lime (about 10d per) to throw upon it,—with liberty to you, in a certn degree (whh I think ought to be more clearly defined than it yet is in Adamson’s Paper), to take instead of lime, bone manure (whh requires no cartage, or almost none?)—

3°. That Fences, House and Offices are to be put in perfect tenantable order by me, and by you kept so. (My task, in this respect, appears to be fully double of what I had lazily guessed it might be: but you know what I have said in regard to all that; you yourself, and yr own honest judgt, shall be satisfied in regard to all that).
This, so far as I know, is all the Bargain I have made with you, or intended to make.

That of undertaking “to lay out £200 on new fencing draining” is a point whh I never heard of till the morning before yesterday; and whh I by no means contemplatd, or contemplate. if at a future time when you have thoroughly investigated, you fairly discern that a special bit of New draining or new fencing will be a good investt, permanently worth its cost to the Farm, I shall (tho’ there has already been twice as much money laid out on it, in
that form, as ever paid interest for itself) be very apt to listen to you, and, on having estimates, specificatns c c, to do what is handsome and desirable. But I never understood myself to be bound in that particr;—and in Paterson’s vague form, I certainly will not bind myself: such a Clause of Lease, so far as I can see, having no tendency except to create haggles and litigatn were the two parties (by any bad chance) inclined that way.

Still more exceptionable, and at once rejectable, seems that Clause of P.’s abt “the Woods”. My Nephew James and I are agreed on a certain plan abt the woods:—and if he care to write it out with brevity and clearness, I have no objectn to sign it, and say for behoof of those that come after me, “This was my plan; now follow yours, if you think better!” But the Tenant, as Tenant, has nothing to do with the Woods,—except to keep his Cattle out of them; to see that the fences are entire, and are maintained entire, to guard agt the least harm from his cattle: that is his whole duty in regard to the woods.

And this, dear Brother, is all I have to say at prest. I have studied to make it as coldly definite and unmistakably plain as I cd (it being of the nature of a “record” in the interim). if on consideratn, you can comply with all this, I will ask you to forward the prest Note to John our Brother at Dumfries,—whom I am grieved to trouble farther with this matter, and am in truth ashamed to have troubled so much;—he will then see clearly what his way in it is. If you have, on the contrary, objections, I don’t know (at this moment) what it will be best to do. Yrs ever truly /
T. Carlyle

postscript.p: (Mr James Carlyle at Birminghm: to be forwarded)Presumably James Carlyle was visiting his da., Jenny Scott, and family in Birmingham.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 8 Dec. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N. B. PM: London, 8 Dec. 1866. MS: NLS 526.51. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
We are going on well enough here; Jean safe with us, beginning to venture out into London and its sights. Mentone is not yet at all absolutely certn; and I begin to shudder sensibly at the horrors of such a journey,—tho’ Tyndall is positive, yet, for himself, will only stay there “six hours”!Tyndall recalled later: “The Mentone scheme he deemed at first clearly impracticable; but the more it was thought over the more evident it became that it was the only really practicable course open to him. As the gloom of December set in, the necessity of getting him away from London became more and more apparent. Counting the days at my disposal, I found that it was within my power to convey him to Mentone, deposit him there, and return in time for my personal duties in the Royal Institution” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 20). Day before
yesterday I wrote to Ly Ashbn; promising to ansr Yes or No, on receipt of her ansr to these practical queries of mine. The weather here is often nasty, and for two months will not improve; but, in all other points, one may easily go farther fare worse. Her ansr will determine mine; and so, at least end this speculatn.

I read the Lease some days ago, and have given it what consideratn I could. The prest Lease will not do at all;—perhaps the price of Stamp can be recovered; if not, it must be forfeited: for a new Lease will have to be written by and by. I wrote yesterday to Jamie,See TC to JC, 7 Dec. explaining with considerable labr and minuteness what I understood myself to have bargained for, and what I had not or yet cd bargain for: you will see the Letter so soon as he has done with it, and if (as I hope) he prove compliant, the course (and tenor of new Lease) will be brief easy. I require only that Mr Paterson (whose suggestns I never heard of, and still put no trust in, compared with Jamie’s own) be entirely marched out of the Document,—his proposals (did one even mean to adopt them) being in such a shape as cd not be admitted into any Lease, or Documt that is to guard agt litigatn or liability that way! But enough of that just now;—surely you have had bother enough to spare, upon a subject you have no interest in except a charitable brotherly one!TC wrote in his journal, 13 Dec.: “Inexpressible burble abt Leasing of Craigenph (to my Brother Jamie),—one of the maddest-looking Proposals ever made to me (chiefly by over-helpfulness and inexperience of my Brother John’s); cost me two wretched nights of insomnia;—finished it off yesterday, sternly fixing and promulgating at least my own resolutn; with whh I hope Jamie will comply (as his interest well leads him to do!) Interruptn the more unwelcome, as it frightfully muddles the decisn on Mentone too (most kind invitatn from Lady Ashbn to pass the winter there on the ‘Riviera of Genoa’),—‘21 decr’ the last day possible for that expeditn; and the very questn of Yes or No not decidable in actual circs!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 11 Dec.: “[TC] sent back the Lease to me I have it here. On the margins of it are notes of the alterations he wishes to have made; along with it I had a short letter in which he refers me to what he had said in the letter to your Father. That letter, I daresay, you will have received by this time. I feel sure your uncle wants to do only what is just right, but he is very imperfectly acquainted with the circumstances. If we all keep our tempers, the thing may yet be arranged satisfactorily; of course I shall be ready to do anything I can in the matter. I at once told your uncle that I considered the £200 for new drains dykes an essential item of the Valuation; but that I thought your Father cared little or nothing what arrangements might be made about plantations. Perhaps you may be able to send your uncle a direct temperate distinct reply to his letter whatever it may be. I dont feel certain that I have any more power in the matter. I did the very best I could for both parties, that is my comfort whatever comes of it” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).—

If you return this Lease to Mr Adamson, bid him reflect on that marginale abt Common the torn-down fences; I am quite in earnest abt it,—especially after yg Jamie’s report (in yr Letter to Jean). Nothing vindictive
agnst poor Common; yet some approach to justice from him,—unless that “liability” be an “admitted humbug”! Enough more.

The article on Compensatn is by MaccallPresumably William Maccall’s “The Theory of Compensation,” Fraser’s Magazine (Dec. 1866): 794–815; see TC to WM, 2 July. (the indignt Ex-Unitarian c, of whom you have heard): I thot it in parts very miserable and devil-like; poor Maccall!—

postscript.p: I wrote to Erskine a few words:See TC to TE, 5 Dec. alas, poor man, poor old man!——

div3.sourceNote: TC-EV, 13 Dec. MS: Yale. Pbd: E. A. Venturi, “A Memory of Thomas Carlyle,” Paternoster Review 2 (Nov. 1890): 127.
div3.head: TC TO EMILIE VENTURI

docBody.p: Froude, whom I did not see till yesterday, is very willing to read Mazzini’s Paper (in yr excellt handwriting), try whether, with the aid of a Preface, it cannot be made to suit his Magazine.Possibly Mazzini’s “The Religious Side of the Italian Question,” pbd. in translation, the Westminster Review n.s. 32 (July 1867): 226–43. Mazzini had mentioned to Emilie Venturi, 11 June, that “somebody translated the Questione Morale [Mazzini’s title for “The Religious Side”] and offered it to Lewes” for the Fortnightly Review; George Henry Lewes (1817–78; ODNB) refused it as too “exclusively Italian” (Mazzini, Scritti 83:185). Although Venturi did not apparently translate it, perhaps she had copied it to send to Froude. She translated many of Mazzini’s writings and wrote various articles about him, but no articles either by or about Mazzini were pbd. in Fraser’s Magazine.

You have therefore nothing to do but send it at once (Address is, J. A. Froude Esq, / 5. Onslow Gardens /TC’s slashes. Brompton), and send yr own or some other person’s Address, to whom it can be returned, in the printed state or the rejected,—let us hope, in the former. Froude will judge it with a very clear eye to all its qualities; but the deciding quality will be, its value or non-value for readers of Fraser.

Mentone is not decided yet,—except that on decr 21 I must either be on the road or have given it up.— — Are you wet in the country?Emilie Venturi was visiting Harriet H. King, Manor House, Chigwell, Essex (12 mi. [19 km.] NE of Charing Cross, London), 8 Dec.–8–22 Dec.; she then returned home to 14 Milburne Grove, Brompton, which was not far from Cheyne Row. You cannot be wetter than we!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 14 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Dear Lady,—I recd your first Note; and, day before yesterday, your second, in ansr to mine;—could not, by accident, ansr yesterday, but do today (tho’ with a hand by no means very willing, as you may see!)—

You are all goodness, as you constantly are to me;—nor, tho’ Cocks are quite fatal, and I cannot stop within earshot of any Cock,TC had a horror of crowing cocks and always insisted that they be silenced; see 43:52–53 JWC to MCR, 28 Nov. [1865]
. wd the circumstance of yr neighbouring Two, have been of any hindrance to my fine intentions (for I count well you wd soon extinguish these “Two,” whosesoever they are, into temporary or eternal darkness, on news of my advent,—perhaps have them lying in silent fricassee for me, as my first provender on reaching Mentone! Not that was the hindrance; but another difficulty whh had unexpectedly arisen in Nithsdale (absurd confusion about letting, and beneficently settling, a certn ever-memorable Moorland Farm there, the duties towards whh are sacred to me while I live);Craigenputtoch. TC wrote, 16 Dec.: “Instruction as to the DISPOSAL OF CRAIGENPUTTOCK. (By T. Carlyle). / Having a thought to set out shortly for Mentone, I find it necessary, before going, or whether I go at all, to write, and leave here, for direction of my Brother John (or failing him, such of my Brothers or Brothers-in-law as may survive), in case of accident befalling me, there or elsewhere,—the following, as part of my solemnly fixed will and intention; viz: / That no part whatever of the Estate of Craigenputtock is, on my decease, to belong to any of my Heirs of Kin; on the contrary, it is, and ever since the stroke that fell on me in April last, has been, my firm and piously fixed intention, to devote the whole of it to charitable purposes, commemorative withal of the honourable Family whose it long was, and especially of the last and probably noblest representative of the same (my late Jane and her boundless filial piety), thro’ whose great love of unworthy me, it is now sorrowfully mine. Which intention I will execute, with my best skill, if I live; my notion at present being that of Endowments for Edinburgh University; but my light on the subject being yet incomplete Fixed only is one point: that those, or whatever Endowments I may decide on, are to bear, as the first part of their Title, “The John-Welsh” So-and-so, “John-Welsh Bursaries,” “John-Welsh Fellowships,” c. (for I can still think of nothing so likely as Edinburgh University, with the light yet come to me). And now, if I be called away before it is done, I hereby request and commission my dear Brother John to act, with all his judgement, instead of me, and to do whatever I may have left undone in this matter,—which he knows well is a sacred one to me. If alive, he will not fail, such his love of me; if not, then my other Brothers c. (as above-said) must, for my sake, do their very best in fulfilling the intention here expressed,—in my name and that of the Maker of us all. / Thomas Carlyle/ 5 Great Cheyne Row, Chelsea / 16 December, 1866” (MS: privately owned. Pbd: K. J. Fielding, “Carlyle Makes His Will (1865–1871): New Documents Discovered,” CSA 10 [1989]: 58–59). and this, whh had been tumbling me abt, at a sad rate, for days past, might, I feared, be unfinishable in time;—and, in effect, it
is only by this morning’s post that the conclusion of that affair (virtual conclusion, I do hope) has arrived, set me free to my devices!—

I do, then, at the prest moment design to come; Tyndall’s latest day is 21 decr; 17th he cd and wd be ready for me, but beyond the 21st he cannot. Witht him, nay for that matter with him, those 45 hours of steam-machinery and clangorous horror fill me with despair; but I do mean to venture (under this Ideal of Couriers), for the sake of what lies beyond. Nay all friends advise and exhort to the enterprise; and a good Country Sister of mine (“Craw Jean,” as we called her in childhood, the only blackhaired one of us, or Mrs Aitken, Dumfries, as she is now called) has been here for some days past;TC wrote in his journal, 13 Dec.: “Sister Jean has come on visit from Dumfries (this her 8th day here): very affectionate, has sense too, much sense, but in a type considerably foreign to me at this date. Poor little ‘Craw Jean’ (of 54 years ago, the only Blackhaired among us), she was one of the cleverest children I ever saw; and is a valiant, generous and clever woman,—tho’ her life-culture has been thrown on stony places” (TC’s journal; privately owned).
