For his longer note on Jean Aitken, see 3:414–15JBW to JCA, [17 Nov. 1825]. on the hypothesis of “helping to fit me out,” but in real truth, I believe, with the view of seeing me before I go, her regard for me being what it is.

So that, if you hear nothing farther, much more if you do hear something confirmatory, fancy Tyndall and me fairly on the road, this day week, decr 21: to rest at Paris one day; thence to Lyon, with perhaps another days pause (but that is left uncertn); thence to Marseille, with or witht do do; and at length, thro’ the 150 miles of tunnel, emerge at Nice,Between 1858 and 1862 the Compagnie des Chemins de Fer de Paris √† Lyon et √† la Méditerranée (PLM) connected Paris by rail with the Côte d’Azur. Having expropriated land, the French government-controlled railway companies found it necessary to create tunnels, particularly between Lyon and Nice. if all go well;—and find yr Carriage waiting, whh latter circe we had never reckoned on. So stands the Program,—if you hear nothing. From Paris, and if handy, from a second point of the route, you shall have another word. Letter hither (if you wrote instantaneously) wd still find me here; but don’t write unless there be need. And so Au revoir, if God please.

div3.sourceNote: TC-FC, 15 Dec. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO FREDERIC CHAPMAN

docBody.p:
Many weeks ago yr man got from me a Copy of all the Stereotype volumesProbably TC referred to the “Cheap Edition,” pbd. by Chapman Hall 1864; it included all of TC’s works, apart from Frederick the Great which was added 1869. A new “Library Edition” was pbd. 1869–71 (Tarr 448–49). (whh had been yr Gift in a detached form), under the notion of having them
adjusted into a “Carlyle’s Works,” and properly bound, or half-bound, in that shape. Nothing whatr has been heard of them since; and I am getting a little impatt to hear,—the rather as I expect to set out for Mentone (Riviera di Genoa) on Friday next. Is it quite impossible that you cd let me see volumes actually finished off and done before that time?—

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: John Stanley wrote, 9 Dec.: “I think that as a soldier it is not the proper thing to express publicly my opinions on matters purely political in the matter of Govr Eyre I have hitherto refrained fr. mixing myself up in it— / But I find on my return home that my two brothers, my elder brother who shd know better my younger one who is an intemperate Godless radical, have both subscribed their names sums of money towards finding the means of persecuting Eyre. / So I am anxious that one at least of my name shd be seen to be of a different opinion if you will be so good as to put me down as one of those anxious to resist the action of the impertinently self constituted Jamaica Committee I shall feel much obliged. I shall be most happy to give £10. Whenever it is required”; his brothers were Henry, the elder, and Edward, the younger. TC sent the letter to Hamilton Hume who returned it, 14 Dec., noting that he had Stanley’s check and that he had joined the Eyre Committee; TC wrote on the envelope: “Stanley (on Eyre Fund);—(did all, since (Nichts!) decr 1866.” Stanley also conveyed an invitation from his mother, Lady Stanley: “My mother having heard that I had seen you desires me to say if you shd feel inclined to come to Alderley you wld find us quite alone anytime after the 31st perhaps a little change of air will do you good— / My mother fears that you will not care to move at present—but shd you feel so inclined it will give her great pleasure.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC [JCRA], 18 Dec. Addr: 28 Albion Street / Lewisham Road / Greenwich. PM: 18 Dec. 1866. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. Julius Avery Crawley (1844–1914) was to become a school teacher (1881 census).
div3.head: TC TO JULIUS CRAWLEY

docBody.p: There is some vestige of talent, still more of industry, discoverable here; but not the tenth or the hundredth part (of talent for rhyming c) whh wd justify a young man for wasting his best years on what he calls “Poetry,”—instead of employg them, with all fidelity all energy, in incessantly gathering knowledge for himself, gradually gathering wisdom for himself, whh is the one thing needful to a man!— This once his, what matters it whether he express this in lines that jingle or in lines that don’t,—or not in ‘lines’ at all, but infinitely better, in actions, in conduct, whh are quite silent?
docBody.closer: T.C. (in very great haste)Harriet Marian (Minnie) Thackeray (1840–75; ODNB) wrote, 15 Dec.: “I am the person whom you once used to call COT. and I hope you will not think it impertinent of me who have known you so long seen you so little to wish to tell you that I am going to [marry] Leslie Stephen the younger son of Sir James Stephen [1789–1859; ODNB; see 43:27743:biographical notes] who I believe was an old friend of yours. Mr Stephen will be very proud if you take the least interest in me, but whether you do or not you will think of me kindly for the sake of past times. I hear that you are going to the South of France I hope you will come back stronger better”; TC wrote on the reverse: “Miss Harriet Thackeray (getting wedded Decr 1866)—(Ansd).” She m., 19 June 1867, Leslie Stephen (1832–1904; ODNB); they continued to live in 16 Onslow Gdns. with her sister Anne (Annie) Isabella (1837–1919; ODNB), later Lady Ritchie; for Lady Ritchie’s description of JWC and their visits to Cheyne Row, see 32:131–32JWC to MR, [20 April 1857]. For TC’s earlier references to the Thackeray das., see 27:1TC to JAC, 3 Jan. 1852, and 29:171JWC to TC, [7 Sept. 1852]. For an invitation to Sir James Stephen to visit Cheyne Row, 1852, see 27:366TC to SJS, 16 Dec. 1852.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, [20 Dec.]. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Adieu, dear Forster; I am in extremity of wretchedness,—sunk in “packing,” with prospect of 45 hours of clangorous metallic delirium just ahead.—— —

closer.name: T. C.
closer.note: William Allingham wrote, 15 Dec.: “I had hoped to see you at Christmas, not hear from Woolner that in a day or two you start for Mentone. Will you accept my best wishes for your good journey, pleasant sojourn, safe return.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 24 Dec. MS: NLS 518.33. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I am here safe; and ought, if my shaking hand, and new pen and conditns will allow, to send you instant intelligence of that fact whh will be so comfortable to you. I have suffered little almost nothing in comparison to what I expected; in truth I seem to have taken no real harm whatr; and expect in the course of the next 4 or 5 days, to have shaken all the dust out of me, got my things into something of order agn, and to do really well in this fine summer country, with such a hearty welcome of affection as awaited my coming.

We left Paris (as Tyndall’s little Note wd predict to you) on Saty at 11 a.m.; sat the rail for 17 hours,—carriage all to ourselves and every possible help from the daring inventive and successful Tyndal;Tyndall later provided a detailed description of their journey: “Rime was in the air, sucking the vital warmth out of every living thing when we started on the morning of the 22nd of December. A raw breeze blew in our faces as we crossed the Channel. … I tried to muffle him up; but immediately resigned my attempted task to a young lady who wound and pinned his comforter in a manner unattainable by me. Carlyle was interested to learn that his kind protectress was the daughter of Sir John Herschel [1792–1871; 
ODNB
; mathematician and astronomer]. She was … Miss Amelia Herschel [1841–1926]. … In Paris we spent the night at the Grand Hotel de St. James, Rue St. Honoré. A bad sleeper myself, I had long before chosen this hotel, because its bedrooms opened into a garden. We were well lodged; but some slight creak or clatter of a loose window roused Carlyle, who became vocal. Noise at night was a terror and a torture to him. I rose, reproved and corrected the peccant window, the night afterwards passing quietly. Next morning we started. … In England, as stated, the weather was harsh; it continued so in France. … Throughout the day the landscape was cut off by freezing mist, and at the Lyons station the outlook was specially dismal; due precautions however had been taken against cold. In view of my winter expedition to the Mer de Glace in 1859 I had purchased a sheepskin bag, lined with its own wool, and provided with straps to attach it comfortably to the waist. Swathed with this to the hips, such heat as he could generate was preserved for his feet and limbs” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 20–21).—and abt 6 on Sunday 
morning, saw that the dirty raw-frosty vapours, whh had continued witht a moment’s interruptn from London onward, had fled quite away; and that a beautiful summer sunrise was colouring the western horizon, and that we were close upon Marseilles and the Mediterranean. Beautiful   strange the difference of climate. We strolled abt Marseilles all forenoon,Tyndall wrote: “On opening our eyes in the morning we found a deep-blue sky above us, and a genial sun shining on the world. The change was surprising; we had obviously reached ‘the Sunny South.’ / We rested at Marseilles, and walked through the sunlit city. Carlyle seated himself on a bench in the shade of trees, while I went back to our hotel. On returning I found him in conversation with a paralysed beggar boy, from whom he had extracted the sad story of his life” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 21).—strangest of exotic seaports; lanes uglier and darker than anything in old Edinr, and close by, streets squares, parks (i.e. Clumps of excellt old wood, in fine broad avenues) equal to anything in London or New Edinr.The New Town of Edinburgh built to the N of Princes St. from the late 18th century into the 19th century. (Louis Napn has pulled down   rebuilt both Paris and Marslles, and I believe many other cities,—thanks to him for that anyway!)Louis Napoleon Bonaparte (1808–73), emperor of France 1852–70, oversaw the modernization of the French economy, both agricultural and industrial, and major rebuilding of many towns and cities, including Paris and Marseille.— To Nice from Marseilles in 6 hours; “start 12–17 p.m.,” said the Program; but delays  c occurred; we did not get to Nice till near 8 p.m;—and by that time, on New and more stringent inquiries as to the Marseilles Nice-Paris post-office courses, had come to the conclusion that the letter we had written from Paris to Lady A. here, whh had had the start of us by 14 hours + 6 (of our Marseilles waiting) that is, by 20 hours in all, was, most probably still in the same train with ourselves keeping us steady company! (As proved to be the fact; letter arriving, this morning an hour after breakfast!)— We had in consequence some bother at Nice, getting post-horses  c; but telegraphed at once to Mentone, “Coming tonight”;—and did at length get under way, tho’ such a road for steepness, such a country for 
tumultuous rocky ruggedness,   such a brilliancy of moon   sky, as I had ever seenTyndall continued: “At Nice the railway came to an end, and a carriage was needed to take us over the hills to Mentone. We had a vigorous altercation at a cab-stand, where gross extortion was attempted. We retired to a respectable hotel, the courteous proprietor of which, after some waiting, provided us with the required vehicle. The lights of Monaco shone below us as we slowly crept over the hills. From the summit we trotted down to Mentone, reaching it at two o’clock in the morning” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 22). J. Henry Bennet wrote in 1860: “The ascent [from Nice to Menton] occupies about two hours, the descent about the same time. … When the traveller … begins to descend, a glorious panorama opens before him. The higher mountains, receding from a beautiful bay, open to the south-east, and form a magnificent amphitheatre, which at its centre recedes five or six miles from the sea. The bay, about four or five miles in circuit, is divided into two unequal portions by a hill, which gradually slopes to the sea, and on the sides of which climb the houses that constitute the old town of Mentone” (Bennet, “Winter at Mentone” 2). The railway from Nice to Menton did not open until 1869. Witht the least accidt we came along; found the ButlerJames Bailey.watching on the road for us, nr 1 a.m.—Lady Ashbn in wait, who received us (me at least with kisses!Tyndall continued: “He was expected, and a loving friend was on the alert to welcome him. The reception was such as a younger man might envy. It was indeed plain to me that the storm-tossed barque had reached a haven in which it could safely rest” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 22). Lady Ashburton was staying at the Villa Madonna.— I got in my strange new bed   rooms (beautiful, but strange, strange!)—and actually slept abt 5 hours sound as a stone. In the rail itself (last half of the 17 hours), I slept immensely; in fact, am not ill off for sleep. I really do hope to get everything adjusted,   do well here. Upholsterers are tumbling abt putting up curtains  c  c.— The weather is incredible; sky bright as steel, sun shining as in June,—sea   sand filling Tyndall with “wonder   amazet.”— I find nothing wrong but my pipes (long ones ‚Öî broken),—item no sleeved grey winter-waistcoat (for the nights seem to be really cold): I can get one made, if needful.

Push this on to the Dr dear Jean; let him write soon. Tell Mrs Warren I have yet found no noWord repeated at turn of page. coffee comparable to hers. In fine, enjoy yrselves James you in London till you are tired of it;—be thankful you have got me off so handsomely, all of you; pity and excuse all that was wrong. Yr affecte Brr

postscript.p: I quite forgot James’s acct!James Aitken Jr. itemized, 25 Jan. 1867, the money he had spent so far for TC: “On other side is a note amounting to £2.13/— of all outstandings that I know of between us up to this date but please do not trouble to send it.” The list included payment, 21 Dec., for 10 lbs. (4.5 kg.) of tobacco at 4s 8d per lb. (Tobacco all safe c); but will sure enough not!

div3.sourceNote:
TC-SW [SWA], 26 Dec. MS: Duke inc. Hitherto unpbd. The letter was delivered to Sarah Warren by Tyndall; see TC to JAJR, 30 Dec.
; it is unclear whether there was a second page of the letter.
div3.head: TC TO SARAH WARREN

docBody.p: Will you send me the grey sleeved waistcoat (whh I used to wear daily), and the two old Pieces of Flannel for the neck,—the new ones being far too big thick.— Professor Tyndal is also to send a man who will try and pack me some pipes.At the foot of the page someone, presumably Sarah Warren, wrote: “Pipes waistcoat to[o] flannels sent to the Royal Institution Albemarle Street.” Tyndall later recalled, “Over the packing of his pipes we had a wrangle. It was clearly evident that his mode of packing would bring the ‘churchwardens’ to grief, and I emphatically told him so. But he would have his way. He knew how to pack pipes, and would be answerable for their safety. Out of fifty thus packed at Cheyne Row, three only reached Mentone unbroken. I afterwards enjoyed the triumph of sending him fifty without a single fracture” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 20). James Aitken Jr. wrote, 2 Jan. 1867: “I handed in to the Royal Institutn … 24 pipes, a waistcoat flannels.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JA Jr. [JAJR], 30 Dec. MS: NLS 518.34. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES AITKEN JR.

docBody.p: I got your Letter yesterday abt noon (Wedny Evg at London, Mentone Saty noon: mark that, pray!)— Tyndall’s Paris Letter shd have got to you at latest on Saty evg, instead of “Monday morning,” had not some Official proved false. On the same Monday I wrote from here; what I hope yr Mother got duly. I am doing tolerably well; sleeping c, writing “always till 2 p.m.”; the place thrice-hospitably put at my entire disposal; the climate, scenery c far surpassing anything of that kind I ever saw before. Let this suffice Dumfries you, if I have room for no farther personal details,—my time being very limited, this bout.— — Attend, however, to the following very punctually:

1°. The Punches,The weekly satirical magazine Punch, which the Carlyles had always forwarded to Betty Braid; see 41:189JWC to BB, 12 March [1865]. when they accumulate to 3, are to be bundled together, one stamp carrying them; and addressed, “Mrs Braid / Green End / Edinburgh.”
2°. All-the-Year-Rounds,Charles Dickens’s weekly magazine, All the Year Round. in like manner, one stamp to 3, go punctually to yr Aunt / “Mrs Austin / The Gill, Cumertrees / Annan N.B.”

3°. The two Magazines, monthly, you despatch always in a day or two, to yr Uncle at Dumfries; who knows what to do with them next.Fraser’s Magazine, sent regularly to Rev. Walter Welsh (see 43:102TC to CAW, 2 Jan.), and possibly Macmillan’s Magazine, also monthly.

4°. Yr Acct of the Letters is what we agreed upon.James Aitken Jr. listed TC’s correspondents and summarized some of the letters; in his 2 Jan. 1867 letter, they included Sir George Sinclair, Charles A. Ward, the Scottish Central Association of Schoolmasters who wanted TC to speak “at Falkirk ‘in April next!’” There was a 20-page letter from “a young English lady” who “has sent you only 28 ounces of [her novel] to taste and advise her upon get published for her as she has neither money nor friends! I dropped back into the post at once addressed as she wished with the addition of the words ‘not at home’ on it, of wh I doubt you approve. She ‘wonders whether you are Scotch or English’—‘has only read your Edinburgh Address’ altogether it is the coolest piece of impudence in that way that I have ever seen but I am sorry to think you must have seen many such!” James also passed on that Ann Welsh sent TC (via her letter to Jean) “very kind regards thanks for your kind message— Grace Welsh still very poorly—sleeps ill.” Better perhaps if you come every Tuesday Evg to Chelsea; and despatch yr report next night; so that arrive here as the week ends. Better get some light envelopes too (I tore yr Letter yesterday before I cd open it); item thin white paper,—I myself like this blue very ill.James Aitken Jr. replied, 2 Jan. 1867, asking whether TC liked the paper his letter was written on “better than that you have I shall send you some.”

And now for a specific thing. Professr Tyndall has probably been at Chelsea before this time, and shewn Mrs Warren a scrap of my writing, in request of a warm grey waistcoat, of old neck-flannels, and if possible of some Pipes.See TC to SWA, 26 Dec. Deduct these neck-flannels (I have already got an excellt pair that suit); and let all the rest be expedited what you Mrs Wn can. If the Pipes come, they will be very welcome; item the waistcoat,—whh seems a little more possible. And now, in additn, there is just one other thing whh you are to undertake on the Tyndall score; this, namely:

Go, the evening you read what I am writing, over to Chelsea, and along with Mrs Warren seek out (in the dining-room it was left,—or perhaps Miss Bromley has it; but if so, ask her “(32. Lower Grosvenor Street)” with my humble apologies to surrender it in the interim for Lady Ashburton’s greater need), seekoutTC’s line above “seek out.” I say a Book called Wornum’s Life of HolbeinRalph Nicholson Wornum, Some Account of the Life and Works of Hans Holbein, Painter, of Augsburg, with numerous illustrations (1867), pbd. 11 Dec. James Aitken Jr. replied, 2 Jan. 1867: “I think the Wornum is still at Chelsea.” (new 4to Book in thick brown boards); get it conveyed to Tyndall “(Royal Institutn, Albemarle Street: for the Dowr Lady Ashbn at Mentone”—better deliver it yrself
perhaps?) to come along with the Pipes c if it can. This is all you have to mind.

One other Book there is indeed; but it is for my ever-obliging Brr at Dumfries to attend to: simply forward this Note thither at once; he will see what he can do. The Book is his own Dante; a copy of whh is very much desired by Lady An (who has now an Italn master, is sunk in Dante), but is nowhere else procurable that I can think of. If the price of direct postage hither is not excessive, say not above 4/, I cd wish him to despatch a Dante Copy at once by that method;John A. Carlyle trans., Dante’s Divine Comedy: The Inferno. A Literal Prose Translation (1849); it was out of print; a new edn. was pbd. 1867. James Aitken Jr. replied, 2 Jan. 1867: “I write to the Dr. by this post to send on the Dante by post direct— Book post to France is 3d for 4 ounces; so that will be the cheaper way.” John A. Carlyle then wrote, 3 Jan. 1867: “Fortunately I have a spare copy of the Dante just at hand otherwise it might have been difficult to get one; I am very glad indeed to forward it by this day’s post to Lady Ashburton. It is lying packed already shall be sent off punctually along with this.”—if not, let it too be sent to Tyndall to accompany the Wornum take its time. Not a word more. I shall follow poor Jean (yr Mother I evidently mean) in her train this night, with abundance of thots wishes.James Aitken Jr. wrote, 2 Jan. 1867: “Mother is still here.” He reported that Jean Aitken had hoped to see Neuberg, Mon. 31 Dec., but failed; she had also intended to leave for Birmingham, 2 Jan., but was prevented by “a heavy fall of 18 or more inches of snow which came down last night has stopped Bus Boat Rail. I had to walk into the City this morning;—no other means of conveyance was to be had.” She left Chelsea, 3 Jan. 1867, spent three days with her niece Jenny Scott in Birmingham, and arrived home at Dumfries, 7 Jan. 1867.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 6 Jan. MS: NLS 526.53. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Yr Letter came yesterday, much to my joy; the BookJohn A. Carlyle’s trans. of Dante’s Inferno; see TC to JAJR, 30 Dec. 1867. did not come with it, not till today 2.p.m.—whh is the reason of my not writing yesterday at once, as I cd perhaps have done with more leisure than now. By directn, the Book was brot in to me, that I might see it with my own eyes before writing (Ladyship liable to be out at the moment): cover of the Book seemed to be considerably ruffled off in its long transit; but the Book itself is perfectly uninjured; may justly be called a quasi-miraculous arrival; whh will be welcome and useful to a degree you hardly dream of, in the sphere it has now got into. The studious Lady herself has declared her fixed intentn of thanking you by Letter; whh I in vain declared to be unnecessary, tho’ it cd do you no ill.

The day before yr Letter I had got one from James of Rood Lane;James Aitken Jr. had an office at 9 Rood Lane, City of London; although all his letters to TC in Menton were written from Rood Lane, he apparently had lodgings elsewhere, as he wrote to TC, 20 Feb.: “when I arrived here this morning.” Mother not yet home,Their sister Jean Aitken was still in Birmingham, on her way home from Cheyne Row; see TC to JAJR, 30 Dec. 1867. it wd seem; but all at Chelsea right and under good managet. Please tell James for me, this of the Letters c are very good,James was checking TC’s letters, summarizing most and sending a few on to him in Menton. He reported, 2 Jan., that Rev. Gerald Blunt (1827–1902), rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea, had called, 31 Dec. 1867, to ask TC to dinner “and was surprised to hear of your having gone away!” He also reported: “Mrs Warren is going to discharge Alice, she seems a very unbiddable little thing her father, she says, does not want her to go out again.”—and that he must send the Fortnightly Review to Dr Russell;Dr. James Russell in Thornhill. unless perhaps you wd like to see it in passing? It has become monthly, under the old title, and Lewes is quite out of it;The Fortnightly Review was founded, 1865, and ed. by G. H. Lewes until late 1867; he was succeeded by John Morley (1838–1923; ODNB), 1867, at which point the magazine became monthly.—poor Lewes, I hear, is dangerously ill of liver, face of him quite shrunk away c; a dreary bit of news in its sort. Tell Jas I don’t want any London or other paper; and that he must by no means, a second time, involve himself in double postage by writing only on one side of the leaf, since two sides, as he may see here, are perfectly convenient! For the rest, that I mean to ansr his promised Letter, whh if punctual is probably now on the road. Item, enclose that Slip of Paper either to Jas, who knows what to do with it; or better, if you are charitable with a few words, to the poor goose himself,—who has not bothered me for a good while now.Possibly James Augustus Baillie (ca. 1800–73), a cousin of JWC’s mother, now impoverished and living in Dover with his wife, Anna-Maria (b. ca. 1812); see 39:136–37JWC to BB, 22 May [1863]; otherwise unidentified. TC sent Baillie money from time to time; he noted in his checkbook: “18 Augt 1867 / Mrs A. Baillie / Jas Baillie’s,—for sake of—ah me!) / £5 .. 0 .. 0.” TC then sent money through James Aitken Jr.: “19 Jany 1867 / to James Aitken (for Mrs Baillie, Dover: from Mentone) / £5 .. 0 .. 0,” presumably postdated by TC to allow for delays in transmission. Mrs. Baillie acknowledged receipt to James, [23 Jan.]. TC sent another check: “21 April 1867 / to James Aitken (for Baillie) / £10 .. 1 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). TC had noted, 28 May 1867: “[JWC] admired a thrifty, shifty, deaf etc. Wife, that seemed to watch over him heroically; inexhaustible in soap and water, at least, and in needle and thread. He lived now with her, in wonderful quiet and thrifty comfort, ‘Captain Baillie, Dover,’ his address” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 75).

figure.p:
Punch’s Almanack for 1867
Courtesy of Perkins and Bostock Libraries, Duke University

docBody.p:
I think I am doing truly well at Mentone; that it will perhaps be a luck to me that I have come.TC did not usually take holidays, his last having been Sept. 1862 (see 38:220JWC to MR, [21 Sept. 1862]). In Jan. 1867, Punch had included, as part of its “Almanack for 1867,” a cartoon of TC going on holiday with a bucket and spade on the conclusion of Frederick, with a rhyme in the margin: “Carlyle writing ‘finis’ to ‘Friedrich,’ altogether, / And off to Scarborough in the summer weather”; the corner also included Chang the Giant and Chung (see 43:12JWC to MR, 16 Oct. [1865] ) and possibly a winged Tyndall; see above. Nothing can excel or equal the kindness with whh I am
treated, everything done to help humour me that possibly can: and as to the most palpable of symptoms, that of sleep, nothing whatr goes wrong with that for the last nine or 10 nights; tho’ I don’t call liver, stomach or muscles in the least perceptibly better, I am certain they are not worse. I live, as it were, in a House of my own;Tyndall wrote later: “A ‘dépendance’ [separate building] of the Villa Madonna had been placed at his sole disposal” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 22–23). some 20 yards apart from the main Villa, a new small House of one story, with wood-cellars c beneath; prettily French-furnished, ca[r]peted c; sitting-room bed-room (latter made as dark as ink, when I draw my blue curtns c): I breakfast by myself (coffee tolerable, if far inferior to Mrs W.’) I sit writingTC had completed his reminiscences of Edward Irving: “(finished at Mentone, 2 january 1867,—looking towards the eastward Hills, bathed in sunshine, under a brisk west-wind (two p.m.) T.C.)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 348). He began his reminiscences of Francis Jeffrey (1773–1850; ODNB) the next day, heading it: “Of Francis Jeffrey, Hon. Lord Jeffrey, / the Lawyer and Reviewer / (Mentone, 3 January 1867)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 349). till 2 o’clock strictly; then take a breakfast cup of potage, go driving bothering (like always best when I can get a walk simpliciter [simply] and witht these preliminaries), return wearied abt 5 p.m.; sip of brandy, whiff of ’bacco, bed dark, and sleep oftenest for an hour; dinner 6½ or 7, eat little, drink one glass of excellt claret; walk of 15 min. before tea (my last for the night); genlly some reading by the Lady till 11; then more by myself over hear till 12½, when a glass of hot milk, and to bed,—generally with 6 or 7 hours more of sleep; out walking agn before 9. This is my daily way of life. Two Bunsens (Old Madam, and a lame Daughter called Emilie,Frances von Bunsen and her da. Emilia; they lived at Carlsruhe, but often stayed with Lady Ashburton; see 43:1–2TC to LLA, 4 Oct. 1865. John A. Carlyle replied, 11 Jan.: “My kindest respects to Madame Bunsen Emilia—whom I have not seen for so many years.” on their way to Florence; but that occasns little difference.
What you say abt the climate c is strikingly correct:—but I find to my surprise unless this Letter go at once (be in the Post at 4), it will lose its day; so I must abruptly end!

The Bunsens make many inquiries for you. One rather interestg person, and one only, I find here, The Lady Marion Alford, really a clever grt Lady, great in statureLady Marion Alford, who had a house in Menton, was apparently a large woman; see her ODNB entry. among other qualities. Of her and of other points, more before long.
And so adieu dear Brother, with many kind regards to them all. Affectely yours always

div3.sourceNote: TC-SW [SWA], 21 Jan. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO SARAH WARREN

docBody.p: I have bragged of my good Mrs Warren’s skill in baking Oat-cakes, so confidently, that certain great Ladies here, especially Lady Ashburton, who is by birth Scotch, have determined on securing, by an opportunity there now is, a stock of her manufacture in that kind. Be speedy therefore and expert; and [d]o yr best! The instructions are as follows:

1. About 7 or 8 pounds of meal, baked into cakes; that is the quantity wanted. Choose a handy little deal-box, or get one somewhere, whh will hold abt that quantity; bake yr cakes, according to the real rules of art; and pack them there (as tightly as you can without much breaking of them;—¬≠vacancies may be filled with Old Newspaper or the like, for the long railway shakes terribly!): you need not nail down the lid very hard (only with tacks, or short nails); as perhaps the custom-house people may insist on looking into it.
2. Having nailed down yr Box, address it:
“For the Dowager Lady Ashburton / Mentone

“Care of Mrs BirchMiss Ellen Birch, court milliner and florist. James Aitken Jr. wrote, 25 Jan.: “I was at Chelsea early this morning found Mrs Warren had already got on a bright fire in the kitchen was just setting about baking cakes—she had gone up to Miss Birch’s yesterday aftn found that ‘Maid will not leave before Tuesday at soonest’ I have arranged with Mrs W to send my boy down to Chelsea on Monday to take the box up to Miss Birch’s”; boy unidentified further. / 19. Orchard Street / Portman Square;”—and, / without delay, leave it with the said / “Mrs Birch,” who has instructns about it, and will relieve you of farther charge on the matter. A maidThe maid unidentified / further. of Lady A’s is to bring it out hither among her luggage; and Mrs Birch knows who and what.

3. One thing only is very indispensable: That you lose not a moment’s time! For the maid is to start “early next week”; and indeed I fear they have cramped you too much for time, tho’ I think it will still do. By the usual course of post, you ought to get this on Thursday morning next. But our posts have been twice stopped by snow in the last weeks; once by snow between Paris us, once by snow betwn Paris you; and there may be a couple of days lost,—whh will run you very hard! Ask Mrs Birch, before you start baking, if that is the case.—— —— I don’t think I can, or need, direct any farther; no[r] can I recollect any other thing you cd send me in the Box,—unless it were one of my wooden clips (for holding papers), and, I grieve to say, a darning-needle and very small lock of grey yarn (my poor stockings being weakish abt the heels, I think, and a hole of two tacks occurring now then, whh I wd rather mend myself than wait for! But really I care nothing abt this latter item; it is only the
cakes and their quality c that I take concern in: and in this, I have no doubt but, for the honour of our poor House, you will come thro’ with flying colours.

Mrs Aitken sends me good accts of yr motherJames Aitken Jr. noted, 9 Jan., that Sarah Warren’s mother was staying in Cheyne Row; he added, 16 Jan.: “Mrs Warren and her mother busy dusting the books c”; she is unidentified further. and you; whh I am very glad of. For myself, I seem to be dining rather well here; get better sleep c than formerly; and almost seem as if I might return back to you a little stronger than I went.

In respect of weather, and singular beauty of land sea, nothing can go beyond us, while you have such a black winter!J. Henry Bennet wrote in 1860 in “A Winter at Mentone, near Nice”: “During the six months that I was at Mentone I never once saw a fog, day or night, morning or evening. Generally speaking, the sky was clear, and the sun was shining in the heavens like a globe of fire. So powerful were its rays, that even in December or January it was disagreeable to walk in it without a lined parasol or umbrella” (Bennet, “Winter at Mentone” 3). James Aitken Jr. reported, 2 Jan.: “Since you left we have had most unpleasant weather here; only one fine day three days of dense yellow fog in the city it was very little better at Chelsea.” For the snowfall in London, early Jan., see TC to JAJR, 30 Dec. 1867.—

postscript.p: (Be so good as post that Note for Mr AitkenPresumably TC enclosed a note to James Aitken Jr. for Mrs. Warren to forward. the day it comes.)TC wrote in his journal, 20 Jan.: “Mentone, on the Riviera, 20 jany 1867,—Am actually here, for almost a month past; came the day before Xmas, Profr Tyndal triumphantly bringing me; our receptn … was of the kindest, after our strange interestg moonlight climb descent ‘out of Gaul into Liguria.’ The heroic Tyndall wd have no whisper of paying his expenses, tho’ hither and back they must have exceeded £20, and he came purely on my acct: some way or other I must make that poor part of the matter good. Xmas day, hot and bright, the gracious Lady took us all, on asses by the rugged cliffs sierras to a village and peak called Saint-Agnore (strangest village in the world, with a strange old castle perched on the very point of the cliff and of it), where we lunch’d, in sight of the whole populatn, gathered round us like a theatre with pit, gallery and boxes,—very civil, tho’ so eagerly curious;—and in the evg we all dined with a Lady Marion Alford, not known to me before, but elegant, gifted, and blandly high in her way,—who indeed with her two Sons (Lord Brownlow Mr Cust, the former of whom seems tragically dying, poor yg man!) are the only interesting (not utterly wearying and profitless) people I have met here. Tyndall set off homeward, the second day after: from Monaco, in the steamer to Nice, he wave us his farewell;— is now, doubtless, deep in his Lecturing operatns among the gloomy populatns of London, whh has been in a plunge of snow ‘hard winter’. … We here have nothing but beautiful weather, compounded of bright sun keen air; broken once or twice by copious gushes of warm rain, sometimes for many hours together;—the need of whh is enormous, but the effect on our temperature … is uniformly soon advantageous. … / I ought to give some sketch of Mentone, and our sceneries and bits of adventures and experiences,—some day perhaps, not this day. Gladstone, on return from Rome the Man of Sin [presumably Pope Pius IX (1793–1878), whom he met 22 Oct. 1867], was expected yesternight in one of our Hôtels here: that was the mighty event. ‘On tuesday evg, if he will come,’ we are to see him here: meinetwegen [so be it], if he will come;—if he won’t, meinetwegen still. The great Earl Russell, too, passed this way, on the same journey, 3 weeks ago; might have bn (at Lady Marion’s), but was not. … / Monday, 21 jany. Did go out yesterday; walked 2 or 3 miles, silently up the silent valley towds Gorbio; trifling wet of mist, whh hung in shifting scarfs and caps all about, among the peaks of the ravine; beautiful green of orange-woods and olive-woods; here and there a silent Olive-Mill, far down, in some nook of the bottom, nothing but its idle mill-race and the voice of the torrent audible; here and there a melancholy ill-kept little Chapel, too … inviting the faithful to take view of the bits of idols inside, and try if prayers were possible. … On nearing home, the sky suddenly broke; and for half an hour, or nearly so, there was (chiefly after I got into the house), one of the finest mellow outbursts of sunshine; painting Mentone Steeple Town bright yellowish white, under its grey canopy of mist (beautiful even to me, who abhor scene-hunting). … Dullish evg indoors, especially latter part of it. Mrs Bn [Frances von Bunsen] (or De Bn I shd say) is here with her Daughter [Emilia Bunsen], for a fortnight past; Dr is a fine intelligent kind of girl; but Madam (with much fine quality otherwise) is of trivial-didactic turn, and goes like a mild-gushing broad cascade, for hours long, in that kind; yielding more twaddle and weariness to the afflicted human soul!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). “Saint-Agnore” is presumably the village and castle of Sainte-Agnes, about 6 mi. (10 km.) NNW of Menton; the village is 2,700 ft. (800 m.) above sea level. Tyndall wrote to a friend, 20 Jan., about the trip to Sainte-Agnes: “On Xmas day Carlyle astride a donkey reached a height of 2000 feet accompanied by Lady A and her daughter. We had luncheon there. They returned I went on to the top of the highest … whence I had a most glorious view of Alps and sea” (MS: NLS 14836.175).

div3.sourceNote: TC-CDB, 23 Jan. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:336–38 inc.
div3.head: TC TO CAROLINE DAVENPORT BROMLEY

figure.p:
Funerary Rotunda, Cimetière du Trabuquet, Menton, 2015
Courtesy of Aileen Christianson

Old Menton
J. Henry Bennet, Winter in the South of Europe (1865)

docBody.p:
In beauty of situation, of aspect and prospect by sea and land, nothing can exceed us in the world. Mentone, old town and new, latter perhaps a hundred
years old, former several thousands, is built principally as a single street by the sea-shore, along the diameter of two beautiful semicircular little hollows, or half-amphitheatres, formed by the mountains which are the airiest wings of rocky peaks and cliffs, all terraced olive-clad, with sometimes an old castle and village. Castle visible like a bird-cage from the shore here, six miles off.Possibly the castle above Sainte-Agnes, about 6 mi. (10 km.) NNW of Menton; for one of the more ornate graves in the two cemeteries above Old Menton, topped with a rotunda that looked like a bird cage, see 124; but the cemetery, around 2 mi. (3 km.) E. of the shore where TC was standing, was almost certainly not what he was describing. I never saw so strangely beautiful a ring of peaks, especially this western one, which is still new to me every morning on stepping out. Western ring and eastern form in the middle, especially form at each end, their bits of capes and promontories and projections into the sea, so that we sit in the hollow of an alcove, and no wind from the north can reach us at all; maritime Alps intercepting all frost and snow. Mentone proper, as diameter or street along the sea, is perhaps three-quarters of a mile long; a fair street of solid high houses, but part of it paved all through with big smooth whinstones, on which at evening all the population seem to gather; many asses, c., passing home with their burdens from the mountains, and many women, young and old with them, and thriftier, quieter, more cheerfully serious and innocent-looking set of poor people you never saw.

figure.p:
Street in Old Menton, 2015
Courtesy Aileen Christianson

Basilica of Saint-Michel, Menton, 2015
Courtesy of Aileen Christianson

docBody.p: Old Mentone,See 125above. thousands of years old (for there are caves of the troglodytes still extant near by),The caves at the foot of a cliff, then called Balzi Rossi, now known as the Grimaldi caves, where bones of prehistoric people were being excavated. They were between Menton and Ventimiglia, the town on the Italian side of the border, about 7½ mi. (12 km.) from Menton. John A. Carlyle wrote, 14 Feb.: “you should take a look at those caves which seem to within half a league of you, as well as of the things that you see quite at hand.” For the caves, see 157TC to JAC, 18 Feb. 1867; they can also be seen in the distance on the illustration of Menton from the west; see 155TC to JRU, 15 Feb. 1867. sprawls up like a huge herring-bone of lanes, steep against the cliff—by way of defence against the Saracens,From the 8th century Provence was often a battleground between the Franks and the Arabs, known as Saracens; the latter were finally expelled in 973. it is thought; at some distance from the sea, and only hangs by New Mentone as a shoulder or fin would. Most of the poor people live there. There also in her fine church, the Deipara misericordiarum Mater [mother of God, mother of mercy],Presumably a statue of the Virgin Mary in the Basilica of Saint-Michel; for the Basilica, see 127above. so called. And finally the ruins of an old castle, now mostly made into a churchyard.The Vieux Cimetière; for a street in Old Menton, see 126above.

div3.sourceNote: TC-MD, 24 Jan. Addr: Gadshill, Higham, Rochester. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. Mary (Mamie) Dickens (1838–96), eldest da. of Charles Dickens.
div3.head: TC TO MARY DICKENS

docBody.p: Will you accept this for an “Autograph”;TC’s letter was pasted to a photograph by Elliott Fry with “John Lothrop Motley” written on the back. The photograph is one of TC leaning on his left hand, taken by Elliott Fry, April 1865; for a similar one, leaning on his right hand, see 42:81TC to RWE, 14 June 1865. John Lothrop Motley (1814–77), U.S. diplomat and historian, had visited Britain several times since the late 1850s with his family, and was known to many of TC’s friends; his only recorded meeting with TC was in Germany in 1852; see 27:303TC to JWC, 25 Sept. 1852. and give it to yr friend,Mary Dickens’s friend was probably one of Motley’s three das., Elizabeth (Lily) Cabot (ca. 1840–1928), Mary (ca. 1844–1918), and Susan Margaret Stackpole (ca. 1846–1915), rather than Motley himself. with my regards,—and regrets that it is not something usefuller!—
You I remember very well; you shall remember me to Papa Household, with many faithful wishes,—and believe me

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 24 Jan. Addr: Palace-Gate House / Kensington / London. / Angleterre. PM: Menton, 25 Jan. 1867, London, 28 Jan. 1867. MS: Univ. of Kansas. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
You are very kind to me; and yr Letter of two mornings ago was a New comfort and kindness.Forster wrote, 19 Jan.: “How often I have been thankful that you left us at the time you did! Ever since, we have had the most atrocious weather, of which all sorts of accounts will of course have reached you—which if there be any truth in the ‘suave mari magno [it is pleasant to watch a storm at sea from the peace of the land; cf. Lucretius, De Rerum Natura 2:1]’ must have made you, out yonder at Mentone, all the warmer and more comfortable. I went to Robert Landor’s in a fog, the day before you left, and returned in a worse fog, the day after you left; and those two fogs settled me. They brought on a terrible attack of bronchitis and from that Saturday the 22d of December to Tuesday the 8th January I never left the house. Only indeed on odd days since I have ventured—but I am getting now a little courage, though the frost and snow continue, and fancy I may say I am pretty nearly right again.” TC left 21 Dec. 1867. Robert Eyres Landor (1781–1869; ODNB), writer, rector of St. James’s Church in Nafford parish, Birlingham, S Worcestershire, brother of Walter Savage Landor (1775–1864; ODNB), poet and author. I only hope you are fairly out of that dreary bronchitis; and are fencing yrself successfully, for the time coming, agt the frightful
weather,—and getting on steadily with yr Landor,Forster was working on Walter Savage Landor’s biography; it was pbd. 1869. in spite of the many impediments, calls to other less importt but far more peremptory kinds of labour!TC presumably refers to Forster’s work as commissioner to the Lunacy Commission. There is no doubt but you will make a pretty little Biography; some speaking Life-Portraiture of yr indignant hero and his course thro’ the world, whh will be interestg to us all.Forster wrote: “I have been going on as well as my poor spirits and continual cough would let me at the Landor book: in which I lose heart often, and less often fancy it may contain something that will interest you—always the reward I promise myself.” His features were sufficiently pronounced; his bad world’s too are legible, and how he spurned it fiercely abt, and went, in various cases, to the length of spasm in his controversies with it; and yet died unconquered and with harness on his back: really a kind of hero, tho’ with importt deductns on some sides!Landor had a turbulent life, and he and Forster, good friends from 1836, were estranged 1859–63; their friendship was resumed in the last few months of Landor’s life and he asked Forster to write his biography; see Davies, John Forster 156–57. Perge, perge [onward, onward].

I am doing very tolerably in this new locatn; and sometimes almost begin to think there is a faint perceptibility of real improvet in health since I left Chelsea, and its distressing puddles, physical and other. In weather, at least, there is evidtly no manner of comparison. Our beautiful hilltops have been once or twice slightly powdered with snow, for a few hours of the bright morning; but that is not felt except as a pleast theatrical surprise, down here by the shore,—where, especially if there fall now then a little rain, our habitl temperature is unsurpassable; like fine grey weather in an English may or june: as is the case today, for instance. More frequently,—habitually, unless there have been rain a day or two before,—we have the brightest of sunshine, all tingling with a fine dry tonic kind of air (like a june in whh you can take exercise); air feeling suddenly coldish or cold, when the sun goes down; at whh time, invalids, and even natives, carefully fling comforters round their necks, and the former regret they are not already home. Our Town itself is curiously exotic; built like a little Sussex-Coast Town, along the shore, or miscellaneously sprawling up the steep cliffs,—cliffs not of hardened mud here, but of ruggedly hard limestone and other rock,For a section of the cliffs at the Franco-Italian border, see oppabove. towering up, visibly, for 6 miles behind us, invisibly for 60 or more (to Col di Tende,Col de Tende, highest mountain pass (6,135 ft. [1,870 m.]) in the Alps, close to the border of France and Italy, separating the Maritime and Ligurian Alps. and the top of the maritime Alps), into the airiest beautifullest ragged peaks and steeples I ever saw; the strange beauty of whh, and their audacious graceful shapes (lower part of them all be-terraced, and clad in olive-woods and orange-groves), with such a sun rising on them; and the bright lights definite shadows, in an atmosphere so pure and transparent,—is still new to me every morning when I first sally out. Up the ravines, are donkey-paths, roughly paved, paved into rough stair-steps in the steepest parts, where you mount at discretn; and have such a walk for silence and loneliness as ought to satisfy a very Timon of Athens (were his limbs good):—these ass-paths are the only roads to the upland villages; and all goes on ass-back, or on caput humanum [people’s heads] (women the cheerful bearers as often as men). Nothing so quaint and strange as those world-old rock-villages did I ever see;—the populatn fine hardy honest-looking excellt brown people, the frugallest, civillest, and you wd say best poor people in the world,—tho’, I dare say, they have their private devilries too.

figure.p:
Rock face, Franco-Italian border, 2015
Courtesy of Aileen Christianson

docBody.p:
Of the English here, some 700 by count, I can say little,—except that most of them appear to have plenty of money, no great share of any better endowt: a populatn courteous but unedifying, rather to be avoided than sought for, if you are seriously given. Gladstone made his transit the other day;Gladstone had been wintering in Italy; TC noted in his journal, 23 Jan.: “Gladstone, en route homewards, called on Monday [21 Jan.], and sate a long time talking, principally waiting for Madame Bunsen, his old friend, whom it was his chance of seeing, as he had to leave for Paris the next day. Talk copious, ingenious, but of no worth or sincerity—pictures, literature, finance, prosperities, greatness of outlook for Italy, c.—a man ponderous, copious, of evident faculty, but all gone irrecoverably into House of Commons shape—man once of some wisdom or possibility of it, but now possessed by the Prince, or many Princes, of the Power of the Air [Satan; cf. Eph. 2:2]. Tragic to me rather, and far from enviable; from whom one felt oneself divided by abysmal chasms and immeasurabilities” (Froude, Carlyle 4:335). Gladstone did not mention seeing TC; he noted, 21 Jan.: “Reached Mentone at noon. … Saw Ld Brownlow, with deep interest and painful apprehension. We dined with them. Saw Lady Ashburton: and Mad. Bunsen—long conversations with each.” He left the next day after breakfasting with Lady Alford and Lord Brownlow (The Gladstone Diaries, ed. H. C. G. Matthews [Oxford, 1978] 6:494). several
hours of him in this house: talk ponderous copious, but to me of no use or emolument.— — Alas, dear Forster,TC completed his reminiscences of Francis Jeffrey, 19 Jan.; see TC to CDB, 23 Jan.—and if I pretended to be in “better spirits” than latterly, or to foresee (or even to wish) any change from the sad sombre to the bright or hopeful, I shd but deceive! Kindest thanks regards to yr dear wife. Some word agn by by?— Yrs everT. CarlyleTC wrote in his journal, 23 Jan.: “a drive to Ventimiglia, thence up the Nervia Torrent a little way, towards Campo Rosso and Aqua Dolce, neither of whh, owing to encumbrances on the road unfinished, cd we get to, only the former of whh even see. Company was Lady A., the two Bunsens self, with one Moggridge, a strange old ‘Naturalist’ familiar in these parts, for cicerone escort,—whose good nature at least, and inextinguishable happiness hope (lively as at 15, tho’ now 75), were laudable and singular to me. Day beautiful as if in June, Campo Rosso very pretty in the distance … mountains, in the distance and at hand, were in best gala … in the farthest distance, was a short definite Sierra (Capelletto, ‘Little Hat’ Co) standing out in a dazzling coat of snow, sharply cut off abt the shoulders, by the brown of the nearer cliffs and peaks. All very pretty indeed; and the Dames took duly to sketching,—while I sat silently and smoked, or sauntered in the sunshine, like a wandering ghost getting wearied. Ay de mi; so much is grown wearisome, a sadness not a pleasure!— Ventimiglia had its Nunneries, its Castle, its traits of old pride and aristocracy: ‘Le donne e gli cavalier’ [of ladies and of cavaliers; cf. Ludovico Ariosto, Orlando Furioso, canto 1.1–2];—all gone like a dream. There is one big street (narrowish this too) passable for carriages, the rest are mere winding high-built lanes, precipitously steep for most part, like those of Mentone. Old Church, very old indeed, ‘11th centy’ said Mge ‘and a couple of Roman Milestones built into it’ very good: these we ‘did,’ these and the views (‘Beautiful, isn’t it!)—then drove home, evg sun just sunk in beautiful but chill cloud-curtns when we got in. Oh, curas hominum,—Oh ignaviam of do [Oh the cares of man,—Oh the laziness of ditto]! I am really very sad, blameable!—” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Matthew Moggridge (1803–82), naturalist, fellow of the Linnean, Geological and Zoological Societies; see TC to JAC, 18 Feb.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 25 Jan. MS: NLS 526.54. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:241–43 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:120.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I recd Jean’s Letter and yours yesterday morng,—thanks to both of you. As it was Jean that mainly wrote, both on this and the former occasn, and yr contributn both times was exceedingly minute, I thot of addressing this Note to her: but I let it stand by the old rule, in hopes of better measure some other time,—indeed it is of small moment to whom it be addressed. Considering my capabilities and known inclinatn, I cannot be considered remiss in writing; there are at this moment in London or on the road two Letters to James (whh I understand him always to forward), to whh there is yet no ansr.James Aitken Jr. wrote, 25 Jan.: “I wrote you a note on Wedny 23d last night recd your esteemed letter of 21st which I sent to Dumfries.” He also noted: “I see Miss [Maria] Prince occasionally; she is always very glad to have news of you. She has begun the study of German lately; likes it very much seems to be making rapid progress in it.” Indeed I have taken lately to paying off old scores in that kind; and for the last 3 days have done almost nothing (being out of a “Task,” since Saty last)Sat. 19 Jan., when TC completed his reminiscence of Jeffrey. but write Letters, of a very helpless kind, and not of a voluntary: after this, there remains but one to Emerson;See TC to RWE, 27 Jan. and then I hope to discover some New and more remunerative quiet “Task” agn: Ah me!— —

figure.p:
Villa Madonna
Courtesy of Les Archives Municipales de la ville de Menton

docBody.p:
Things continue all well, and as it were, at their best, with me here. I sleep habitually like a common human creature (a tendency to sit too late, but I am seldom after 1 a.m.); I genlly get a fair nap withal before dinner, whh is much suitabler than after; and in short have no reason to complain abt sleep. My bed is a little French crotchet of a thing, with paltry mosquito curtains (whh I stuff away as much as possible, wd gladly burn were they my own); but it is very warm easy (thanks to a thick English matrass above the iron-spring concern, 2 new blankets under the fluffy quilt they have, in Jean’s kind, very good that too as finish): and nowhere in the world was I so quiet. For you must know, my two rooms, bed sitting, are in a separate house “pavilln” so-called, one half of it mine, the other a place for fire-wood with only a Butler’s bed a small guest’s-bed; nothing of whh do I ever hear of; but live serene in my two airy jaunty little rooms, high, newish, with big windows, commanding the finest silent prospect, on both sides,—and such a thorough draught, on being opened, as permits the freest smoking (had my new pipes only arrived, whh they haven’t!).Most of TC’s pipes had been broken on the journey to Menton, and Tyndall had promised to replace them; see TC to SWA, 26 Dec. 1866; for their arrival, see TC to JAC, 18 Feb. This is the “Pavillon Madonna,” so-called, standing hill-ward
garden-ward, connected with villa Madonna by a smooth-plastered parapeted terrace, first-floor high, perhaps abt 40 paces in all,—to whh I have no objectn, except that it is shaped like a joiner’s-square, dangerous for the kneepan in night-time, and also has 3 blue steps at one part, requiring still stricter cautn, investigatn by yr stick before venturing. Villa Pavillon don’t quite suit, you see; but have been brot together by recent contrivance: Villa, I believe, was not long since a Convent (of whh the Chapel, still free for use, accessible from a Country road that passes close,The Villa Madonna and “Pavillon Madonna” were demolished in 1968. The Chapel of the Madonna (Chapelle de la Madonne) is on rue Paul Morillot (presumably TC’s “Country road”) W Menton. For a late nineteenth-century photograph of the Villa Madonna, see above; for two recent photographs of the Chapel of the Madonna, see opp. is directly under Villa drawing-room, and the big old Bell is still visibly attached to an outside corner of the same: Bell whh I almost rub upon daily is tied up into perfect dumbness; Chapel, without even a bambino or candle-end in it, but with some broken wood lumber flung in, seems to have seen its finis as “Chapel”:
indeed the whole Property, Villa, garden, wood c a good way up the Hill, belongs to—the prest Mayor of Folkstone;Charles D’Oridant (1816–85), b. in France, m., 1861, Adeline, b. Painter (1833–91); proprietor of the Pavilion Hotel, Folkestone; he was mayor of Folkestone 1863–69. The photograph of Villa Madonna is listed as “Villa Doridant, previously convent of the Madonna” (trans.) (Menton Archives 11Fi321). who bot it from the paltry little Duke of Monaco,Charles III (1818–89), prince of Monaco 1856–89. some years ago, for £50; and cd now, I suppose, get something like £5,000, if it wd do him any good! “Ta filthy gutty hallions [clumsy fellows] ’at tay are!” as the creature DugalDougal Gregor; see Walter Scott, Rob Roy (1817), ch. 9. said.— — “Villa Madonna (or de Madonna),” you perceive, is the name of our mansn; but for Post-office things, “Dowr Lady An” is fairly better; therefore please stick by that.

figure.p:
Two views of the Chapel of the Madonna and its gate, 2015
Courtesy of Aileen Christianson

docBody.p:
I will say nothing of Mentone Town or Neighbd: you will figure us as situated along the fine shingly sea-beach, at the safe and sheltered bottom of an alcove (properly 2 alcoves) in the beautiful outskirt and finis of the Maritime Alps, with the wild ragged peaks visible as if almost at arm’s-length, tho’ six miles away, so pure is the air and the light; their bare savage tops, and their ample multiform green petticoats (of Olive Orange c) are certainly the airiest, strangest most picturesque bit of Earth I ever set eyes on: really quite a kind of pleasure to me, in the bright morning when I first sally out to recover heat! For the peaks are in number manifold; in shape, posture, aspect, perilous, audaciously graceful, lie in the brightest sunshine, or oftener in sunshine shadow mixed, whh is still finer. Nay with a sky grey, and the white mists climbing abt among them, like hoods, like neckcloths and scarves,—I like right well to look at them,—to walk among them; as I have done on such a day; so silent are they, so mysterious and mournful, with perhaps some Convent bell jangling out of the unknown distance for a minute or two, awakening thots beyond this world!— Up the ravines is generally some, roughly paved passable Ass-path, sole highway to the Hill Villages; there I pretty often go, and wd go oftener, were my limbs feet better:For TC’s walk towards Gorbio, 20 Jan., see TC to SWA, 21 Jan. Bennet described this area: “The space between the sea and the receding mountains, which are between 3000 and 4000 feet high, is occupied by a series of lower hills, which slope gently to the shore, and which are divided by numerous ravines and torrential valleys” (Bennet, “Winter at Mentone” 2). in bad weather, I prefer the carriage road (excellt highway, from Nice to Genoa, blasted out maca¬≠damed by Napoln I),Le chemin de la Corniche, the road linking Nice and Genoa, was opened, 1812, by Napoleon I (1769–1821), emperor of France 1804–14. part of whh may be made to alternate with “Promenades” streets by the sea-shore. “Bad weather,” I said, but meant merely rain (of whh, after long ruinous drought, there has been much more than usual at this season); and don’t at all dislike that,—except only the mud of it,
the bother while it lasts. For my gutta-perchas, whh alone can deal with it, have rather gone awry;—and one of my principal small griefs is that of an unreasonably mutinous little toe, chiefly provoked thereby: not a very weighty grievance, you will say! Today, since breakfast, when there was an interval, it is agn raining “calm mighty” (in the style I have heard you describe); but it is of warm temperature, will possibly cease abt 4 or 5 p.m. Or if not, I have mackintosh, uneasy perchas and hat. Better “climate,” in fine, I think I cd not have found anywhere:— — I must now finish: I have drawn you a most helpless kind of map;TC’s map not found. whh, if you arm yrself with yr powerfullest spectacles patience, and call in all the neighbrs with do, may perhaps help you some little in regard to our topographies; of whh I have surely said enough more. Of the people, properly, none of whh, are much interestg I may speak by some other chance. At prest I must say adieu. (will Jean inclose, in next Letter, a small needle and one black thread: her hemming of my black trowsers, has slightly given way; I cd mend it in a minute with that apparatus!) Blessings with you all

div3.sourceNote: TC-MW, 26 Jan. MS: NLS 2883.243. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote the address on the letter, “To / Miss Welsh / Auchtertool Manse / Kirkcaldy / N.B.,” for James Aitken Jr. to forward.
div3.head: TC TO MARGARET WELSH

docBody.p:
Dear Maggy,—I duly got yr Letter and kind Gift; just in the struggle (whh was furious and miserable) of deciding Yes or No as to this place;—and didn’t calculate on leaving it so long unacknowledge[d],Letter omitted. or on ansring with such brevity. It was Tyndall at last (the good friend Professor whom you recollect) that at last tore me off,—as it were dragged me by the hair of the head;—witht him I shd not have escaped the dismal winter you are all suffering. The journey was not quite so miserable as I anticipated: Tyndall was miraculous or nearly; but still it was a terrible jumble. Nor did the “jumble” quite end here for abt a week or more:—often enough I regretted my good Maggy (and still may a little regret),—tho’ I know not, in real truth, whether it wd have quite suited her or not. But as to myself (so pleast and so wholesome is the climate scene) I really seem to be doing rather well (fairly better sleep than usual, c); and sometimes think I shall actually grow a little (very little) healthier, betn this and April, whh is the likeliest time of my return, tho’ there
is nothing yet fixed or talked. You shall hear of me agn before that. Meanwhile I want a word from Auchtertool,—something abt poor Grace WelshGrace Welsh, JWC’s paternal aunt, was very ill; see TC to AWO, 13 Nov. 1867. in particr! I did request my Sister to apply to Ann,Ann Welsh, Grace’s sister. Jean Aitken wrote, 3 Feb., including a transcription of a letter from Ann: “I am sorry I cannot give you much better accounts of my sister Grace—there has been changes in her complaint since I wrote about ten days ago she had an attack of inflammation in her right lung for a week or so her side stomach were both much better it seemed as if the inflammation had gone from the side to the lung—as the Drs have all along said her lungs were sound although she suffered so much from breathlessness. … She got almost no sleep for many weeks— that taking so little food has reduced her very much. She has so often been a little better got worse that we fear to be too sanguine. … [The doctors] say her weakness is more to be feared than the disease we cannot by any means get her to take food to keep up her strength. She has now been confined to bed 15 weeks she is wonderfully calm and free from nervousness resting on the Saviour knowing all will be well with her whither living or dying.” She d. 15 Feb. whom she knows a little, and to keep me in tidings; and there has been something, but nothing like enough. Write to me, you; the truest you can! With kindest wishes to Wr SistersMaggie’s brother Walter Welsh, sister Mary Welsh, and Maggie herself; the third sister, Jeannie Chrystal, lived in Glasgow.—

div3.sourceNote: TC-GEJ, [ca. 26 Jan.]. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:338–39 inc.
div3.head: TC TO GERALDINE E. JEWSBURY

docBody.p: I seem to be doing rather well here, seem to have escaped a most hideous winterThere were heavy snowstorms in London in Jan.; see TC to SWA, 21 Jan. The cold weather also led to skating in Regent’s Park where there was a terrible accident, 15 Jan.; see opp. Both Froude and James Aitken Jr. wrote about it; James wrote, 16 Jan.: “There was a very sad accident in Regents Park last night from the breaking of the ice on the lake—150 people (skaters c) went down about a third of them have been drowned”; Froude wrote, 23 Jan.: “There has been a bad accident in the Regents Park the whole extent of which is not yet known—nor will be till the lake is drained—they have removed forty bodies or more—young men boys all of them.” for one thing, if other griefs were but as easy to leave behind.

figure.p:
“The Disaster on the Ice in Regent’s Park”
Illustrated London News, 26 January 1867

“Dragging the Lake for the Dead”
Illustrated London News, 26 January 1867

docBody.p:
The weather, ever since I awoke at Marseilles, has been superb; not only bright, sunny, and not wintry, but to my feeling more agreeable than any summer, so elastic, dry, and brisk is the air, an atmosphere in which you can take exercise, so pure and beautiful are all the elements. Sun, moon, sky and stars have not yet ceased to surprise me by their incredible brilliancy, about ten times as numerous, these stars, as yours. The sceneries all around, too, these wild and terrible Alpine peaks, all gathered to rear of us like a Sanhedrim of witches
of EndorCf. 1 Samuel 28:7. and looking blasted, naked rock to the waist, then all in greenish and ample petticoats of terraced olive woods, orange groves, lemon groves; very strange to me.Maggie Welsh wrote, 8 April: “I wonder what is become of Geraldine? I have not had a word from her for long, long. Had she been ill I think I should have heard, for I begged her to ask some one else to write a line were that the case.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 27 Jan. MS: RWEMA. Pbd: Norton, CE 2:336–41 inc; Slater, CEC 551–53 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:119; Kaplan 486.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p:
It is a long time since I last wrote to you; and a long distance in space and in fortune,—from the shores of the Solway in summer 1865,TC last wrote to Emerson 14 June 1865; see 42:79TC to RWE, 14 June 1865. to this niche of the Alps and Mediterranean today, after what has befallen me in the interim! A longer interval, I think, and surely by far a sadder, than ever occurred betwn us before, since we first met in the Scotch moors, some five and thirty years ago.They first met at Craigenputtoch Aug. 1833; see 6:425TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1833. You have written me various Notes too, and Letters,For two of Emerson’s letters, see 43:117TC to JAC, 22 [24] Jan. 1866 , and 232TC to LLA, 20 May 1866. all good and cheering to me,—almost the only truly human speech I have heard from anybody living;—and still my stony silence cd not be broken; not till now, tho’ often looking forward to it, cd I resolve on such a thing. You will think me far gone, and much bankrupt in hope and heart;—and indeed I am, as good as without hope and without fear; a gloomily serious, silent and sad old man; gazing into the final chasm of Things, in mute dialogue with “Death Judgement and Eternity”Cf. John 5:24. (dialogue mute on both sides!), not caring to discourse with poor articulate-speaking fellow creatures on their sorts of topics. It is right of me;— yet also it is not right. I often feel that I had better be dead than thus indifft, contemptuous, disgusted with the world and its roaring nonsense, whh I have no thot farther of lifting a finger to help, and only try to keep out of the way of, and shut my door agt. But the truth is, I was nearly killed by that hideous Book on Friedrh,—12 years in continuous wrestle with the nightmares and the subterranean hydras;—nearly killed, and had often thot I shd be altogether, and must die having the monster not so much as finished! This is one truth, not so evidt to any friend or onlooker as it is to myself: and then there is another, known to myself alone, as it were; and of whh I am
best not to speak to others, or to speak to them no farther. By the calamity of April last, I lost my little all in this world; and have no soul left who can make any corner of the world into a home for me any more. Bright, heroic, tender, true and noble was that lost treasure of my heart, who faithfully accompanied me in all the rocky ways climbings; and I am forever poor witht her. She was snatched from me in a moment,—as by a death from the gods. Very beautiful her death was; radiantly beautiful (to those who understood it) had all her life been: quid plura [what more]? I shd be among the dullest stupidest if I were not among the saddest of all men. But not a word more on all this.

All summer last, my one solacement in the form of work was writing, and sorting of old documents and recollectns; summoning out agn into clearness old scenes that had now closed on me witht return.TC wrote his reminiscences of JWC between 25 May and 28 July 1867; see TC to JF, 29 July 1867. Sad, and in a sense sacred; it was like a kind of worship; the only devout time I had had for a great while past. These things I have half or wholly the intentn to burn out of the way before I myself die:—but such continues still mainly my employt,—so many hours every forenoon; what I call the “work” of my day:—to me, if to no other, it is useful; to reduce matters to writing means that you shall know them, see them in their origins sequences, in their essential lineaments, considerably better than you ever did before.TC completed his reminiscence of Jeffrey, 19 Jan.: “Finished at Mentone, this Saturday 19 January 1867; day bright as june (while all from London to Avignon seems to be choked under snow and frost), other conditions, especially the internal, not good, but baddish or bad!)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 383–84). TC wrote in his journal, 28 Jan.: “Whole week spent in writing Letters, mostly bad, factitious, hitting wide, and all involuntary. whh indeed is perhaps the father of all their ill qualities! Last, and, one of the worst, was to Emerson yesterday. ‘Task’ of any the least likelihood of real interest to me I can find none. I have been dismally sad, several of these days; the Irreparable returning on me, time after time, as if I cd repair it! Oh, my Darling, one radiance of my dark and sick existence, what is the use, then, of lingering here behind thee? Peace, howevr; ‘all the days of my appointed time will I wait,’ as my dear old Mother, in still deeper waters than thine of mine, was wont to say! I have also certn bits of duties, whh ought to be done; whh I cannot here or yet quite do. At any rate, sit not idle! Nor do I altogr, nor will. / Task being undiscoverable, am abt beginning (Paper laid out, all ready) a Quasi-Task, Reminiscences of Sundry Notable or Noted Persons. To it, then; with vigour rapidity! … / What a strange attractn is this betn one human soul and another! How precious is one mortal creature capable of becoming to us, at once, or by degrees: it strikes me sometimes, lately, as wonderful, unaccountable; and I do not here express the precise and as yet not quite articulate meaning of my thot on it. Oh my Jeannie, my darling little bit of nobleness and love, whh gave its radiance to all my day,—what of radiance the day still had, and now hasn’t!— Was all the force of love that was in me to be turned, then, upon One who is now in the Eternal Kingdom, and can never know it, or take joy in it more? to display itself as sorrow silent lamentatn, and to my own consciousness alone? It is tragical, most sad; but it may be salutary too. Be it so; it lay in the strange fate of me.— I sometimes think there may be in this abstruse element, of utter loneliness, of pain and fret and paltriness, in a world all gone to shadows, there may be a lesson getting slowly taught me?— / To work, however! Hardly got begun yesterday; have agn had a night too sleepless; am agn far enough from the mark, even the average mark; but let not rusticus wait expecting [cf. Horace, Epistles 1.4.42]” (TC’s journal; privately owned). TC then began writing his reminiscences of Southey and Wordsworth, 28 Jan.; see also TC to CDB, 23 Jan. To set abt writing my own Life wd be no less
than horrible to me; and shall of a certainty never be done. The common impious vulgar of this earth, what has it to do with my Life or me? Let dignified oblivion, silence, and the vacant azure of Eternity swallow me; for my share of it, that, verily, is the handsomest or one handsome way of settling my poor acct with the canaille of mankind extant and to come. “Immortal glory,” is not that a beautiful thing, in the Shakspearian Clubs Literary Gazettes of our improved Epoch?—I did not leave London, except for 14 days in August, to a fine and high old Lady-friend’s in Kent;TC visited Caroline Davenport Bromley at Ripple Court near Dover, 13–27 Aug. where, riding abt the woods by the sea beaches and chalk cliffs, in utter silence, I felt sadder than ever, tho’ a little less miserably so, than in the intrusive babblets of London, whh I cd not quite lock out of doors. We read, at first, Tennyson’s Idyls,Alfred Tennyson (1809–92; ODNB), poet laureate of the U.K., 1850–92; his Idylls of the King (1859–85) was eventually a cycle of twelve narrative poems, although only the first four were pbd. by 1867. with profound recognitn of the finely elaborated executn, and also of the inward perfectn of vacancy,—and, to say truth, with considerable impatience at being treated so very like infants, tho the lollipops were so superlative. We gladly changed for one Emerson’s English Traits;R. W. Emerson, English Traits (Boston, 1856); TC had first read the book in Dec. 1856; see 32:40TC to RWE, 2 Dec. 1856. and read that, with increasing and ever increasing satisfactn every evg; blessing Heaven that there were still Books for grown-up people too! That truly is a Book all full of thots like winged arrows (thanks to the Bowyer from us both):—my Lady friend’s name is Miss Davenport Bromley; it was at Wooton, her Grandfather’s House, in Staffordshire, that Rousseau took shelter in 1760;Jean-Jacques Rousseau (1712–78), French philosopher; for the visit, see 38:227–28JWC to MR, [30 Sept. 1862] . and 106 years later she was reading Emerson to me, with a recognitn that wd have pleased the man, had he seen it.

Abt that same time, my health and humours being evidtly so The Dowr Lady Ashburton (not the high Lady you sawLady Harriet Ashburton; Emerson visited Britain between Oct. 1847 and July 1848, and met Lady Harriet Ashburton during that time, including at a dinner on 24 March 1848; see 22:281TC to JCA, 26 March 1848. but a Successor of Mackenzie-Highland type), who wanders mostly abt the Continent since her widowhood, for the sake of a child’s health, began pressing inviting to spend the black months of Winter, here in her Villa with her;—all friends warmly seconding and urging; by oneJohn Tyndall. of whom I was at last snatched off, as if by the hair of the
head (in spite..spiteWord repeated at turn of page. of my violent No, no!) on the eve of Xmas last, and have been here ever since,—really with improved omens. The place is beautiful as a very Picture, the climate superlative (today a sun sky like very june); the hospitality of usage beyond example. It is likely I shall be here another six weeks or longer. If you please to write me, the Address is on the margin; and I will ansr!

postscript.p: T. Carlyle Esqr / Aux soins [care of] de Mylady Ashburton / Mentone / France

I liked yr yg friend SmalleyGeorge Washburn Smalley took tea with TC, 29 Aug. 1866; see TC to GWS, 28 Aug. 1866. very much indeed (as did everybody),—a good, a courteous, patient quietly intelligt young Citizen and patriotic soul.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 Feb. MS: NLS 526.55. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:243–45; Wilson, Carlyle 6:119; Surtees, Ludovisi 127.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I fully designed to write yesterday; but was interrupted by the trifles too common here; wherefore I have taken it up today the first thing, and will put it beyond the reach of such accidts. Yr Letter, whh was very kind and affectionate, did me a great deal of good, on its arrival the morning before yesterday (Thursday morng). I observe that when you fill yr sheet, yr Letters are far more agreeable, even in the separate parts of them. If there be even no news, as happily there cannot be much from yr still locality so long as all (by Heaven’s mercy) continues well, yet the very effort to be liberal in quantity necessitates more reflexion, and the tone of yr feeling at least comes out, whh to a solitary heart is the best result of all. For above a fortnight past, till some 3 days ago, I have, owing to mere insignificancies, of my own poor bringing into play, been a good deal bothered, and annoyed in the way of sleeping and all that depends on it; in my gloomy moods have felt often enough, very lonesome, forsaken, and of little use farther in the world.— I am agn got back to my usual state or above it; and the matter, whh you may have heard of thro’ James, was never of moment: but I had better tell you of it outright, that it may not get into any of yr fancies there play tricks.

The fountain of all (or at least the visible fountn) was that contemptible corn on the little toe, whh is already known to you! I know not what shd have hurt it here; I had my old Chelsea shoes, gutta-perchas especially, whh did tolerably well there; and, except finding my stockings all in a rather feeble state of darning, and no clear method of ordering anybody to darn them truly,
I had nothing to complain of in the matter of shoeing. So it was, however, the right little toe (sorrow on him, with his two corns, a hard always actual, and a soft always potentl) got into sorrow irritatn; whh I, too stoically, ignored; forcing him to his insignificant duty, regardless of complaints: upon whh he rebelled utterly; took to prickling, twinging, when I went to bed, and fairly forbade sleep, or next to altogr forbade. This was the prologue to—you guess all what. For abt 10 nights I was up in the short hours, smoking, sorrowfully stumbling abt;TC wrote in his journal, 28 Jan.: “I cd not well be worse-fitted, in regard of health c (kept awake all night or nearly so, nay be exact, I did sleep in pieces for abt 3 hours, tho’ very miserable genlly, and 3 times up, smoking, nail-brushing with soap my wretched prickle-prickling little-toe, and its pair of CORNS, the contemptible cause of so much misery: what a piece of work is man! [Hamlet 2:2])—but there shall be no farther ‘waiting till the stream run dry’; grip-to at once!— And be ashamed of yrself rather than sorry for” (TC’s journal; privately owned). discovered, in the early morning, innumerable small noises (nothing ever was so quiet as here, till abt 7½ a.m. when gardeners c c begin to stagger abt, and break the sacred silence by their patois greetings and the like,John A. Carlyle wrote, 3 Feb.: “I comprehended your description little map of Mentone quite well, for in passing to Genoa I have seen in the distance what kind of a country it is. I suppose you cannot talk with any of the people, as they will have a kind of unintelligible dialect for you.” “French is generally spoken at Mentone, whilst the lower orders use a peculiar patois” (Murray’s Handbook [1867] 560).—much unconscs of the pangs they are causing!)—and was in effect, at once ashamed of myself, and obliged to be very contemptibly wretched. Everybody was as kind to me as possible, especially the poor Lady was in daily despair,—insisted on a Dr Frank,Dr. Philip Frank; see TC to LLA, 21 July 1867.
