Ld Brownlow’s Dr, and a very loyal clever kind of man, coming to see me; who at once prescribed iodine for the toe, and at once put an end to the pricking of it, or taught me that a little coat of that kind of brown paint (tincture of iodine put on with a camel’s hair-pencil) wd at any time end it. This was one of the many careful corn-prescriptns of Dr Frank; this one proved truly valuable, I will keep this in mind: the rest, after bothering over a week, I wholly dismissed as inexecutable in given circs; and took to my own methods with that old devil of a toe. Cut out, namely, a beautiful oval hole in one of those old gutta-percha shoes; set all the others (including a new Italn pair, of fine soft leather, but too strait in that sore part, in spite of my prayers) resolutely aside; got a corn-plaster from James’s Letter, and am now wearing it with success:—cd I have got a shoemaker to hang on the highest gallows in Europe, with this inscriptn “For incessantly tormenting his fellow-men!” it wd have completed the recipe! In short the corn was silenced, or reduced to terms:—but not a bit more wd the sleep come back. I then “re-entered into myself,” as the French say; found that I had too long neglected my hepatic and adjoining concerns; humbled myself,
acknowledged that perhaps the corn was a blessing and admonitn:—in a word, finished off, 4 days ago, a decisive bout of blue-pill castor (whh had been infinitely needed); have had, in consequence, 4 nights of fair sleep; and fancy that my “foot is on the fog”See 5:367TC to MAC, 26 Aug. 1831. agn, or even that I am better than ever. Is not this a beautiful little epic, fit to be called an Iliad of Corns? We will let it end here.— And don’t bother yrselves thinking I am worse than formerly; for beyond doubt I am not, but better if anything.

I continue to like this place as well as ever; and am getting more adjusted into my circs, and abler to make the most of what capabilities there are. I try to “work” a little daily, that is, have paper before me,—tho’ it is flattery to call it by any name betokening labour as result: but the process or attempt does something to still me, and I do not neglect it: till 2, I am (theoretically, and indeed practically for most part) invisible here. In my late dietetic tempest, I have substituted tea for Coffee; make excellt Tea always, out of the crazy and crank machinery; and find it much better than the Coffee, whh cd never rise above the character of tolerable with contempt. I am thinking to give up my morning egg too, as there is always the cup of fair potage at 2 p.m. before going out. Dinner is at 7; but I believe, I shall never quite reconcile my poor digestive-apparatus to that bad hour. Another duty rigorous upon me is that of walking abt 2 hours: we have a dashing carriage pair, with plenty of confused swift-driving (when I care to accompany); but howr much of that there have been, I always make it set me down, 4 miles or so from home at least. Jean’s thick cape does excellt service in the carriage; I always leave it there; and put an excellt Shetland Comforter in my pocket (weight hardly two or 3 ounces), whh is effectual plentifully if sunset overtake me Jean can tell poor Symington this, i.e. tell his WifeAndrew J. Symington (1826–98) and his wife, Mary (1832–1917), who was from the island Unst in Shetland; the comforter may have been a gift in return for the mementos of TC given to Symington by JWC, July 1865; see 42:162JWC to TC, [30 July 1865], and 23942:biographical notes. for it was she that wove said comforter, and I hardly used usedWord repeated with a line over it at turn of page. it before. These two duties, that of writing something that of walking 4 miles (by myself in preference), I reckon to embrace all the strict requisitns of my poor day: the rest comes as it can; and the only thing constant is the effort to shirk being bored,—to shirk so far as possible, for a large allowance of that is not to be avoided anywhere; at Chelsea latterly, it was fast becoming far too large!— Everybody is kind to me; nothing can exceed the industry, patience, and continual contrivance of my hospitable Lady A.;Thomas Woolner reported to a friend, 9 Feb.: “I saw Carlyle at Mentone and was delighted to find the dear fellow in good spirits, and Lady Ashburton was rejoiced in having the mighty man to pet and honour, and make cosily comfortable” (Woolner 275). and she really has a great deal of sense and substantl veracity of mind—tho’ so full
of impulses, sudden resolutns, and living so in an element of “float” as poor Wull BrownWull Brown (d. 1838; see 10:248TC to JAC, 26 Dec. 1838), TC’s paternal cousin; for the phrase, see 6:270TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1832. called it! She made dinner-parties at first, one or two; but finding me incurably abhorrent of them, generously gave it up. We usually dine quite alone, talk not a burden to me; and wind up with a bit of reading,—generally it is in Friedrich that she prefers to read, as the bad best; her progress thro’ the Book has never quite ceased since it was first published, but it seems as if it wd never end either! In forenoons she has been in the Vita Nuova almost ever since yr Dante came;John A. Carlyle had sent Lady Ashburton a copy of his trans. of Dante’s Divine Comedy: The Inferno; see TC to JAJR, 30 Dec. 1867; Dante’s La Vita Nuova was not translated by John A. Carlyle. but now she is afloat in the Inferno agn, was speaking two days ago of what a help you yielded her. A most impulsive, uncertn Lady; performance differing much from program now then!— She talked the other day of yr good old “Lady Clare in the Isle of Wight” being dead;Elizabeth Julia Georgina Fitzgibbon, b. Burrell (1793–1879), countess of Clare; see 5:343TC to AC, 18 Aug. 1831. John A. Carlyle traveled with her in Europe as her doctor in the 1830s; she now lived in Ryde, Isle of Wight. John A. Carlyle replied, 25 Feb., that his Lady Clare was still alive: “it must have been the death of some other Lady Clare.” but cd not tell me where she had read it or heard it:—is the fact so or not?

The weather here is supremely good: better not only far than any feby weather, ever imagined by me; but I almost think than any weather, I cd ever imagine, or at least experience, for any season: sun strong as you can stand, or almost stronger; but the air brisk and bracing; pure as aether all the elements round you. I have thrown off my duvet quilt; two blankets (1 pair) abundtly enough, with the air of an open window not far off.

The people are civil, polite, but as idle as any set of Italn-English can well be: a people avoidable altogr, or merely salutable with the hat in passing. The good souls, yet the very poor!— One Ld Brownlow, or rather his mother, the Lady Marian Alford, a really great kind of Lady, who live a 30 minutes walking from us: their house is almost the only one Lady A. calls much at, or I call at all. They are splendid people very; the poor Ld B. a most interesting creature, age 26, “revenue above £100,000,”—and knows quietly, as his poor mother does more visibly, that he is fast dying of hereditary lungs.— I have to go and dine there, perhaps once a week, but it does me no ill: a thing of supreme elegance too, fine people in people inWords repeated with a line over “people” at turn of page. the House; and all of them are clever in their way—whh indeed is not my way!— — But surely I shd end now: when will you write me so long a letter, I wonder? Write something soon. “The Box is to be here on Tuesday”:—hmph!Presumably the box of new pipes; see TC to JAC, 25 Jan. Reed-pipes still hold out Love to Jean everybody.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 10 Feb. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead / London / Angleterre. PM: Menton, 11 Feb.; London, 13 Feb. 1867. MS: NLS 553.285. Pbd: Sadler 296 inc; Wilson, Carlyle 6:121–22 inc. Quot: Kaplan 483.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Several times I have heard of you from James Aitken and others, not always the best of news;James Aitken Jr. wrote, 25 Jan.: “I had a note from Mr Neuberg this morning— Last time I saw him I offered him the stray dog wh followed me home but he writes to say his sister has vetoed its coming he does not want to revolt against the female authority of the house! / The sudden breaking up of the frost had made him very ill but though still confined to the house he is much better ‘ wishes to be kindly remembered to you.’” and if I have not written, it is not for want of kindly thot and remembrance, but because of my own sombre mood, fitter for silence than for speech with any of the living. I grieved to learn that you had been suffering, in those dark storms of yr English Winter;—tho’ still standing obstinately to yr Work, and now a little improved agn since the boisterous thaws have come. Perhaps yr work is a benefit to you withal; but I cannot help wishing you had done with it:Neuberg was working on his German trans. of Frederick. —everything connected with that Book is more or less gloomy and miserable to me; the one recompense and consolatn seems to be that one do get done with it for all time and all eternity! Ah me, ah me!— In another winter, too, you might escape hither; and fairly have a quasi-summer instead; whh to you might be especially beneficial, as perhaps it is now in some less degree to myself. It is certain I had no belief in such a winter climate as this has proved to be; and for bright sun, and beauty of earth and sea and sky, we may challenge the whole world! I never saw such a feby even in my dreams; nor with eye and sense such weather as we now have, in any month of the year: This is something always,—tho’ it is by no means all!—

For sublimity, the picturesque c, c, I care less than most of my neighbours profess to do; indeed, except as secondaries, may say I care nothing: nevertheless it is a fact, I seldom yet rush out on a morning after bathing witht some sentiment of wonder and almost pleasure over those wild stony Peaks (whh girdle us all in from the North, and kindly press us upon the sea and the sunshine); they are wildest mountn architecture; towering up, jagged, sharp and bare, steeper than church-spires (sometimes with a little castle perched atop, strangely near to you, tho’ 6 miles off by measuret);For the castle above Sainte-Agnes, see TC to CDB, 23 Jan.
—they sit there grim cruel, like so many haggard old Witches of Endor holding conclave,—stone-naked to the waist; but after that, furnished with the beautifullest green ample petticoats (all of terraced olive-woods and orange and lemon
woods); the strangest thing I ever looked at in the “scenery” kind. I wander much by the wild rocky paths in those entirely silent Olive woods; entirely solitary till the sun sink, and the poor peast people (most of them old women) with their asses packages shrink home, bidding me as they pass, “Bon soir, M’sieu!” whh is nearly all the French the old part of them have. “Camino [go on]!”Presumably the donkey women’s version of the Italian “cammina [go on]!” I hear them say to their donkeys;—the ass is most respectable here, indeed a fine loyal animal, and the staff of life to Mentone; at nightfall one meets on our main street endless rows of them filing home, loaded with miscellanies big and small packages, whh I sometimes wish to break into, and take some inventory of! These native people seem to be the poorest and the frugallest, also the peaceablest, civillest probably happiest I have seen for a long time.Neuberg replied, 11 March: “How much happier in your bright, sunny, peaceable Mentone, with its grand Nature, loyally patient population, and donkeys of a superior quality!” J. Henry Bennet wrote: “The able pedestrian may be said to command the entire Mentonian amphitheatre; but it is not so with the invalid, with ladies, children, and the weak generally. The ascents are often winding and steep, the roads mere broken tracks, and were it not for the donkeys, much of the most wild and picturesque scenery would be all but inaccessible to the invalid population. These animals are numerous, as every peasant, the owner of a few mountain terraces, keeps one as a beast of burden. Donkeys are as peculiarly suited to a rugged mountain district as the camel is to the desert. At Mentone they are mostly fine handsome animals, and more than usually docile and good-tempered; probably because they are treated with affection and kindness, instead of with contempt and brutality. The peasants always guide them by the voice, not by blows. … The donkey women are only the owners of the saddles, hiring the donkeys from the peasants” (Bennet, Winter in the South 164–65). For Lady Ashburton’s party’s ride on donkeys to Sainte-Agnes, 25 Dec. 1867, see TC to SWA, 21 Jan.; for Bennet’s illustration to this passage (164) of “the donkey woman,” see oppabove.

figure.p:
“The Donkey Woman”
J. Henry Bennet, Winter in the South of Europe

docBody.p:
There are 5,000 natives in Mentone; perhaps 4,500 of them of this poor class; nobody very rich that I hear of, tho’ several now making money by the English;—and the place all bursting out into Villas c c like a mushroom in a favble night. There are 7 or 800 English; 300 Russn German; 180 French, of whom (says my authority, one Palmaro,Fran ccedil;ois Louis Palmaro (1823–95), wine merchant and banker, rue St. Michel, Menton, who later served as British vice-consul at Menton 1874–85. Banker, Wine-mercht c c, and an old acquaintance of Garibaldi’s,Giuseppe Garibaldi (1807–82), Italian patriot. whom he laughs at along with me), of whom “on ne tire rien [one can get nothing out of].—— The English, Germans c c are unutterably wearisome (with scarcely one or two exceptns); and one’s sole care abt them is to keep out of their way. Our English grand grandest exceptn, is The Lady Marian Alford (Mother of a certn tragical amiable Lord Brownlow, age 26, revenue boundless, who is dying of consumptn): this is really a high Lady, of much talent in her kind, and begirt with elegancies, whom it is not a hardship to visit sometimes. There is also
the F√ºrstina von Waldeck, infinitely polite menschlich [human], but not of much sure insight, has Husband withal (for the last few weeks), a most kind big man, with his tongue too big,Helena Wilhelmine Henriette Pauline Marianne (1831–88), princess of Nassau, m., 1853, Georg Victor (1831–93), prince of Waldeck and Pyrmont; Neuberg replied, 11 March: “Your F√ºrst von Walbeck was a contemporary of mine at Bonn. He was then a ‘Minor,’ his Mother reigning for him. … He was a most plebeyan looking Prince, with puffy red cheeks.” so that you can hardly half understand, at best when he speaks English as he insists on doing. The cleverest German is a Baron von S√ºlzerBaron Karl Friedrich von Sulzer-Wart (1835–68), m., 1865, Maria Selma, b. von Sulzer-Wart (1844–67). (of kin to the “Ach, mein lieber Sulzer,”Johann Georg Sulzer (1720–79), with whom Frederick the Great debated the issue of original sin in one of TC’s favorite exchanges; see 39:218TC to CAW, 18 Oct. 1863, and Carlyle, Works 16:337–38. he says) from Winterthur in Switzd);Winterthur, city in N Switzerland. he is an altogethr modest, courteous, serious, intelligt young man (Wife very poorly); his German, his French and his English alike intelligible to me;—company always the tolerablest, if any be.— But enough;—write to me.James Aitken Jr. wrote, 4 March: “I went up to Hampstead yesterday called on Mr Neuberg— He has been very ill for a long time— Your letter had found him, laid up, in bed he has only yesterday got down stairs again but dare not go out of doors yet; has not been doing any kind of work for a month past; has no specific disease about him only, as he says ‘Altogedder oud of sordds’ (altogether out of sorts). He asked me to tell you that, by way of apology for his not having answered your letter.” Neuberg replied, 11 March: “I was lying buried in gloom and sore misery … when your letter came to me like a blessed voice from Upper World. It arrived the morning after my undergoing a surgical operation, which is to do me permanent good, but was withal a rather terrible business. … I was happy to hear from various sources, and at last from yourself that your migration has answered so well. It was indeed a lucky change. You have escaped a winter of unusual severity;—to say nothing of the Reform hubbub which filled the air all these months.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAF, 10 Feb. Pbd: “Carlyle’s Last Letters to Froude,” ed. Waldo H. Dunn, Twentieth Century 159 (Jan. 1956): 49–51.
div3.head: TC TO J. A. FROUDE

docBody.p:
‘Inclination’ to write letters is a thing I have not traced in myself for many years back, and in these past months naturally less than ever! But your kind little NoteFroude wrote, 23 Jan.: “We heard of your arrival at Mentone from Tyndall. If you have time or inclination to write letters we should like to hear a little more from yourself of your subsequent condition.” did me so much good, I compel myself, and write a word, in hopes
of tempting you to another. If you would write without answer, the arrangement for me would be perfect;—but one cannot expect the like of that, in this stinted scene of existence, and must comply with its conditions such as they are!—

figure.p:
Menton from the east
J. Henry Bennet, Mentone, the Riviera, Corsica and Biarritz as Winter Climates, (1862)
Courtesy of Edinburgh University Library, Special Collections Department

docBody.p:
It must be said I am doing fairly rather well in these beautiful new localities;—and have at least escaped a great deal of meteorological horrors, which you describe in such frightful colours. What would have become of me while the mode of transit from Piccadilly westward was by skating alone,Froude wrote: “The pavements covered with frozen snow have made walking dangerous for the last three weeks. Last night rain fell froze on the ground. … Those who could skate took to that, and so made their way from Piccadilly to Knightsbridge.” I cannot conjecture! I hope, however, there was an increase of admiration for the Solon-like Law of our Metropolis, which fines men when they do fling out ashes before their door on such occasions, and try to reduce the cipher of broken bones:Solon (ca. 638–ca. 558 BC), Athenian politician and poet, known for his humane laws; it was against London bylaws to throw ashes and other rubbish into the street, but most towns had bylaws allowing ashes to be spread in time of frost to help prevent accidents; in a letter to the Times, 19 Jan., signed “CIVIL SERVANT,” the correspondent wrote: “If during this severe weather the heads of families would simply direct their servants to throw the ashes into the street, instead of into the ashpits, locomotion, both for men and animals, would be greatly facilitated, and horses drawing heavy loads would be eased of more than one-half their labour in the present state of the streets.”—in the universe we are surely an unrivalled people, for civic
“commonsense,” above all things.— Here at Mentone the Heavens, of their own accord, send a climate which, for the Spring and Winter months, I think must be the best in the world: such a february, following such a january, I never dreamt of; nor indeed did I ever see such weather elsewhere as we now have, in any month of the year. Mrs Froude might, I should think, with the minimum of inconvenience and maximum of profit, have taken shelter here;—or might still, till your bad march winds bitternesses go?Froude wrote that he was planning to go to Spain in March: “Mrs Froude is afraid of the journey in the cold weather and stays behind.” Nothing in or near Seville,Reference unclear; probably TC uses Seville as an example of a warm winter climate. I am told, is to compare with us:—and you in April, could of course fly out from Marseilles to BarcelonaPresumably Froude could sail from Marseilles to Barcelona. Marseilles is about 111 mi. (178.5 km.) W of Menton. in a no time and to SimancasFroude was planning to visit the Spanish national archives in Simancas, which contained letters and state papers relevant to his History of England, 12 vols. (1856–70); he previously visited 1861 and 1864, and he was going again in March to gather material for the final two volumes, which covered the defeat of the Spanish Armada, 1588. and your work, leaving Madam with a fair route home, and plenty of English escort if she liked. Or perhaps the careful MotherThe Froudes had a three-year-old son, and Henrietta Froude was expecting another child. will prefer to stay at home altogether, and take what comes?

This is certainly a most “beautiful” Country, too; and has the charm of strangeness “picturesqueness” c, c to a singular degree; and, what I like still better, of perfect clearness in heaven and in earth, air pure as aether, c, c, the stars at night seem ten times as numerous in the firmament as [in] ours, and have a quantity of light for your path which surprises. Truth is, we stand in a fine little alcove backed by the Maritime Alps,For a view of Menton from the east, showing its “alcove,” see 151; it was the frontis. of Mentone, the Riviera, Corsica and Biarritz as Winter Climates (1862), 2d edn. of J. Henry Bennet’s ever-expanding guidebook to Menton and the S of Europe for invalids. In the list of illustrations to its 5th edn., Winter and Spring on the Shores of the Mediterranean (1875), it was described as “Panorama of the Mentone Amphitheatre.” and their ultimate stony peaks, and have got the sun for our share, leaving you the snows and the north-winds.

Our population again, English population (700 or so by count), is not much to speak of; perfectly civil, but probably the idlest in the earth;—capable of boring you nearly to madness (I should think), if you didn’t keep on your guard. I wander a great deal in the brown shade of these Olive and Orange Woods; I have grandly silent sombre walks,—silent almost as Crusoe’s in
Juan Fernandez;Daniel Defoe (ca. 1660–1731; ODNB) in Robinson Crusoe (1719) possibly based Crusoe’s island on one of the Juan Fernandez Islands in the SE Pacific Ocean.—that is the best I can do with myself. Great men have made transit; Earl Russell, Duke of Argyll, Gladstone,—only the last of whom visible in this House,Gladstone visited Lady Ashburton, 22 Jan.; see TC to CDB, 23 Jan. he with little profit, I doubt, to self or others. Oh Heaven, what a beautiful future he has probably ahead of him!— My kindest respects to Mrs. F.

div3.head: TC TO GEORGE W. KITCHIN

docBody.p: I have by accidt had evidence, satisfactory to myself, that Mr BMr. B. not further identified; TC left a space in the MS, presumably intending to add the full name. is a clear-headed, accurate, truthful substantial kind of man; not likely to undertaken anything he is totally unfitted for: but with his literary talents or performances I have next to no acquaintance; and can make no preditn as to his proposed Book on the subject you mentn.

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: TC noted in his reminiscences: “(Finished, at Mentone, 8 February 1867;—after many paltry and miserable interruptions, which there was no avoiding, had there even been much motive, which there wasn’t!)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 400). He wrote in his journal, 13 Feb.: “Finished something (if it can be called a ‘thing’ at all) abt Southey, two days ago; no other Sectn of the small (imaginary) ‘Task’ yet entered upon. Have had, till abt a week ago, very great botheratn (in regard to sleep c) with certainly the smallest and paltriest of terrestrial objects,—the meeting (very justifiable) of my little toe, right foot, agt its shoe and shoemakers! Such a piece of work is man; the mind of him capable of being passed under the yoke, and utterly profligated and humiliated, by a cause of that magnitude!” (TC’s journal; privately owned).

postscript.p: G. W. Kitchin Esq c cJulia Sterling, da. of TC’s old friend John Sterling, wrote, 12 Feb.: “In case you are returned to England I write you a line to tell you that our dear sister Charlotte is gone to her rest—after a long suffering illness of many months. Happily the pain was less latterly, the end very peacefull.— / We feel desolate enough as you will believe, but I have my poor little Hester left my brothers.— / A few days before her death, Lotta heard that you were or had been at Mentone she said she was so glad that your friends had tempted you out for a bit.— I hope it did you good? that there comes some comfort for you.” TC wrote on the envelope: “Poor Charlotte Sterling (John’s eldest) gone / March 1867 ‘Share my Doll’; abt 1837 perhaps!).” For Charlotte’s doll, see 9:120TC to JOST, 17 Jan. 1837, and 229TC to JOST, 9[8?] June 1837.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 15 Feb. MS: Ruskin Lib. Collection. Pbd: Cate 124–26. Quot: W. G. Collingwood, Life and Work of John Ruskin (1893) 2:67.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: If the few bits of Letters I have written from this place had gone by the natural priority and sequence, this wd have been the first or among the very first;—and indeed it is essentially so,—the first that I have written except upon compulsion, or in answer to something written. My aversion to writing is at all times great. But I begin to feel a great want of having some news from you, at least of hearing that you are not fallen unwell; and there is no other method of rousing you to yr duty.Ruskin replied, 17 Feb.: “I should indeed have written to you, as you bade me—long ago, if it had not been that I had nothing to say except … what you knew very well—(that I loved you—and because I did, was glad, for the time, I had lost you).”

I have done passably well since getting out hither; and cannot but count it a kind of benefit that the impetuous Tyndall tore me out from the sleety mud-abysses of London, as if by the hair of the head; and dropped me here, on a shore where there is at least clean air to breathe, and a climate that is bright and cheerful to move about in,—and where, if frost did fall, and the streets became all of glass, people wd not be “fined for throwing ashes before their door,”See TC to JAF, 10 Feb.
and trying to save one’s bones or brains from being broken if one ventured out!— That is really hitherto the most unmanageable, or almost the one unmanageable point for me in the problem of my London Winter: compelled to take no exercise except under peril of life or limb;—“most thinking people,” was there ever the match of you for a power of “common sense” especially!—

I dare say you have been here; and descriptn of scenery, locality c wd be quite thrown away on you. From Antibes on the west to BodighieraAntibes, town in France 33 mi. (53 km.) W of Menton; Bordighera, small town in Italy 15 mi. (24.5 km.) E of Menton. on the east, a stretch of perhaps 40 miles diameter, is a beautiful semicircular alcove, guarded by the Maritime Alps, from all bad winds; included in this big bay (or alcove) are five or six smaller ones,—of whh Mentone, towards Bodighiera, is the last but one:—no climate, you perceive, can have a better chance to be good: and indeed, ever since Xmas last, when I arrived, it has far surpassed all my expectatns, or requirets in that particr; rather too hot, for most part, and
driving me into the Olive-woods and shaggy ravines, if the Sun is still high. One’s paths there are steep exceedingly and rough exceedingly (donkey-paths for the country people, paved into dreadful stairs in the bad places); but they are silent, solitary; a walk there is soothing to one’s sad thots, instead of irritating, and does one good, tho’ of a mournful kind. As to “scenery,” you know me to care next to nothing for it; but I must own, these pinnacles that stud the back of our little Mentone “alcove,” for example, are the strangest and grandest things of the mountain kind I ever saw; bare-rocks, sharp as steeples, jagged as if hewn by lightning; most grim, perilous, cruel, “sitting there,” I sometimes say, “like so many witches of Endor, naked to the waist, but therefrom with the amplest petticoats of dark or bright green” (for all is terraced, and covered with Olives or oranges and lemons, down almost to the sea),For Menton from the west, see above; the groves going “almost to the sea” are in the foreground; Villa Madonna was in this part of new Menton and was possibly one of the buildings among the trees that can be seen. —a really fine scene, especially at morning evg in light shade, under a sky so clear pure; scene whh I never yet raise my eyes to witht something of surprise and recognitn.

figure.p:
Menton from the west
J. Henry Bennet, Winter in the South of Europe, (1865)

docBody.p:
The worst of my existence here is that I am thoroughly idle,—for the “work” I try at intervals is a mockery of work;—and my real task is to walk abt 4 or 5 miles every day, and to guard myself vigilantly from being bored by
surrounding blockheads. For we are abt 800 here, and none of us has really anything to do. Patience, vigilance,—and shirk off into the Olive woods!

Often I begin to think of my route home agn; what I shall next do then. Alas, all is abstruse and gloomy on that latter head; but surely something shd and must be settled as to all that too: while the days are, and any remnant of strength is, one ought not to wander in mere sadness of soul, doing nothing! The only point I look forward to with any fixed satisfactn as yet, is that of having Ruskin agn every Wedny evg, and tasting a little human conversatn once in the week, if oftener be not practicable!— But the very time of my returning is uncertn; tho’ I care not for yr March tempests, and perhaps had better be at Chelsea even now: but there are grand speculatns abt seeing Rome first, Genoa at least and Florence first,—and many attempts to awaken my appetite that way, hitherto witht success perceptible. It is strange how one’s love of travel perfects itself by simply sitting still, if one do that long enough!Ruskin wrote: “I must still unselfishly pray that you may be enchanted away by magical ‘hair of the head’—to Florence at least, if not to Rome. That satiety of travel is surely a kind of lichenous overgrowing of one’s thoughts when one has been too long at rest—very good for most people … but surely not for you? I think your interest in seeing would increase … and that the mere change of air and of slope of sunray, by whatever endurance of irksome motion obtained, would be—of—so much better for you than the monotonous effluvium of Chelsea shore.”—
Adieu my Friend; I want a little Note from you qu√†m primum [as soon as possible]. I send many regards to the good dear old Lady;Margaret Ruskin, Ruskin’s mother.—and am ever

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 18 Feb. MS: NLS 526.56. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 128.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Yr news is all satisfactory; especially Alick’s Letter is welcome: I never till now cd clearly be sure that he had got that money;TC had sent £100 to John A. Carlyle to send to Alick; see TC to AC, 20 Oct. 1867
. and, had he said nothing of it this time, shd have been really uneasy. But now Jean can understand that, except his own bad accidt,Alick’s accident untraced. poor fellow, all is right on that score; and send him my love, constant as I know his own is; and say that he is not to bother himself writing anything about that matter, but only to send me news of himself his household, whh are always precious to us from that far land.

figure.p:
“The Bone Caves”
J. Henry Bennet, Winter in the South of Europe, (1865)

docBody.p:
My toe is behaving well;See TC to JAC, 9 Feb., and TC to GWK, 13 Feb. and I have another plaster in store for it (probably this week, or even tomorrow), whh I hope may quite unroot the vile bottom of it, enable me to pluck it off, and be where I was some weeks ago! I have very fine walks in these precipitous ravines (all paved as cuddy-paths, whh are the sole roads in our mountns; paved into stair-steps in the more precipitous parts; paths rougher, wilder, steeper, or more solitary are not in
the world!)—at other times when the sun is too hot, as it already sometimes is, I go meandering abt in the Olive-woods, under beautiful brown speckled shade,—in such a silence as I have not had for years and decades, and might hear the small still voices, sad but holy, as I cannot in noisier localities. The place is beautiful exceedingly, rustic, quiet, wholesome; and the human creatures in it are uniformly either harmless or kind to me,—the very bores avoidable if one take a little pains. I have been to see those Caves of the Troglodytes,See TC to CDB, 23 Jan., and 157above. “Lord Northbury” (Tom Baring,Thomas George Baring (1826–1904; ODNB), 2d Baron Northbrook (since 6 Sept. 1867; TC misspelled the name), politician and diplomat; first cousin once removed to Lord Ashburton; m., 1848, Elizabeth Harriet, b. Sturt (1827–67), who d. 3 June. a fine intelligt youngish man, gone this day to Nice) escorting me with great care; the path or track, whh partly overhangs the Sea, is rather difficult; and the Caves,—only 3 in reality, and not 6,—are worth nothing, their bones c mostly plundered out, and their extent or other qualities inconsiderable. The old Moggridge giver of the BookletMatthew Moggridge; see TC to JF, 24 Jan. John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 14 Feb., thanking him for “the interesting little book concerning climate c of Mentone, which you had got from Mr Moggridge sent on to me. … I read it at once found it good of its kind.” The book was probably Moggridge’s Panorama from the Bridge of the Boirie, Mentone (1867). is a Welshn, of 75, one of the most ridiculous, and yet likeable, happy old creatures you ever saw; who is here, these 6 years, with a Wife and Pulmonary son:Moggridge’s wife, m., 1836, was Fanny, b. Dillwyn (1808–94); their consumptive son was John Traherne Moggridge (1842–74), entomologist and botanist, author of Contributions to the Flora of Mentone (1867–71). son is avoiding consumptn and getting deep into Botany as an employt, a really goodish young creature; the father, who for the rest is perfectly the Englh Gentn, is a figure, and character, you can hardly look at witht laughing tho’ with the best goodwill to him too. A slouching, tall, harrow of a fellow, with crane neck always advanced, grey foolish all-knowing eyes, and long sickle-nose: Oh how perfectly at home in this world, and copious upon all things from the cedar of Lebanon to the hyssop on the wall! One thing he did tell me, “What was that corn-craik I had begun to hear in the woods? Can it be a Landrail then?”Landrail is another name for a corncrake. “Not a bird at all, Mr Carlyle: oh I followed it for years; it is a frog, “the tree-frog,” green as the olive-leaves, no finding of it;—and it croaks in that manner!”— But I must not get into these descriptns and details of our human populatn, at prest.

The thing is, What of my coming home? The Lady Ashburton contemplates a month’s travel or so in Italy, sight of Genoa, sight of Rome, of Bologna, Florence, sight of c c, before finally quitting this region. She has often
been spiering and examining whether I wd not accompany; to whh I have no adequate temptatn, hardly any temptatn at all (agt the miscellaneous horror of noisy inns, poisonous food, and grinning dilettantism);—and at length the kind Lady herself seems to see that it will be really better to leave me alone, and betake her to Florence, where Emilia Bunsen may be picked up, and made cicerone. To me all Bunsens are good, but much to be avoided,—if you dislike sententious commonplace, and harmonious cascades of twaddle! I therefore intend to be off, soon after my Lady goes;—whh ought to be “early in March”; tho’, in fact, there is no knowing whether it will certainly be at all: for things are extremely unpredictable here, resolutns changing almost like the wind! However, I in any case hold myself ready;— indeed cd do perfectly well in the weather there will now be in Engld. You can tell me what you think of all this, till we see farther.— Tyndall, I must not forget to tell you, being himself tied hand foot, had provided a certn learned tall awkward Mr Hurst,Thomas Archer Hirst (1830–91; ODNB), professor of mathematics at Univ. Coll., London; a friend of Tyndall’s (see 29:221TC to EE, 22 Dec. 1854), there is no record of him meeting TC. who professes grt love of me, but not I of him, to come “fetch me home on April 17th”; fixed he that way,—and I do the other way from first hearing of it. So writing today abt the Chelsea Pipe-box (whh has arrived yesterday “by Globe compy,”The Globe Parcel Express had three offices in London: 150 Leadenhall St., 150 Cheapside, and 23 Regent Circus. all safe), I added that I was perfectly adequate to come home by myself, and meant wd do that;—that;Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page.— and that Hurst must forever abandon the remotest notion of such a kind. So stands the affair,—and is not in hurry. Adieu dear Bror. Let Jean have time in plenty and over-plenty to read this! Yrs affecte T. Carlyle

postscript.p: Erskine’s Letter is very gentle, pious true.Thomas Erskine wrote to John A. Carlyle about his sister Christian’s death, 13 Feb., and John copied the letter for TC, 14 Feb.: “If I had thought that all the letters which I have received on this sad occasion really called for an acknowledgement, I should indeed have felt them an intolerable burden—but I have given my friends credit for a generous indulgence in this respect I have believed that they themselves (at least as many of them as were really acquainted with my sister) took a pleasure in expressing their sympathy with me on the loss of one who had become almost a necessary of life to me— who had indeed by her kindly wisdom made my path in this world pleasant to me.” He continued: “I was glad to hear of your brother’s comfortable condition at Mentone under the care of Tyndal Lady Ashburton. His life like mine is dislocated sadly.” Send my faithful remembrances.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 24 Feb. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. / [An]gleterre. PM: Menton, 2[4] Feb. 1867; Paris and Calais, 26 Feb. 1867; London, 26 Feb. 1867. MS: NLS 23167.147. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:122–23; Kaplan 485.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Some days ago I heard from Maggie Welsh that poor Grace, at Craigenvilla, was gone;Maggie Welsh wrote, 16 Feb.: “I grieve to have the most sad news of poor Grace Welsh to send you. This very morning I had written a letter to you to tell you of Walter’s visit to Craigen Villa, the letter is lying beside me now sad in vain! Walter came in only half an hour ago to tell me that all our hopes fears about poor Grace are of avail no longer! There is a notice of her death in the newspaper today; she died yesterday. It will be a sad blow to her sisters, poor old ladies. Of late I do think they have hoped Grace might have been spared to them, though of course they could not but face how precarious her state had for long been. So lately as Monday when Walter was there, poor Ann spoke cheerfully even hopefully, now! … I know you will feel it much for the sake of Her we all loved so dearly.” Walter Welsh also wrote, 16 Feb.: “Maggie tells me she is sending you a few lines, much grieved you will be to hear of poor Grace Welsh’s death which took place yesterday. Perhaps rather one should think it well that she is released from the state of weakness suffering to which she was reduced, from which she herself looked for no recovery. She has borne all calmly peacefully throughout her long illness.” TC wrote in his journal, 20 Feb.: “News this morning that poor Grace Welsh, my Jeannie’s youngest Aunt, is dead,—Edinr 15 feby. 1867— She had been suffering much (liver c) for months; little other result cd be anticipated, from the light I had. (interruptn——21 feby ). The last time I saw her was on the evg of that saddest of days (26 April 1867) after I laid my Dear One in her Father’s Grave. We had an hour or two at Edinr; John and I drove out to the poor old Aunts. Their grief was genuine; tho’ to mine it was like a pail of water to the sea. Poor Grace was the first of them I saw; nobody cd then have thot she wd be the first of us to pass away. She was not witht fine qualities; my Darling, tho’ not blind to her bits of affectatns c, always liked her,—and wd often repeat to me old faithful Betty acct of their exorbitant profession of ‘religion,’ as they heartily endeavoured to think it: “Oh my dear, they might ha’ ta’en to waur!’— She came to see us at Humbie (Fife year), Ann she both came; and were very affectionate and good: that was the last time I ever saw my Darling any of them together. They had built a pretty little cottage at Morningside; called it ‘Craigenvilla’; there will now be only two of them instead of 3,—sad, sad to think of for the good old souls. One of my reflexns, on hearing of it, was ‘My Jeannie has been spared this grief’—yea, yea. Blessed are the dead that die well. God be with us all Dead or yet to die!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). See also TC to MW, 26 Jan. JWC and TC stayed at Humbie, Fife, 28 June to 5 Aug. 1859; neither noted any visit of Ann and Grace Welsh in this time (see vol. 35). and yesterday, thro’ James, I had what the Dr had heard, whh was not then new to me. I am very sad and wae to think of it all; and feel well how desolate the Two Sisters will be in the old house whh lately belonged to Three! The end of all things comes; and it is sad and solemn to all thinking and loving Souls. The last time I saw poor Grace was on that saddest day of my life, when I had buried all that was most precious to me in the world:—Grace was then the youngest of the whole party, and one cd little have expected that she
was to be the first of us that shd be called away. We shall, all of us be called soon; why shd we sorrow over-much, since it is but for a little while? We shall go to them; they will not return to us.— — I have not written to Ann or Elizth; knowing how paltry, and even provoking and distressing, are most “letters of condolence”; but I wish you to take some good way of assuring that suffering pair that my heart is sore for them; and that it is not want of sympathy but a very difft feeling that keeps me from writing.Jean Aitken wrote to Ann Welsh, 27 Feb.: “I had been writing delaying writing to you for some little time before your dear sisters death till I shd get later accounts, from Mentone little dreaming that the end was so near. / I have been wishing to write ever since but know how worse than idle are all words of comfort are in such cases. … My reason for writing tonight is to give you some extracts from a letter wch came from Mentone this afternoon. It is dated Feb. 24 begins”; Jean then copied TC’s first paragraph and closing part into her letter. As a way of taking “some good way” of sending his sympathy, as TC requested, she ended: “I wd have sent the letter itself dear Miss Welsh but the Dr thinks you might have great trouble in making it out as it seems to have got wet of something wrong with it” (MS: EUL).

James manages everything for me in London very well; and his letters are models of clearness in the briefest compass. He had some intimatn abt a “small bit of busss” for himself; abt whh I made inquiry, but he does not ansr except in the genl strain; seems almost tragically eager to get forward, withal steadily hopes.James Aitken wrote, 20 Feb.: “Many thanks, Dear Uncle, for your kind inquiry as to my business— I am glad to tell you I am getting a little work in Insce c slowly, very slowly though at times I feel like to cry but I never, for a moment have quite lost hope of getting paying business or of doing well— Once or twice of late I have got into such gloom despondency about my prospects in the world shd this fail as I have nearly turned my head I have to thank you alone Dear Uncle, by your manly-divine counsels in the Everlasting Yea elsewhere of Sartor Resartus, for cheering me on again in face of false insurance—scuttling other kindred blackguardism to stand firm here wait my turn for a trial.” A sentence from yr last Note to him, that poor Sl Wright was quieted into natural wholesome weakness, and “desire to lie in his bed,” was very welcome to me; I had hoped as much from the acct you already gave myself of the poor wandering distracted creature,—frozen, as if by voluntary hardship of thrift, into that pitiable state. Want is want, from whatever cause it spring!— The weather here continues almost too magnificent; this morning, on the “Promenades” N. South by the sea-shore, (southwd of the street and its edifices) the English people were seated with umbrellas above them, reading the Newspapers: a sun like july, in a sky clear as diamonds, with the mountns seeming within arm’s-length, tho’ the farthest peaks are perhaps 10 miles away. Sunday gone a fortnight, the day before I last wrote to the Dr, gave us, on the other hand, 18 or 20 hours of such rain as I never saw: windless, straight-down, in continual streams torrents;—for the first time in 30 years, I did not get out, the whole day; but had to content myself with an hour
of quarter-deck-ing within doors instead. But for this I shd have called the rain also glorious,—one day of it at least, among many sunny; tho’ otherwise it might have grown ugly enough. With all this of the “glorious sun,” it will surprise that I have got a dirty cold,TC wrote in his journal, 22 Feb.: “very weak wretched today; caught cold yesty, and not a wink of sleep all night c c: day, thrice beautiful, helps me somewhat” (TC’s journal; privately owned). with whh I have been obliged to apply to castor take vigorous judicious measure to check it, and set it on the recoil, as I hope it now fairly is; reduced to sniftering agn or alternate tickling of the windpipe:—much reduced since yesterday, the castor day! Natives ansr may surprise by saying, “Everybody has cold in this Season; that it is not good to be in the sun, that the sun is treacherous (perfide)!” I mean to take care of him a little better. It is certn, howr, that much of my inflictn rose from the liver; indigestn is a thing I cannot with all my art avoid, in this land of New climate (and of multiplex irregularities to boot, in this otherwise so snug corner of it)— The Pipes came, that wet sunday, as I perhaps told you: 24 of them, charge 12 francs, abt 4 d each—after waiting some 6 weeks on a Lady SmithJames Aitken Jr. wrote, 9 Jan.: “I only heard from Mr Tyndall yesterday that he has forwarded The Life of Holbein to Lady Smith, Berkeley Square the address given him by Lady Ashburton— The Book was too large to go in the Box with pipes c Mr Tyndall thought it a pity to disturb the packing by taking out the Flannels they are in it still.” Lady Smith unidentified further. that was to bring them gratis: but put off, put off,—just till the very day the Pipes had set out on their own footing. Of course I have now a glow [word unclear]— a day if I liked! This is all my personal news. Public news, in the Colony, is the sudden death of poor Ld Brownlow last tuesday:TC was confused about the day; he saw Lord Brownlow, Tues. 19 Feb., and Lord Brownlow d. Wed. 20 Feb.; TC wrote in his journal, 21 Feb.: “a touching and mournful event occurred here at Mentone; sudden end of young Ld Brownlow, an amiable intelligt young man of eminent possessns positn, who had been tragically waiting, this long while back, to die. Seized with consumptn at the age of perhaps 16; age now 26; for those 9 or 10 years, by continual shifting of climate, by the cares of a tremulously tender mother, and every help and appliance, he has been kept living, beautifully patient and even happy, tho’ continually only escaping death. At length death came, as he must; in a moment it is now all done. By accidt I saw Ld Brownlow, on his last day in the world, more at large than ever before; and I had never seen him so brightly childlike, intelligtly active in his way, or freer from pain or the least trace of chagrin (tho’ hope, they all knew was not in him). We parted from him his abt 10½ p.m. Tuesday [19 Feb.]; on Wedy evening abt the same hour, he was suddenly no more. / I did not know these high people till my coming hither; nor do I yet much know them, or much expect or wish to do it, tho’ they have been very kind to me, and of exuberant courtesy in the most elegant forms;—but I shall never quite forget last Tuesday, and the amiable and strangely tragic Living Flower whose evanescence I chanced to witness so near at hand.—” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Mary Louise Boyle (1810–90; ODNB ), poet and novelist, also staying in Menton, wrote of Lord Brownlow’s last day: “On the day previous to his death he rode, as was his wont, his favourite cob through the pretty woods of Cap St Martin, accompanied by myself, two other lady friends, and Carlyle, on foot” (Mary Boyle, Her Book, ed. Sir Courtney Boyle [1901] 267). Cap St Martin, now called Cap Martin, is immediately W of Menton. —the Family
go all off with the Body, for Engld,Lord Brownlow was buried in the family tomb in St. Peter and St. Paul’s Churchyard, Belton, Lincolnshire. tomorrow morning,—the poor Mother much broken down in grief. She was Lady A.’s, chief friend and resource in this place:—so that Lady A. is now I think almost sure to set off on her Tour thro’ the cities,—and indeed has fixed to leave on “Saty at noon” by the Steamer for Genoa, whh takes only six hours. It is not unlikely, if the weather continue bright, and this cold go quite away, I may accompany her so far;—with the option of returning next day or tuesday if I don’t don’tWord repeated with a line over it at turn of page. take with the adventure. I confess a clear route homewards in not many days hence, wd please me still better;— I must earnestly take thot abt it!—— — Here is a Letter from Ruskin with a fine paragraph abt you;Ruskin wrote to TC, 17 Feb.: “One pleasant thing I had to tell you of, however, was a most happy evening we had with your sister [Jean Aitken]. I think she enjoyed it too. My mother was entirely happy with her at once. … Her modest gentleness of power is notable to me above anything I have yet seen of womankind.” TC sent the letter to Jean, writing on the first page: “Thinking to send only a half, I slit, but now recant.” whh you may keep,—¬≠believing as much of it as you fairly can!

closer.name: T.C.
closer.note: John A. Carlyle wrote, 25 Feb., that Jean’s da. Mary wanted to become a pupil teacher: “On Saturday [23 Feb.] Jean and young Mary went to Peebles returned in the evening. A niece of Aird’s had been performing as a Pupil Teacher on slenderer qualifications than Mary’s, an advertisement appearing last week in the Scotsman, Mary had answered it, got a very nice looking letter in reply. And it was thought right that she her mother should go see the people it had come from. They found a doctor’s widow daughter (Mrs Miss Renton) living in a nice isolated house of their own, with abundance of boarders all looking very healthy happy, were quite satisfied that Mary might have an excellent chance of success in such an establishment with two such mistresses as Mrs Miss R. Mary had said nothing of her wishes to anyone here, so that we were all taken by surprise. She is very solid steady in her ways, has plenty of talent, an ardent desire to learn German, French c taught by natives. Not more work as a Teacher than might be desirable in order to test what she learns herself. She is to go off next monday try at least for one quarter, I will gladly pay the £5 per quarter for her—that being the fee for board c. At the beginning of winter I had made inquiry about terms for the best boarding school in Edinr, but I could not see my way in regard to sending her into so artificial expensive an arena, without any definite prospect of success—unless one had wished her to become a mere governess. I shall miss her here for it is she who has kept things right for me.” John wrote to their sister Janet Hanning in Canada, 7 March: “Young Mary went off last Monday [4 March] morning to a boarding school at Peebles as Pupil Teacher, for she is determined to learn languages c. She got the place by her own exertions, her mother only going with her to look at the thing before finally fixing. And she (Mary) seems to like her new position quite as much as she anticipated” (MS: Yale). Thomas Aird (1802–76; ODNB; see 6:361TC to JAC, 29 March 1833); Aird’s niece was probably the da. of his brother James; Martha Renton (ca. 1799–1874), b. England, winow of Alexander Renton, surgeon, and their da. Margaret Renton (b. ca. 1836), b. Peebles, teacher; by the 1871 census, another da., Mary Schultze (b. ca. 1833), widow, also a teacher, lived with them at The Priory.

bibl.person: PHOTOGRAPH OF AREA West OF OLD MENTON

div3.sourceNote: TC’s notes to photograph of area W of old Menton [NPWM], [26 Feb.]. MS: Thomas Carlyle’s Birthplace, National Trust for Scotland. Hitherto unpbd. Three photographs of Menton were taken, probably in Feb. TC wrote comments on photographs 1 and 3. 26 Feb., the day after he walked home from “Mustola” [Mortola]; see above. The three photographs were sent to John A. Carlyle, 27 Feb., but were then sent back by French Post Office officials who objected to TC’s marginalia as “illegal”; see TC to JAC, 4 March. On photograph 1, TC’s comments and marks were written in small handwriting on the left, top, and right-hand margins; see above. There were no comments on photograph 2. On photograph 3, TC wrote one comment at the top; see TC’s note to photograph of Old Menton, [26 Feb.] . For photographs 2 and 3 (of a small bridge near the Franco-Italian border and of Old Menton), see vol. 45.
div3.head: TC TO PHOTOGRAPH OF AREA West OF OLD MENTON

docBody.p: †TC’s first comment, top margin, top left-hand corner, “‚Ä†”: TC drew a broken line from this cross down the left edge of his first comments, ending with an arrow pointing to the top margin. The left-hand margin has “W” with a line from there to the edge of the photograph: as TC wrote, the two lines would intersect at the point where the “biggest Villa” was (visible only with magnification), behind the line of trees on the left of the photograph. The photograph was apparently taken from a point W of Villa Madonna and is so faint that it now mainly shows the trees and shrubland in the foreground.

villa N (approximately): N. W. point to (and their lines wd intersect at) the biggest Villa in Mentone; once the Duke of Monaco’s “Town-House,” now the Casino, or agn a “villa”The eighteenth-century Palais Carnolès, previously the summer residence of the princes of Monaco. Its current use was unclear as TC indicated; Bennet wrote: “A much more extensive and elegant Casino [than the one previously in Old Menton], or club was opened at the close of the year 1864”; its owner (M. Gillot) “purchased it off the Prince, with the grounds around, extending over ten or twelve acres. He has renovated the palace, decorated and furnished it in a very elegant and luxurious style” (Bennet, Winter in the South 173). Murray’s Handbook (1867), in the middle of its list of Menton hotels, noted: “[O]n the opposite side of the road [from Hôtel du Pavillon], surrounded by a large garden, is the former residence of the Prince of Monaco, splendidly fitted up and let furnished, perhaps the most comfortable residence for a large family in Mentone” (Murray’s Handbook [1867] 560). It is now the Musée des Beaux-Arts du Palais Carnolès. (broken gambler, one TothernTothern unidentified further. lives hungrily in its wide expanses!)—behind and within a gunshot of it, stands Villa Madonna, hidden from the Photographer by the woods and it; next house (of 4 chimnies) on the Hill, on left, is abt as far off as (and not quite so far ahead) on our right, when we look up, as “Casino” is with its trim gardens,Jardin du Palais du Carnolès was laid out in 1725 next to the palace. sea beyond,
when we look down—i.e from out upper window; for we too are on the flat, just where it ends; and were an old Convent, till almost a year or two ago

figure.p:
Photograph of area west of Old Menton with TC’s notes, February 1867
Courtesy of the National Trust for Scotland

docBody.p: Points towardsTC’s second comment was written sideways above the image, just past the middle of the top margin, with an arrow pointing from its first line to top margin, about the center. a steepled old “Castle” or Stone Blockhouse; on a skirt of low crag whh runs into the sea—where is the point of visn of Photograph No 3Murray noted that the E and W bays of Menton were “separated by the old Genoese fort on a projecting promontory” (Murray’s Handbook [1867] 560); this promontory (and fort) can be seen on the illustrations of both Menton from the east (151) and Menton from the west (155) and was the viewpoint of photograph 3.

Points towdsTC’s third comment, also written sideways above the image, has an arrow pointing from the first line to the top margin, to right of center. ghastliest bare stone chasm and little Bridge at bottom,Photograph 2 of a low bridge near the Franco-Italian border may be the bridge that Bennet described: “About half a mile beyond the torrent that descends from the St. Louis ravine, the path passes over a gully, by a bridge of one arch, so thin and light that it is crossed for the first time with some apprehension. It is said to be of Roman construction, and, small as it is, seems worthy of such an origin” (Bennet, Winter in the South 123). Or it may be Pont St. Louis, of which Murray noted: “the road begins to ascend, and passes the frontier at the bridge of St. Louis over a picturesque ravine” (Murray’s Handbook [1867] 562). For the illustrations of Pont St. Louis, probably up-ravine from TC’s low bridge, see above and opp. now
the “boundary of France and Italy.” Three French soldiers (the picture of ennui in widest of red breeches) are always there—road, made by the First Napoln (mainly by gun powder), can be traced on Photogh above halfway to Ventimiglia— “Caves of the Troglodytes”See CDPTC to CDB, 23 Jan. , and 157TC to JAC, 18 Feb. are a little way eastward of “boundary” chasm bridge

figure.p: J. Henry Bennet, Winter in the South of Europe (1865)

docBody.p:
Church of Mentone has its spire;TC’s fourth comment; the end is bracketed by TC with an arrow pointing to the top right corner of photograph. remains of real Old “Castle of Mentone” there (mostly turned into churchyard);See TC to CDB, 23 Jan. old Town of Mentone hangs thereabts mainly; gray old honeycomb hardly sensible to the Photographer.— Slight “a”A very faint “a” may just be visible when picture is magnified when direction of arrow is followed into top right-hand corner of photograph. if you look thereabts in the sea, marks the mouth of Turin valley
torrentTC presumably referred to the river Careï. A “carriage-road” had been completed from Menton “up the valley of Carrei to Monti” (Murray’s Handbook [1867] 561), which in due course was to reach Turin via Sospel (Sospello). Bennet wrote that the “Turin road … ascends the deepest and longest valley in the amphitheatre—that of Carei, at the entrance to the town” (Bennet, Winter in the South 160). Turin, N Italy, was about 155 mi. (250 km.) NE of Menton. whh is the stand of view-point of Photh No 2The photograph of the lower bridge at the Franco-Italian border; the river at the border was rio San Luigi, which rises in Italy. Now basta, 20 times!—

figure.p:
Pont St. Louis, 2015
Courtesy of Aileen Christianson

docBody.p: [R]oad vanishes from Photh where you see:TC’s fifth comment, middle right-hand margin; arrow pointing from “road” to above tree line, detail not visible, presumably to the point where rio San Luigi entered the Mediterranean. near a Hamlet called Mustola,Mustola: TC presumably means Mortola, which was near the caves, both of them just over the Franco-Italian border. abt 2 miles from Ventimiglia. Yesty (feby 25) my walk was from that point home (I had come out on 16, no on 8 airy feet [i.e., a two-horse carriage]) walk home, you perceive was all downhill or the level; for the first time

“Cape” St MartinTC’s sixth comment, bottom right-hand margin; the double broken line ends with arrow pointing at writing (not the picture as all the others did). abt a furlong further on; Cape a low angry cairn of sharp bewildered boulders, sprinkled with pitifullest myrtles rosemary ;— “Hill” (of St Martin), whh adjoins, is no more than a “swoln Plain” in these parts, and 9/10; of it too are boulder ugly angry sharp stone; but it is carefully terraced, spreads into wide waving expanses of Olive,Murray noted: “The excursion to Cape St. Martin, through olive and carouba groves, is most agreeable; it may be performed by the indifferent carriage-road, but more agreeably on foot, or by donkeys” (Murray’s Handbook [1867] 562). This was the ride that Lord Brownlow, accompanied by TC and others on foot, took the day before his death; see TC to JCA, 24 Feb.—our richest and biggest in all this region: “O how beautiful, are n’t they?” to which I make a point of answering strictly nothing.

div3.sourceNote: TC’s note to photograph of Old Menton [NPOM], [26 Feb.]. MS: Thomas Carlyle’s Birthplace, National Trust for Scotland. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO PHOTOGRAPH OF MENTON

docBody.p: “VillaAn arrow points from beneath the V of Villa, down the side of the words toward the photograph, slightly to the left of its center. Usborne”Presumably belonging to Mrs. Usborne, an English resident of Menton, and a relative of the Rev. Mr. Morgan, who was the minister of the English church; she had given land, 1862, in the eastern bay near the sea for the building of the new English church in Menton; opened by 1867, it was noted on a map (late 1870s—1880s) of Menton and its surroundings as “Usborne Temple protestant” (Menton Archives 1Fi29).

Late Ld Brownlow: high up the HillPossibly TC referred to the house above Old Menton visible on the photograph. Lady Alford and her sons were staying at La Grande Bretagne, a hotel not far from Villa Madonna (see TC to MB, 20 March), but apparently also had access to Villa Usborne. (whh is almost as steep as a ladder wd like to stand; quite crowded on the sea in this part); 1½ miles from us; we have a road to it partly thro Old Mentone (below the Church), but it is rough dismal, little or no nearer; it is thriftier to keep by the sea-wall (and side-
pavt) whh you see, till it issue in the main street, abt a gunshot nearer you than where the Photh begins

figure.p:
TC’s notes to photograph of Old Menton, February 1867
Courtesy of the National Trust for Scotland

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 27 Feb. MS: NLS 526.57. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 128.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I sent you on three big Photographs of Mentone; whh I hope may afford you and Jean some entertaint when they come; and elucidate, as if to the very eye, some particrs of my situatn here.See the photograph of the area, W of Old Menton with TC’s notessee 165; for photographs 2 and 3, see vol. 45; see also TC’s note on the photograph of Old Menton, see 69. They are directed to Dumfries as usual; but I am not quite sure you are there. If you did go to attend the last duties to poor Grace Welsh in this world, it will be a consolatory thot to me, amid the many, many sad ones abt that event, and the reminiscences it awakens into new vivacity, whh were by no means asleep! Say to Ann and Elizth, if you have opportunity, all that is kind and tender on this mournful event; whh will have left a most sad blank in their loving little circle. Ah me, ah me!— If you are with Erskine, too, I shall be well pleased.John A. Carlyle wrote, 25 Feb.: “I was invited to the funeral would have gone, but there was no vacancy for me in my old lodging, I did not feel well enough to go stay in any inn. I … may go into Edinr for some days … then I will call see Miss Welsh Miss Anne, also Mr Erskine, tell you about them all. I am almost as thin-skinned in regard to strange beds as you yourself are, I really could not safely go to the funeral.” His case is too like my own to need vocal assurances of my sympathy: alas, as if these, at any rates cd profit one sensibly, in one’s woe!—

All is getting unfastened here,—for departure somewhither, Poor Ld Brownlow’s long worn thread of life snapped in the gentlest unexpected manner yesterday gone a week; and he suddenly passed away, and was gone like a dream. The Household there is shut accordingly (nothing left but some servants packing it together); the rest are all off to England,—to the funeral (in Lincolnshire) and what will follow. This has quite extinguished any chance there was in Mentone for Lady An, who used to be there daily and almost hourly;Lady Alford and her sons had been staying at La Grande Bretagne hotel; see TC to MBO, 20 March. But TC implied in his note to the photograph of Old Menton(see 169) that she and her sons were staying in Villa Usborne in the hills above Old Menton. Presumably they had the use of the villa but were mainly in the hotel. and indeed had nobody she specially cared for except “Lady Marian,” that now bereaved Mother. The result is, Lady An is more eager than ever to be off for the Italian Expeditn, or for something or other,—cd she but get the many lines of her complex affairs to intersect handsomely: whh she cannot!
Her situatn here is really intricate; and she makes it, by her impetuous handling, often enough not less but so more so. For me, I think I have abt renounced the notn of “accompanying”; nay, seeing my situatn, weak health and gloom of mind, she herself I think has renounced me. And then her own plans, alas they are manifold, and hardly anything stands firm hitherto!

This very morning I was speaking to her abt your “meeting” me somewhere (for as to needing to be fetched home, I profess to scorn it), and abt a questn I had raised with myself whether “a month of Vichy”Vichy, spa town, the Auvergne, central France, known for its healing mineral waters; Lady Ashburton had been there the previous summer; see TC to LLA, 21 July 1866 , and was to go there again in May; see TC to LLA, 8 May . on the road homewards might not be a good thing (stomach the great mainspring of all my weakness, that not a bit stronger I doubt than on leaving home; and how, possibly enough I cd persuade you to meet me at Vichy; spend March there (Bath-guests all as yet far),—she suddenly broke out, “Oh why cdn’t yr Brother come here, and guide us away to Rome, and everywhere! What is to hinder him?”—and seemed delighted with the pretty dream. Whh I naturally left standing there on its own feet, what feet it had.John A. Carlyle replied, 5 March: “As to Vichy, I think the waters there, as in many other similar places, would not do at all, unless in summer or autumn, when all external relations are different from what they are in spring—such as temperature, action of the skin c. I don’t think such waters are ever used in winter or spring, but I am sadly rusted in that many other medical matters. … Possibly we might go together in summer, give them a fair trial in the proper season! The distance is not very great, there must be quiet lodgings in such a place. … I feel rather shaky sensitive myself at present, have no experience of railway travelling in France, otherwise I might have started at once to assist you without farther discussion.” He wrote again, 6 March: “now I feel that I ought to have said expressly that I shall be ready to meet you at any place you choose to name on the way home from Mentone, do the best I can to assist you on the journey. I dont feel very well at present, but it seems to me that the travelling might do me good rather than otherwise, as the main part of my ailments probably arise from the tendency to stagnation which is unavoidable at Dumfries.” In short she is the most generous-hearted, but the most tumble-headed (not that she wants sense either, far from that) of existing Hostesses;—and it appears to me, I ought to lift anchor before long, as the handsomest method, and reappear in Chelsea taliter qualiter [one way or another]. Not to say that the Sun has absolutely got too hot for me here; and that (partly as a consequence) I have taken cold, on the small scale hitherto, but any scale is too big. I am very lazy, too, and very idle; more solitary (intrinsically) no human soul can be. It seems to me, March in Chelsea may be abt as tolerable as March here.—— Write to me; James will forward this to where you are. Adieu dear Brother.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 4 March. MS: NLS 526.58. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:341–42; Wilson, Carlyle 6:125.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I got yr long welcome Letter, since that Jean’s: I am abt writing shortly today; and as it is on a kind of conclusive busss, I will study to stick by the practical points. Let me first say, however, that the Photographs are still here; after lying 2 days in the Post-Office, they were sent back (stamps unhurt), the Officials objecting to my marginalia of expositn as illegal. Good, good. A hasty Englishn setting out on Tuesday has undertaken to convey them to Rood Lane, where they will come to you, I hope, by surer better courses. I am writing to James also today; and send this note to be forwarded by him.

So far as I can judge the Roman expeditn is now given up by Lady An herself; and it is uncertn whether either she or I shall so much as “see Genoa,” tho’ it might so easily be done.Lord Northbrook wrote from Nice, 2 March: “I have tried to find someone going home with whom you would like to travel, but everybody is now going to Florence Rome not to England. Lady Ashburton … told my wife that you think of going to Genoa with her … in that case I suppose you will not want anyone to join you from here.” But my cold still continues (threatening to root itself in the larynx, and be hanged to it!) and the “sight” of anything is become worth extremely little to me. Not to say that a fierce east-wind is blowing, almost equal to an English do, sometimes grey, whh I like better, not improved at all to one’s feelings by the blazing of a sun, whh is only like roasting you and icing you both in one. March comes in like a lion here too, it seems; these last 4 days are far the worst, and properly the first disagreeable ones, we have yet had.

To cut matters short I intend to be off towards Chelsea in abt 8 days (March 12 or so); and expect to be in my own house (home, alas, I can call it no longer) before next week quite end. The Butler of the late Ld Brownlow people is abt setting out on that day (will “stay to any day,” “do any c c for me[”]; he is one of the most perfect-looking, wise, quiet and obliging persons of his statn, this Butler “Tweedie,”Mr. Tweedie not further identified; John A. Carlyle wrote, 8 March: “It is a very great relief to me also to Jean to know that you are not to start alone from Mentone, but are to have good sober guidance on your journey homeward.” I have ever seen: Dr Frank,Dr. Philip Frank; see TC to JAC, 9 Feb. Murray’s Handbook (1867) listed Frank’s address in Menton as 1 Villa Massa (561). whom he stays for, will settle every detail to my mind;—in short, on best calculatn, I find I shall hardly have any other chance of the least like equal quality, if I let this go. I intend to sit in a coupéA coupé is an end compartment in a train, with seats on one side only. if I can, and have a trial for sleep on the floor
now then. Starting from Nice at 3 p.m. one might get on to Avignon that night;—I shd really like to see some City or fractn of that fine Rhone Country; “Lyon!” “Avignon!” the statn people called out, but it might as well have been “Cleughbrae! Dogslacks!”Cleughbrae, a mill about 1 mi. (1.5 km.) NW of Ecclefechan; see 19:183TC to AC, 31 Aug. 1845; Dogslacks, a farmstead about 1½ mi. (2.5 km.) NW of Ecclefechan. in the dead of night. In Paris I may try agn for some wretched snatch of sleep; next night, if all prosper, I shall find some real shelter at No 5.

I propose now, what has more than once been in my head, that you shd come and give me a month’s visit on this occasion,—if you felt yrself inclined equal to such an enterprise? It is not very many times that we can now hope to meet in this world;—I am often truly grieved to think how unreasonable and unmanageable I was with you last time; surely your sympathy was all I cd have expected, yr readiness to help me was, and continues, far beyond what I cd have expected!—but perhaps with a definite period, “one calendar month,” and each doing his wisest, we shall be able to do much better.TC wrote in his journal, 3 March: “abt March 15th I expect (thank Heaven) to be on the road to Chelsea; where at least I shall have freer element: ‘home’ there, alas alas, I cannot expect ever to have more. I think of asking Brr John to be in waiting for me there. God help us all, for the time we may have left” (TC’s journal; privately owned). John A. Carlyle wrote, 8 March: “I will cheerfully meet you in London. I feel sure that we shall do well together for the month you specify. Neither of us has any selfish narrowness or bad temper at bottom, though we may sometimes be rather thin-skinned.” If yr own feeling object, and you think otherwise, don’t try it, at such an expense of railwaying, resettling, c c. I intend to make an effort at regulating my Chelsea affairs a little, ordering my diet, my hours (dine at 3 or 4, for example?),—especially sweeping my premises, a little clearer of the intolerable intrusns that torment me there: I fancy too I shd not try agn the gaunt entirely solitary life I led latterly; but am not certn as to getting back Maggie Welsh, or as to whom I shd get. On these points I do not know that you cd give me much advice c; I only feel that it wd be a kind of light amid the gloom of my arrival, if on stepping out I found yr face there instead of dead blank. Do as you shall candidly judge wisest. Notice shall be given to Mrs Warren, at any rate; all receptionary things be ready. You cd ansr this Note, but it wd permit of hardly an hour’s delay; Poste Restante, Paris gives a better chance and I will make somebody ask there. But don’t bother, in any case; leave me to my luck, and wish me “good journey.”TC wrote in his journal, 3 March: “Fallen into a sad abeyance; caught a baddish cold c; incapable of anything whh even I can call ‘work,’ for two weeks past,—cannot even touch upon the poor babble abt Wordsworth (till today with effort);—am, in brief, below, not equal to, the paltry complexities of my situatn; and for most part miserable, dismal oftenest sad as the grave. Pure sadness of that kind, when it comes pure, is in fact my tolerablest mood; all bitterness and discontent then taken away!— Shakespeare has been my common reading; far the best for me I can fall upon here” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Kind love to one and all. Yrs ever

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: Caroline Fox (1819–71; ODNB; friend of the Carlyles since; see 12:147–48TC to MAC, 20 May 1840) was also staying in Menton at the time and visited TC, 5 March; she wrote in her journal: “Called by appointment on Carlyle at Lady Ashburton’s. He has a sort of pavilion separate yet attached to her villa, where he may feel independent. Found him alone reading Shakespeare, in a long dressing-gown, a drab comforter wrapped round and round his neck, and a dark-blue cap on, for he had a cold. … He looks thin, and aged, and sad as Jeremiah, though the red is still bright in his cheek and the blue in his eye. … / First he launched out, I think, on the horror of the journey, ‘I should never have come but for Tyndall, who dragged me off by the hair of my head, so to speak, and flung me down here, and went his way. He had better have left me alone with my misery’” (Caroline Fox, Memories of Old Friends [1882] 338–39).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 10 March. MS: NLS 526.59. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 128, where misdated.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Yr welcome Letter of March 5 arrived yesterday morning; and set me thinking while I was at breakfast in my fantastic “Pavillon” here, that you wd be agn in George Street,John A. Carlyle lodged at 73 George St. when in Edinburgh. also making yr solitary breakfast,—in circs fatally changed for one of us since we last sat there together! This morning a second Lr or Postscript to the former, brief and kind, informing me that yr purpose still held; and farther that you wd come and meet me cheerfully at any point of my route home. Thanks, thanks; but that will not be necessary, I hope. Since the last of these two Letters from you, I think you must have recd my latest; whh was to the effect that I purposed to be home, taliter qualiter [one way or the other], on resources extant here, abt the end of this week now begun; and that it wd be gratifying to me if I cd find you at Chelsea, on visit to me for a month. Yesterday, finding you were gone to Edinr, I meant to write but was prevented, and today do write, That you were not to lame or curtail yr Edinr visit on my acct; but to do all yr purposes there, and aftds come to me so soon as it shd be really agreeable to you. Probably you may be ready abt the “end of the week,” at any rate; but you are to let that be as it can. I find, on looking stedfastly into the face of my ugly Journey, that its ugliness is chiefly an affair of the imaginatn; that the realities of it, tho’ ugly enough too, can be fronted and subdued even by me in my weak state;—and that it wd be altogether foolish to bring anybody lumbering thro’ the like to help me to bear them. If you had the least errand of yr own to Paris, for example, it wd be cheering to me doubtless:—but there is no such thing conceivable! As to Vichy, too, don’t give yrself any trouble. Vichy is 40 or 50 miles strt west from
Lyon,John A. Carlyle wrote, 5 March: “I do not exactly know where Vichy is, or at what distance from the Marseilles route by Lyons; it is not marked in any of our maps. I am going out to have a long walk, being much in need of it, will add what else I have got to say when I get back. / Jean I have just returned from our walk. She cannot give you any advice, but clearly thinks it might be your best plan to start for home very soon. And I think what is said above as to this not being the season for Vichy waters will be found correct, for I used at one time to have full knowledge of such matters”; see also TC to JAC, 18 Feb. with railways c; but with me it was merely a transt thought. We have Vichy water in bottles here, whh I latterly sometimes drink: agreeably styptic (rather less so than Selzer)Seltzer water, effervescent mineral water from Niederselters in Germany; often used to apply to any carbonated water. aerated c, and of alkaline quality all; so that an acid, perpetually flatulent miserable stomach finds solace in it, and possibly might get profit by degrees: having heard such miracles from DuffyCharles Gavan Duffy (1816–1903; ODNB), Irish nationalist, lawyer, and politician; known to the Carlyles since, he emigrated from Ireland to Australia 1855, but made several long visits to London thereafter. on this head, and feeling well that my one malady is a hopelessly incompetent stomach indifft to “fine climate,”—also that the place wd be vacant cool and habitable till abt April 10 or 15, when the idle multitudes, quack doctors, and solar smotherTC probably meant the oppressive heat of the sun. The “quack doctors” of Vichy, presumably unlike those who wintered in Menton, like Lady Ashburton’s Dr. Frank; Murray’s Handbook (1867) listed “5 English medical men”: Dr. Henry Bennet, Pension Anglaise … author of a very interesting work on Mentone and the climate of Southern Europe generally.
