Dr. B. who is an eminent practitioner in London … his fee is that of a London practitioner, 25 fr.; he seldom goes out at night, only in extreme cases”; Dr. Frank and Dr. Montgomery were both at 1 Villa Massa, and there were also Dr. Siordet and Mr. Marriott, a “general practitioner,” as well as “several French and German medical men, the number of invalids from the latter country having considerably increased of late years”; the “leading native physician, Dr. Bottini, has written a very instructive essay on ‘Menton et son Climat’” (561). combine there,—the vague imaginatn of a March possibility, and useful half-way house, struck me in surveying this surprising March thro’ Liguria Gaul whh lies ahead! I never thot of bathing in the hot Vichys or the cold; solely of drinking,—in case the styptic alkalines might, for the first time in my medical experience in this world, be of some benefit to me. Enough, enough on all that!—

I am sorry I can still tell you almost nothing, or altogr nothing, of more precise sort than what was contained in my last Letter (not yet recd when you wrote); viz, that I vaguely understand I am to be off, escorted by the Brownlow Butler,Mr. Tweedie. abt Wedny next, i.e. 3d day hence; and that failing him and all extranea [additional matters] else, I do design to be myself at Chelsea, in some
form, before this day week. But “Dr Frank” has not yet appeared from Engld (perhaps he came last night, “perhaps” too he won’t for some days yet): and witht him no detail on that side can be gone into. If Butler go with me, I am to stop or proceed as I like, pay strictly my own expenses; sit or lie in a coupé of my own (if no passable-looking comrade turn up): these are my intended conditns, were “Frank” here;—these I can execute, if Frank never come: but I will wait yet a day or two for that obliging active person; after a day or two of waiting I will settle witht him. I think vaguely of stretching for Avignon the first night, thence probably to Paris at a stretch:—but in fact I cannot yet read the French Indicateur [guide] (Bradshaw outbradshawed thrice and 4 times!),The French Indicateur de Chemins de Fer [railway guide] and Bradshaw’s Monthly General Railway and Steam Navigation Guide; TC often found the latter hard to understand; see 42:14 TC to JC, 8 May 1865. nor (till a certn yg Baron von S√ºlzer reads it, and writes it off for me, this afternoon; an excellt intelligt young gentn, the only comple[te]ly human soul I have met with here!),See TC to JN, 10 Feb. TC wrote in his journal, 8 March: “One S√ºlzer came to walk with me yesterday; a young Swiss gentn,—decidedly the most ingenuous and intellt I have met in these parts. Rain overtook us; otherwise our walk (up the Gorbio Valley) wd have been pleasanter than walks (accompanied or solitary) usually are to me. Princess of Waldeck was to have driven with me today;—has already done so twice (her own volitn request);—but sends to excuse herself, the day being a deluge of rain. Very good,—all but the rain part! This Princess is a daughter of Nassau, of Princess-like manner, bearing, and appearance, a schöne Seile [seele: beautiful soul] in her sort; to whom it is impossible to be uncivil; tho’ her love of knowledge dreadfully outstrips her capability to profit by it,—and other company than mine might be a suitabler and far cheerfuller match to her. Ach Gott, what a depth, what an extent, has the Empire of Twaddle in this world. Another Princess, called of Hainau, sent gracious request, but only thro’ a fop of a Dr; whh, with reluctance, I was obliged to decline” (TC’s journal; privately owned). For the princess of Nassau, see TC to JN, 10 Feb.; the princess of Hainau (Rhineland, W. Germany), not further identified. can I give you the least particr. Tomorrow possibly, or within 3 days, if in any way possible, I will try to send you the name of my Paris Hôtel;—failing whh, understand at any rate that I will call at Poste restante there, as already promised.

Thus you see I do intend to be off abt Wedny, “in a coupé of my own”; and that, at present, is nearly all. In fact the crowdy of things has become doubly crowdied here; I cd not think of staying much longer. Lady An is off to Genoa, Florence c c; suddenly as a whirlwind after all! We were almost glad to see her go, strange as our circs were; such had her dubitatns botheratns been for weeks past.TC wrote in his journal, 8 March: “Lady Asn is gone for Rome c; fairly rolled off with Veturino, Courier rapid equipts on Tuesday last. The good, but too impulsive, exaggerative and uncalculating Lady. There are two invited guests [Ann and Sophia Ogle] here, besides myself: all this she has left to collapse, or adjust itself as it cd. We do well enough, all; our regularity much increased, and the day a little more my own than it used to be. … Wet, wet;—but here has my potage (tea-cup of innoct soup, not brown, at 2 p.m. daily) been waiting for about ½ an hour” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Caroline Fox noted about her visit, 5 March, that they were called to see Lady Ashburton before she left: “[TC] spoke of the beauty of this country, and specially of the view from the bridge, which he must have crossed seventy times, and the pleasure of the warmth and the sunshine with the clear blue sky above one, rather than the cold and wet and mud of London. Then he took us to Lady Ashburton, whose carriage was getting ready, and we took leave of him. … She encouraged our coming again to see Carlyle, thinking it quite a kindness to stir him up. She was glad he had spoken of anything with pleasure, ‘for,’ she added, ‘I’m very fond of the old man, and I did what I thought was for the best, and I really hope he is the better for it in spite of himself, though sometimes it seems as if it was altogether a failure” (Fox, Memories of Old Friends [1882] 340–41). Caroline Fox saw TC one more time in Menton. She is we suppose at Florence this morng, sitting
placid under the cascade of “Madme de Bunsen’s” mild ever-flowing river of “didactic twaddle”: √° la bonne heure [well and good], poor I being far enough off! Lady An had invited two new female guests (or 2½ strictly);Ann and Sophia Ogle; see TC to JAC, 13 March. The “½” was Mary Florence Baring. Caroline Fox noted: “She leaves ‘her one treasure,’ an only little girl, and Carlyle under the care of two good, kindly, wise-hearted ladies” (Fox, Memories of Old Friends [1882] 341). and left all that to collapse and settle as it cd. I myself suffer nothing from the arrangt, am left more to myself,TC noted in his journal, 8 March: “Finished the rag on Wordswth to the last tatter; won’t begin another; cui bono [what good is it], it is wearisome naught even to myself” (TC’s journal; privately owned). He ended the reminiscence: “Why should I continue these melancholy jottings in which I have no interest; in which the one Figure that could interest me is almost wanting! I will cease. (Finished, after many miserable interruptions, catarrhal and other, at Mentone, 8 March 1867)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 409). have my dinner more regularly;—feel too, at all times, the propriety of being off. My cough is mostly extinct or gone latent. March began here with 3 or 4 furious east-wind days (really bad, and our first bad weather); since that there has hasWord repeated on turn of page. been one day of Italn downpour (like to wash the world away); now there is a sky and earth lovelier than May’s,—probably the first of our intolerably hot weather. God bless you, dr Brother.Signature cut away.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 13 March. MS: NLS 1763.290. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
By yr three Letters whh came in successn from Dumfries, I infer that you got to Edinr last weekJohn A. Carlyle wrote from Edinburgh, 11 March: “The Miss Welshes I saw on Saturday evening had tea with them. Mr Erskine I have also seen at great length, am to dine alone with him tonight. He looks composed as well as usual, but has less strength for walking.” On 13 March, he reported: “I have seen the Miss Welshes today. They look more quiet cheerful. I gave them a copy of the Inscription at Haddington wh I got on the Monday before writing to you my first Poste Restante, Paris. I have seen much of Erskine dine alone with him this evening.” (whither accordingly I wrote 3 days ago); that
probably, the day after tomorrow, you will make for Chelsea, arrive there that night; and be found there, a rather wearied on Saturday morng, when this reaches you. So far all will be well on that side!—

My purpose stands to bend for home immediately, in fact to start by the Express from Nice tomorrow at 3.20 p.m.;—but for the rest, everything round me is fallen into inextricable jumble; chiefly by waiting for that “Dr Frank,” who did arrive in Town last night, but in spite of repeated messages has never shown face here yet, but keeps me waiting till the Post-hour is in danger of passing;—and who indeed I begin to suspect has nothing comfortable to tell me; his Butler Tweeding with luggage and serving-maid arrangts being probably obliged to go by trains and methods whh wd never suit me! Foolish fellow, I am perfectly ready for that form of the adventure, and can go perfectly on my own footing, since need is: him I merely wanted to ask a few questns abt Hôtels in Paris c, and to take honble leave of [indecipherable symbol].“Tweeding”: Mr. Tweedie; TC’s symbol may be to indicate Dr. Frank.— — Pooh, pooh, pooh! Here at this point is Frank in person, as large as life; and tells me that “Tweedie” is discharged of his maids burdens; and is ready and eager, he Tweedie solus [only], to take charge of me, and carry me triumphantly thro’, in what manner I like! One of the best “couriers” too, Frank tells me; and a thoroughly safe, obedt, punctual respectable man. Very well, very well; much better than the other way!

We drive off to Nice, then, in Lady An’s carriage, whh is at Command; T. and I are there, and start in the express, tomorrow thursday a[t] 3.20 p.m.— Stop that night at Avignon 12.47 (a.m., i.e. nr 1 a.m, hotel said to be good); see Avignon: leave, so far as I can make out abt 2 p.m (of Friday), are at Lyon abt 7 p.m.,—and in 12 hours more (if we choose to make no farther stops) are at Paris, 6.55 Saty morning; can go on in abt an hour (i.e. I can, tho Twe has to stay a day there), but will probably stop till night at least,— not arrive till Sunday by one of the two Boulogne trains. Frank tells me the Calais Railway is all jumbled to pieces at prest, by the frosts the heavy lumber of the Exhibitn Luggages;The International Exposition of 1867, organized by Napoleon III, held in Paris from 1 April to 3 November; more than 40 nations were represented. so that everybody ought to take Boulogne Folkstone for route. Wish us well on our journey:—this is all I can say; but perhaps (at least if there occur any delay) I shall try to scribble a line by the road.——
Tweedie, it seems, knows one of the stillest hôtels in Paris; but is not yet here to give me the name of it,Hôtel Meurice; see TC to LLA, 18 March. or I wd send it you. Wait patiently that is the best.
If you are not come to Chelsea, Mrs Warren is to open this. If you are, tell her what is needful. And Heaven send us all a safe meeting soon!—

James will probably be over on Sunday! I am overwhelmed in busss (all the more, as confusn here is grown worse confounded today!)— — The Lady An is joyously posting on betn Florence Rome; her little Girl is left here (under charge of 2 Miss Ogles,Ann Chaloner Ogle (b. 1832) and her sister Sophia (b. 1834) of Tormoham near Newton Abbot, Devon. Ann Ogle wrote to Lady Ashburton from Villa Madonna, 7 March: “Mr Carlyle talked the whole evening and seemed in good spirits. He says he sleeps well here and now that his arrangements are made is very comfortable and he is less tormented by his fellow creatures here than in London. All his quaint sayings are so new to me that I enjoy them very much” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). bless the mark!)Coterie speech; see Merchant of Venice 2.1 and Othello 1.1. and “sends a telegram every morning,” tho’ we don’t get any. Adieu dear Brr: a safe meetg to us soon.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 18 March. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
I know not in what part of the Earth you are wandering, probably at Rome on sunny heights, with “fine street architecture” and the other accompaniments, of fine weather and locality; but as for me, it is certn I arrived here, safe and thankful, abt six 30 hours ago,—viz. a little after midnight on Saturday 16th;—and am lying here perdu [concealed] ever since to rest myself a little, and doing better than cd have been expected. Under the excellt couriership of Tweedie, whh indeed was perfectn in that kind, I suffered a strict minimum of misery; and even had some noticeable bits of enjoymt by the road. We stopt at Avignon the first night, a kindly place, tho’ sleepless to me; and next day in the hot still sunshine, I wandered abt the antique malodorous City, and had my contentmts in surveying the Petrarcan LandscapeFrancesco Petrarch (1304–74), Italian scholar and poet; he spent several periods of his life in Avignon, and it was there that he saw Laura, about whom he wrote many of his most famous poems; for TC’s opinion of these, see 2:213 TC to JBW, [Early December 1822] . and old Pope PalacesThe Papal court was moved from Rome to Avignon in 1309 by the French Pope Clement V (ca. 1264–1314); in 1377 it was moved back to Rome by Pope Gregory XI (ca. 1329–78). (now quiet as barracks), and the much that has come and gone, whh still hooks itself there
to the idle memory [of]Omitted by TC. men. To Nice the younger Miss Ogle,Sophia Ogle. in yr carriage, with the ever assiduous Bailey,James Bailey, Lady Ashburton’s butler. under the swift whip of Antoine,Presumably Lady Ashburton’s French coachman; unidentified further. had conveyed me,—and delivered me into the hands of Tweedie. Adieu then to Mentone; “a heart-warm kind adieu,” right well merited by all and sundry,—not to say more specially, from one (now absent) who has included and been equivalent to all!— From Avignon we started abt 2 p.m.; did the “horrors of the middle passage”Expression used to describe the journey of slaves from Africa to America; see 25:180 TC to CR, 29 Aug. 1850
. on tolerable terms; and got to Paris, in the grim grey morng,—first comfort, an attempted washing, and cup of warm café-au-lait in the Hôtel Meurice,Hôtel Meurice, rue de Rivoli, Paris, founded, 1817, by Charles-Augustin Meurice (1739–1820) specifically to offer the English upper class the comforts of home. where the fat German waiter c were extremely patient humane with me:—and my enjoyt of the hour’s promenade on the old-known streets of Paris (for I went strolling to various old places I had seen 43 years agoTC visited Paris Oct. 1824; see 3:178–81 TC to JBW, 28 Oct. 1824
. with a silent thot that I was now seeing them for the final time) amid the novel populatns, and their brisk French features, and my memories of them for the last 100 years and prophecies of them for the next 100,—was fully equal (I do believe) to what the best oil canvas “gallery,” in Rome or elsewhere, cd have yielded me in double or treble the time! For this, yr Ladyship observes, was “painted” by Almighty God, who far excels Raphael or Titian in certn points of Art, if one consider His “paintings” well!— — At 1½ p.m. we were afloat agn, for Amiens, for Boulogne, for London,—completely successful (carriage to oneself c) all this part;—and in fine I was set down here, as above-said; people still waiting for me; and my Brother, who had arrived that afternoon, receiving me at the door, and doing what he cd to dissipate the stern gloom that now hangs over all my entrances here! I have got back my sleep; took a long walk yesterday (in the icy tempest of east wind, such a contrast to Mentone and its torrid ardours!)—I feel, so far, as if I had perhaps really gained some health;—and, if you were once safe back, shd be prepared to say thankfully, “all’s well that ends well.” Yr little Mary was in a state of perfectn, when I left (kissed me very handsomely, good little soul), and everybody seemed to be intent on his charge (especially the MamsellMary Florence’s governess, Mlle. PetitPierre; see TC to GEJ, 20 Nov. 1866
. Dr Frank): but of course the sooner you get safe home to take the helm in inWord repeated with a line over it at turn of page. yr own hand agn, it will evidtly be the better.

The weather here is cold as Spitzbergen;—never was such a contrast in the space of 60 hours:—but I really like it better, and find myself far abler for vigorous walking. Dizzy’s Bill (Household suffrage) is to be presented this night;Benjamin Disraeli introduced, 18 March, a Household Suffrage bill, proposing among other measures to extend the eligibility to vote in boroughs to all adult male householders. The bill was hotly debated and various changes implemented before it passed the House of Commons, 15 July. all Engld figures itself to me as on the edge of one of the ugliest adventures!— Adieu, dear Lady, adieu.

div3.sourceNote: TC-MBO, 20 March. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. Mary Boyle wrote about meeting TC in Menton: “It was on the death of his wife that Carlyle’s attached friend, Louisa, Lady Ashburton, knowing the state of grief into which he was plunged by the sudden blow, persuaded him to come out to Mentone to pass some weeks with her in a charming villa not far from the hotel, La Grand Bretagne, where I was staying with Lady Marian Alford, and her son, the late Lord Brownlow. During the early part of the winter there had been daily intercourse between the Villa and the Hotel, and Lady Ashburton, anxious to distract the mourner’s mind, and give a new turn to his thoughts, induced him with herself to become a constant associate in our walks and drives, and to dine and pass the evening very frequently at the Hotel, and while away the hours in delightful conversation with the mother and son to whom I have before alluded.” TC reminded Mary Boyle, “in one respect, and one alone,” of Walter Savage Landor, “and that was the violent invectives in which he not infrequently indulged against persons, places, and opinions. … Carlyle would launch forth into the most unwarrantable philippics, but then he would break off suddenly, and all the venom and bitterness be drowned in a burst of ringing laughter, and his handsome, though naturally grim, face would ripple all over with good-humoured smiles”; she thought TC’s words reported in print were misleading as they failed to show the laughter that accompanied them in spoken form (Mary Boyle, Her Book, ed. Sir Courtney Boyle [1901] 267, 268).
div3.head: TC TO MARY BOYLE

docBody.p:
Under guidance of the excellent Tweedie, I was safely landed here, shortly after midnight of Saturday last. Tweedie I can describe as worth ten Couriers to me; and the most industrious, assiduous, and perfect servant and protector any man cd have had, in that nightmare tumult of a journey (whh my fancy had likened to Jonah’s in the Whale’s Belly),TC noted in his journal, 23 March: “abt midnight of this day week (Saty 16) I was tumbled out (‘like Jonah from the Whale’s Belly’) at this door: and had done with my Mentone adventure, and once so formidable Journey. … I lie private ever since, none seeing me but Brr John. … My life, except for trivial despatch of bussses is utterly idle,—often grandly sad, now then sinking contrariwise to the sordid” (TC’s journal; privately owned).—the horrors of whh, vastly inferior in actuality, were in all points strictly reduced to the absolute minimum,
by Tweedie on my behalf. Pray let this, at some fit time, be known to his Master Mistress,Lady Marian Alford and her surviving son, the 3d Earl Brownlow. for the good man’s own sake; and also by way of intimating, whh I doubt not it will sufficiently do, what a beneficence and real and importt favour I find it to have been to me, on the part of that high Lady and her noble Son, in these the days of their own deepest affliction. Silence farther, but lasting remembrance, is enjoined me on that head.

Inclosed is the Jean-Paul AutographTC enclosed a letter signed by Jean Paul Richter to which he attached a note: “Recd by me from an admiring ‘Meta Wellmer,’ whom I have never seen, or otherwise heard of (14 Novr 1865):— / Sent now (by permission) To the Hon. Mary Boyle at Ashridge,—in sad memory of Mentone, and much that we witnessed there in the past weeks. / T. Carlyle / Chelsea, 20 March 1867” (MS: Strouse). For his receipt of the Jean Paul letter, see 43:64TC to MEW, 4 Dec. 1865. See also TC to MHU, 9 Nov. 1867. I spoke of; the History c of whh are sufficittly given, if you shd ever try to read it, in some bits of marginalia there appended. Pray don’t seek any better Earl of Orrery for me; the prest is only too good: indeed I know not where you cd possibly find a truer-looking Portrait of my distinguished old Friend,—whom I have already, in his present form, found a place for, in my little dressing-room, in compy with Oliver Cromwell, and others more or less related to Oliver him. That is now his place; don’t disturb him there!Roger Boyle (1621–79; ODNB ), Baron Broghill, who joined with Oliver Cromwell in the conquest of Ireland; ennobled as earl of Orrery by Charles II. TC wrote under his copy of the Lord Broghill engraving: “Oliver’s ‘Lord Broghil’ (Bro’il)”; see opp. It is still in Carlyle’s House, Chelsea.—

figure.p:
Roger Boyle, Baron Broghill
Courtesy of Carlyle’s House, National Trust

docBody.p: With many kind regards to yrself, and much silent sympathy for One at your side, whom I do not name,Unexplained.

div3.sourceNote: TC-FF [FJF], 24 March. MS: sold at auction; untraced. Frederick J. Foxton (ca. 1807–70; see TC to JCH, 6 June 1853 ), lapsed clergyman, writer, accompanied TC on his visit to Germany 1858; their last recorded meeting was in London Oct. 1863; see TC to JAC, 23 Oct. 1863 . TC thought of visiting him, July–Aug. 1865, but did not; see TC to JWC, 31 July 1865 , and TC to JWC, 25 Aug. 1865 .
div3.head: TC TO FREDERICK J. FOXTON

docBody.p: [Letter untraced]

div3.sourceNote: TC-[AW] [AWO], 28 March. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Thomas Woolner had apparently passed some of the organization of the enameling to his wife, Alice.
div3.head: TC TO ALICE WOOLNER

docBody.p: Yes, for certn, dear Mrs W.;—and yesterday I was sending, by Mr Tait, an impatt message on the subject!TC wrote a check, 28 March, to “S. E. Wootton,” the Wootton sisters, for £9 .. 12 .. 0, in payment for two enameled photographs of JWC and an enameled picture of Cromwell; he noted: “3 enamels (1 of them of Cromwell)—the two for myself (ah me!)” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Woolner delivered them, 15 April; TC wrote in his journal, 21 April, the anniversary of JWC’s death: “Monday afternoon Woolner, in my absence, left the poor bits of ‘Enamel Photographs’; yesterday [20 April] I put them up, as I best could: how wae, how wae to think who cd have put them up to perfectn, who, alas! ‘Oh Heavens, and is this all I have left me instead of Her, this bit of china with her shadow fixed on it?’—that thot also was abdundtly miserable to me” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Sotheby’s noted the selling of “Carlyle’s two favourite portraits of Mrs. Carlyle, from T.C.’s bedroom at 5. Cheyne Row” (Catalogue of Printed Books … Drawings and Engravings … c [June 1932] 42, item 223).—— In haste, with thanks,Presumably the check was delivered by Alice Woolner.

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: John A. Carlyle wrote to JWC’s old friend Eliza Aitken, b. Stodart (ca. 1794–1869; see 43:26543:biographical notes), 13 May, about copies of the two photographs that were used: “I am glad to hear that the photograph of Mrs Carlyle pleases you. The enamel done in Paris was from the same negative, it looks quite as well. Indeed I have hardly ever seen a better photographic likeness. The two I now enclose are done by an artist amateur in London—both on the same day some four years ago—one reading, the other looking out with something almost like a squint. Both are heads of the full figures” (MS: EUL). If John was accurate, the photographs would have been taken around 1863; they are not further identified but may have been photographs taken earlier by Robert Tait who was possibly the “artist amateur” of the two photographs of JWC that were enameled. For possible photographs, see TC to TWO, [24 Oct.], and 78.

div3.sourceNote: TC-TE, 1 April. Pbd: William Hanna, ed., Letters of Thomas Erskine of Linlathen (Edinburgh, 1877) 2:304–6; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:243–45. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:152–53.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS ERSKINE

docBody.p:
Dear Mr. Erskine,—Your mournful tidings, not unanticipated, were abundantly sad to us here;Erskine’s sister David Paterson d. 23 March; his other sister, Christian Stirling, d. 1 Dec. 1866; see TC to TE, 5 Dec. 1866. and have been painfully present ever since though till now I have written nothing. Alas! What can writing do in such a case? The inexorable stroke has fallen; the sore heart has to carry on its own unfathomable
dialogue with the Eternities and their gloomy Fact; all speech in it, from the friendliest sympathiser, is apt to be vain, or worse. Under your quiet words in that little note, there is legible to me a depth of violent grief and bereavement, which seems to enjoin silence rather. We knew the beautiful soul that has departed, the love that had united you and Her from the beginnings of existence,—and how desolate and sad the scene now is for him who is left solitary. Ah me! ah me!

Yesterday gone a twelvemonth (31 March 1867, Saturday by the day of the week) was the day I arrived at your door in Edinburgh, and was met by that friendliest of HostessesTC stayed with Thomas Erskine in Edinburgh, 31 March–7 April 1867, when he went to deliver his rectorial address; Erskine’s sister Christian Stirling acted as hostess during that visit; see 43:153–54TC to JAC, 30 March 1866. David Paterson had long been an invalid and was living at 8 Newbattle Terr., Morningside, Edinburgh, with her son, James Erskine Paterson, and his family: “Broken health, requiring change of climate, and family ties requiring separate residence, had hindered her from being so much with her brother as her elder sister” (Hanna, Letters of Thomas Erskine of Linlathen 2:301). and you; three days before, I had left at the door of this room one dearer and kinder than all the earth to me, whom I was not to behold again: what a change for you since then, what a change for me! Change after change following upon both of us,—upon you especially!

It is the saddest feature of old age, that the old man has to see himself daily grow more lonely; reduced to commune with the inarticulate Eternities, and the Loved Ones now unresponsive who have preceded him thither. Well, well; there is a blessedness in this too, if we take it well. There is a grandeur in it, if also an extent of sombre sadness, which is new to one; nor is hope quite wanting,—nor the clear conviction that those whom we would most screen from sore pain and misery are now safe and at rest. It lifts one to real kingship withal, real for the first time in this scene of things. Courage, my friend; let us endure patiently and act piously to the end.
Shakespeare sings pathetically somewhere:—

lg.l: “Fear no more the heat o’ the sun,
Thou thy worldly task hast done, Home art gone, and ta’en thy wages:”Cf. Cymbeline 4.2.

docBody.p: —inexpugnable and well art thou! These tones go tinkling through me sometimes, like the pious chime of far-off church bells.

Adieu, my friend. I must come to Scotland again at least once, if I live; and
while you are there it is not quite a solitary country to me.Erskine replied, 5 April: “Your recognition of me as one of the ties still drawing you to Scotland is very gratifying.”—

p.note: TC apparently wrote to Maggie Welsh around 2 April as she replied, 8 April: “Your letter received last Thursday [4 April] was indeed welcome, for though we had heard of your being really come home it was pleasant to hear from yourself that you are returned safe well not much the worse for the journey. I can fancy from what you say that the burning heat of the sun abt Mentone becomes quite too great for comfort after March; and those noisy little animals the frogs must have been growing somewhat of a nuisance; almost worse perhaps than the cocks, in that they could not by any means be caught ( cooked!).”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 6 April. MS: John Rylands Lib., Univ. of Manchester. Pbd: Sanders, “Carlyle’s Letters to Ruskin” 225; Cate 130–31.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: Yr Letter reached me, with warm welcome, at Mentone; but nothing of the interesting “gossip”Ruskin had written, 17 Feb.: “I hope to have some interesting little gossip to write to you about my cousin, next week.” Ruskin received a letter, 7 Feb., from Percy La Touche (1846–1921), formally asking permission to propose marriage to Ruskin’s cousin and ward, Joan Agnew (1846–1924). Percy was known to be rather a wild young man, but Ruskin was cautiously optimistic that the marriage might be good for him, and agreed to an informal engagement until Joan’s twenty-first birthday, 12 July. However his behavior was such that Joan broke off the engagement in Sept. c whh was promised for “next week”! What has become of that?Ruskin wrote a letter, dated 31 March and 4 April, addressing it to Menton, unaware that TC had returned home; the letter apparently reached TC in Chelsea, 12 April.

Above a fortnight ago, I got home (if this can now be called a “home”); and have been lying strictly perdu [concealed] ever since, in the hope of recovering myself a little;—have called literally on nobody, except on Froude taking leave for Spain,See TC to JAF, 10 Feb. and on ForsterMaggie Welsh wrote, 8 April: “I had a kind letter from Mrs Forster not long ago. You had called there when she was writing it. She Mr Forster seem to have been sadly ailing during the severe winter.” with whom I had pecuniary “busss”;Forster had responsibility for handling Carlyle’s financial arrangements with his publisher, Chapman Hall. He wrote to TC, 9 March: “Frederick Chapman sent me the acct of Edmonston of Edinburgh for the Address: by which it appears that 3000 copies were printed of which something like a half up to this time are sold. They tell me the arrangement was to give a royalty of £10 on every thousand—that seems small; but was it so? … Supposing the alleged sum to be correct, I say that 30£ will have to be now paid: whereas the Edinbro’ man claims that this is not due until all sold. Give me merely a line as to this. / From [Chapman] I have requested that your general account of sales to the end of 1867 should be handed in to me; and upon it I find that … £385 is now due. F.C. tells me that it is usual for him to give you a bill at 3 or 4 months. … Shall I obtain it from him and forward it to you—or … send it as a payment in his name to your bankers?” Edmonston Douglas, Edinburgh publishers of TC’s Inaugural Address; see 43:195TC to JAC, 16 April 1866 . nor
has anybody (so to speak) called on me. I am very quiet, of humour very sombre;—looking, in these days, upon an “April last,” whh must be forever memorable to me. My Brother John, who was here to receive me, still continues, for I suppose ten days yet; and is the only company I have.

If you durst lift anchor agn (Wedny night, 8 p.m. exact), you wd be a very welcome appearance here! John, who knows you, and has sense to estimate you, will not be in our way at all,—if he be even here on any terms, whh is not certn for that evg.
If you don’t write, I shall conclude you are coming.Ruskin noted in his diary: “April 10th. Wednesday. … At Carlyle’s this evening” (Ruskin’s Diaries 2:615).

postscript.p: My kindest regards to the dear Old Lady the do Young.Ruskin’s mother, Margaret, and his cousin Joan Agnew who lived with them.

div3.sourceNote: TC-RF [RFR], [11 April]. Pbd: Sadler 296–97 inc, where undated; Wilson, Carlyle 6:126 inc, where dated 11 April. Text from Wilson as he included the final sentence. Neuberg died during the night of 22 March. TC wrote in his journal, 3 April: “Yesterday gone a week (Tuesday 26 March, abt 5 p.m., John and I just sitting down to dinner), Painter Tait surprised us by a visit, to comunicate very sad tidings,—that poor Neuberg, whom I had not yet gone to see, and did not know to be in the least seriously ill, was suddenly no more! Had died abt midnight of the Friday before (22 March 1867), and was to be buried on the morrow. The news fell on me like a heavy dull weight, not like a pungently sharp stroke; and so hangs abt me ever since. We took what steps were possible (now so insignift!)—despatched a fit person to take plaster-cast of the dead face (his poor Sister having signified some wish of the kind); went, all three, to the Funeral next day (poor Sister passionately welcoming us), c c,—and, this day week, returned home, with the dreary feeling that our poor Neuberg lay in Highgate Cemetery, and that our eyes shd never behold him more.— For the last 20 or 25 years, he had been my most attached adherent, ever-loyal, ever patient, ardent, ever-willing to do me service in every kind:—we were twice in Germany together, where I defined him to be ‘worth 10 Couriers’; in regard to the Book Friedrich (especially till he took to translating it, and I had not the face to apply so often) his help was truly valuable (or invaluable; sat 3 months in the State-Paper Office, for example, excerpting there, with a skill and rapid felicity not to be rivalled); he did all kinds of excerpting and abstracting c c as if I myself had done it;—and, in brief, was an alter-ego in all the deeper parts of that horrible immensity of drudgery wh I believe wd have been impossible to me witht him. Got not shanow of reward, nor sought any; stood all my spurts of ill temper c, witht once wincing; worked like a patient hero for me, as if he had been nothing, I something, and as if it ennobled his poor existence so to do! Perhaps no man of my day had such a servant and subject (in the noblest sense of these words),—acquired to me witht the least effort too; rather permitted to give himself, than in any way asked for. All this is now lost (a very small care to me that); but all this comes back to my memory in a difft aspect now, and surely ought to continue there. Immense masses, containing huddled wrecks of his old work on Friedh c, were just being put away (under wrappage in Garret Press), the task just in the act of closing when this sad news came to me. I had written to him from Mentone; and a very pretty Letter of his followed me thence the day after I got home. Must be in my last bundle of Letters also upstairs (I suppose). His Letters were always pretty and attractive,—much beyond his talk, tho’ that too was replete with sense and informatn,—always the talk of an enlightened, honest superior kind of man, tho’ with clumsy manners; Neuberg’s age was only 61;—I judged that it had been at least 6 years nearer my own. He was a strong-built middle-sized man, capable of great fatigue, and full of rugged energy and healthy vitality; but I cd notice that within the last few years, he had more frequent fits of liver c; was occasionally deaf more or less; seemed to be breaking down: but it never once entered my thot that he cd precede me in the way we all have to go. He had not finished his Translatn of Frh; 1½ voll. of it, I shd think, still to do:—a task he infinitely liked, and took far too much pains abt; as I often seriously told him witht producing any impressn. He was rich, rather than otherwise, ‘good busss in the City’ (managed by a Nephew, whom he visited twice a week); his Sister Rosetta, and her two young children, will be perfectly at their ease in money matters, it appears. / Neuberg was a native of Hedingfeld nr Wurzburg, by birth a Jew, and indeed by aspect and character: a blond, thickset heavy kind of figure, features not acquiline but coarsely blunt with a tendency to plumpness, and on the face rather a defect of hair. Jew of the better type or almost of the best: a man of perfect integrity, of serious reflective temper, of fine strong faculties (able to understand anything presented to him), of many high aspiratns. I never questioned him abt his history; partly out of delicacy, tho’ I saw he wd have told me. … / Poor good Neuberg; far better to me than I ever owned him as being!— Alas, it is not yet a year (tho’ near it now) since he was trying (not very acceptably or successfully) to sympathize with me and my great Sorrow;—and now he is himself gone from this world. Adds himself to my many thots on the April days now passing, and on all that I had then parted with for the last time” (TC’s journal; privately owned). For the complete journal entry, see K. J. Fielding, “New Notes for The Letters … Carlyle’s Sketch of Joseph Neuberg,” Carlyle Annual 13 (New York, 1993) 4–6. See also 41:203, where TC’s remarks are quoted when he found, 1 May, an old letter of Neuberg’s from 5 April 1865.
div3.head: TC TO ROSETTA FRANKAU

docBody.p:
If the bust give you any satisfaction, surely I shall think it, all my days, well
worth while.TC had a bust of Neuberg made from the plaster cast, which he gave to Rosetta Frankau. He himself kept a photograph of Neuberg in his dressing room (Carlyle’s House 108). Wilson wrote that TC’s letter also contained an agreement to Rosetta Frankau’s suggestion that Friedrich Althaus be the man to complete the translation of Frederick that Neuberg had left unfinished (Wilson, Carlyle 6:126); it presumably came first in the letter. No kinder Friend had I in this world; no man of my day, I believe, had so faithful, loyal, and willing a Helper, as He generously was to me for the last 20 or more years. To look for his like again would be very vain indeed, were I even at the beginning of my course, instead of at the end! A man of fine faculty, too;—decidedly the most intelligent, swift, and skilful, at that
kind of work, whom I have ever seen or known of. The memory of him will remain dear and noble to me;—the sudden stroke that has cut away such a Friend, in these my otherwise desolate days, may well be sad and heavy to me. But if so to me, what then is it to you and your dear little ones?Rosetta Frankau was a widow with two young children; Neuberg had assumed responsibility for them after the death of her husband, Adolf Frankau (1820–56), Oct. 1856. Alas on this head I must say nothing. I will bid you be of courage, of pious courage, and in all things try and do as He would have ordered and wished, which I believe will daily be your best consolation in this sore trial. …

My brother and I mean to venture up to see you before many days.Wilson wrote that TC and John A. Carlyle called on Rosetta Frankau, 29 April. She gave TC the pipe that Neuberg had made for him for his travels, but had been unable to give him before he left because of fog; it was a meerschaum pipe with a jointed stem that could easily be packed or carried in a pocket.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 20 April. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Cate 26; Kaplan 496; Surtees, Ludovisi 129.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I ought to have written sooner; and wd have done so perhaps, had there been a definite address; but you were to “leave Mentone on the 11th,” whh was within 3 days, and after that there was nothing but “Nice” and “Switzerland” of specified locality.Lady Ashburton wrote from Menton, 6 [5] April: “We leave this on 11th go to Nice for a few days, then on to Switzerland.” Truly I might have known that anything sent to Mentone wd in all likelihood follow you;—and I am not witht blame, but beg yr forgivenness as a sinful man. A sinful, and a heavy-laden just now!

The truth is, my own life has been utterly inarticulate all this while; sunk in sorrowful reflexions and confusions, little prone to speak themselves, and indeed fitter for silence than for any utterance of them possible to me. These days are the anniversary of my Edinr ones last year.TC left London, 28 March 1867, traveling first to the home in Fryston of Lord Houghton (1809–85; ODNB ; see 43:272 43:biographical notes ), and then to Edinburgh for his inaugural address as rector of the univ., 2 April. By the day of the week, this saturday; by the day of the month, tomorrow (Easter Sunday), abt 3 p.m., there happened—I need not tell you what;JWC’s death, 21 April, the news of which TC received in Scotsbrig. nor how the memory of it must forever dwell with me; with me for all manner of reasons, best speakable to my own heart alone.— The death of poor NeubergLady Ashburton wrote, 17 April, also from Menton: “I cannot hear of the death of your old friend Neuberg without writing you a few words of affte sympathy.” came upon me like a dull
heavy weight; as a kind of corollary to that other, but with nothing of its poignancy; a dull broad blow following a stab into the heart; so remains with me. Did you hear of poor Erskine’s new loss? His other Sister, Mrs Paterson; his Note upon it to us was very sad, very brief and quiet, good old man. He says to me, “the utter separatn made by death is wonderful”;Erskine wrote, 5 April: “The complete separation which death makes, is indeed wonderful—we must walk by faith hope—or else lie down die.” Lady Ashburton replied, 26 April: “How much I feel for that dear old Mr Erskine!—but he will soon follow those he loved so well—his life now must be desolation—for the young people can in no wise supply their place in his heart—or life— how, my dear friend, I feel for you—knowing as I do the wound that is always bleeding. Time does not cure such wounds—only makes them deeper, I think—most thankfully shall I devote my life to being of any use to you I can— I am so grateful to you for allowing me to try— I often think I did not make half enough of you while I had you at Mentone.” and surely so it is, the palpablest and sorest miracle in this our miraculous existence!— — You comprehend that I have called on pretty nearly nobody; admitted few to see me; and feel, in general, least unhappy when left to silence, having as it were no interest whatever in the babbles and the nonsenses, “Reform Bills” c c, whh occupy all my neighbours, for the time being.

Froude is gone to Spain; Ruskin I have seen twice (who seems to have great things in posse [potentially], more ways than one); he is writing some pungent Political-Economy Letters “addressed to a working man” (whh come out in the Manchester Newsprs);Ruskin wrote 25 letters to Thomas Dixon, Sunderland cork cutter, Feb.—April, pbd. in various newspapers and later in book form, Time and Tide by Weare and Tyne. Twenty Five Letters to a Working Man of Sunderland on the Laws of Work (1867). The first two letters were pbd. in the Scotsman, 27 Feb. and 4 March; from 1 March–7 May they were pbd. in both the Leeds Mercury and the Manchester Daily Examiner and Times. In his preface to the book, Ruskin wrote, Dec. 1867: “The following letters were written to Mr. Thomas Dixon … during the agitation for reform in the spring of the present year. They contain, in the plainest terms I could use, the substance of what I then desired to say to our English workmen, which was briefly this:—‘The reform you desire may give you more influence in Parliament; but your influence there will of course be useless to you,—perhaps worse than useless,—until you have wisely made up your minds what you wish Parliament to do for you; and when you have made up your minds about that, you will find, not only that you can do it for yourselves, without the intervention of Parliament; but that eventually nobody but yourselves can do it’” (Ruskin, Time and Tide by Weare and Tyne [1867] vii). well worth reading, these, among the deluge of stuff that requires not to be read. I am everywhere told, “Dizzy will carry his Bill,”See TC to LLA, 18 March .—thank Heaven, we shall have done with it then! I have never inquired what it was: but have this one point of comfort that Dizzy carries it; that the wretched persons who sold their Country (and gradually got it launched on this insane course) for a mess of Official pottage, are not to have the pottage after all, but that a dextrous Jew snaps it up from under their noses!— Enough of all that.

I didn’t quite like yr taking a renewed Lease of Villa Madonna!Lady Ashburton wrote, 6 [5] April: “Dr. F. [Frank] has insisted on my taking this house again for next winter—as he says it is almost necessary for Mary.” My notion is, the sooner we cut the painter let Mentone drift, the better we shall get to port. Be steadily rational with bright little Mary, and there seems to be no fear of her health. Also, please don’t loiter over Vichy,Lady Ashburton wrote, 17 April: “We are still here—waiting till Vichy is opened, to go there.” but keep yr set time with England and us!— Our weather is showery, but blessedly beautiful withal. No more today today, except a little kiss to Marykin if she will have it.

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: TC wrote in his journal, [28 April?]: “The sympathetic Lady Lothian (with so many sorrows of her own) had remembered my Anniversary; and a very kind little Note lay waiting me from her on Monday morning: yesterday I had to call and thank. Enough here;—try now for some line or two of actual writing (if possible! While the minutes yet are” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Lady Lothian wrote, 21 April: “I am afraid that we ought not to bring ourselves before you at all, but Lothian I have been thinking a great deal about you to day, are longing to say how little our sympathy in your sorrow, has been cooled by the lapse of a whole year. I know that what we could say can be of no comfort, but we can hardly help wishing to say how fresh the memory of last year is in our minds, how we are praying that you may feel comfort peace even in yr loneliness. The thought that those we love are at rest is to me a very beautiful one.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-[MCA], [28 April]. MS: Ryals inc. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by John A. Carlyle’s departure the following day, 29 April.
div3.head: TC TO MARY C. AUSTIN

docBody.p: But I have managed to write the Enclosed;TC sent Mary a check: “22 April 1867 / To Sister Mary / £50 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). He wrote in his journal, [28 April?]: “To Mary my bit of a Gift; to the Bield do (intended to be annual)” (TC’s journal; privately owned). and beg you to accept the same, as a small token of my continued and ever-continuing affectn, the same whether I be silent or speak, so long as life lasts with me. The Dr goes tomorrow; and I wish [gap in MS]
No more, no more just now. Adieu, dear Sister, blessings be upon you all that are dear to you.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady Am [LAA], 3 May. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY AMBERLEY

docBody.p: I am very sorry to report myself unfit:—alas, I have not been out to dine anywhere for above a year past.

You shall be right welcome here any afternoon,—3 p.m. perhaps the surest time.Kate Amberley had visited TC, 27 March: “we found him in his dressing gown, smoking a long pipe and very miserable indeed, an old friend of his [Neuberg] having died just lately; he worked himself quite into a frenzy against Reform and the idea ‘of asking all those low drunken fellows to come and vote as if they knew anything but what cd. best fill their bellies’” (Amberley Papers 2:23).

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 8 May. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Yr Invitatn of me to that fine “Chalet” and the salutiferous neighbourhoods of Vichy,Lady Ashburton wrote from Chalet Clermont, Vichy, 26 April: “I am going to make a preposterous demand on you! no less than that you shd come out here— drink the waters— I have got this most charming house, till 31st May— I am most anxious you shd come give these wonderful waters a trial.” Her plan was then to travel to Fontainebleau and Versailles, “if the Hotels are good … then to Addiscombe—where, I hope, of course you will come.” reinforced by such domestic treatments as I have known,—is a signal proof to me not only of yr boundless hospitality and kindness of heart towards friends, but also of yr sanguine temper, always flying off into perfect hope on their behalf, and forgetful what a set of crabbed and imperfect creatures, whether as guests or otherwise, you do find them on trial! I shd have thot you had enough of me in that capacity, not very long ago!— Well, I am flattered, and thankful; but must not dream of such an adventure in practice. The railway itself wd lie like a Gorgon on the road; the heat itself, were I there, wd be enough to kill me. We have here already a blazing a roasting daily, under whh I know not what to do with myself: indeed it has made me quite ill; and I cd long to be back into the sweeping storms of March agn, as far preferable. Come home you, home to the verdant shades of Melchet or Addiscombe; that is the one recipe, that is what all yr friends now expect of you.

My Brother went away last monday; has spent his “week in Edinr,”—a good
deal in Erskine’s company,TC wrote in his journal, 3 or 4 May: “Brr John is away; went (for Edinr) Monday night last [29 April]; kind, pathetically almost tragically, kind letter (his 2d) waited me yesterday morng: poor good soul!—Memory of Neuberg, among others sadder, hangs much abt me: I mark here the date of his death,—‘Friday 22 March 1867 (nr midnight)’” (TC’s journal; privately owned). John A. Carlyle wrote, 2 May, from Edinburgh with news of Ann and Elizabeth Welsh (“Both of them look very much better stronger more cheerful”) and Thomas Erskine: “Poor Erskine was cheerful outwardly last night. We walked together and smoked a cigar. … He does not talk to me of Mrs Paterson, as he did of Mrs Stirling—perhaps because I did not know the former so intimately.” He enclosed a letter about John Rutter Chorley, who was very ill. of whom he reports well:—today I suppose him to be shooting thro’ the Mountains towards Dumfries and quiescence agn.

I myself have been nearly altogether silent since he went; not even physically speaking to almost any human creature. Yesterday I went to Tyndall for a few moments, on an errand not my own; my small errand I did; but found T. unexpectedly sad of heart,—he had suddenly lost his good old MotherSarah Tyndall, b. Macassey (d. 1867); she had been widowed for 20 years. Tyndall’s father was John Tyndall (1792–1847), shoemaker. (age above 90, and always dear venerable to him); I fancied what the journey to CarlowLeighlinbridge, Co. Carlow, Ireland, where Tyndall was born, and where presumably his mother had still lived. and back agn must have been to him on such a summons. But he is up to the neck in busss; that is a favble circe.

Up to this time I have still made no “calls”; my humour in genl is much too sombre, not to say ghastly and sepulchral often enough, to favr such an operatn. Alas, who are they that I shd long to “call on”; whom it wd delight me to speak with? They are not here, they are forever hidden from me, and have spoiled me for the sight of all others hitherto. But I need not continue this.

Our “trade” is said to be all tumbled flat, this good while past; our “railways threatened with bankruptcy,” nearly ever one of them visibly in spasm to weather that fatal cape; “house-building” stopped, many people thrown out of work, c c;TC possibly refers to the bankruptcy, May 1867, of the London, Chatham and Dover Railway Company, due to financial irregularities in its funding; this had led to the failure of other railway companies, the ensuing financial crisis provoking a steep rise in interest rates, which in turn caused numerous other banks and companies to fail. The Times reported, 16 April: “The January return issued by the Poor Law Board shows what a large amount of distress there has been in England in the past winter. … [I]n the metropolis, where misery as much as wealth centres, [the increase from the same period in 1867 was] no less than 72.6 per cent.” —in short, Mammon pulling the nose of his worshippers (as he is always wont now then), and great suffering and mutual accusatn in consequence. A good many people beginning to think it “ominous,” and that probably we are in a bad way! Courage, this is not the end, my long-eared friends;Asses; see 40:107 TC to TWO, 31 May 1864
.
tho’ that end will be here: Après nous le déluge [after us the flood]!Saying popularly attributed to Louis XV (1638–1715), king of France. Meanwhile we are passing our divine Reform Bill (Quack Dizzy doing it, and no other Quack, to my comfort); Yesterday Beales, in spite of Walpole agn, had his demonstratn in the Park;Edmond Beales, president of the Reform League, had planned a rally in Hyde Park in support of parliamentary reform, 14 April, but this was postponed until 6 May. The home secretary, Spencer Walpole, first banned the meeting but later yielded to the demands of the demonstrators; see also TC to LLA, 7 Sept. 1866.— we are certainly to be blessed with that fine measure before long: let us be thankful! London is as racketty, high-flying, loud and dusty as ever,—but I keep well out of its way. In fact, the withering dry heat of the weatherThe Meteorological Observatory, Aldershot Camp, Hampshire, recorded: “The maximum temperature of this day (May 6) is higher than has been recorded so early in May during the previous nine years at this station. … In Shade Deg. 82.6 [28.1 C]” (Times 8 May). wd itself condemn me to silence.TC wrote in the same vein in his journal, Sun., 26 May: “My days, since Brr John’s departure [29 April] (not on acct of that, but because that left me to collapse into the natural gloom vacuity of my now existence), have been very idle, very sorrowful,—peopled mainly with recollectns fond and futile of those who can never return to me. Never, never, never: how strange and new that is, when it actually comes upon us, proclaims itself a very fact!—I have been below average in health, too; hurt by the sudden 10 days of Ultra-July weather, followed by the almost 20 of Ultra-December, we have had in this singular May. Last night, with a great deal of rain, things came to a balance agn in that particr; might I hope there wd otherwise be some improvet! For certn, such a life as I now lead is painful, and even disgraceful; the life of a vanquished slave,—who at best (and that not always) is silent under his penalties and sores. There is no spirit in me to ‘write,’ tho’ I try it sometime; no topic, and no audience, that is in least dear or great to me. ‘Reform Bill’ going its fated Road,—i.e. Engld getting into the Niagara Rapids (far sooner than I expected); even this no longer much irritates me, much affects me; I say rather, ‘Well, why not? Is not Natl Death (with New-birth or witht) perhaps preferable to such utter Rottenness of Natl Life (so called) as there has long hopelessly been? Let it come when it likes, since there are Dizzies, Gladstones, Russells c c triumphtly prepared to bring it in!’—Providence is truly skilful to prepare its instrumental men. Indeed all England, heavily tho’ languidly averse to this, embarking on the Niagara rapids, called ‘Reform Bill,’ is strangely indifft to whatever may follow it, ‘Niagara’ or what you like. ‘We will at least have a villa on the Mediterrann (such an improvet of climate to this!) when Church and State have gone!’ said a certn shining Countess to me yesterday. Newspr Editors, in private (I am told), and discerning people of every rank (as is partly appart to myself) talk of approaching ‘Revoltn (Commonwealth, Commonilth or whatr it may be) with singular composure” (TC’s journal; privately owned). The “shining Countess” unidentified; possibly Lady Marion Alford, Viscountess Alford, rather than Kate, Lady Amberley, also a viscountess, who was a liberal and approved of the reform bill. Lady Amberley heard J. S. Mill’s speech in the House of Commons, 20 June, in favor of his amendment to clause 3 of the reform bill, for “person” to be inserted instead of “man” (Amberley Papers 2:36–37). Enough of all this, too!

Remember you are due, within season, in “the last days of May.”In her letter of 6 [5] April, Lady Ashburton wrote: “[I] hope to be at Addis, sans faute [without fail] the end of May or 1st week in June.” She did not return to Addiscombe until Oct. (Surtees, Ludovisi 132). Take care
of little Darling self;—and be punctual to keep that promise! That seems yr first duty at prest.——

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 11 May. MS: NLS 526.60. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I hope yr cold is gone; that is a quite superfluous compann in one’s rough journey,—and is apt to be obstinate in the hot weather, they say. Obstare principiis [face the enemy], is always good policy;—and I trust you will report yrself entirely rid of it, for one thing.

The other day I sent you a distracted little Book,Possibly William Washington Evans, A Pure Mind in a Pure Body, that is Health. A New System of Health and Medicine. The Antiseptic Treatment (1860), in which the author summarized the numerous medical benefits of charcoal. whh I had gallopped thro’, looking to right and left, not quite witht some assent here and there, and entertaint at the man’s genl folly: perhaps you did not look into it at all, and have sent it to the fire, whh indeed is its place. Nevertheless there was one thing it suggested to me, upon whh I will write you a word. My sleeping, my digestion c c have gone quite to chaos since you left; I suppose it is the violently hot weather that may have hurt me: but certn it is, nothing helps, pills I seem to regard no more than if they were peas; castor itself, whh I went upon yesterday, has only half done its functn: in short, the curse of indigestn has fallen upon me more heavily than usual; and I am groping abt for some relief or remedy

“Charcoal” I had heard of before, as recommended “by Dr Russell”Dr. James Russell at Thornhill, Dumfriesshire. (ah me!), and I have been in the habit of not rejectg a bit of burnt toast always, but oftener of eating it,—and the small result rather good. Now it struck me, in glancing at that mad Dr’s “Anti-septic treatment” and perpetual talk abt charcoal c: “Well surely with me ‘Septic’ is entirely the rule; my whole digestn is become a Sepsis, disgusting and miserable; and I really think a mouthful of charcoal, cd I get the right kind, and know the right method, might do me good!” This is the fact, and this is what I want you direct me in. I never in my life before had the least notion of a particr medicine; but I really have of this,—and I must try it, rather than welter along in this rotten quagmire witht alleviatn: so pray tell me what the right “course of charcoal” is for me; or if you don’t at once know, ask Dr Russell for me,John A. Carlyle replied, 12 May: “I do not know how the charcoal is used, cannot learn accurately from the little book you sent. But I will write to Dr Russell by this days post—for tomorrow morning’s early mail— request him to give the necessary instructions without delay.” Dr. Russell wrote to TC, 13 May: “I am sorry to understand that you are suffering as you have formerly suffered, from dyspepsia, and that you have a wish to try charcoal as a remedy. Recently prepared charcoal, in fine powder, is very simple and safe, and. … I have known it sometimes to give great relief. It may be found at any respectable chemists. It should be recently prepared and kept from the atmosphere in a well stoppered phial. … A drachm or teaspoonful (not larger at first) may be taken in water, say, twice a day, from one hour to three hours (as convenient) after breakfast after dinner.”—and I will proceed upon the
thing a little; aided by hope at least!— I did try one ride, not witht promise of benefit; but the mid-day season was so hot, I cd not ride agn witht changes in my dinner hour c c, whh are not yet settled: I mean to try that agn too.Dr. Russell continued: “Permit me to say farther, that where there is difficult digestion, it is most important that meals should be taken punctually at the same hour daily, and carefully masticated. … Only a rigorous stomach can digest a meal rapidly thrown into it.” But expedite the charcoal process, I pray you!——

Five minutes ago, I get yr Letter abt “Craigk repairs.” I don’t see much use in yr going up, nor even in James Aitken’s, tho’ of course it can do no harm.John A. Carlyle wrote, 17 May: “Yesterday I did drive up to Craigenputtock, spent two or three hours there. / James Aitken young James of Scotsbrig were with me.” He explained that their brother Jamie was unable to go with them. John A. Carlyle wrote a detailed description of the condition of the buildings and fences. I am quite willing to let Jamie go wholly his own road, within limits of the sum fixed;James Carlyle was to lease Craigenputtoch from June 1867; see TC to JAC, 2 Nov.1867. my only wish being that House, offices fences be put in “proper order,” and kept in do; and that at the next letting of Craigk, there be no abominable, intolerable (and, it seems, irremediable, and unpunishable) abyss of sluttish waste, like this of Common’s,John Common, tenant of Craigenputtoch; see TC to JAC, 2 Nov. 1866 ; he was to leave the farm 27 May. to fall on my innocent successors, as this (or most part of this) does on me innocent! In one word, I don’t design to torment myself any further upon what I cannot remedy:—and the briefest way will be, That Jamie, with acct-book in hand, be left to do (as you propose) what he gradually finds wisest and fairest in regard to “repairs”; and that, except on specific points (like this of the cottage “house,” for instance), I do not wish to be consulted much, and that if in any case (as in this of the cottage,—tho’ I do, from sympathy c, rather incline to the restoratn into househood!), I answer nothing, he is to take it as a sign that I wish him to follow his own judgt. He understands well enough how I am circumstanced, and what my feelings are; that I have the most perfect reliance on his integrity: and you can tell him that I don’t think there is accessible to me any wiser, friendlier or more just advice on those matters than his own is like to be. And so enough for the prest. Don’t you go, if it is the least unpleast; or at all, if yr cold still
lingers. Young Jamie may as well write to me (what writing is indespensable), on those points, for the future.

AdamsonSamuel Adamson. is silent, the indolent “Pluit”; nor will I urge him farther to write or to act on the Common’s achievts.— I have summoned MassonDavid Masson lived in Edinburgh, but was planning to visit London in June. Masson was advising TC in drawing up the bequest of the Craigenputtoch estate to Edinburgh Univ. to me, having discovered his address; and have drawn out a kind of Paper.See TC’s draft bequest, 12 May.— My love to Jean Household.

bibl.person: FIRST DRAFT OF THE BEQUEST OF CRAIGENPUTTOCH

div3.sourceNote: TC’s first draft of the bequest of Craigenputtoch [FDBC], 12 May. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. The revenue from the bequest was to provide student bursaries. TC sent it to John A. Carlyle, who was negotiating for him with David Masson, prof. at Edinburgh Univ., and John Cook, W.S. [writer to the signet], in drawing up the deed. John A. Carlyle replied, 19 May: “I have read the enclosed I think it is every way simple suitable, I hope the completion of the matter under Masson’s Cook’s guidance will not cost you much more labour.” Masson then wrote to John A. Carlyle, 23 May: “[Y]our note and the Paper have come. I will step round to Mr Cook’s this afternoon. … All seems ready now for the preparation of the Draft. I shall tell Mr Cook to embody Mr Carlyle’s Paper in it, continuously and verbatim; which he said might easily be done. The Draft as a whole may bring out little points of detail not yet thought of, but nothing, I should fancy, that will cause trouble” (MS: NLS 1768.247). John Cook, W.S., 61 N Castle St. (his chambers), Edinburgh; see also TC’s final bequest, 20 June. The spelling Craigenputtock was now invariably used by TC as well as his family, instead of the previously preferred Craigenputtoch.
div3.head: TC TO FIRST DRAFT OF THE BEQUEST OF CRAIGENPUTTOCH

dateline.hi: Proposed Bequest of Land Estate to the University of Edinr (main particulars noted).

docBody.p: Name of the Estate in Craigenputtock,—or for distinctn, Upper Craigenputtock (a wing of it having been sold some 70 or 80 years ago, whh is now called Under Craigenpk),—it lies at the head of the Parish of Dunscore, in Nithsdale, Dumfriesshire. Extent is of abt 800 acres; improved moor pasture, do arable ground; do meadow pastures, with rather copious plantatns, solid enough mansion and offices: rent at prest (on lease of 19 years) is £250;—annual worth with improvets now in progress, is probably £300. Title-deeds c are in the hands of “Saml Adamson Esq, writer, Dumfries”; official record of the Will c by whh the property became mine, is in the County Registry there. Note one other thing as preliminary.

Craigenputtock was, for many generatns, the Patrimony of a Family named Welsh, head of it usually a John Welsh,—in series going back, think some, to
the famous “John Welsh,” son-in-law of the Reformer Knox:JWC wrongly believed that she was descended from John Knox; see 32:13 JWC to RMM, [17 Oct. 1856] . His son-in-law was John Welsh or Welch (1568–1622), Presbyterian minister; JWC’s ancestor was his elder brother, David Welsh of Colliston; see 3:420TC to JBW, 28 Nov. 1825. Despite TC’s cautious disclaimer of “think some” about JWC’s ancestry, Alexander Donaldson, the Welsh family lawyer in Haddington, imputed the belief to TC, not JWC, 18 June 1833: “it will be the titles of Nether Craigenputtoch which carry back your forefathers to the great reformer. I do not think I had this tradition from you, but from Mr. Carlyle” (2:305).—the last such Heir of this Family was John Welsh Esq, Surgeon, Haddington (died in 1819, a highly honoured, widely regretted man; is buried in the Abbey-Kirk of that Town); whose one Child, and Heiress, was my late dear, magnanimous, much loving, and to me inestimable Wife,—in memory of whom, and of her constant nobleness and piety towards him and towards me, I now, she having been the last of her kindred, intend to bequest to Edinr University, the most piously I can, this Craigenpk whh was theirs hers. On the terms following:

Land not to be sold, but to be kept and administered as land. Net annual revenue of it to be divided into ten equal Bursaries; whh are to be called the “John-Welsh Bursaries”: under charge of the Senatus Academicus to bestow them on the Ten applicants entering the University, who, in strict and thorough examinatn, and open competitive trial, by Examiners whom the Senatus will appoint for that end, are judged to show the best attaint of actual proficiency, and the best likelihoods of man, in the departt or Faculty called of Arts, as taught there. Examiners to be actual Professors in said Faculty, the fittest that can be chosen. n.l.TC’s insertion, for “new line.”

More specially I appoint that Five 5 of the John-[Welsh Bursaries]Some words in the draft are obscured by crossings out and extra pieces of paper stuck on; Masson wrote to John A. Carlyle, 1 June: “Mr Cook would like to have back Mr Carlyle’s original paper, after Mr Carlyle has compared the Draft with it adjusted both finally to his mind. He would like, he said, to keep it as the autograph Paper of Instructions on which the Deed was framed, and would prefer it exactly in the original form, with the interlineations attached bits of paper” (MS: NLS 1775C.135). For the final version (pbd. inc.), see TC’s final bequest of Craigenputtoch, 20 June. be given for best proficiency in Mathematics (I wd rather say “in Math[esis,”Mathesis: mental discipline, mathematical science. if that were a thing] to be judged of from competitn),—but practically, above all, in Pure Geometry;—such being perennially the symptom, not only of steady applicatn, but of a clear methodicl intellect; and offering, in all epochs, good promise for all manner of Arts pursuits.— The other 5 Bursaries I appoint to depend (for the prest and indefinitely onwards) on proficiency in Classical Learning, in Latin and Greek, either or both,—I dare not yet add, “in English and its Classicalities”;Masson, prof. of rhetoric and English literature, wrote to John A. Carlyle, 23 May: “Mr Carlyle does not see his way to the introduction of English, though he hints at it as a future. I still hope he may come to the view of some practical insertion of English and do it by a word in the Draft” (MS: NLS 1768.247). John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 24 May: “I wrote at some length to Masson when I sent on the Instructions to him, having read them his own long letter on the subject very carefully indeed. I agreed with him as to the expediency of adding English to Latin Greek for the five Bursaries; now after fuller consideration I agree with him still more decidedly. The addition of English, it seems to me, is of itself most important, would make the testing in Latin Greek clearer more effectual. And in Scotland it would do much to hinder any imitation of the Oxford Cambridge plan, by which students may be crammed with Latin Greek remain very imperfectly acquainted with their mother tongue.” tho’ perhaps the future times gradually will whh also
gives good promise of a young mind;—but as I do not feel certain that it gives perennially, or will perennially be thot in Universities to give, the best promise, I am willing that the Senatus of the University, in case of a change of its opinn on this point hereafter in the course of generatns, shall bestow these latter 5 Bursaries on what it does then consider the most excellt kind of Proficiency in matters Classical, or the proof of a Classical mind, and directs its own highest effort towards teaching diffusing, in the new generatns that will come. In brief: Five Bursaries for Proficiency in Mathematics, especially in Pure Geometry; and Five for do in Classics Latin Greek: this,—as far as we can practically see ahead at prest, yet with liberty to modify the latter Five, shd New and better light arise, and the Senatus come to be convinced that such light is better,—expresses my intention and desire in regard to occupants of the John-Welsh Bursaries. n.l. white lineTC’s insertion, presumably meaning “new line” and, perhaps, “line space.”

Bursaries to be open to free competition of all who come to study in Edinr University, and who have never been of any other; competitn to be held on, or directly before (after?), their first matriculatn there. Bursaries to be always given, on solemnly strict and faithful trial, to the worthiest;—or, if—what in practice can never happen, tho’ it illustrates my intentn,—the claims of Two were absolutely equal, and cd not be settled by further new trial, preference is to fall in favr of the more unfriended and unrecomended.TC wrote “1” over unrecomended and “2” over “unfriended,” to indicate order of importance. Under “penalties” graver than I, or any highest mortal, can pretend to impose, but whh, I never doubt, will punctually be exacted if incurred, this is to be the perpetual rule for the Senatus in deciding!—n.l.

Bursaries are to continue [word obscure] actual Students in the Faculty of Arts, and to be visibly attending one or more Classes in the same, so long as their Bursary lasts. Are not permitted to hold, or compete forTC enclosed the phrase “or compete for” in a rectangle, presumably to stress its importance. any other Bursary, or similar Endowmt in the Universy: are permitted to compete for
givesany Scholarship or Fellowship, falling upon them; but forfeit their Bursary if successful. Bursaries, to last till the usual term graduatn as M. A., (that is, for 4 years, as things now stand),—misbehavr of the Holder, if sooner; New appointnt to be made at a Session.

And so may a little trace of help, to the young heroic soul [words obscured] highest, spring from this poor Arrangt and Bequest; may it run, forever if [words obscured] as a thread of pure water from the Scottish rocks, tinkling into its little basin by the thirsty wayside, for those whom it veritably belongs to. Amen.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC Jr. [JAJR], 18 May. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE JR.

docBody.p: I did not hear what yr Father did the other day at Craigenputtock (if indeed he went up at all, whh I rather doubt);—nor was there the least hurry in regard to hearing what he settled upon there, all likelihood being that I shd and shall assent upon every point. But there is another thing there, upon whh (Whitsunday being so nigh)Whitsunday, one of the Scottish quarter days, fell on 9 June this year. I will now apply to you, having no method otherwise,—I mean Mr Common’s behaviour in regard to dilapidatns, what damages are to be exacted from him; and my getting to the bottom of that matter, and clearing my conscience upon it, whh I have never yet quite done.

Four or five weeks ago, I wrote to Mr Adamson,John A. Carlyle wrote at length from Chelsea to James Carlyle Jr., 9 April, mentioning TC’s letter to Adamson of 8 April: “Your uncle wrote to Adamson yesterday about the damage Common has done to the houses, fences especially of the plantations; is determined to try if possible make him pay for it all. This became necessary in my opinion too, after Common told the ‘sixty men who gave him a dinner’ how ill-used he had been in not getting timely warning to quit the farm. / Now your uncle today bids me request you to give the best estimate you can of the amount of damage Common could justly be charged with—or in other words how much of the £400 for repairs one would have a right to demand for the injury he has done to houses fences. / … I have found it useless to tell your uncle how unlikely it is that he will be able to get any considerable compensation. He is determined to try it, I can only let him do so himself. … The weakest part of the case seems to be that the woods were never looked after during the lease” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). expressing with all emphasis what my feelings upon it were; and instructing him to take practically every strenuous and reasonable step towards getting such an intolerable injustice and absurdity abated, and reduced to its strict minimum. By negociatn, by arbitration,—failing them, by deed of Court, or of successive Courts;—in
fine, by any and every just and legal method; the thing, as I looked at it, being (not on the money score, but on deeper and better grounds than money) an intolerable abominatn to me. Mr Adamson ansd. He wd write to me upon it in a day or two; but has never since written.Adamson wrote, 9 April: “I purpose writing you fully in reply to the position respecting the Farm and explaining matters in the course of a few days so soon as I have got the Leases c. examined.” James Claremont from the British Linen Company Bank, Dumfries, wrote to TC, 18 April, that Adamson had been called “hurriedly to the country today but before leaving desired me to write you that the other business alluded to in your letter will be attended to as soon as possible.” John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 19 April: “I hope A[damson] will just repeat what he said to me on the subject when I talked to him before leaving Dumfries—in substance quite the same as what you say—only one can hardly hardly expect him to state as plainly briefly as you do, that the affair is not one of right but of law.” And there it rests ever since.

As I have found you a hardy, punctual and practical person, I now request you to take it in hand for me, and to do yr best in it on my behoof witht delay. You will have to go up to Dumfries directly, I suppose; and have an interview with Mr A., who will shew you my Letter to him, explanatory of all my knowledge or feeling on the subject: and then, upon consultatn with him, and best reflexion with yrself, ascertain what it is proper to do,—or to do farther, if anything has already been done. I want to write no more upon so vile and disagreeable a matter: but you will greatly oblige me if you do or can put this extremely ugly puddle into a clean state for me,—or, if not into a clean, then into the very cleanest that is possible in the case.

If it do turn out that I am not only to suffer Common’s having put his cattle into my woods witht permission (nay with the contrary), but also to rebuild the fences he has torn down in so doing,—there is one thing I will at least look to (and I must ask you as “Wood-forester” what the method of it is): To prevent an infatuatn of the like kind ever occurring agn under any Tenant!John A. Carlyle wrote, 17 May, after visiting Craigenputtoch: “We went saw the fences too in their worst parts. Those for plantations only in a ruinous state of disrepair, caused chiefly by long neglect, falling of trees on them, roots of trees raising them c. but in no case by apparent pulling down. Those for farm purposes all in tolerable repair what is called ‘tenantable order.’ In my opinion in Jamie’s James Aitken’s, Common would not be liable for any damages on account of them in the usual mode of settling such matters.” James Carlyle Jr. then wrote to Samuel Adamson, 4 June, enclosing a report from two local tenant farmers, John Fraser of Glaisters and David Stobo of Crogomains, who had looked into the state of Craigenputtoch at his request: “the Fences should be accepted as in tenantable order because any repair the out-going tenant could be compelled to put upon them would be of very trifling advantage to the Proprietor. … It is our opinion that the Mansion House and Offices may be considered as in ‘tenantable order and condition’ at the end of the Lease; but the Cottage we consider far otherwise and to have been greatly misused, and now quite unfit to be inhabited. Of the probable cost of restoring the Cottage to a habitable condition we cannot form an estimate” (MS: Ian Campbell).

In short I want you to help me out of this, dear James, with all the insight
and prudent energy you have;—and not to write to me abt it any more than is indispensable.—— I hope JohnJames Jr.’s brother, John Carlyle; John A. Carlyle wrote, 15 May: “John [is] rather unwell unfit for work of any kind.” is got better than by last accts.

closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: John A. Carlyle wrote, 24 May: “The two Jamies were at Craigenputtock roup yesterday, you will be glad to hear that they helped the sale for Common very essentially, also bought 5½ score of Ewes with lambs—best of the 160 that were to sell—besides various other things, all at a price which they thought very reasonable.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 22 May. MS: Harry Ransom Center, Univ. of Texas. Pbd: London Express, 29 May 1867; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:249–50; Ruskin’s Works 17:481; Wilson, Carlyle 6:128; Cate 27. The letter is to “a working man in Rochdale” (Shepherd, Carlyle 2:249); unidentified further. Cate identified correspondent as Thomas Dixon, but TC already corresponded with Dixon who lived in Sunderland, County Durham, NE England, whereas Rochdale is in Lancashire, on the outskirts of Manchester, NW England.
div3.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT
