docBody.p: Sir—the thing now “going the rounds”In Ruskin’s 25th letter to Thomas Dixon (see TC to LLA, 20 April), dated 27 April (pbd: Leeds Mercury, 4 May, and Manchester Daily Examiner and Times, 7 May), Ruskin reported a conversation he had with TC, 25 April: “[H]e was speaking of the differences in good and evil—between the coast of the Mediterranean in winter and the Thames shore in spring. And the one great difference which he felt bitterly was not in cloud or cold, but in the different temper of the people about him. For the peasantry at Mentone (where he lived all this last winter) were gentle and modest and kind; and he could walk alone, far among the hills, and meet with nothing but quiet human courtesy, and rendering of such simple respect as to an old man is both due and comforting. But in the streets of Chelsea, and of the whole district of London round it … he now cannot walk without being insulted, chiefly because he is a grey, old man; and also because he is cleanly dressed. … [T]his temper of the London populace has been, he said, steadily on the increase for the last twenty years, and so that now the streets have become nearly impassable to him, riding or walking, and he must either get through the quietest he can find to the Park, or be fain to walk his rounds under the night, when it cannot be manifest to the public provocation either that he is old or has a whole coat on” (Ruskin’s Works 17:480–81). TC’s alleged comments were reported and discussed in a number of papers in the following days, including the Pall Mall Gazette (8 and 11 May), the Daily News (9 May), the Manchester Daily Examiner and Times (18 May), and the Glasgow Herald (20 May). is untrue; diverges from the fact throughout; and in essentials is curious by the reverse of the fact; an “incredible” (and at once forgettable) “thing” That is the solution of your difficulty.
Chelsea 22nd May 1867 T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-[C]SR [CSR], 23 May. MS: Trinity. Probably Charles William Thomas Spring Rice (1819–70), politician, son of TC’s old friend Thomas Spring Rice (1790–66; ODNB), 1st Baron Monteagle of Brandon, and younger brother of Stephen Spring Rice (1814–65).
div3.head: TC TO [CHARLES] SPRING RICE

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, [23 May]. MS: EUL inc. Pbd: David Southern, “Letters from John A. Carlyle to Charles Butler,” CSA 25 (2009) 203–4. Text is taken from John’s quotation of TC’s letter to himself, 23 May, in his letter to Butler, 25 May.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Now it strikes me at this moment that in case of my decease, Heirs may have to go into the American Chancery c undergo a great deal of bother delay,—somewhat as the present Dowr Lady A has had.John A. Carlyle prefaced the quotation from TC with some explanation: “I staid some two months with him at Cheyne Row, have heard from him regularly since I returned here. He has been sorting all his papers putting his affairs in order. … / Yesterday I had a letter from him, in which he requests me to write to you with his kind regards, ask your advice with regard to the money-investments he has in America. Lady Ashburton, he tells me, has large Estates left her by her late husband, from which she has for the last three years got no income at all, has had to send her case to your Chancery which seems to delay somewhat like our own in England” (MS: EUL). Or perhaps this does not apply to inheritors of Shares, but the mere share-document (if I have such?) is valid for any Holder? I really wish you would write to Butler upon this last question,—which seems to me of immediate interest (if lying as Lady A. found it, or in the least involving difficulties to Heirs)! Say I requested you, with my kind regards to him. … My American things too are considerably unpleasant,John A. Carlyle noted: “In another part of the same letter, after speaking of some English R. W. Shares he holds which have fallen much in value, wh I had advised him to sell at once” and then quoted TC’s words (MS: EUL). but I keep hoping there will come a fitter or cheaper time for bringing them over hither,—as I should truly like them to be.John A. Carlyle added information about TC’s book profits: “I may also mention that my brothers books continue to sell better better every year. For the year that ended last March he received nearly £1000 from his publisher. And now I need not say more on the subject, as you have all the materials for forming an opinion.” He enclosed a photograph: “by far the best of Mrs Carlyle. My brother has had it enamelled at Paris, from the negative, most successfully—by some newly invented process,— has got it framed” (MS: EUL). If you please, write to Butler consult him?John Forster wrote from Plymouth, 26 May: “Adieu, dear Carlyle, I am sick of the Reform Bill, and the Compound Household, and the right of women to vote, and the right of Irishmen or Yankees to commit treason without peril to their necks, and the right of Beales to this Park, and all other corresponding Rights of Man—but I am always far more than I can say / Yours / John Forster / My companion through all my journey has been Sartor.”

bibl.person: THE EDITOR OF PALL MALL GAZETTE

div3.sourceNote: TC-Editor of Pall Mall Gazette [EDPMG], 28 May. MS: Hilles. Pbd: Pall Mall Gazette, 29 May; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:250; Ruskin’s Works 17:481; Cate 27. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:129; Kaplan 497. The Pall Mall Gazette was owned by George Smith (1824–1901; ODNB) and edited by Frederick Greenwood (1830–1909; ODNB).
div3.head: TC TO THE EDITOR OF PALL MALL GAZETTE

p.hi: To the Editor of the Pall Mall Gazette

docBody.p: Sir,—In reference to a Newspaper ParagraphSee TC to UC, 22 May. now idly circulating, with my name in it as connected with “insults on the streets” and other such matter,—permit me to say that it is an untrue Paragraph; disagrees with the fact throughout, and in essentials is curiously the reverse of the fact; a Paragraph altogether erroneous, misfounded, superfluous, and even absurd.Ruskin wrote in his diary, 29 May: “At Carlyle’s. Foolish letter of C’s in papers” (Ruskin’s Diaries 2:619). He wrote to TC, 30 May: “I deeply regret … that you have been induced to write this letter. / It seems to me that the only thing which now in justice remains for you to do, is to furnish me with a succinct statement of what you remember yourself to have said on the occasion in question.” TC may then have sent Ruskin, [late May], a suggested reply by Ruskin to the Pall Mall Gazette: “Sir,—You say ‘The Paragrh of which Mr. Carlyle complains originally appeared in ‘a letter of Mr. Ruskin’s, published in the Manchester Examiner.’ The ansr to whh is. No, not it precisely, not the ‘absurd Paragh,’ variously cooked and pushed abt in all manner of Newsprs, did ever appear in Manchr Examiner, or from me; but a mistake of mine whh certainly occasioned it, did,—and shall be explained, set right, and I hope turned to its real use in the world, so soon as I have time to republish those Manchr-Examr Letters. Till then, absolute silence upon it, from me especially. (loquitur [speaks] Jn Ruskin)” (MS: Luis Gordon Sons, Ltd.). Ruskin’s letter of 1 June may be a reply: “I am under the sorrowful necessity of ignoring your present letter. You have given the lie publicly, and in the most insulting terms possible to you, to the man who probably of all men living, most honoured you. It is … because he so honours you … that he is compelled to require you to do right in this matter; and the right manifestly is that you either justify the terms of that letter in the Pallmall Gazette, or retract them, and that publicly; and with all convenient speed.” TC later wrote on the envelope: “The Ruskin Newspr rubbish (june 1867)—judiciously trampled out!” I remain, Sir, Your obedt Servt

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 1 June. MS: NLS 526.61. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I had better have written yesterday as I meant; but I had to go out riding; and there was, as there is, literally nothing to say. The riding did me little good; blazing sunshine everywhere (the first day of it for a fortnight,—not 2 yards together of shade discernable anywhere in the Park;Hyde Park.—so that I had to go into ambiguous streets and detours, to make my poor horse go at a walk instead of a good shaking gallop (that I might not kill him in the heat); and in made a profitless enterprise of it. If the day were agn hot (whh it now doubly is) I forbade him “for next day.” Last night was very bad with me (such the reward of “virtue”); and if it were not to prevent yr entire disappointt, perhaps I had better not have written,—in this mood of body and mind. “Hot weather,” I suppose, must have something to do with it agn. I am abt resolving on a radical change of hours (such as once was the good rule here in summer); dine at 3½; go riding rather before 5,—for if this poorest of all extant stomachs don’t mend— Well surely I ought to try at least. But that cannot be till Tuesday next; owing to a pitiful engaget I have: “Lady Stanley to escort to the Portrait Exhibitn”The second of three exhibitions of national portraits being held at the South Kensington Museum, 2 May to 31 Aug. 1867. The portraits in this exhibition covered the period from 1688 to 1800; for the first exhibition, see TC to JAF, 2 Aug. 1866. (a paltry enough Exhibitn, I conjecture!)—

There has not the least vestige of Letter worth reading arrived here (and fewer not worth than usual, thank Heaven): Forster’s, I think, was here when I wrote last; but it contains some Chapman shadowForster wrote from Plymouth, 26 May: “Just before I left (the day after seeing you) I had a word with Frederick Chapman about a projected ‘Library’ Edition of the Works. I told him that if he named it to you, I had no doubt you would refer it to me—and that I should think well of the proposal, if it would make it the opportunity of getting rid of the over-printed huge volumes of Frederick, and begin this experiment with a proper Library Edition of that book. I mention this now that you may think of it, talk it over with me on my return.” (of whh I know nothing), and I suppose he will be here tomorrow to speak of it. Ruskin is in great agony abt that beggarly Pall-Mall “Paragraph” Affair; but I have at least ended it, and the dirty rumour of impertinent nothingnesses abt it;—and he feels, or will feel, that the headlong folly he fell into was ‘absurd.’ Finis to that dirty bubble!—

Masson is not come, and kindly keeps silence. My last Paper to you him was hardly gone when I bethot me that the notion of “Official persons” attending to such a matter was totally futile; but I hoped ( believe) you wd
silently suppress that, retaining the other kind of “Assessors” in small number. if all the Bursaries were to be given at once, it wd be something for a Public like Edinr: but I compute there can only (after a certn length of time) be abt 2 of these each year! I am glad to have complete silence on it, till the Draught of Deed appear.Masson wrote to John A. Carlyle, 23 May: “It may be yet a few days before I go to London”; he wrote two more very long letters to John A. Carlyle, 31 May and 1 June, detailing his views on the proposed management of the bursaries. John A. Carlyle forwarded them to TC, writing, 3 June: “I got this [Masson’s] second letter very early in the morning, have read it carefully more than once, spent the whole day in considering it, as I had done on Saturday yesterday with the first. And the two have convinced me: / 1. That the Examiners should be the Professors themselves of the Faculty of Arts, the Senatus naming one or two Professors from the other Faculties as Assessors to the Faculty of Arts. / 2. That the awarding of the Bursaries be left solely to the Senatus. … / 3. That Latin, Greek, English be the subjects of examination for Five of the Bursaries. And I should think it best to leave the Senatus to determine the relative values of Latin, Greek, English. / 4. That the Senatus shall award the Bursaries on a written report from the Examiners.” TC wrote in his journal, 26 May: “The ‘John-Welsh Bursaries’ now actually in hand; the main last thing then of setting one’s house in order;—do that” (TC’s journal; privately owned).
I had a Note from Js Aitken; but have not seen him this week; letter is inclosed.
I send my love (perhaps more love than some wd think) to Jean everybody.

div3.head: TC TO THOMAS BALLANTYNE

docBody.p: I can say nothing abt those “Passages” cBallantyne edited two volumes of TC’s writings, Prophecy for 1855, Selected from Carlyle’s “Latter-Day Pamphlets” 1850 (1855), and Passages Selected from the Writings of Thomas Carlyle. With a Biographical Memoir (1855), both pbd. by Chapman Hall. (the other Books don’t seem to refer to me at all): I understood the reprinting of “Passages” to have been definitely forbidden by the Messrs Chapman;A second edn. of Passages was pbd by Chapman Hall 1870. I cd not (nor can) interfere with their decisn, or their new-decisn whatr that might be.
In very great haste indeed

div3.sourceNote: TC-Editor of the Times [EOT], 7 June. MS (draft): Ruskin Lib. Collection. Pbd: Times 10 June; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:251–52; Wilson, Carlyle 6:129–30; Cate 133. Quot: Kaplan 497.
div3.head: TC TO THE EDITOR OF THE TIMES

docBody.p: To the Editor of the Times.

Sir,—I cd still wish, by way of Marginal Note to yr friendly Article of Monday last (Times, june 3),The article in the Times, 3 June, expressed satisfaction that TC had publicly contradicted Ruskin’s remarks about him being “unable to walk about the streets by day without being insulted,” and advised Ruskin that “if he must needs lament over the degeneracy of his countrymen, to point his moral with a more authentic example.” to add, for my own sake and for a much valued friend’s, the two following bits of observations:

1° That I by no means join in heavily blaming Mr Ruskin, and indeed do not blame him at all, but the contrary, except for the almost inconceivable practical blunder of printing my name, and then of carelessly hurling topsyturvy all he had to report of me,—of me, and indirectly of the whole multitude of harmless neighbours whom I live with here in London and its suburbs, more than two millions of us, I shd think, who all behave in an obliging, peaceable, and perfectly human manner to each other,—and are struck with amazemt at Mr Ruskin’s hasty Paragrh!—

2° That in regard to the Populace or Canaille of London, to the class distinguishable by behaviour as our non-human or half-human neighbours,—whh class is much more extensive and miscellaneous, and much more dismal and deplorable, than you seem to think,For TC’s expansion of this to Ruskin, see TC to JRU, 13 June.—I substantially agree with all that Mr Ruskin has said of it.

closer.salute: I remain, Sir, yr obedt servt,
closer.name: T. Carlyle
closer.note: On the draft of his letter TC also wrote: “Today (8 June), have sent a Note to Ruskin (rigorous but good-humoured,—as absolute finis to the paltriest absurdity I was ever dragged into as if in my sleep!)”; and “No 4 (Letter to ‘Times,’ in consequence of No 3)”; and “from Ruskin of 1 june is adjacent (I think there was one before, but I have by mistake destroyed it;—it merely said (with supposed provocatn) ‘Tell me what you did say then?’—Impossible!”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 8 June. MS: Estate of Helen Viljoen. Pbd: Cate 133–34. Quot: Kaplan 498.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: Last night I sent away to The Times a paltry little Note (whh agn, this morning, does not please me, and Be hanged to it!)—after such concoction, rejecting, remodelling, nightly and daily botheratn, and sheer waste of time and means as might have sufficed for a Book of the Iliad almost, instead of a Note to the Newspaper! For the beggarly Nothing is of a delicacy and difficulty almost infinite; like that of forging a horse-shoe in the middle of crazy powder-barrels,—i.e. of the hardly yet “sleeping” whirlwinds of impious Newspr rumour, capable of being re-awaked by a wrong word.— This wretched Note you will probably see on monday morning; and from me, sure enough, it is intended to be Finis on the matter.Ruskin referred to the dispute in prefatory remarks that he made to his lecture at the Royal Inst., 7 June, “On the Present State of Modern Art.” Moncure Conway (1832–1907; ODNB; see 43:26943:biographical notes) later recalled: “Ruskin … before beginning his lecture … said words nearly like these: ‘It may be expected that I would say something concerning the matter which has been publicly discussed relating to a statement of mine; but I will only say here that there are reasons, quite apart from the question of my accuracy, which prevent me from saying anything on the subject.’ / This was said so simply, so quietly, and Ruskin was so unconscious of their pathos, that there was a burst of applause” (Conway, Autobiography 2:106–7).

Your prest state of provocatn does not surprise me at all, still less anger me at all. Excuse me if I say, there is even something of amiable in it too (as there has uniformly been in all you have ever done, said or intended towards me); something generous and filial; like the poignant sorrow of a very good, but far too headlong son, getting his rebuke from papa, with the consciousness as yet of only having meant the said papa too well and too kindly; a poignant sorrow whh goes over into sparkles of wrath withal, for the time being. In abt 4 or 5 weeks of silence, I calculate that all this will have vanished and subsided; and the state of the case (one of the absurdest I was ever concerned in) will have become mathematically clear to you, on both sides of it; as it has, for the last fortnight or so, completely been to me,—mathematically clear, I assure you, after ample considering; and now as inflexible and unalterable “as the 47th of Euclid,” or as the Fifth of Euclid,Proposition 47 of Euclid’s Elements is the theorem of right-angled triangles; proposition 5 is the theorem of the isosceles triangle; i.e., with two equal sides. if we like that instance better!— ¬≠Believe me, my friend, you will find that that Letter in the Pall Mall was a necessity and duty on me. Better still, you will find that nothing I cd or can have
written, or forborne to write,—that not even the immortal gods, can wash you clear of having done, thoughtlessly and with intentions purely noble and kind, an immense imprudence of its sort (nothing worse, but for certn that); a deed done,—whh neither I nor the very gods can render not done! Of whh there is no conceivable remedy, but what (I hope) you are now on the way towards, and will reach in abt 4 or 5 weeks hence, as above said.

If, by that time, you have arrived at complete contritn, resolutn of amendt, and mathematical clearness on both sides,—right happy shall I be to see yr sunny face agn unclouded as before: but if not, I recommend that we both wait to try if you can’t and won’t;—and that in the meanwhile that accursed Paragrh be deleted from yr reprint of the Dixon Letters.For the report of the disputed paragraph, see TC to UC, 22 May. At prest this is all,—except unabated regard for you, of whh you youWord repeated at turn of page. need no assurance. You see how mutinous my very hand and pen are!— Yrs ever (whether you achieve “contrition” enough or not),Ruskin replied, 10 June: “[A]las, you do not yet in the least see into this thing. I never denied the imprudence—discourtesy—Sin— … of my Dixon letter. But I emphatically deny its falsehood. And that is … the one question which has to be settled … the worst harm of all would be its remaining unsettled.” He insisted that the Dixon letters would remain unaltered when published in book form, but the passage was not included in his published book of the letters, Time and Tide (1867).

div3.sourceNote: TC-GFW, 8 June. Addr: Little Holland House / Kensington. PM: London, 8 June 1867. MS: EUL. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 6:131; David R. Sorensen, “Une religion plus digne de la Divinité,” CSA 23 (2007): 77. George Frederic Watts (1817–1904; ODNB), painter and sculptor. TC was sitting for his portrait; the sittings began “June 1867, perhaps earlier” and were still continuing July 1868 (M. S. Watts, The Annals of an Artist’s Life [1912] 1:249); they took place in Watts’s studio in Little Holland House.
div3.head: TC TO G. F. WATTS

docBody.p:
* Mahomet’s “eyes were very large, black and full of fire,” (Biographie Universelle, tome 26, p. 206; by Silvestre de Sacy):During one of the early sittings the discussion turned to the color of Muhammed’s eyes, and “whether the brown eye or grey eye denoted the man of action, Carlyle maintaining that the brown eye belong of necessity to the active temperament, and the grey eye to the contemplative” (Watts, Annals of an Artist’s Life 1:250); TC’s source for the detail about Muhammed’s eyes was a biographical entry, “Mahomet,” by A. I. Silvestre de Sacy (1758–1838) and Henri d’Audiffret in Biographie Universelle, Ancienne et Moderne (Paris, 1811–28) 26:186–213. For TC’s opinion of this work, see 25:194TC to WA, 4 Sept. 1850. for its excellence, and clearness
from whh you might paint, I have had the whole Descriptn copied for you;TC’s note to Watts was written at the end of the Biographie entry on Mahomet’s appearance that was copied by Maggie Welsh (MS: EUL; pbd: Sorensen, CSA 23:75–77); she had apparently returned to stay with TC as he wrote her a check for household expenses: “4 june 1867 / To Miss Welsh (House c) / £50 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). and send it, revised,—with my Compts.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JMC, 9 June. MS: NLS Acc. 10367. Quot: “The Collection Online,” Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York. Julia Margaret Cameron (1815–79; ODNB), photographer, is identified as the recipient as she referred to TC’s dislike of her photographs of him two days after he wrote the note (see below); TC’s response was later summarized as “Terrifically ugly and woe-begone, but has something of likeness: my candid opinion” and printed in the commentary posted beside the photograph in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Cameron took her camera to London to photograph TC in Little Holland House, Kensington, where her sister Sara Prinsep, b. Pattle (1816–87), and husband, Henry Thoby Prinsep (1792–1878; ODNB), m. 1835, lived. Watts also lived there, and Cameron may have photographed TC in his studio. TC’s sitting probably took place 7 or 8 June as she registered the copyright of two negatives, 8 June. One was full face and the other a right profile (see above). A slightly different full face was also taken; it was not registered and only ever printed as a carte-de-visite and given by Cameron to a friend (Julian Cox and Colin Ford, Julia Margaret Cameron The Complete Photographs [2003] 312). The photograph of TC’s left profile sometimes printed is a reverse of Cameron’s original right profile. She met William Allingham on her way home to the Isle of Wight, 10 June: “and Carlyle refuses to give me a sitting, he says it’s a kind of Inferno!” (William Allingham A Diary, eds. H. Allingham and D. Radford [1967] 153); presumably she meant another sitting as she had already photographed him.
div3.head: TC TO JULIA MARGARET CAMERON

docBody.p: Front-face has something of likeness, tho’ terrifically ugly and woe-begone;Julia Margaret Cameron wrote later: “When I have had such men before my camera my whole soul has endeavoured to do its duty towards them in recording faithfully the greatness of the inner as well as the features of the outer man. The photograph thus taken has been almost the embodiment of a prayer” (Julia Margaret Cameron, “Annals of My Glass House,” Photography: Essays and Images [1981] 137).
Profile ought to be destroyed at once, it has lost its jaw altogether, and has a chin, nose c whh are not mine

My candid opinionCameron wrote to an unidentified correspondent, 11 June: “Carlyle’s photograph is more like a block of marble out of Michel Angelo’s [sic] hands than a work out of such a machine as the camera so the great artists who have seen it say. The Profile Mr Jones delighted in as the most supremely beautiful thing I had ever done but it is fair to tell you Mr Carlyle does not like my Photographs of himself” (MS: St. Andrews Univ. Lib., Dept. of MS 38345; pbd: Sophie Gordon, Roger Fenton, Julia Margaret Cameron [2010] 19). Mr. Jones was presumably Edward Coley Burne-Jones (1833–98; ODNB ), painter. Cameron inscribed some copies of the photographs: “Carlyle like a rough block of Michelangelo’s sculpture” (In Focus: Julia Margaret Cameron Photographs from J. Paul Getty Museum [1996] 62).

p.note: Presumably this note was a response to copies of the two photographs sent by Cameron to TC.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 13 June. Addr: Denmark Hill. PM: London, 14 June 1867. MS: Yale. Pbd: Sanders, “Carlyle’s Letters to Ruskin” 227–29; Cate 136–40. Quot: Kaplan 498.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: With a Poet’s temperament, you immensely exaggerate this miserable, but intrinsically small and paltry matter. “The most dishonouring words ever spoken of you”Ruskin wrote to TC, 12 June, accusing him of writing: “the most dishonouring words that could be set down in public sight.” are, as you will understand by and by, simply to the effect, That you in headlong incautious way, with the best and truest intentions in the world, strode into one of the foolishest practical puddles recently heard of, and dragged a most unwitting friend along with you,—who refuses to lie there with you (especially to lie undermost as he chanced to be), and, finding you took no steps and did not even recognise the puddle much, has striven honestly to save first himself, and then his more or less blameable compann too,—really with his best endeavour, and utmost stretch of faculty and skill, exerted in an element infinitely foreign and unpleast to him. So that he is now out, and getting his mind cleaned; and you too are out (if you will be wise) with only an infinitesimal minimum of smutch upon you,—such as all sons of Adam catch to themselves from time to time, and are all absolved from, so soon as they heartily acknowledge it. For the man that never made a “mistake” was not heard of hitherto.On his draft up to this point (MS: Ruskin Lib. Collection), TC wrote, perpendicular to the last line: “ended now, and Be-hanged to it! (for the 10th and positively last time!— / (T.C.) 14 june.” And these are “the most dishonouring words that ever” c c. Oh dear, oh dear!—

But on the whole, I too, my friend, have had my abundt vexations, botheratns and distresses abt this small and miserable matter,—whh is so extraneous, so infinitely incongruous, and comes intruding on me with such a ghastly contemptability, amid the serious, sad and solemn matters whh are my constant occupatn otherwise (especially sad in these weeks),—that I too find it at last unbearable; and decide to have done with it at once, till it take a quite new figure! Please don’t send me any “formal Letter”;Ruskin wrote a brief letter, 10 June: “this is private—you will have my formal reply tomorrow”; he then wrote, 12 June: “I cannot write the formal letter to day, any more than I could yesterday.” but take this as my ansr to
it beforehand, and the only ansr I will make to it or any other on that subject, as matters now stand betn us:

First, therefore, I never told you, nor cd tell any mortal, that “Mr Carlyle” was liable to be insulted on the streets of London or Chelsea; the constant fact being that I have the natural liberty of all quiet persons to walk the streets unmolested, and if need were, protected defended; and that in no street, lane or place, of London or any other City, Town or Region, did “Mr Carlyle,” when personally recognised, meet with anything hitherto but an evidt respect far beyond what was his due, or what was in the least necessary to him. This is the stedfast fact; and this you have carelessly tumbled heels over head, into a statement incredible to all who hear it, and monstrous to imagine. Secondly, I did tell you that, by order of the Doctor I had discontinued my midnight walks, whh used to have a sombre soothing charm, and to seem salutary, as the last work of the day.John A. Carlyle wrote, 11 Jan.: “I am especially glad to hear that you do not go out late at nights, I trust you may be enabled to lay the habit aside altogether for it is a very unnatural one at your time of life not without danger.” This I perfectly remember telling you. And what mad reversal you have made of this you cannot have forgotten! A domestic picture unexampled in Brish History or Biography. The wretched dreary old Dotard and Coward peering tremulously out of door at midnight, If he might now steal a little exercise,—and not substance enough left in him even to kill himself if he cdn’t alter such a state of matters. Papae, proh pudor [indeed, oh shame]! if a man were on the outlook for “dishonouring words,” or cared much abt them when they came, here by accidt they are, in richest measure for him.

In fine, so far as I can recollect those unlucky 10 minutes of loose talk, whh memory took so little charge of, and whh are now several weeks away, our discourse did not turn upon public streets, thoroughfares or walking, but almost wholly on my experiences in riding, thro’ the unfrequented slums and waste-lying outskirts of London (tempted thither by the soft ground, or the immunity from wheels), where the lower populace or canaille inhabit: nor, agn, was my experience there in the least definable as “Mr Carlyle’s,” but simply as that of A. or B., riding, seemingly for his amuset, and from his age or gravity of aspect, not very likely to use his horsewhip in reply (whh more than once proved a miscalculatn, too, and had firm effects on the individual two-legged canis, if he chanced to stand within reach). These are the precise certain facts (as precise as I can now give them) of that bit of private dialogue betn us).

And now had you, instead of carelessly, hastily and heedlessly reversing these, stated the whole of them with the accuracy of an affidavit, and then printed my name to them,—what cd I have called it but the absurdest oversight,
and foolishest “practical blunder” that ever dropped upon me of its own accord, from any man of sense, in all my days! And this is the last word I intend to write upon a subject, whh has already cost me a great deal too many.

For I have had, not on my own acct alone, to manipulate in my sad and sick Soul this paltry bit of nonsense not a little, to tease it carefully down to its elemental fibres, and to sight and survey it on all sides, till I cd completely reckon it transparent to me and not it only but something of you too, my friend, and of the mad worlds way with you and me; and in fine “to forge my miserable horse-shoe” (as I told you), “nay in successn two horse shoes in the middle of leaky powder-barrels”:—and I now thank God to have done with it altogether. Further words upon it especially betn you and me, what good cd be in them, till a considerable change come; till, as I once said already, we both of us come to see both sides of the matter? Till each see, in a perfect and quietly transparent manner, not only his own grief, and whether he brot it wholly on himself, but also his neighbour’s and whether he did so! If I am so egregiously in error to suppose that “six weeks”In his previous letter, 8 June, TC hoped that Ruskin would come around in four or five weeks; Ruskin replied, 10 June: “My chief wonder is to see how little you have known me all these years!—when you fancy that I should alter my mind in six weeks!” will work this salutary change in you, I shall be profoundly sorry (and much surprised withal, for it is still my belief); but the actual coming of the change does not now depend on me at all; and till it do come, we must wait.

The tone and new style of yr last Letters, especially of yr last but one, has been perhaps or seemed a little singular; and I want no more of that fashion soon. But as to “implacability”Ruskin wrote, 12 June, contrasting TC’s “lava-current of a mind—tumbling hither thither and cooling in the odd corners of it at necessary periods” with his own “poor little leguminous climbing-tendril of a vegetable mind—subduable and flexible by a touch—but utterly unchangeable and implacable in its poor wounded way—and changeless of temperature.” c c, it is, to myself, void of meaning or conceivability; and on such a score as you assign, it wd savour to me of utter madness;—nor do I believe it of you at all, nor will unless forced. If I had in any degree injured a certn interestTC was presumably referring to Ruskin’s wooing of Rose La Touche; see TC to JRU, 27 Sept. 1866 . (of whh I was not thinking at all), that wd indeed have been a cruel and most forbidding circe in my necessity; but that was not there; nor do I now believe (whatr your wildly exaggerative mind may do) that it will have the weight of a fly’s wing in the beautiful resolute and candid soul on whose vote you alone depend:—nay if it did, if she did see it to proceed from a too headlong habit c and to require a little censure and attempt at amendt, might it not be better that she know it now, before closure of the bargn than after it? There is for you!—

Adieu, my friend. Since you won’t accept my counsel on that mutual plunge into the puddle, I must leave you to yr own. Quod faustum sit [May it be favorable]. I consider it still possible that by this accidt we may become “better friends than ever”; more sincere, more frank, ruggedly veracious, much more humanly helpful to one another. But the chance depends now altogr on yrself, and I can’t control it farther.TC’s letter initially failed to appease Ruskin, who noted in his diary, 14 June: “Ugly letter from Carlyle in evening” (Ruskin’s Diaries 2:620). However Ruskin next wrote to TC, 25 June: “I am going into Scotland for a week or two on Friday, and I want to see you before I go—if I may, without any reference to newspaper business. Don’t think there is any change in my notions respecting them,—but between you and me, they ought not to come. … / I come to you … as I should come to my Father. … If you are going to speak or teaze me, on such … matters, I won’t come. … If you were not my Father—I would not come at all—but being so, and because moreover you love me, and I love you, I want to see you.” He noted in his diary, 26 June: “At Carlyle’s in evening with Scotch Provost” (Ruskin’s Diaries 2:621); provost not further identified. TC wrote on the envelope: “(Ruskin: / Nichts, hardly read / june 25 1867).” Adieu: none of yr fine qualities and talents, nor of yr uniformly amiable procedures, are forgotten by me at this moment, nor have much chance of ever being.

closer.salute: Yrs sincerely, (so far as you will permit), /
closer.name: T. Carlyle

postscript.p: P.S. Please send me that Ms. of Edwd IrvingTC loaned Ruskin the MS (1 May; Ruskin’s Diaries 2:617) of his reminiscences of Edward Irving that he had begun by 26 Sept. 1866 (see TC to WDC, 27 Sept. 1866, and TC to JCA, 26 Nov. 1866) and ended 2 Jan. 1867. at yr convenience; I want it for a reason, but not till you have quite done with it.TC wrote in his journal, 12 June: “Paltriest and most incongruous of all has been Ruskin’s Newspapr Paragrh (deliriously absurd and most spontaneous and unexpected!) whh he had thoughtlessly rushed into circulatn, and whh I had at last to stamp out by one brief stroke of heat. To Ruskin’s (still delirious) real indignatn; unworthy of noting here. I rolled all the stuff up … dated and labelled; and suppose now that a little word I have on paper, waiting ready, shall be inexorably my last, to or from, on that ridiculous, irrational, extraneous, and completely contemptible subject. Figure its intervening among these other employts!— — Ruskin, I rather judge, is flown off me for good! I answer, ‘Well, if you are such a spoony, and even waspish spoony, go!’ A curious specimen, Ruskin, with some really high and pretty talents in him, who has fluttered abt me (abt us especially, while it was ‘us’!) with an exuberant, constant, and plainly excessive amiability of ways, whh was not unpleast, nor to be taken as ‘hypocritical,’ but only as weak and well-meaning; and was so taken by both of us,—with clear insight that in regard to ‘affectn’ for us it amounted to nothing or to infinitely little. As now at length shows itself! We always remarked, too, that his talk had no solidity, hugely lacked sincerity, trustfulness, ease; and was always flying off, on the deepest topics, into idle affect [affectation] of skepticism, pococurantism c c, as if eager to hide agn, and ashamed to be seen. Pretty notions, pretty talents, sharp, arrowy utterances, and perceptns and aspiratns, but all of a restless not of a quiet: of a weakish not a strong character;— as central element, an immense pruriency of ambitn, what might have been called by us (but never was, till now by me) a merely great and transcendt vanity, if nothing else was ‘great’!— Poor Rn, I really can’t be seriously angry at him, either; and will still keep hoping he is not quite a waspish spoony,—as I seemed to perceive him to be, yesterday morning (by his foolish Letter) for the first time. Basta, basta” (TC’s journal; privately owned).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 16 June. MS: NLS 1796.109. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: If I miss you today, let this Note convey to you my earnest request (if at all convenient to you) for ten minutes of yr presence here, on Thursday next at 3 p.m. Ten minutes here will suffice; but with cab to and from, it will take how much more you best know. The business is, To bear witness and write yr name to a certn Deed of Bequest to Edinr University,See TC’s first draft of the bequest of Craigenputtoch, 12 May. TC wrote in his journal, 12 June: “Last night Profr Masson (who has been very helpful and along with my Brother, and by accidt John Forster, is alone participt of the secret) carefully revised along with me here, my final correctns of the ‘Draft of Deed’ (Bursary matter, i.e.); and sends it back to Edinr today for revisal; after whh deed itself, signatures with witnesses, who I intend shall be Masson and Forster. All likely to be finished now in abt a week. Very solemn to me; very sad and high,—re-awakens all the religion I have. Alas, it is my poor ‘Abbey of Cor Dulce,’ for burying my Loved One’s Heart: and I wd see it done before I die!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Abbey of Cor Dulce, or Sweetheart Abbey, is another name for New Abbey in Kirkcudbrightshire, SW Scotland, so called after its foundress, Dervorgilla, who was buried there holding a casket containing her husband’s heart (see 14:14TC to DL, 17 Jan. 1842); see also TC’s final bequest of Craigenputtoch, 20 June. of whh, so far as I know, you alone are clearly cognisant, in these parts; and to whh, all the more since I learnt that circumstance, I shd like that your hand were put rather than another’s. Professor Masson (David Masson), who is here just now, has faithfully, wisely and altogether silently, guided me, while still at home in Edinr, thro’ all the Law intricacies, Drafts, Second-Drafts c c: he is to be yr fellow Witness to my Signing;—and, so far as I know, you are the only Two, except my BrotherJohn A. Carlyle. and the Edinr Lawyer,John Cook; see TC’s first draft of the bequest of Craigenputtoch, 12 May. and I intend shall continue so, who are aware of this poor act of mine.

If, as I know is possible, you cannot, witht a good deal of official or other inconvenience,Forster’s work as a lunacy commissioner often took him out of London. come,—pray tell me; and I will at once absolve you. For Froude is just come back, to whom I once hinted something of the thing as an intentn ahead; and who is perfectly free and accessible at any hour.

In matter of sleep c c I have had nothing but a series of confusions and petty disasters, since I saw you; but really don’t feel worse otherwise, almost better in some points; and am earnestly remodelling my dietetics, hours, and
poor bits of procedures, in hope of getting back to par at least, whh you know is never a very high figure.

This thing once finished, on Thursday, I shall feel more independt of the Future and its paltrinesses. Thank God for leading us so far, not in captivity to the paltry Enemy; (paltry, tho’ world-huge), but in some degree of victory over him! And God’s will be done.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HFC, 19 June. Pbd: Henry Fothergill Chorley, Autobiography, Memoir and Letters, ed. H. G. Hewlett, 2 vols. (1873) 2:285–87; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:252–54. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:132. Henry Fothergill Chorley (1808–72; ODNB), journalist and writer.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY F. CHORLEY

docBody.p: Your note of yesterday is a most welcome favour to me; a very great and almost sacred bit of charity and solace done me in the dark and sad element where you yourself are now living and waiting! The last time I saw your dear brother—alas, I little thought it was the last!John Rutter Chorley, longtime friend of TC, who was suffering from atrophy (i.e., a progressive decline); he d. 29 June. TC last mentioned visiting him Aug. 1866; see TC to JAC, 28 Aug. 1866.— I noticed no fatal symptom in him; nothing but very great misery and disquiet, which I lightly supposed the summer weather, and a shift to the shore of the sea, which was always such a favourite with him, would clear away; and I am never since free from an occasional doubt that I may have really pained him and done myself injustice by my light and hopeful way of treating all his misgivings and bad prognostics, which have proved so dismally true—alas, alas!

From your brother William’s letters to my brother JohnWilliam Brownsword Chorley (1804–79; see 9:400TC to UC, 11 Dec. 1834), M.D., and John A. Carlyle regularly corresponded; John wrote to TC, 2 June: “I have not heard again from Wm Chorley since last Sunday indeed I suppose he has nothing new to say. Of course John can see no one in his present state.” He then wrote, 5 June, enclosing William Chorley’s letter of 25 May: “John does not seem to be suffering much pain. I dont altogether feel desperate yet in regard to his case, though there can certainly be very little hope. Of organic disease there never were any symptoms that I heard of.” But William Chorley had written: “I regret to say I can give no more favorable account of my brother’s health than when I last wrote. He is now confined to bed; and [the doctor] has lost all hope of his ever recovering. This severe weather has borne heavily upon him: and the wasting and decline in strength increase from day to day. We can only pray for him to the Almighty who in His wisdom orders for the best even when we cannot now see it, for I fear the case is past all human help” (MS: NLS 1775C.125). at Dumfries, I am kept in knowledge of the progress of things from day to day towards their inevitable goal; and I thank Heaven along with you, that pain and irritation are
quite gone, and that sleep and quiet are now the attendants of that ardent soul to its final rest. Final and perfect, where all the weary do at length rest!

If in any fit moment you could whisper to him, that I, who owe him so much,His most notable assistance had been supervising the building of TC’s soundproof room in the attic of 5 Cheyne Row in 1853; see 28:245TC to JCA, 11 Aug. 1853. did always honour and esteem him as few others; am touched to the heart with what is going on, know well what loss I am sustaining, and shall piously regret him all my remaining days, the fact will abundantly support you; and should the opportunity offer (not otherwise, I beg), it will be a drop of consolation to me.
May God be with him! may God be with us all!

div3.head: TC TO AUGUSTUS DE MORGAN

docBody.p: I did undoubtedly translate the Legendre’s Geometry, to whh Dr Brewster gave his name and nothing more,De Morgan wrote to David Masson inquiring about Carlyle’s role in the translation of Legendre’s Éléments de Géométrie (1794). Masson replied, 13 June: “The translation you spoke of was wholly done by Carlyle, who also remembers that he gave in the book some simplification of the 5th Book [of Euclid] which he thought at the time might be valuable. … Brewster gave him £50 for the job—not much for the work, but acceptable to him at the time” (MS: Univ. of London Lib.; pbd: Campbell 27:47.). Sir David Brewster (1781–1868; ODNB); principal and vice-chancellor of Edinburgh Univ. 1859–68.—nothing more, except (as I suppose, but don’t recollect) some supervision of the first few Proofs, and then, finding it wd go it itself, gladly let it go. The poor Book is still an innocently pleast reminiscence to me, as of a quiet little Island in the waster seas I was then sailing;—tho’ I have never seen it since, and indeed do not remember ever to have seen it as a volume at all.

On the Galbraith Legend I can throw no light, I did, sometimes, hear the name of Galbraith in those years, as of a diligt enough Mathematical “Private-Teacher”;William Galbraith (1786–1850), initially a parish schoolmaster in Eccles, Berwickshire, took a degree in mathematics at Edinburgh Univ. and became a respected mathematician and geographer. but not as of a writer, or in any other capacity; nor did I ever see
him, or hear more of him in the long years that have followed. So that the Cambridge myth of him becomes darker even than before!De Morgan wrote later: “I picked up a notion, which others had at Cambridge in 1825, that the translator [of Legendre] was the late Mr. Galbraith. … But it turns out that it was by a very different person. … a young man named Thomas Carlyle. He prefixed, from his own pen, a thoughtful and ingenious essay on Proportion, as good a substitute for the fifth Book of Euclid as could have been given in the space” (Augustus De Morgan, Budget of Paradoxes [1872] 499).— He was rustic Scotch by birth; may have frequented Brewster, but I think, if so, it must have been at a subsequt time.
It gives me pleasure to have this opportunity of expressing my respects:—thank poor Galbrth at least for that!
I remain / Dear Sir

p.note: De Morgan replied, 29 June: “I have deferred acknowledging until I could sort out a few things to send you which are not mathematical, though verging upon it. They are an acknowledgment of what has been to me a very useful book. You may give your look at them—and then I dare say you will find out some one who may like to have them. I make it a principle not to write the name of the donee on any presentation copies; it is like binding him over to keep them. … In these days it ought to be assumed that a person who receives these things will part with a large proportion of them. / The preface on Proportion (your’s) was a thing I remember reading with interest. … / I shall stick to Galbraith until I find out something about the legend.” TC wrote on the envelope: “Profr De Morgan (abt not ‘Legendre’ but sequel to: Nichts!).”

div3.sourceNote: TC’s final bequest of Craigenputtoch [FBC], 20 June. Pbd: Sir Alexander Grant, The Story of the University of Edinburgh (1884) 2:146–48 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:134–35. The bequest came into force after TC’s death, 1881; it was subsequently overridden and the farm sold to George Armour; see 2:305JBW to EA, 8 March [1823] . TC wrote in his journal, 22 June: “Finished off, on Thursday last, ‘at 3 p.m.’ (by appointt), 20 june, my poor Bequest of Craigk to Edinr University, for Bursaries. All quite ready there, Forster Froude as Witnesses; the good Masson, who had taken endless pains, alike friendly and wise, being at the very last objected to in the character of ‘witness’ as ‘a party interested,’ said the lawyer in Edinr. I a little regretted this little circumstance; so, I think, did Masson secretly. He read us the Deed with sonorous emphasis, bringing every word and note of it home to us. Then I signed, then they two, Masson ‘witnessing’ only with his eyes and mind. I was deeply moved, as I well might be; but held my peace, and shed no tears (tears I think I have done with; never, except for moments togr, have I wept for that catastrophe of April 21,—to whh whole days of weeping would have been, in other times a blessed relief. Deed had to go back to Edinburgh for insertion of ‘testing clause’ at the end. The lawyer (excellt careful Lawyer) one J. Cook, W.S.; yesterday the Deed came back to him all complete, to be seen once perhaps by my Brother John, not in my lifetime by any other. Woe’s me,—and yet, in a sense, Blessing is me! This is my poor ‘Sweetheart Abbey,’ Cor Dulce, or New Abbey, a sacred casket and tomb for the Sweetest ‘Heart’ whh, in this bad, bitter world, was all my own! Darling, Darling!—and in a little while we shall both be at rest, and the Great God will have done with us what was His will” (TC’s journal; privately owned). TC recorded in his checkbook: “20 june 1867 / to J. Cook Esq W.S. Edinr,—for a most solemn matter; ah me, my poor ‘Cor Dulce’! £5 .. 13 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). John Cook wrote, 21 June: “I have to acknowledge receipt this morning of your letter of 20 inst. returning to me the Disposition (Testamentary) by you in favour of the University of Edinburgh executed by you yesterday. I have completed, and now in terms of your instructions herewith return the deed to you. / I have to acknowledge also receipt from you of cheque for five pounds 13/— in full of my charges for preparation of the deed. / Allow me to thank you for your kind expressions as to my services. The duty has been one most interesting to me.”
div3.head: TC TO FINAL BEQUEST OF CRAIGENPUTTOCH

docBody.p:
I, Thomas Carlyle, residing at Chelsea, presently Rector of the University of Edinburgh, from the love, favour, and affection which I bear to that University, and from my interest in the advancement of education in my native Scotland as elsewhere; for these, and for other more particular reasons, which also I wish to put on record, do intend, and am now in the act of making to the said University, bequest as underwritten, of the estate of Craigenputtock, which is now my property. …Ellipses are in the pbd. version. Craigenputtock was for many generations the patrimony of a family named Welsh—the eldest son generally a “John Welsh”—in series going back, think some, to the famous John Welsh, son-in-law of the Reformer, Knox.For notes to TC’s final bequest, see the notes to TC’s first draft of the bequest of Craigenputtoch, 12 May. The last male heir of this family was John Welsh, Esquire, surgeon, Haddington (born at Craigenputtock in 1775, died at Haddington in 1819, a highly honoured, widely regretted man, and is buried in the Abbey
Kirk of that town); his one child and heiress was my late dear, magnanimous, much-loving, and to me inestimable wife; in memory of whom, and of her constant nobleness and piety towards him and towards me, I now, she having been the last of her kindred, am about to bequeath to Edinburgh University, with whatever of piety is in me, this Craigenputtock which was theirs and hers, on the terms and for the purposes underwritten. Therefore, I do mortify and dispone, etc., for the foundation and endowment of ten equal bursaries, to be called the “John Welsh Bursaries,” in the said University, all and whole the twenty-shilling lands of Upper Craigenputtock, etc. … More especially, I appoint that five of the John Welsh Bursaries shall be given for best proficiency in Mathematics (I would rather say “in Mathesis,” if that were a thing to be judged of from competition), but practically, above all, in pure geometry, such being perennially the symptom, not only of steady application, but of a clear, methodic intellect, and offering, in all epochs, good promise for all manner of arts and pursuits. The other five bursaries I appoint to depend (for the present and indefinitely onwards) on proficiency in classical learning—that is to say, in knowledge of Latin, Greek, and English, all of these or any two of them. This also gives good promise of a mind; but as I do not feel certain that it gives perennially, or will perennially be thought in universities to give the best promise, I am willing that the Senatus of the University, in case of a change of its opinion on this point hereafter in the course of generations, shall bestow these latter five bursaries on what it does then consider the most excellent proficiency in matters classical, or the best proof of a classical mind, and directs its own highest efforts towards teaching and diffusing, in the new generations that will come. … Bursaries to be always given, on solemnly strict and faithful trial, to the worthiest. … Under penalties graver than I or any highest mortal can pretend to impose, but which I can never doubt—as the law of eternal justice, inexorably valid, whether noticed or unnoticed, pervades all corners of space and of time—are very sure to be punctually exacted if incurred, this is to be the perpetual rule for the Senatus in deciding. … Bursaries to last till the usual term of admittance to trial for graduation as Master of Arts … and so may a little trace of help to the young heroic soul struggling for what is highest, spring from this poor arrangement and bequest; may it run, for ever if it can, as a thread of pure water from the Scottish rocks, tinkling into its little basin by the thirsty wayside, for those whom it veritably belongs to. Amen. Such is my bequest to Edinburgh University. Dated 20th June 1867.Grant noted: “Perhaps no document of the kind was ever composed in higher literary style, or was more imbued by the philosophy of the testator. From it we learn Carlyle’s theory of education—that mathematics must perpetually hold their place among the most important instruments of cultivation; but that Latin and Greek may very likely be superseded, in favour, perhaps, of the modern languages of Europe” (Grant 2:148).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC Jr. [JAJR], 20 June 1867. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote on the reverse of the letter: “For / Mr James Carlyle junr / Joint-Tenant of Craigenputtock / (T.C. Chelsea 20 June / 1867).
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE JR.

docBody.p: Dear James,—I have never heard of this Glenessland SchoolhouseGlenesslin (Glenessland) School, Dunscore parish; the Rev. John Hope, minister of the parish, wrote, 1 June: “At a meeting of the Electors of the parish of Dunscore … it was unanimously resolved that, in consequence of the ruinous state of Glenesslin School, a new one should be built, along with a dwelling to the Teacher. At a subsequent meeting plans were produced and one adopted at an estimated expense of upwards of £200– It was also agreed that as the Electors in the Glenesslin district of the parish were more deeply interested in the school they should pay two thirds of the … subscription. … / I have been instructed to write to non residing Electors, with a view of ascertaining what amount of subscription each is willing to give.” affair till now; and I wish you to go, and clearly inform yrself abt it; that, by yr Report, I may be able to judge what it will be just and fit for me to do or to subscribe upon it.TC sent Rev. Hope’s letter to John A. Carlyle, who sent it on to James Carlyle Jr., 9 June, asking him to look into the matter: “Yesterday your uncle sends to me the enclosed Dunscore letter about rebuilding the Schoolhouse in Glenessland building a house too for the Schoolmaster; requests me to ask you ‘what it is just reasonable for him to do or give in this matter, which he never heard of before.’ … Please look into the business give your opinion as to what your uncle wants to know” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).

I also wish you to get or form a correct estimate of what it will cost to rectify into its old state the Tomb of John Welsh (in Dunscore Churchyard), from the shot rubbish or broken stones whh have been negligently tumbled agt it.After the death of Grace Welsh (see TC to JCA, 24 Feb.), Ann and Elizabeth Welsh had apparently asked TC if he could add the names and dates of their parents to their father’s tombstone in Dunscore churchyard, which at present had only his name: “Erected / To the Memory of / John Welsh of Craigenputtock.” John A. Carlyle wrote, 2 May: “They said the monument of their father had cost £40, it should have lasted longer. … I hardly think it would be worth while to add anything more than they suggest. They are narrow vehement irritable, as you know, it would not be easy to deal with them for the addition you speak of.” He went to look at the tomb, 13 May, and reported, 15 May, that the stone was 6 ft. by 3 ft., with the name at the top, that it was “enclosed by a suitable stone frame … which looks solid simple strong. There seems to be only two graves in front of it, an iron railing (also simple strong) encloses the space containing them. A large mass of stones on one side, resting against the railing on that side, will ere long break it down, if not removed, it being already much bent by them.” He was less severe about the Welsh sisters, explaining they “had spoken a good deal about the monument at Dunscore … said they would like to have something put on it to memory of their brothers sisters, but were afraid of your incurring additional expence.” I have always given my bit of subscriptn to all Parish objects, witht exceptn hitherto: but this of the shot rubbish on a Tombstone seems to me an item whh will require to be deducted from whatr my next subscriptn may be.

div3.head: TC TO LADY AUGUSTA STANLEY

docBody.p: You are always very good to me; of whh I am deeply sensible. But, alas, since April gone a year, I have never once been out to dinner;—and in the last two months, furthermore, am fairly below par in respect of health; “par” itself being, as you know, so very low a figure with me. I ascribe it to the ill and fitful weather; and have always some hope.

div3.sourceNote:
TC-JC Jr. [JACA], [24 June?]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Dated tentatively after TC’s request for James Carlyle Jr. to inquire about the cost of rectifying the tomb of John Welsh, which “had stones negligently tumbled agt it”; see TC to JACA, 20 June
. TC wrote “Mr James Carlyle junr” diagonally on the reverse of the letter.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE JR.

docBody.p: Yr Letter this moment came;—I on the wing out. Here is the Mandate.The mandate is untraced; possibly it was to authorize James Carlyle Jr. to arrange for work on and around the tombstone. I don’t yet feel satisfied abt tumbling rubbish on a Tomb, visibly enough belonging to the ChurchydDunscore churchyard. (outside the wall or in),—and can’t but esteem it still a decidedly brutish procedure, done because it seemed safe to do. T.C.

div1.p: Notes on the Carlyles’ contemporaries referred to more than once in the present volume are given below, cross-referenced to earlier information. Some relatives or old friends who died before the starting date of this volume are retained because of frequent references to them. Otherwise, individuals are accounted for in headnotes and footnotes when they appear in the letters.
Adamson, Samuel (1831–80), of British Linen Co., Dumfries, where TC had an account; son of Robert Adamson (1787–1861; see 10:23TC to JA, 14 Feb. 1838, and 37:26137:biographical notes).

Aitken, Jean (“Craw”) Carlyle (1810–88), TC’s sister; m., 1833, James Aitken (1809–87) from Troqueer, housepainter of English St., Dumfries; they moved from Assembly St., Dumfries, to their new house, The Hill, Lochmaben Rd., Dumfries, 1863. They had two sons who d. in infancy (1834–36 and 1855–56), both named Alexander; their surviving sons were James Jr. (1836–71), who worked in a mercantile house in London 1858–ca. 1864, then moved to work in Liverpool, and from early 1867 was living in London, trying to establish himself as a shipbroker; Thomas (1841–69), who had been at an inst. for the deaf in Glasgow (see 29:186TC to JAC, 4 Nov. 1854), but was apparently now living at home; and John (1843–1911). Their das. were Anne (1839–1919), Margaret (1845–1932), and Mary (1848–95), who began as a pupil teacher in Peebles, March 1867; Mary Aitken m., 1879, her cousin Alexander Carlyle.
Atkinson, Blanche (1847–1911), writer and naturalist, da. of a prosperous Liverpool soap manufacturer.

Austin, Mary Carlyle (1808–88), TC’s sister, m., 1831, James Austin (1805–78), farmer of The Gill, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SW of Ecclefechan. They had eight das.: Margaret (see Stewart); Grace (b. 1833), who m., 1856, William Yeoward (b. ca. 1824), of Toronto, Ontario; Jessie (b. 1836), who m., 1859, George Grierson (b. 1835); Jane (b. 1840); Mary Anne (b. 1842); Catherine (1844–1908), who m., 18 Sept. 1867, her cousin James Carlyle; Isabella (b. ca. 1846); and Mary Carlyle (b. 1851); and one surviving son, James Jr. (b. 1848).
Bailey, James (b. 1809), Lady Ashburton’s butler.
Baring; see Ashburton.

Bennet, James Henry (1816–91), physician; studied medicine in Paris; his tuberculosis led him to go to Menton, 1859; his health having been restored, he established a practice there, mid-Oct. to April, and at 60 Grosvenor St., London, May to mid.-Oct.; he first wrote of the benefits of the climate for invalids in “Winter in Mentone,” an article in the Lancet (July 1860), then extended it into Mentone and the Riviera as a
Winter Climate (1861), which became a series of ever-expanding guides; the third edn. was Winter in the South of Europe (1865).
Bismarck, Otto Eduard Leopold von (1815–98), Prussian politician, minister-president of Prussia 1862–90.

Braid, Betty, b. Pringle (1795–1875), Grace Welsh’s Haddington servant, close to JWC (see 21:82 JWC to SS, [29 Oct. 1846] , and 24:221 JWC to TC, [5 Sept. 1849] ); b. in Prestonkirk, E. Lothian; m. Alexander (1792–1874), stonemason and shopkeeper. Three sons d. in infancy: Alexander (b. 1826), James (b. 1829), and James (b. 1831); their son George (1827–65) survived into adulthood but suffered ill health. Previously living at 15 Adam St. (see 17:127 TC to JWC, 12 Sept. 1843
), they moved in 1858 to Upper Stenhouse, Greenend, Liberton, S Edinburgh.

Bromley, Caroline Davenport (1820–91), da. of Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley (1787–1862) of Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, and his first wife, m., 1818, Caroline Barbara, b. Gooch (1791–1827). A friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton’s, she became a close friend of JWC’s. Her London home was at 32 Grosvenor St.

Butler, Charles (1802–97; see 28:314 TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853
), U.S. lawyer, financier, land speculator, entrepreneur, and philanthropist; welcome in Britain for his part in handling the threat by some U.S. states in the 1840s to default on their bonds; met TC in Nov. 1853 and looked after his Illinois bonds and other American investments. He m., 1825, Eliza, b. Ogden (1803–78); they had five children: Abraham Ogden Butler (1832–56), two other sons who d. in infancy, and two das., Emily (b. 1840) and Anna (d. 1877).

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1797–1876), TC’s brother; emigrated with his family to Canada, 1843; settled at the Bield, 4½ mi. (7 km.) W of Brantford, Ontario. He m., 1830, Janet, b. Clow (1809–91); they had six surviving sons: Thomas (1833–1921), John (1839–1924), Alexander (see below), James (1846–1924), William (1849–1935), and Robert (1851–1932); and three surviving das.: Jane Welsh (1831–84), who m., 1852, Robert Sims; Janet (1836–1916); and Margaret (1847–1935); see 1:166 TC to AC, 23 Feb. 1819
. An unidentified son (1832–33), Margaret (1835–36), James (b. 1840), and Euphemia (1853–54) all d. in infancy; see 32:4 TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856
.

Carlyle, Alexander (1843–1931; see 16:153 TC to AC, 4 May 1843
), Alexander and Janet’s son; m., 1879, his cousin Mary Aitken; lived with TC from 1879 and ed. various collections of the Carlyles’ letters and TC’s writings.

Carlyle, James (Jamie) (1805–90), TC’s brother, farmer at Scotsbrig; m., 1834, Isabella, b. Calvert (ca. 1813–1859). Their children were James Jr. (1835–71), who had been working in Glasgow as a clerk but was now back home; m., 18 Sept. 1867, his cousin Catherine Austin; John (1836–1901); Thomas (1839–41); and Janet (Jessie or Jenny) (1843–74), m., 1864, William Scott (b. ca. 1829), draper from Birmingham; their son was John James Carlyle (b. 1865).
Carlyle, Margaret Aitken (1771–1853), TC’s mother; TC’s father was James Carlyle (1758–1832); they m. 1795.
Clark, Alice, servant, appointed 23 Sept. 1867, dismissed by Mrs. Warren Jan. 1867.

Dixon, Thomas (1831–80), cork cutter from Sunderland; working-class activist and educator; he had first written to TC Aug. 1862; see 38:168 JWC to TC, [27 Aug.] , and 38:175 TC to JWC, 29 Aug. 1862
.

Dods, William (1795–1873; see 33:79 JWC to LAI, [11? Sept. 1857] ), Haddington bank agent; childhood admirer of JWC’s. He m., first, Harriet, b. Shirreff (ca. 1804–53), with whom he had seven sons and two das.; see 37:265 37:biographical notes . He m., second, 1854, Jane, b. Wilkie (ca. 1809–85); they lived on Court St., Haddington; for his photograph, see 39:63 JWC to JAD, 121 Feb. [1863]
, is incorrectly captioned. His brother was Thomas Dods (1800–1878; see 33:88 JWC to WDO, [19? Sept. 1857] ). William Dods organized JWC’s funeral in Haddington for TC; see 43:216TC to WDO, 22 April 1866 .
Elliott, Joseph John (1835–1903), and Clarence Edmund Fry (1840–97), photographers, 55 Baker St., London.

Emerson, Ralph Waldo (1803–82; see 6:425 TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1833
), philosopher, essayist, poet, and transcendentalist. He first met TC in Aug. 1833; in spite of their differences they had close ties; he introduced many Americans to TC and played a leading part in arranging the publication of TC’s works in the U.S.

Erksine, Thomas (1788–1870; ODNB ; see 10:18 TC to JAC, 1 Feb. 1838
), theologian and retired advocate, living at Linlathen, Dundee; during the winter he usually lived in Edinburgh, winter 1865–66 at 11 Gt. Stuart St., winter 1867–67 at 16 Charlotte Sq.; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1830s. He had two widowed sisters: Christian Stirling (1789–1 Dec.1867), m., 1817, Charles Stirling (d. 1830), who lived with Erskine, and David Paterson (1791–23 March 1867), m., 1821, Capt. James Paterson (1795–1856), who lived with her son, James Erskine Paterson (b. 1826) and his family at 8 Newbattle Terr., Morningside.

Frank, Philip (1830–1913), surgeon and physician; b. Manchester; studied medicine in England and Berlin; joined the army as an assistant staff surgeon, 1855; admitted to the Royal Coll. of Surgeons, 1856, and the Royal Coll. of Physicians, 1859. In Menton he lived at 1 Villa Massa.
Fry, Clarence Edmund; see Elliott.

Hanning, Janet Carlyle (1813–97), TC’s sister; m., 1836, Robert Hanning (1796–1878), who had emigrated to Canada in mysterious disgrace in 1841; she joined him in Hamilton, Ontario, Aug., 1851, with their two das., Margaret (b. 1838), and Mary (b. 1840), who m., 1864, Charles Coates Holden (b. 1836). In Canada they had two more das., Catherine (b. ca. 1852) and Jane.

Irving, Edward (1792–1834; ODNB ; see 1:92 TC to RM, 12 Feb. 1817
, later vols., and Carlyle, Reminiscences), the Carlyles’ great friend; religious leader and preacher.
Kerr; see Lothian.

Lothian, Lady Constance Harriet Mahonesa, b. Chetwynd-Talbot (1836–1901), marchioness, da. of Henry John Chetwynd-Talbot (1803–68), 18th earl of Shrewsbury, and Lady Sarah Elizabeth, b. Beresford (1807–84), m. 1828. She m., 1854, William Schomberg Robert Kerr (1832–70), 8th marquess, a noted bibliophile, and an invalid for much of his life. They lived at Blickling Hall, Norfolk, and Newbattle Abbey, Dalkeith.

Mazzini, Giuseppe (1805–72; see 11:225TC to JSM, 6 Dec. 1839, and 28:xiii—xiv28:introduction), Italian revolutionary; friend of the Carlyles since the late 30s. He was usually based in London, although he continued to agitate for a united Italian republic. His photograph, 39:64, is incorrectly captioned.

Neuberg, Joseph (1806–22 March 1867; see 11:231TC to JN, 21 Dec. 1839), a Jewish German businessman who had worked in Nottingham; naturalized British, 1845, and retired from business, 1849; m., 1841, Marian (d. 1848; see 23:77TC to JN, 22 July 1848). He was introduced to TC, whom he had long admired, by Emerson, 1848; helped TC as an unpaid sec., translated his work into German, and twice accompanied him on visits to Germany (1852 and 1858). From 1863 Neuberg lived at Roslyn Park, Hampstead, with his widowed sister, Rosetta (or Rosette) Frankau (ca. 1816–98)—who had m., ca. 1851, Adolph Frankau (1820–56; see 32:32TC to JN, [20 Nov. 1856])—and her two children, Frederick Joseph (b. 1854) and Gertrude Rosette Adolphine (b. ca. 1856). After Frankau’s death, Neuberg managed Frankau’s company, which imported meerschaum pipes and fancy goods, at 25 Clement’s Lane, Lombard St., London.
Paterson; see Erskine.

Price, Maria Ann (1839–1910; see 43:27543:biographical notes), lived with her widowed father,
Joseph Price (ca. 1800–1872), master tailor, and three sisters, Ellen (b. ca. 1840), a governess, Martha (b. ca. 1842), and Mary (b. ca. 1844), in Camberwell, S London. Maria m., 12 Nov. 1868, Henry Henshaw (1845–80), corn (barley, oats, and wheat) merchant. Her “Recollections of Thomas Carlyle” (which included material on her friendship with JWC) was pbd. Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine (Jan. 1896) 31–37.

Reichenbach, Oskar von (1815–93), Silesian landowner, liberal deputy to the Frankfurt Parliament 1848–49, exiled to London in 1850. Friend of the Carlyles since the 1840s. His wife, m. 1842, was Friederika or Fredrike (called Hedwig in error before vol. 39), b. Plattnauer (b. 1817), sister of Richard Eduard Plattnauer (b. 1814; see 41:23441:biographical notes); their children were Elisabeth (b. 1843), Hedwig (1844–92), and Oskar (b. 1845). They emigrated to the U.S. in 1853 but returned to London in 1863. They lived at 5 Carlisle Terr., Kensington. In 1867 Reichenbach visited Prussia to assist Otto von Bismarck in the drafting of a constitution for the North German Confederation, which formed the political basis of the later empire.
Russell, John; see Amberley.

Russell, Mary, b. Dobbie (1802–75; see 6:145TC to AC, [7 April 1832]), close friend of JWC and her mother. She m., 1829, Dr. James Russell (ca. 1796–1878); they had moved to Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, by Oct. 1859. Her father was Rev. Edward Dobbie (1773–1857; see 14:65TC to JWC, 9 March 1842).

Smalley, George Washburn (1833–1916), journalist; covered the American Civil War for the New York Tribune, then was their correspondent in Britain and Europe; American correspondent for the (London) Times, 1895–1906.

Sterling, Sir Anthony Coningham (1805–71; ODNB ; see 9:103 TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1836
, and later vols.), soldier; m., 1829, Charlotte, b. Baird (d. 1863), who suffered attacks of insanity and was jealous of JWC (see 18:266-67 JWC to HW, [12 Nov. 1844] , and 19:9 JWC to HW, [9 Jan. 1845] ); he lived at 3 South Pl., Knightsbridge. His brother John (1806–44; ODNB ), writer, had been a particular friend of TC’s; see CL vols. 8–18 and Carlyle’s Life of Sterling (1851); his surviving children were Edward Coningham (1831–77), Anna Charlotte (Lotta) (1833–67), Julia Maria (1836–1910), John Barton (1840–1926), and Hester Isabella (1843–1908).

Stewart, Margaret, b. Austin (1831–74; TC’s niece), m., 1859, Thomas Stewart (1832–69), farmer from Hollybush, now living at Ernhirst (Ironhirst), about 5½ mi. (9 km.) SW of Dumfries; see 38:19 TC to JAC, 1 Dec. 1861
; they had a da., Mary (b. ca. 1861), and three sons, William (b. 1863), James (b. 1864), and Hugh (b. 7 Oct. 1867).
Stirling, Christian; see Erskine.

Tait, Robert Scott (1816–97), portrait painter and pioneer photographer; friend of the Carlyles since 1853, he painted TC (see 31:84 ) and A Chelsea Interior (see 33:197 JWC to MR, 29 March [1858]
), as well as taking and he took photographs of both Carlyles.

Venturi, Emilie (ca. 1819–93; ODNB ), da. of William Henry Ashurst (ca. 1791–1855; ODNB ; portrait painter), supporter of Italian independence and campaigner for women’s rights; unhappily m. to Sydney Hawkes, whom she divorced 1861; see 30:215 JWC's journal, 13 Nov. 1855
, and 235
27 March 1856
. She m., 1861, Carlo Venturi (ca. 1830–27 March 1867). A strong supporter of Mazzini and the Young Italy movement, she published various English editions of his writings and Joseph Mazzini: A Memoir (1875).

Ward, Charles Augustus (1828–1914), vintner, author, antiquarian, and book collector; see 29:123-4 TC to CAW, 6 July 1854
. He lived at 1 Chapel St., Mayfair. His mother was Eliza, b. Wade (1796–1864), and his father, Charles Ward (b. ca. 1791). He often wrote under the pseudonym Feltham Burghley; see 36:262–64 TC to CAW, 24 Sept. 1860
.

Warren, Sarah (b. ca. 1812 in Norfolk), a widow with adult children (see 41:96 TC to JAC, 17 Nov. 1864
), cook and housekeeper at Cheyne Row from Nov. 1864 until at least 1871 (listed in the 1871 census as still at 5 Cheyne Row). Mrs. Warren was wrongly identified as Eliza Warren (ca. 1816–1905) in vols. 41 and 42.
Watt; see John A. Carlyle.

Welsh, Alexander (Alick) (b. 1816), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; m., ca. 1849, Sophy, b. Martin (b. ca. 1824). Their children were John (Jackie) (ca. 1853–64), Isabella Helen (b. 1856; see 31:201 JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856] ), Margaret (b. 1858), and Jean (b. 1860); they lived at Sandown Park, Wavertree, Liverpool.

Welsh, Ann (1799–1877), Elizabeth (1792–1877), and Grace (1801–15 Feb. 1867), JWC’s paternal aunts (see 14:67TC to JWC, 10 March 1842 , and 16:219JWC to JW, [ca. 26 June 1843] ), living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh.
Welsh, Grace, b. Welsh (1782–1842), JWC’s mother; m., 1800, John Welsh (1776–1819; see 1:202–3JBW to EWE, 5 Oct. 1819), JWC’s father, doctor in Haddington.

Welsh, John (1785–1853; see 28:286-87TC to JCA, 12 Oct. 1853 , and 28:286-87JWC to HW, [12 Oct. 1853] ), JWC’s maternal uncle, brass and copper founder, who had lived at 20 Maryland St., Liverpool; m., 1808, Mary, b. Colliver (d. 1838; see 10:200TC to AC, 15 Oct. 1838); their children were Helen (ca. 1813–53); Walter; Alexander; Jeannie (Babbie) (1818–95), m., 1853, Andrew Chrystal (ca. 1811–83), wine merchant from Glasgow; they had a da., Mary (1857–1937), see 40:226-27 40:biographical notes ; John (1820–60); Margaret; and Mary.

Welsh, Margaret (Maggie) (b. 1821), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter; was JWC’s nurse, Dec. 1863–May 1864; she came to Chelsea to look after TC after JWC’s death, late April–mid-Aug. 1867. She returned early June 1867.
Welsh, Mary (1823–79), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.

Welsh, Rev. Walter (1815–1879; see 16:12 JWC to JW, [8 Jan. 1843] ), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; minister at Auchtertool, Fife, since 1842. His sisters Margaret (Maggie) and Mary lived with him.

Woolner, Thomas (1825–92; ODNB ; see 26:37 TC to TWO, [21 Feb. 1851] , and 29:176–77 TC to LA, 20 Oct. 1854
), sculptor and poet; he lived at 29 Welbeck St., London. He m., 1864, Alice Gertrude, b. Waugh (b. 1845), da. of George and Mary Waugh; they had six children, including Amy (b. 1865), Hugh (1867–1925), and Geoffrey (1867–82).
